review_body: Being aware its a luxury hotel, this place has great value on your money. The service staff is extremely helpful, solved all our doubts and booked all our reservations. Spa is amazing. So if you can afford it then i highly recommend this hotel.

Wauw! What a hotel! The view was fabulous from the lobby on the 38th floor, as well as in the room. The rooms also had lots of nice facilities, such as a bath, a shower, WiFi, a tv.... They always were perfectly clean. I enjoyed the lovely breakfast and dinner in the restaurants and the cosy places at the bar to have a coffee or an other drink. The staff was extremely kind and always prepared to help if needed. They speak English very well, which is very useful. Because it was my sister's birthday, we got a delicious cake to celebrate. It was wonderful! Another great facility was the beautiful spa with a jacuzzi and sauna. It was nice to enjoy the peacefulness in the hotel in the busy, but lovely city of Tokyo. I just can't write any bad comments. I loved to stay at Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo!

The hotel is beautiful, but what makes it special are the employees who go above and beyond to make you feel like a valued guest. Rooms are very nicely appointed, clean and above-average in size for Tokyo. Hotel is in a great location for shopping and transit access. Be sure to visit the bar at sunset to enjoy the amazing views. Highly recommend the MO Tokyo.

We spent the first week of July in Tokyo and stayed at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. We had a king bed in the Mandarin Grand Room. What a great experience! The service was impeccable and this room offered a view of Mt. Fuji. We were lucky and were actually able to see it on most mornings. We utilized room service most mornings which was fantastic and also ate at Signature and Sense which were both unbelievable culinary experiences. We will definitely be back to both the hotel and the restaurants on our next trip to Tokyo.

I just feel like home at M.O. Tokyo. People there are excellent! It is not difficult to get No.1 "hardware" in many hotels, but it is not easy to get No.1 "software", i.e. PEOPLE, that I find at M.O. Tokyo.

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is perfect in every way. The hotel features spacious, impeccably clean rooms with amazing views of the city, thoughtful amenities at turndown each evening and an incredibly warm and gracious staff. Special thanks to Suguru Hirose, Fuyumi Sato, Yoji Osada and Yuka Sankoda. I'm already looking forward to a return visit!

You can't go wrong with this brand. From the time you walk in on ground level to the checking at the top floor, everyone is so nice. Thought I don't understand why they still have smoking rooms. Isn't that so yesterday? Just be aware when you reserve. They don't have pool just fitness only in case you want to do your laps.

My family of 4 and I are currently staying at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo. Unfortunately, we have had a very unpleasant stay due to the heavy smoke in the lobby area. We have stayed in numerous MO hotels around the world (most recently last summer in Bangkok) and luxury hotel chains such as the Four Seasons, Ritz Carlton, Peninsula, Aman, etc in dozens of countries around the world (many developing countries as well) and we have NEVER experienced such disgusting smoke smell in the common areas of a hotel. We have not been able to enjoy any of this hotel because of the smoke smell. Just in the past hour, we ordered up room service instead of eating in one of the many restaurants in the lobby areas. It is difficult to use the concierge services because they are located in the smoke-filled lobby area. Even in the breakfast area, we have to sit in the very back of the restaurant to avoid the smoke emanating from the lobby.We have spoken to the lovely managers at the desk and they said that they have heard this complaint numerous times from hotels guests and have reported it to senior management but they report that their concerns fall on deaf ears.We only go to and from our rooms to the entrance/exit of the hotel and have not spent any other time on the hotel property because of the smoke smell. One of the members of our family has asthma and her symptoms have worsened since arriving at this hotel. While the hotel is lovely and the staff is pleasant, this smoke smell is absolutely horrendous and unacceptable in 2017 at an expensive luxury hotel. I look forward to hearing back from the MO regarding this situation. Thank you.

My family has stayed here once before and came back exclaiming how wonderful was the experience. After, this stay, their reaction is a bit more subdued; overall excitement of the service has greatly diminished. Of the big threes in Tokyo, the MO has the most incredible view. One can easily skip visiting the Tokyo Sky Tree, as the views from the hotel is equally impressive. It also has the best sauna and jacuzzi of any hotel; memorable to soak alone and see the Tokyo Tower flickering in the distant. The rooms are very big and house keeping remains first rate. However, tired is the Molton Brown products and a particular receptionist. I swear, she must have received her hospitality training from Air Koryo and degree somewhere up North of the Peninsula. Otherwise, high standard expected of the MO. Breakfast spread excellent with great F&B management. Extra thank you to Ms. Jennifer Miu who had done meticulous arrangements for an excellent stay.

There are not enough superlatives in the English language to describe the stay that my wife and I had at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo over four nights in late April. Its position at the top of these rankings is earned and then some. The location, the service, the rooms, the amenities: they are all top notch, and you will want for nothing. My main piece of advice is to go ahead and book the Mandarin if it’s in your price range (and, even if it wouldn’t normally be in your price range, you should consider making the splurge anyway), but if you want to know why, read on for copious amounts of detail about our stay. I’m not kidding either: this is going to be really long, and this first paragraph sums it up pretty accurately, so if you want to stop here I don’t blame you.  This review, like all of my hotel reviews, must start with a discussion of the Mandarin’s location, which is essentially in central Tokyo. Specifically, it’s in the Nihombashi neighborhood, which is more or less directly north of Tokyo Station. (The hotel is walkable from Tokyo Station, but if you take the Narita Express in from the airport and you’re laden with luggage a taxi will be easier; our ride cost just over 1000 yen.) The immediate area is definitely more business-oriented than other parts of Tokyo; it seemed like everyone walking around during the day was in a suit (we were there for three weekdays), and this is certainly not where you want to be if nightlife is your thing. The surroundings are far from dead, however. There are plenty of restaurants, bakeries, and coffee places nearby, not to mention a Family Mart convenience store about a block and a half from the Mandarin’s entrance. (Aside #1: once you start looking for them you’ll see either a Family Mart, a 7-Eleven, or a Lawson convenience store on practically every other block in Tokyo, which is great for many reasons but mainly because they all have ATMs that accept foreign cards.) The enormous main branch of the Mitsukoshi department store chain sits adjacent to the Mandarin and there are numerous other stores in the vicinity as well. Unless it’s a nightclub you’re looking for, you'll find whatever you need in close proximity. And then there’s the public transportation aspect. The skyscraper that the Mandarin can be found in is directly connected to the Mitsukoshimae station of the Tokyo Metro where trains on the Ginza Line and the Hanzomon Line stop. This means that you’re no more than one transfer away from pretty much any destination in Tokyo, and all without even having to go outside. (Two caveats: 1) The exit from the station that leads into the Mandarin’s building closes at 8:00 pm, thus forcing you to take one of two nearby exits and enter the hotel from the outside after that hour. Not a huge deal, but it could be frustrating if it’s cold or raining. 2) Though part of the same station, the Ginza Line platforms are much closer to the hotel than those of the Hanzomon Line. I’m talking like 500 meters closer (there are signs indicating such information), which is not an insignificant distance. Again, not a huge deal, but by the end of the stay I tried to plot journeys that started/ended on the Ginza Line.)  The overall convenience of essentially being on top of the Metro cannot be overstated. I’m a seasoned public transportation user, both at home in Chicago and when we travel, and for my money Tokyo tops any list of systems for efficiency, speed, and value. We rode all over the city at all hours of the day and I am not exaggerating when I say that the longest we ever waited for a train was about four minutes. The trains were never overcrowded (even during rush hour), seats were comfortable, straps were plentiful for standing riders, signage and announcements were in both Japanese and English, most lines had video monitors with helpful information, maps were abundant, and to top it all off there was free wifi. (Needless to say, the only cabs we took were the one from Tokyo Station to the hotel and then from the hotel to Haneda Airport when we left.) There are many fare-paying options for the Metro, but forget all the others and get yourself a Pasmo smartcard from a machine, as the fares will be automatically deducted from the balance based on the distance traveled. They’re easily added to with cash and can even be used at most of the thousands of vending machines you will see all over Tokyo. (Aside #2: cash plays a surprisingly large role in many transactions, and to a certain extent it’s easier to just get more from one of the aforementioned ATMs than it is to try to use a credit card in many places. And if you get tired of carrying them around, the yen coins you’ll end up with in change can simply be used in one of said vending machines for a refreshing beverage.)  (Aside #3: the proximity of the Mandarin to the Metro must be contrasted with the utter lack of similar proximity enjoyed by the Park Hyatt in Shinjuku, which a certain movie makes look like an appealing hotel option. And it might very well be, at least until you go there in person (we visited the New York Bar depicted in said movie) and realize that it is far removed from Shinjuku Station, which can only be reached by either a 15-20 minute walk through desolate, windswept plazas that are unfriendly to pedestrians, or a short bus/taxi ride. Not to knock a hotel we didn’t stay at, but if you care at all about such things, your time in Tokyo is too valuable to stay somewhere that far away from the Metro.) Enough preliminaries, it’s time to discuss the hotel itself. My discussion actually begins about three weeks before our stay when I sent an email to the general email address for the Mandarin asking three distinctly disparate questions. Within 24 hours I had received a response that indicated that each of the three parts of the hotel in question (spa, concierge, and restaurant reservations) had been informed of my inquiries and would respond individually. And so they did: I booked a spa appointment for my wife and was also able to determine that I didn’t need to make a reservation for one of the Mandarin’s restaurants for the night of our arrival because it was a Sunday. Special mention must be made of the assistance of the concierge, mostly through email correspondence, who went above and beyond in their attempts to make restaurant reservations. I initially emailed to ask if they could get us into a Michelin three-star restaurant that I had already called myself and learned was full. Alas, the concierge was unsuccessful, as they also were in regards to my request for a reservation at a second three-star establishment (aside #4: if you want to dine at a two- or three-star Michelin restaurant in Tokyo, of which there is no shortage, give the concierge a little more notice than the two weeks I did and they can probably make it happen). However, as an alternative, the concierge was able to recommend and book us a counter spot at a one-star sushi restaurant in Ginza and then also book us a counter spot at a different Ginza restaurant known for its Kobe beef. We arrived after our twelve-hour flight at about 6:00 p.m. on Sunday evening in the aforementioned taxi from Tokyo Station. As soon as our taxi was spotted pulling into the enormous porte-cochere a small army of hotel staff assembled to greet us. Our luggage was removed from the trunk and was on its way to our room before I even finished paying the driver. We were greeted by name (I still don’t know how they knew exactly who we were; they did have our flight info but we had landed about three hours prior) and offered a welcome beverage before we had even passed through the automatic doors. Our greeter walked us to the elevators, asked how our flight was, and accompanied us to the front desk where we were swiftly handed over to the person who would check us in. The preferences that I had noted upon booking the room (higher floor and away from the elevators) were both specifically noted and the entire process was extremely courteous and efficient. Once the formalities were completed, we were personally escorted to our room where we were reunited with our luggage and given fruit and tea to welcome us. This staff member asked us if we needed anything else and we noted that we wanted to eat dinner in the hotel and wondered if we needed a reservation. Once we had decided on Sense, the Cantonese restaurant, this person told us she would make the booking and called us within about two minutes after leaving to inform us that it had been made for our desired time of 7:00 p.m. (It turned out that Sense wasn’t full and we probably didn’t need a reservation at all, but the willingness to accommodate us, and to do so expeditiously, just speaks to the comprehensive service that a guest receives.)  Before I get to the room I must briefly describe the lobbies. The lobby on the ground floor is tastefully and beautifully appointed and is quite large compared to other hotels that are in skyscrapers. It also has coffee, tea, and bottles of water available for guests early in the morning. The door to the lobby of the office building is here, which is the way to the Metro station, though it gets locked at an unknown time. There are three elevators that whisk you to the main lobby on the 38th floor. The main lobby, also tastefully and beautifully appointed, is notable first for the pleasant scent that greets you as soon as you step off the elevator; I never did put my finger on its source but I also never failed to notice it. The standard chairs and sofas were in the middle with the front desk and concierge desk off to one side and a staircase down to the 37th floor on the opposite side. Oh, and the views are commanding: a view of the Tokyo Skytree to the northeast behind the front desk, and a view of the rest of Tokyo and Mt. Fuji (on a clear day) to the southwest behind the staircase. The main bar and most of the restaurants are down on the 37th floor, but we didn’t spend very much time down there. We booked a Mandarin Grand Room and were given 3508, which was indeed far from the elevators (though the halls are so quiet I can’t imagine the distance would make much of a difference). The room was large, spacious, and faced southwest with a commanding view of other skyscrapers, trains coming in and out of Tokyo Station, and the rest of Tokyo. (Though the room is advertised as having views of Mt. Fuji, it should be noted that Mt. Fuji is approximately 60 miles away and thus requires an nearly perfectly clear day to be seen from the room. Though there were sunny days during our stay, each day it was a bit hazy off in the distance, and aside from a brief glimpse just before sunset on the first night we arrived, we never did get to enjoy the view of Mt. Fuji.) Immediately inside the front door was the closet area with a pass-through locker of sorts which allows hotel staff to deliver items, or vice versa, without having to knock on the door (if you’ve ever stayed at an all-inclusive resort in the Caribbean you know what I’m talking about). This is where our daily newspaper was found each morning, and folded nicely in a protective sleeve at that. (Again, it’s the attention to detail that sets the Mandarin apart.)  The bathroom was behind the entry area and it might be the best I’ve ever seen in a hotel room. It was spacious with one sink and ample counter space, a separate room for the toilet (with phone, natch), a walled-off shower without a door, and a large soaking tub. There was a television on the wall with its own remote and a ceiling-mounted speaker for its audio (that is, if you could figure out how to operate it, which I could not). Both long walls of the bathroom had windows looking into the other parts of the room, but both sets of windows had blinds that could be drawn for privacy, and there was a pocket door to completely close everything off. A magnified mirror was on the vanity. Almost every single beauty and/or grooming item was provided, from the obvious shampoo/conditioner/body wash/lotion to both men’s and women’s razors, shaving cream, a toothbrush, toothpaste, mouthwash, two kinds of bath salts, and even a foldable hairbrush. The shower had three components: a rainshower in the ceiling, a regular showerhead on the wall, and a detachable sprayer on the opposite wall. Two could be used simultaneously, but not all three. There was no door to the shower area but the tile was connected to that in front of the tub and thus stray water was kept to a minimum. Robes were provided and there was an ample supply of large, sufficiently fluffy towels. We never did use the tub so that’s about the only bathroom element I cannot comment on, but overall it receives very high marks. The bed was behind the bathroom with the aforementioned floor-to-ceiling windows at the far end. It was a king-size bed with a small bench of sorts at the foot and bedside counters (there were two levels) flanking each side. Both electrical outlets and USB ports were provided on each side. Slippers were also found on each side of the bed. There was an extensive pillow menu provided but the ones on the bed were deemed to be sufficient. Other furniture included a chair, a round ottoman, a chaise lounge, and a desk. The flat-screen TV was large (I would guess 42” but it might have been closer to 50”) with various Japanese and English language channels; the setup was a little confusing in that a specific button on the remote had to be pressed to access the HD channels, but once I figured that out it was smooth sailing. Climate control was via a wall-mounted panel and both heating and cooling were perfectly adequate. The lights were a bit wonky in that they were controlled by various panels located around the room but didn’t seem to be perfectly responsive to our selections, sometimes requiring multiple presses before the desired effect was reached (the bathroom lights were the most temperamental in this department). This was hardly a major problem, however, and with sunrise at about 5:00 a.m. when we were there, artificial lighting wasn’t needed very much anyway. Wifi worked for our phones and my iPad without any problems but was free only because I registered online with Mandarin first; while I quibble with any luxury hotel brand not providing free wifi as a matter of course, especially considering what you pay to get a room in the first place, creating a profile is not that big of a deal in the grand scheme of things. As expected, service was a highlight. One example was our request for an iron and ironing board (it was somewhat surprisingly not in the room already); I called before we headed out for the day to ask if it could be brought when housekeeping came later. Housekeeping immediately offered to bring it right away before I assured them that there was no rush. Upon our return later that evening the board was unfolded with a unplugged iron ready to go on top of it. Another example was my request for a prearranged taxi to take us to Haneda upon our checkout the next day. I called before the concierge was officially available but the front desk staff didn’t make me leave a message or tell me to call back. They effortlessly handled the arrangements, and a confirmation letter was left for us in our room for when we returned. As for the spa, my wife had a massage the morning following our arrival and she described it as very good. She also noted that the service was gracious. The spa itself opens at 9:00 a.m. to the public but starting at (I think) 6:00 a.m. the gender specific “heat and water experiences” are open to hotel guests only. I’ve never been a huge user of spa offerings but I enjoyed these amenities on two different mornings. There were two separate warm water baths with jets, an amethyst crystal steam room, and a dry sauna with commanding views (the men’s was to the Mt. Fuji side; my wife says she enjoyed the bath with the view to the northeast). Multiple shower stalls were found in this area with shampoo/conditioner/body wash dispensers mounted to the wall of each stall. Towels were in ample supply. There were two locker areas and all lockers had the computerized locks that allowed you to set your own combination. All toiletries were provided for post-shower needs and bottles of water could be found in multiple locations. The best part was that I saw a grand total of two other men during my mornings; this may have been a function of being there before 7:00 a.m., but it certainly wasn’t crowded at all.  Our checkout was early in the morning but was handled effortlessly. A bellman arrived to collect our luggage maybe three minutes after I made the call and they went ahead and placed it in the trunk of our waiting prearranged taxi. Water, coffee, and fruit were offered and accepted before we got in the cab. Flawless execution from start to finish.  If you’ve made it this far, thank you for staying with me. I could easily continue with more raves but 3000+ words already is probably sufficient. Seriously, if you’re even in the ballpark of being able to afford to stay here, just do it. Tokyo isn’t exactly a bargain travelers’ destination in the first place (e.g., we dropped over $300 each on two different meals) and if you’re expending the time and money to fly across the Pacific (or Asia, for my European readers) to get there, you might as well be rewarded for your efforts once you arrive. This might be the best hotel in the world. At the very least, it’s the best hotel I’ve ever stayed in.

This was a truly customer focused hotel. What surprised me most is that I had previously stayed earlier in the week at a Ritz Carlton (Kyoto) and expected their world renown service to be tops. I was wrong - Mandarin clearly led the service excellence for the following reasons:During a bar visit, my husband and I mentioned that we were interested in trying different saki with our server. We were having an exploratory conversation with the server, when we then moved on to our next stop in the evening. Later that night, we had a letter in our room from the concierge following up on our request from that discussion. It is truly incredible to me that in the fast paced world of hospitality when an employee makes a point to follow up on such a request. Secondly, when we arrived, our room had not been quite finished for our check in (we needed to wait about 20 min). We were treated to a tea break in their beautiful lobby, overlooking the city (at their expense). Next, we were celebrating our wedding anniversary. This hotel truly did a great job remembering this - and acknowledged it with several special treats throughout, as well as a lovely parting gift of green MatchaLastly - the concierge truly aims to please - they offered up many delightful suggestions and made our holiday that much special. There was one opportunity for development here - we wanted to see the Sumo practice, and evidently this training is difficult to get tickets to see. It would have been better if the concierge had told us that and really prioritised that activity and we would have worked the other sight-seeing around it.Recommendation to future guests: Do take advantage of the concierge services, they know their stuff. Also, for a special night out go to the Sora Sushi and amazed at the chef's cutting and preparation skills!Recommendation to hotel management: Do ask your concierge to help prioritise the more difficult to book / high demand activities first, to avoid disappointment.

The best of everything is the standard for this hotel in the sky above the center of Tokyo. The service is exceptional and the staff take every opportunity to assist you. Of course the bathroom is a truly unique experience for a Westerner

MO standards were high throughout our stay and often surpassed expectations. Service levels are close to faultless by the whole team. Thoughtful details in the amenities provided make MO a class above e.g. Kettle is pre-filled with distilled water for convenience, gym has granola snack bars and juice again for convenience.

Takes Japanese hospitality to a whole new level. Beautiful rooms (we stayed in two kinds) and very attentive staff. Warmth, attention to detail and smiles all around make this a hotel you wish you didn't have to leave.

We had high expectations after reading reviews and being referred here by friends. IT was our anniversary so we decided to splurge at the Mandarin, as we've always wanted to stay at one! We figured Tokyo was the best place because it was high up and the service would be great in Japan. This hotel exceeded our expectations! We would have been happy missing tours just to spend time in the hotel, there are NO words for the incredible staff and experience. Everytime we wanted to sit by the window, they would find a spot for us, even if there was a line! They even took our coats and put them in our room since we didnt need them anymore. You can use the spa without charge every morning for a few hours, the sauna, steam room and jacuzzi which was a fantastic overlooking the city! FOOD: Pizza bar was the best pizza we have had in our lives. Hands down fantastic! We had high tea as well and they were very accommodating to our vegetarian needs. ROOM: Very spacious, beautiful large modern bathroom with Botega Venetta designer toiletries! SERVICE: Always available for suggestions, help, directing us where to go, best route to take, and inexpensive ways to do thingsIf we ever come to Japan we would stay here again, no question! It's more than worth it!

We stayed here for 4 nights. It is a truly international hotel where on arrival you are greeted in true Japanese style and whisked up 38 floors to the spacious reception hall with wonderful views overlooking Tokyo.You then go down in different lifts to the6 floors of stunning accommodation - plenty of hanging space, beautiful bathrooms everything you could wish for provided by the hotel.There are dining facilities in the hotel from casual to fine dining and shops restaurants and subway system are a few metres away.
user_name:
Ruth S
Greater London, United Kingdom

review_body: We stayed here a total of 4 nights. 3 nights at the start of a tour and 1 night at the end. The hotel is beautiful all around, lobby, restaurants,lounges and the spacious rooms with great views. Everything in the Hotel is immaculate. The location is great with shopping and tourist attractions within walking distance. Service was excellent as expected. Fast and free Wi-Fi. I only noticed a few very minor items that kept this hotel from being perfect: The bathroom lighting over the sink area needs to be brighter. The closet does not have an interior light. Eggs or cooked to order items in the Breakfast Buffet are ordered separately and come from the kitchen so it is hard to match up hot eggs with hot toast or bacon etc.that you get from the buffet. But these are just minor problems in my opinion so if that's all I noticed it must be a pretty great place to stay.

This was my 2nd time staying at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo, and I loved it as much this time as my 1st. From the second you arrive the service is unbelievable, to the point where you feel guilty. The room was beautiful with tons of tiny details carefully thought out and spotlessly cleaned each day. The in hotel dining options are all great. We enjoyed the breakfast buffet one morning and loved the high quality food and variety. The pizza bar was excellent as well. While I was traveling on business and didn't personally pay, I would definitely be willing to pay the fairly high price myself as well as it is an amazing hotel experience.

Upon arrival a few mistakes regarding reservation were quickly rectified and the rest of the stay was perfect. The restaurant in the hotel Sushi Sora was a wonderful experience..forget the cost and let the sushi chef take you on a journey you will remember!

This magnificent hotel with the superior front desk and dining room staffs provides outstanding hospitality to their guests. The beautiful and spacious rooms have large bath areas with great soaking tubs. The views out of the floor to ceiling windows provide impressive views of the city which are unforgettable. The concierge staff are informative and very helpful. Caution: check the menu prices in the restaurants before entering so that you do not have an unpleasant surprise when you get the bill.

Every detail of this hotel is geared to your comfort and enjoyment. The concierge arranged babysitting for our 2 year old child in our room and the experience was excellent. The in-room dining is fabulous and the hotel staff is second to none. This property receives my higher possible recommendation!
user_name:
adami634
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Stayed for 3 nights at the end of our honeymoon trip to Japan. Was probably the best 3 nights I have ever spent in a hotel. Was lucky enough to stay in the Oriental Suite, which was just brilliant - very spacious, views of Mt Fuji and access to the in-house onsen. The service was fantastic. The hotel took care of our restaurant reservations and were always very helpful. The hotel restaurants are also excellent and once again the service was great. The buffet breakfast was good quality however perhaps a little small for the type of hotel. I would absolutely love to stay here again!

There are really no words to describe the elegance and shear delight that is saying at the Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo. We stayed 4 nights, but easily could have stayed for weeks. Quite frankly, the overall service experience in Japan is extraordinary regardless of where you are or what you are doing, but this hotel manages to find a completely different level of service quality. Our stay could not have been more perfect and I believe it will be exceedingly hard to find another hotel in the world that would rival it.Many people have commented on the buffet breakfast and while it was nice, my personal recommendation is to take your breakfast in the lounge/restaurant next door. It is an absolute delight with far fewer guests. The service there is among the best I have ever experienced (and it is basically the same food just in sit down fashion).Overall, this was a truly magical experience and a hotel that clearly deserves its place among the world's best.P.S. it is also connected by subway (underground) and easily in walking distance to many highlights.

We went there to get a drink at the bar and enjoy the view on Tokyo skyline. Big deception on many aspects: the service is very present in number but with no soul or connection with the customer, cocktail list is a bit disappointing in taste, and worse of all, we were told that wifi access was extra. At 2500 yen (excl. tax and service) the drink, it's just a disgrace by the MO name... Overall, we did not feel welcome at all. Go somewhere else, plenty other choices in the city.

If you've got the financial means to do so, then stay at this Hotel in Tokyo. The service is by far #1 in the entire world. The people were so helpful and would do anything to help us during our stay. Between business and pleasure I have travelled more then most people and I can tell you that it has the BEST breakfast buffet I have ever enjoyed. Yum yum yum.The lobby ambassadors are so helpful and we met a very sweet young lady named Erin. She helped to make our trip extraordinary.The gym is nothing short of spectacular ---- imagine being on a treadmill staring out the window on the 38th floor overlooking Tokyo. I am hopeful to attach a picture that I took of the view out the window.This hotel is NOT one to miss!!

The Mandarin Oriental combines a sense of tranquility and beauty with perhaps the most gracious and efficient service I have ever encountered. Kudos to the staff. Convenient to the Ginza area and close to the Subway it ideally located for a visit to Tokyo.

The breakfast buffet is a great way to start your day and sample many different kinds of local food. With only three days in Tokyo, we would have been limited in what could try if we only had complete entrees to try. The rooms are spacious with an amazing view. The staff is friendly, speaks excellent English, and was helpful with mailing letters, arranging taxis, etc. They even provided a special birthday snack. This is a great location with many classic tourist sights within walking distance.

Was in Mandarin for 2 nights and it was the most awesome experience I ever had!When we at the lobby, we were surprise of the view of this building have.Especially at the men toilet.We were greeted with kindness and respect, and since we arrive quite early than expected, they treated us at the lounge with extremely good green tea while waiting for our room to get ready.And another great thing of Tokyo Mandarin Hotel, is the train station (Ginza Line) is exactly below the building, So much convenience.Anyway, if you've the money this is the place for you!

During our first trip to Japan we could not have been happier staying at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. The room was amazing with a view of Mt. Fuji and the service was outstanding. We stayed for 8 nights and we were never dissatisfied. We ate at most of their restaurants, all top notch. The staff is what made the entire stay. They were always courteous, informative and the most wonderful people to interact with. We will definitely be staying here again should we return to Tokyo in the future.

The hotel aesthetics are lovely, as was expected, but the attentive service is truly the star here. The hotel team makes you feel welcome from the moment you pull up. The concierge went above and beyond to make my holiday successful. Two of the concierge attendants (I am ashamed to say I forgot their names) even walked me to the train station to help make sure I purchased the correct bullet train ticket for my next destination. You MUST have dinner at Tapas Molecular Bar. The pizza bar on 38th is also great for a quick snack. A five star hotel should be spectacular in my opinion, but this hotel offers something a little extra. I would not stay anywhere else the next time I visit Tokyo!
user_name:
ACRuns
New York City, New York

review_body: Loved the ambience of hotel from the time I arrived until I left. Staff was excellent. Location was excellent. Subway line right under the hotel building. Can't wait to return. Breakfast was delicious with lots of variety.

Amazing views, incredible service, expensive but worth it. Superb amenities, huge rooms with outstanding furnishings. Staff some of the best ever encountered in a hotel of this calibre from Reception to Bell to Housekeeping.

We stayed for just one night, after a few days in the Niigata mountain area, but what a nice experience it was ! After arriving at the ground floor entrance, we were warmly met by hotel staff who quickly unloaded our luggage and ushered us to the 38th floor where the hotel reception was located. Since it was "Golden week" in Japan, the hotel was very busy and our room was not ready, even though we arrived at 2pm. We were courteously escorted to the lounge on 37th floor, where we had coffee and a lght meal. After about an hour, a senior (and distinguished gentleman) staff member came to look for us, to bring us to our room - to our pleasant surprise, we had been upgraded to a corner suite on the 30th floor (perhaps because we had reserved our room through the Visa Luxury Hotel program), The suite was very spacious and bright, with superb views over the city - including Mount Fuji in the distance ! The decor was contemporary and in the signature colours of Mandarin Oriental. All the amenities, fittings, and appliances were modern - Nespresso machine, flat-screen large TV's, tall wireless speakers - wow ! The bedroom and bathroom did not disappoint either - super-comfortable bed with a large number of pillow choices; and the bathroom was very large, with an open, walk-in shower area (with 3 types of shower-heads), adjacent to a deep soaking bathtub. Colours were in grey black stone, and cedar wood-beige colour contrasts. The amenities included everything you can think of (Bottega soap and gels !) My wife could have stayed inside the whole evening ! We had superb sleep that night, in the very quiet room (Couldn't hear other guests, even though the hotel had full occupancy!). However it was very crowded in the breakfast area on the 38th floor, and we had to wait about 20 minutes to be seated. Nevertheless, the service staff and attitude was execellent, even though they were so busy. Breakfast was buffet-style, with a decent range of interesting Japanese and Western food, juices, etc. After our morning outing, we checked out at 2pm - very prompt collection of our luggage, check-out, and then transfer to a taxi to the airport (all within 15 minutes !) Few negatives about the hotel - wi-fi charges are rather high; similarly laundry and pressing (no iron in the room). Food and beverage costs also expensive, but high quality. But there are many good restaurants within short walking distance. Many positives - very elegant atmosphere and luxurious furnishings and decor throughout the hotel, and superb staff attitudes and service quality, from the bell service to housekeeping, front desk and restaurants. We will definitely stay longer when we next visit !

This is one of the most spectacular hotels anywhere. The suite was incredible. The lobby is on the 38th floor, the bar and restaurants are on 37. All are beautifully designed with water flowing in and around them. Had a sushi lunch which was great, the breakfast buffet even had chocolate babka as good as anywhere in NYC or anywhere else. You won't be sorry with the Mandarin as your choice in Tokyo, we certainly were not. Which we could have stayed longer. I want to add that when we needed to take the train back to Yokohama to rejoin our ship a staff member walked us to the station and helped us use the ticket machine. Outstanding service on all levels.

Very kind staffs, really good facillities ( include good sauna), great care of customers (warm-heart, family-like service). there is nothing like this hotel. It was wonderful stay. I highly recommend this hotel.If you conern avout this hotel, please do not hesitate choose this hotel. This is the best hotel in Tokyo.

We recently stayed at this amazing Hotel to start a trip to celebrate our 10th year anniversary. First we had a little trouble with the concierge, but the staff came a long way to make it up and boy they know how to. We found details in every step of our entire stay. BTW the breakfast is truly great (best eggs benedict of my life) The French restaurant is worth of it's Michelin Star and our room was perfect.The hotel is amazingly well located. Great Moscow Mules in bar (ask for extra ginger sweets)Rooms are all totally equipped be sure to check out their spa. Thanks to Raul Levis and Julio for helping us feel special during our stay. Would definitely come back next time we visit my wife's family in Tokyo.

A group of three friends, we spent one night at the Mandarin as the base for our final day of our trip in Tokyo.I've stayed at several other Mandarin locations worldwide so had very high expectations given the reputation. The hotel, the amenities and the staff did not disappoint. The location is central, very close to Tokyo station with near direct access to Mitsukoshi-mae station in the basement - so it's very easy to get anywhere from the hotel.Both the king and twin rooms we had were fantastic with views out over the city - all the way towards the Tokyoskytree tower. It's righ ton the edge of the high rises, meaning as you look out you have an uninterrupted view of everything below you and into the distance.The hotel is styled in a modern and classy decor. The lobby is at the top of the hotel, and you have to switchelevator to get to the rooms which are on the upper floors, but below the lobby. Very, very helpful and courteous front desk staff who accompanied us to our room to introduce us to the roomsfeatures and functions, as well as giving a tour of the hotel ameniteis. Fantastic spa, several different restaurants - many of them Michelin starred. I made use of the fitness suite,the spa and the K’shiki breakfast restaurant.No doubts about recommending this fantastic hotel and if back in Tokyo would happily stay again - the price matchesthe service and attention to detail provided.

Luxury hotel - you pay high price but you get what you are paying for. We stayed there for our last night in Japan and had amazing , relaxing 24 hours before the flight. Service if great , food and drinks very tasty, spa is peace of art. Ready to go home now .

This hotel lived up to all expectations. The staff were courteous and efficient and the facilities were outstandig. Sarah Besser, Dining Floor Ambassador was especially helpful and is deserving of special comment.

I'm so disappointed from the Hotel specially from the concierge team. I have great expectations since we are planning our trip.. we sent few mails asking for restaurants, trips, so we can plan our days in Tokyo..but nobody answers our questions. I have to ask for help to a friend since we have no answers from the hotel.

I'm a little late in writing this review but nevertheless I have to add my glowing review to the pile. My husband and I stayed for 3 nights in October 2016 on the Japan leg of our honeymoon and had very high expectations given the reputation. Luckily, the hotel didn't disappoint. The location is great - located in the business district so not a lot to do in the immediate area, but it's very close to Tokyo station and had direct access to Mitsukoshi-mae station in the basement, making it a great base from which to explore this amazing city.Our room was stunning, had an incredible view of the Tokyo skyline, amazing bathroom and unbelievable amenities - truly everything you could think of, kettle refilled every day, binoculars, even the pencil sharpener in the stationary drawer was awesome. The care and attention that's gone into the rooms is really unbelievable. The hotel itself is gorgeous, we loved the classy and modern decor. The view from the lobby is to die for and leads you to the warmest and most helpful concierge team I've ever encountered. They went above and beyond in every aspect. The food and beverage services at the hotel are top class, from breakfast, the pizza bar, to cocktails in the evening, the food and drinks were excellent and the staff were even better. Everyone seemed to know we were on honeymoon, gave us their warm wishes and topped it off with lovely touches like complimentary drinks, fruit, cake, great seats with great views, we really were treated so well.There was a bit of confusion with what was included in the package we had reserved, down to a miscommunication between the agency we had used and the hotel, but management handled this professionally and courteously. Once they had identified the issue, they gave us complimentary breakfast (probably the best breakfast buffet I've ever seen) and a heap of goodies and information on Kyoto which was our next destination.We also stayed three nights at the RItz Carlton but we absolutely preferred the Mandarin Oriental. It comes with a hefty price tag but in my opinion is truly in a class of its own.

Took me back to January 2015 , we went to Japan and stayed at Oriental M Hotel for a week , Wow so beautiful from room to service and restaurants locations everything I could asked for during away from home ! The hotel is just right next to a big department store and a huge like a supermarket that have everything you need in terms of food we were enjoyed our stay soMuch , the service was excellent , front desk was always helpful , we went to Disney land by a private Taxi , taxi so comfortable and doesn't cost much at all , best location great food beautiful room very lovely bathroom ! Everything at Oriental Manderin was a beautiful memories for all of us ! Will stay there in our next visit ! This was my second times in Tokyo , love the city love the people ( love ❤️the Hotel ) Happy M

We absolutely loved our stay at the Mandarin Oriental: from start to finish, we felt taken care of. The breakfast buffet was fresh and beautiful, and the servers were gracious. A meal at the pizza bar was excellent after a long plane trip, and an evening spent at the Tapas Bar (booked in advance) provided great entertainment. Our stay will be a great memory of Japan.I also want to add that although leaving was hard, the luggage storage(for a delayed departure) and loading was the best we have experienced in all of our travels.

Tokyo lacks no shortage of swanky hotels and great hospitality - what else could you expect out of Japanese omotenashi. A regular business traveler to Tokyo, I have stayed at many of its' hotels, the Aman, the Peninsula, the Mandarin, the Grand Hyatt, to name a few. None matches the feeling of arriving home like the Mandarin. Perhaps it's the compact scale, the quietude of its rooms with clear views of the city below, and definitely the always personalized efforts of the entire team, bell captains to front desk, to concierge, to housekeeping and its restaurants and bars.None excels the hard work, diligence of the excellent concierge team and "never say no" attitude of Tomoya (Tom) Mori in a destination where breaking through to gain access and knowledge, especially if not fluent in Japanese, requires much help from a concierge.Kudos to Paul Jones, general manager, for leading an exceptional team head first with stiff competition.
user_name:
S M
New York City, New York

review_body: This is a typical 5 star hotel - it's beautiful and the rooms are spacey compared to Tokyo standards. I was told it was one of the nicest hotels in Tokyo so I had pretty high expectations. It did meet my expectations, however it was pretty pricey when I stayed there. Potentially prices were higher due to the end of March being Sakura season but pretty unreasonable. The bathroom and the views are what pretty much makes the hotel. I am a clean freak and the bathroom is probably one of the most important factors for me. The bathtub - I loved and in general the shower, bathtub etc was pretty impressive and clean. The views are beautiful especially sunrise and night views. You get a good birds eye view of Tokyo. You can the famous Yokohama Ferris wheel! The stay was comfortable and pleasant. I would stay here again. Location wise - not the best if you are in Tokyo for pleasure. It is quite far away from all the main places. I would recommend this hotel for business stay.

The hotel met all our expectations for the Mandarin Oriental group. The service was superb, with staff ready to help us settle in and arrange meals as soon as we arrived. The room was excellent with a fantastic city view. The food was very good. Notably, the breakfast buffet was one of the best we've experienced in Japan.My only criticism would be the bar/lounge area, where the multitude of smokers made sitting there unpalatable for us non-smokers.

I was now the fourth time in the MO Tokyo and are absolutely pleased with the overall experience. The concierge team is one of the best I have seen in the entire world, they will go out of their way to secure very difficult dinner reservations

This was our first time at the Tokyo Mandarin but it showed again what a great group of hotels they are.Centrally located within 20 minutes walk to Ginza and the high end shopping and direct access to a subway station in the basement it makes it perfect for a business trip but also for a couple of days holiday.Although you have the lobby area on street level the actual reception is on the 38th floor with breathtaking views across Tokyo.The rooms are on floors below the reception and bars and restaurants and offer equally fabulous views.The rooms are immaculate as you would expect and so are all the common areas like bar, restaurants etc.The service is faultless and always with a smile and great care to detail.The two breakfast ereas provide excellent service and variety.We are great fans of the MO group and we think that this one in Tokyo is right at the top.

We returned to the Mandarin Oriental over Easter weekend for a 3 night stay. Having stayed there several times over the years, this experience was particularly special thanks to the team at K'shiki Restaurant, who went the extra mile each day to make sure we felt extra welcomed and looked after. The service this time was particularly resonant via the staff asking if we still wanted the same style of coffee and eggs we had during our last stay over a year ago. It was through the team who made sure the day before we knew who to reach out to on our last morning there when we needed to show up at opening time. It is through the attention to detail such as this that provided an unrivalled enjoyable experience. Rooms are as per Mandarin Oriental standards top notch with certain rooms looking out to the Tokyo Skytree. We also enjoyed its location with the building located just above Mitsukoshi-mae station on the Ginza line, a small and fuss free station that allows direct access to key areas such as Shibuya, Omotesando, Ginza and Ueno. Making the subway experience as pleasant and easy to navigate as can be despite its complex layout. Wholeheartedly recommended and we cannot wait to come back soon.

This hotel gave me a very memorable memories, the front desk is very polite and hospitality, but also help us to implement Lee room, very careful,The room is very positive, though not too big, the enterprise is very comfortableLocation is good near the tourist attractions, even with the old people here are very suitable for Li Du, fully take care of the needs of our familySo the next time you must stay againThe best hotelIn addition, the hotel facilities are very meticulous, very beautiful, is indeed a Zhuoer extraordinary hotelI recommend more people to visit itThe The The The The The The The The The The TheThe The The The The The The The The The The TheThe The The The The The The The The The The TheThe The The The The The The The The The The The

Great position in the business district (internal access to the metro), fantastic rooms with superb view of the city (try to get the highest floors), and great attention to the furnitures. A special mention for the outstanding level of service, making you feel like a king.

We stayed 3 nights in their Executive Suite, the room was quite big and beautiful. Good location of the Hotel, the subway just at the basement of the building. The staff were very polite and good service. And the buffet breakfast was excellent.

Stayed 3 nights at mandarin Tokyo. Excellent hotel, food and quality of service. Based in the business district so central but far from the tourist sites. Food quality was excellent and would definitely recommend.

This hotel has it all: good service, superb views, excellent buffet breakfast and a very good location. It is a short walk to the subway, and if you get a day pass you can easily reach anywhere you wish to go. We spent 5 days here on a group tour, and if I ever returned to Tokyo this would be my hotel of choice.

On our last night in Tokyo after 3 weeks touring we thought we treat ourselves. Lovely welcome, excellent room with matching view. Bathroom exceptional. Breakfast let it sadly down. The choice is nowhere near as good as in the Conrad. Running out of jam is quite an achievement. Coffee wasn't offered, we had to catch the eye of someone passing. My expectations were high, because of the general outstanding service in Japan and the reputation of the hotel. Didn't match.

I have done work with the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo so coming from NYC, I was very excited to stop by and see what it was all about. It is phenomenal! Kai and his team have customer service down pat and my husband and I felt very fortunate to be able to sit and have drinks overlooking the gorgeous view. Sushi Sora is great and made our first sushi dinner in Tokyo incredibly memorable. Thank you MO team - we can't wait to be back!

frankly speaking, this hotel deserves the luxury price of its rooms.i have been completely and always spoilt.room view - stunningroom furnishing - very cosy breakfast - excellent laundry - super efficientconcierge - perfectroom service - equal to a restaurantit is really difficult to find negatives or strong improvements.

I was having dinner upstairs from this lovely gourmet bakery/shop and after viewing their delicious looking baked goods I decided to stock up on some for the rest of my trip. The senior supervisor for the shop, Ms. Mai Tsuzuki, could not have been more helpful, not only in helping me with packing up my newly found treasures, but also holding them while I finished up shopping and had dinner upstairs. I noticed upon my initial purchase, a walnut-raisin bread loaf that had quickly sold out while I was dining. Ms. Mai Tsuzuki was very apologetic that this happened and accommodated me with other goodies (not their fault, except that their products are exceptional and made of the finest ingredients... they don't stay on display long).What a pleasure to be received by such a professional staff, eager and willing to help and accommodate in any way. Their products are without a doubt exceptional, as is their service!
user_name:
DuaICitizen
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: I stayed for 4 night u had best service and staff are friendly and helpful in discrete way . The room beautiful design and every night the housekeeping Put for us relaxing oil and small note . And best concierge . Easy excess to subway . And many restaurant in area and elegant mall .

We came to have dinner were rushed through entire experience got 2 shrimp for an entre' paid $58 very rude staff!! We dressed up for a very nice birthday evening and took a cab over. Staff speak no English.

The hotel is very well located, just few steps from Giza Underground in a quiet, beautiful, business area. Rooms are beautiful, clean, nice city view.. everything is beautiful. Nevertheless the "top" of this hotel is the personnel and the service. You feel like a king and everything you could need is possible and available in a while! Thank you.

Enjoyed the Tapas Molecular experience on the top floor of the Mandarin hotel. Probably one of the best dining experiences we have ever had. Not cheap but worth the splurge. Amazing concoctions and surprises using lots of scientific techniques and lot and lots of liquid nitrogen . Only 10 diners can dine per evening so book very early - you will not be disappointed. The chefs are urbane entertaining and incredibly skilled. many course dining experience with real attention to detail.

Excellent experience. Rooms large and lovely and the spa/osen was very modern and bright. Having a hot bath overlooking Tokyo was pretty amazing.Sushi Sura in their lobby excellent. only 8 seats so reservations an absolute must but well worth it. Two chefs for 8 people. Theatre and good food all in one!

Beautiful Mandarin bar on 37th floor. We asked for seats by the window to have city view and was taken to counter/bar, which has a beautiful blooming branch of sakura in the middle. Staffs speak great english, extremely nice and great customer service ( compared to many places I have been to in Japan- this is the best). Cocktails section is amazing with many choices, especially ones that are Japanese styles/ have sake/sakura. There was "Sakura pop up" when I was there- not sure what it was but it gave the menu more options. We all loved our drinks.

I just spent one week at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo and it was a perfect stay. Hotel is beautiful. The personal is kind and has a lot of attention to make you feel comfortable. Always smiling.The food at the restaurants is very good and again the service is great.

My husband and I stay in the hotel so many times. My husband last time complained the noise in the room.The noise was due to the strong wind and come through the bed board. He called and the manager came down and said that my husband should use an ear plug and nothing they could do. He checked in on this Tuesday and received an apology but still put him in an old room. The furniture looks old and no expresso machine which is quote a standard equipment for 5-star hotels these days. We stay here because of the walkable distance to both our offices in Tokyo. The room rate is not cheap but still quite disappointed. I would like to book the sushi restaurant but seems extremely difficult to get 1 seat even you are a hotel guest. So at the end, I had dinner at the lounge but not really good experience about the food. See the other comment on the lounge.

Any hotel is only as good as its staff and the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo excelled in this department.I arrived early so my room was not ready but the staff immediately upgraded me to a beautiful view of Mount Fuji and made me comfortable with tea and biscuits while I waited.I was attended too by the most lovely Spanish lady, whoes name i have forgotten which is criminal because she was an utter delight and could not do enough to make sure my stay was special.

You get what you pay for: at the Mandarin Oriental you'll enjoy an outstanding experience. The bar is a must visit: Uber cool vibe. Signature restaurant has outstanding views of Tokyo. Premier location for the best quality shopping.

I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental in Feb 2017. All staff were extremely helpful and courteous, and the facilities were fabulous. Breakfast is done well (if rather extravagantly) and the location of the hotel is very good both for walking, shopping and catching the subway. I was lucky enough to experience the Pizza bar and Molecule Tapas Bar, and really enjoyed not having to leave the hotel at night to have these great quality meals. The spa was really very good, I can highly recommend the pools and treatments, even though when I was there the steam room was sadly out of order. I look forward to returning in the future.

3rd or 4th stay at the Mandarin in Tokyo, and same of what happened in my previous ones, this tiime was perfect again. The room, service, staff, location, atmosphere,.....all is great. It is very friendly and well managed luxury hotelRoom is spacious, spotless clean, very well equipped, excellent wi-fi connection, very comfortable bed, great view from the city (I was on the 31st floor). In terms of food, went to the bar and also used the room service. All great. Good gym, very well equipped too.Once again: my preferred hotel in Tokyo.

I think when you are travelling on business and staying at the top notch hotels like MO, you will have a higher than usual leisure casual kind of expectations. Yet Tokyo's MO has made it to surprise me with very superior guest services... the amazingly and importantly surprising service that they knew me by the name when I got off my taxi and walked into the hotel lobby. Spooky. Yet you feel so recognised and expecting speedy check in which it was supersonic speed and in-room.They did everything and extra to delight me when I had a request.Plus their generous and luxury daily in-room treats with the beautiful fruits in season was gastronomical and pleasantly surprised me 2 more times with 2 nights stay... That i had Japanese 4-type and Citrus Trilogy as you can see...Very well done, MO Tokyo.

This was my first trip to Tokyo with a baby and with my husband and parents. I had such a great time that I can't wait to return. I have always gone to Tokyo for business and never really got to explore the city so this short 4 day trip accompanying my husband for his business was a rarity for me.  When planning my two week trip to Asia and also the first time taking my 8 month old on an International trip, I checked TripAdvisor to see where we should stay. And am I glad I chose the Mandarin.  The Mandarin lobby has an incredible view of the city. It is worth going there for dinner or drinks just to see the view. The hotel lobby is typical of many Asia hotels where the lobby is high above and rooms are often below. When we entered our room, both my husband and I were shocked by how baby proofed the room was. The staff had baby proofed all the corners so that my son would not get hurt. Plus they had every baby amenity that you can ask! I had contacted the hotel ahead to ask for sterilizer, crib, humidifier but when I arrived there was more! They even had a changing table, bath tub, bottle warmer, and diaper pail for him! This is THE place to stay if you are traveling with a baby. I wish all hotels we travel to are like this.  The room itself was spacious and the furnishing was very traditional. I would say the rooms are nice but probably need a update soon to keep up with the times.  Breakfast every day was great. Incredible selection of food. The kitchen made my son applesauce daily. We didn't even have to ask for it a second day. Since there were 5 of us traveling together, they placed us in the same private dining area daily.  Concierge service was great and they made sure all the restaurants I booked were baby friendly. That was another thing that really surprised me about Tokyo restaurants. I took my son to a lot of high end restaurants this trip and they all allowed babies. One even had a bassinet in the tatami room! Will have to write a review on that one!  Overall, great hotel and incredible staff. Definitely keeps with the Mandarin Oriental brand. Area is conveniently located for business travelers but also quiet and walkable to main shopping area by Tokyo station. Subway is right below hotel so very convenient.

Absolutely amazing hotel in every way. All the staff are very friendly and helpful. Our room was very nice and spacious. The room's view from window was spectucular. Great location, great breakfast. Great stay!

My husband and I choose to stay here march 6-10th 2017 and it was the best decision of my life. This hotel treated us as if we were family they were so warm, kind, friendly, helpful! The staff is supreme I can't say enough about how they went out of their way to make our stay perfection. Tom at the conceiger desk was the best thing to ever happen to me. Everyday for 6 months we emailed back and forth planning our trip and he made sure everything was perfect for me. He got us into all 4 michillian star restaurants, he even went to the train station to get us tickets so we didn't have to. I honestly can't say enough about him he's the definition of kindness and dedication to service. The bar staff was INCREDIBLE especially Sarah from Germany she was best!! All the staff knew our names before we walked in how we wanted our drinks and even our reserved spot every day. Their attention to detail is bar none! We are officially spoiled and now nothing will be of our standard again. The breakfast staff was perfection they knew our drink orders and egg orders before we could even put our napkins on our lap!! Tell me where would you ever get this type of hospitality! Please don't research anymore book this hotel then message me after and thank me!! One word PHENOMENAL!!!

We had a great experience to stay and had lunch at Mandarin. Their service is mostly perfect. And the remarkable night view even in our room , bar and sushi sora !!! It was amazing no matter day and night time!!! Highly recommended their spa with view likely hot springs u will feel so relaxing and chilling after a long day rid. and sushi sora, it was my first experience enjoying tradition sushi with amazing view. Finally, we went to take our car for leaving , they had prepared 2 blotters water and candy in the car... it was so sweet!!!before I thought that's my bf did....Definitely will be back soon!

Excellent Hotel in Tokyo. You have everything you need here to make your business travel a pleasant one. Friendly staff, nice room, great food and in a perfect location. Mall nearby and it's right next to the metro station. Cant ask for more.

Mandarin Oriental never disappoints. We stayed 8 wonderful nights. Perfect location wonderful staff!Outstanding dining at the Sushi restaurant and a wonderful breakfast buffet. The staff remembered what we ordered the prior day. We want to give a very special thank you to Tomoya from the concierge desk. He went above and beyond to retrieve our shopping bags that we accidentally left behind after a quick stop at the Park Hyatt for a business lunch. Tomoya offered to personally pick them up after his work shift and bring them back to the hotel the next morning as we were checking out!!What a selfless and kind thing to do. Thank you again Tomoya!!

I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo for business last month and was absolutely amazed at the quality of service. The location is great of course but the service is what really makes a great hotel. You are only 1k away from the Imperial Palace, which is a great place for a run. I had a box of collaterals delivered to the hotel prior to my arrival. I did find the box in my room upon arrival, but for the first time ever, I also found a pair of scissors next to it! No need to battle with a pen, a key or the bottle opener to open the box! I travel a lot and this is the first time I experienced such an attention to detail.Next day I went to the front desk to ask for directions for the subway. Two things happened: first when the front desk clerk saw me arrive, she steeped out from behind the desk and came towards me rather than just wait. Then she escorted me ALL THE WAY to the subway station and helped me buy a day pass on the machines.The room had a great view and the breakfast was fantastic.Definitely one of the best Mandarin I have aver been to and one do the best hotel, period.I will be back!

Arrived late afternoon on a Saturday having endured a long week of red-eye Asia travel. The Mandarin was, as-always, incredibly welcoming and helpful - stayed nearly w week on Tokyo business. Following a long night of sleep-catch-up, as I raced around Tokyo hitting shops and museums, Concierge Tomoya Mori arranged a Sunday evening counter seat for me at Ginza Seamon (tough to manage last-minute) which was superb. I also treated myself to a massage in the Mandarin Spa, which was an extraordinary experience. I enjoyed a few evenings in Mandarin Bar reviewing the days client meetings over a drink. Dining Floor Ambassador Yu Yamase introduced herself; we had a lovely chat about Tokyo and the Mandarin. We saw each other a few other times during the week - Yamase-San was very kind and attentive. Facilities and dining options are superb. As I mentioned to the hotel staff as I checked-out, the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo remains my favourite hotel - the facilities are superb however the quality of the hotel staff, their care and attention to detail is extraordinary.

The entire hotel begins at the 34th story which results in breathtaking views from the common areas and each guest room. Add in the Mandarin's extraordinary sense of design, zen mystique and service that redefines extraordinary and it baffles me why anyone would opt for another 5 star hotel in Tokyo.

You cannot believe the amount of attention to the details this hotel gives! From lovely papers in the desk, the perfume in the air, the air purifier in the room and other countless details that really make you feel at home. Mr RAUL, the director, is Brazilian and welcomed us in Portuguese! In Tokyo!! Fantastic!

Amazing experience from start to finish. Greeted warmly upon arrival, asking us how our trip to Kyoto was (mentioned in passing via email a week earlier). Our room was spacious and luxurious.Concierge patiently made many attempts to get us into some of the best & smallest restaurants in town, and secured a spot at a great sushi restaurant on the day.PROS:- Customer service is second to none. Similar to the level of service at a Gordon Ramsay restaurant. They made us feel welcome without being overbearing.- Views from the check-in area, bar and all rooms is breathtaking.- Excellent spa bath and sauna on lvl 37. No charge in the morning until 9am.- Comfortable bed, to be expected.CONS:- It was expensive (for me), even on a heavily discounted corporate rate. But you get what you pay for!- Having to leave!Have a drink at the bar just below reception if you feel like splurging. Ask them to book you the table surrounded by water for the best seat in the place.

Thank you to every single member of staff for your attention to detail, service does not describe what happens here, you are nurtured. Facilities wonderful, wouldn't have missed the molecular restaurant which was an unparalleled food experience.

My husband and I stayed here during our honeymoon in November. The staff was aware of our honeymoon and they went to great lengths to make us feel welcome and special. They gave us beautiful fruits and deserts customized to us for our honeymoon and surprised us with champagne and rose petals upon our arrival. We ate at the sushi restaurant, the Chinese restaurant, the molecular tapas restaurant, and we had room service and afternoon tea. ALL were ridiculously wonderful. The only one I would skip next time would be the Chinese restaurant. It was very expensive and very stuffy. More like fancy business lunch type of place. We went to the spa one of the days and it was beautiful. If you want to spend money, it's worth it just for the view. Bottom line, you get what you pay for and this is a very pricey place but it's worth every penny. If you want to spend money, spend it here! Also, very convenient location because there's a subway stop in the basement of the building!My husband and I are planning to go back to Japan and stay at the MO annually for our anniversary. It was truly THAT amazing of an experience.

This is an incredible business hotel for staying in Tokyo. Conveniently located near the major financial district, the hotel is extremely well appointed, has wonderful food, and amazing views of Tokyo from all sides. I would highly recommend it to others. (Also right on top of a subway station which is convenient for transit)

The room is spacious when compared to other hotels in Japan. Breakfast is superb, live jazz band at the bar and the bar itself was awesome. Staffs were very attentive and helpful, amongst the best MO I have been in Asia so far. Can't wait to stay at MO again

The hotel is close to perfection. Nice rooms great service. A wonderfully 8 seats sushi restaurants probably one of the best in Tokyo. The only missing star is because of the spa : at first they asked for us to pay to get in :-/ then they said no need but there is no swimming pool... you usually expect one in this kind of hotel. Room was great but no need to pay extra for the Fuji view because you usually don't see it. We have seen it just one morning out of 4.

Stunning view over Tokyo. We enjoyed a fantastic massage in a room overlooking the city. The size of the room is very generous and the staff speak a gfluent English.The sushis restaurant is really fantastic.

We have stayed in many hotels across the globe and this one is by far the best. The service is second to none and the food is outstanding. Tetsu, Yu, Fiona, Yu & Tsudoi have shown us such a wonderful time we will come back to this hotel to enjoy the experience all over again. We would recommend this as a stop over to all Australians on their way to Europe and UK instead of Singapore or Dubai. Well worth the visit.

Incredible service and nice people. The views are stunning and the gym is amazing.My only complaint is the spa room which only allows guests until 9 am. I mention this because after a full day in Tokyo I want to recline and take a steam. I disagreed that I should pay a day pass at 730 pm. Meanwhile no guests are using the hotel at that hour.I told the manager and they allowed me to use it for free.I thought the service was much better here then Pennisula. The only reason for the Pennisula is they allow you to use the spa at your leisure Charlie

This was both a business and personal trip. The hotel exceeded my expectations in every possible way. Its quality from facility, ambience to food and hospitality is of the finest among all five-star hotels I have stayed with in my life. Furnitures in room is a bit old as is the case for majority of hotels in Japan but are in very good conditions. Size of room is also very generous relative to other Japanese hotels. Hotel staff from front desk to maids all speak fluent English making basic communication so much easier for foreigners, and went out of their ways to make my experience at the hotel an excellent one. Mandarin Oriental will be my number one choice should my future travel brings me back to Tokyo and I highly recommend it for others.

We stayed in a grand premier room on the 32nd floor with stunning views over Tokyo. Early in the morning we could see Mt Fuji, and in the evening the skyscrapers and transport system were lit up across the city. At these prices you would expect the facilities to be good, but I can honestly say they were worth every penny. The large bathroom had a rain shower and Bottega V toiletries. The room was very comfortable with plenty of space, very quiet aircon, Nespresso coffee, minibar, chaise longue, large working desk area and excellent wifi (though note wifi is not usually included in the price, and is expensive). Location is superb. The Mitsukoshimae subway station is steps away from the hotel. The famous Nihonbashi bridge is very close and the huge Mitsukoshi dept store is very close. Across the road, the Coredon mall complexes house floors of independent stores and restaurants that sell an incredible variety of quality and quirky Japanese goods.The staff are all very hospitable and speak English well. The restaurants are superb! I will write separate reviews. I am coming here again!

There are 5 star hotels and then there are 5 star hotels. This is the ladder. From the moment you make the reservation the service starts. Emails from the concierge are on point. The hotel is stunning. The service is second to none. The room I had, upgraded via American Express fine hotels program was great. The spa was outrageous. Stunning. The food in the restaurants kept getting better. The bar and lounge was lively and well appointed. But all of it means nothing without the people who provide the 5 star service provided with the walls of a 5 star hotel. Everyone. And I mean everyone on the entire staff was incredible. Every single detail was attended to. Nothing was missed. The inly reason to stay anywhere else would be for necessity of a different location within the 845 square miles of Tokyo. The subway is directly under the hotel for the adventurous. Tokyo station is a 5 minute ride to the hotel by taxi or 10 by subway. Transportation from Narita airport is EXTREMELY expensive . A taxi is 200-300 and a car service 5-6. The train was $45 and much faster. Ticket counter was 40 feet past customs. The train station was a escalator ride away. The Mandarin has its own reputation. They have excelled even further with this property.

The Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Tokyo is a lovely beginning to any visit to Japan. The hotel is located on the top floors of a high rise building in the Nihonbashi area of the city- new Tokyo Station. The rooms were very comfortable with silk fabrics and state of the art electronics. Ask for a room facing Mt Fuji. Our room faced the Sky Tree Tower which was also interesting. Breakfast was a sumptuous buffet of many selections.The baked goods are even better than in Paris! The staff is helpful and attentive. The only downside to the hotel is the extra charge for the use of the spa- which we skipped due to time limitations. The lobby is on the 38th floor and the residential floors are below it. To get from your room to the street level you must go up to the lobby and change elevators to go down again. It is a bit of a hassle but I am sure it helps maintain security in the hotel.

their service is amazing- very courteous and professional. the view from our room was beautiful- especially at night. the location is so convenient- you can enter through the station. you will not regret booking this hotel

Location is close but not walking distance to some part of Ginza and site seeing area. Close to the train station if continues travelling by train to other parts of Japan. Excellent staff service and onsite restaurants are very good.

I travel for business and for vacations. This was my first visit to Tokyo. The Mandarin Oriental was recommended to me. Without doubt, this was a wonderful choice. The service is exceptional, the food is excellent, and the rooms (along with the views) are fantastic. This is a terrific hotel and I would highly recommend this hotel if you are planning a trip to Tokyo.

Everything I expected of a Mandarin Oriental property. I have spent a lot of time at the Mandarin in Hong Kong the the experience here was very similar. They are extremely attentive and go out of their way to ensure that they address you personally and make you feel welcome. The amenities there were great, my wife had a great facial at the spa and we both enjoyed a few drinks at the bar where the service was very good.The location was also great. It is very close to Tokyo station so if you are coming in on the Narita Express or Shinkansen it takes about 5 minutes to get to. Shopping and restaurants in the area are great which was a big plus. Also if you are a runner it is almost exactly a 10k loop from the hotel around the imperial palace and back, which was a plus for us.
user_name:
CourtC_13
New York City, New York

review_body: So far here one night. The service is impeccable. It was my birthday a day before and they left me a sculpted chocolate gift filled with chocolate covered nuts. Will eat at their molecular tapas meal tonight. Could see Mt Fuji yesterday pm beautifully from the hotel lobby.

The hotel is brand so nothing can go wrong since i arrived to the day i left. The room was clean and grand. The foods havfe many option but little over price. The staff is extremely helpful. The breafast view is beautiful. Highly recomment this hotel.

The Mandarin was an excellent hotel for our event. Their staff are friendly and helpful. The restaurant staff were so accommodating and gave flawless service.
