The breakfast choice available was varied and delicious. The views from the hotel are amazing. The décor is quite dark, even with such big windows. Everyone seems to glide around the hotel. My massage overlooking the city was 2nd to none. Can't wait to go back.

We have stayed in a few hotels in Tokyo and know high standards of 5 star hotels there, so we were looking forward to Mandarin Oriental as we thought we can´t be wrong with this brand in Japan. What swayed me to choose this hotel were really good reviews, but we were disappointed from the check in. The lady at the Front Desk was not very welcoming (I was surprised you can get it in Japan in a 5 star hotel). In addition to her rather cold demeanour, when we inquired about the spa, she said we have to pay for it or go in either really early (smth like 8 am, which would not work for us due to jet leg). As we were staying on my husband´s birthday I thought she would give us an exception and treat us on his special day. Unfortunately, she was very stubborn and treated us like any regular guest disregarding the special occasion. She said we could pay extra to enter, but the room rate was very high and it just did not feel right to pay more to enter the spa. So we said we would think about it. Once we entered the room there was another disappointment. It was all clean and fine, but the style was somewhat outdated for a sleek 5 star Tokyo hotel. We stayed in the Palace Hotel, Shangri La, Peninsula and Four Seasons and the decor of all these hotels seemed a lot fresher and more modern.In the end we left after 1 night and went back to Palace Hotel.I am probably too harsh with my review and probably the service from many staff members is impeccable as you get in Japan, unfortunately, our experience was different and so I could not resonate with the other good reviews of this hotel. Also I was surprised not to come across much feedback regarding outdated décor…

One of the best Hotels I have ever stayed in. The staff were absolutely amazing.Highly recommended. From the moment we arrived to the time we left no request was too much trouble.The view of Fuji from breakfast was an absolute pleasure to behold.

This is one of our favourite hotels in the world.. and by far the best Mandarin Oriental we have stayed in. The staff are amazing, and the levels of cleanliness, attention to detail etc are the highest. Breakfast is great, (make sure and get a deal with it included as its expensive separately), and the bar is terrific (best hamburgers when you need some western guilty pleasure). Location is awesome... right next to the Mitsukoshi Dept store with a great lower level food hall that will blow your mind, and the station also. So getting to all the other hot spots in Tokyo is a cinch. If you are staying soon be sure and check out the nearby production of Sakura which the hotel is promoting... its like a more cultured, but just as wild version of the Robot restaurant sans robots and more anime!

Loved the hotel. It is everything a 5 star hotel should be. But do not eat at their restaurant senses which is listed a Michelin starred Cantonese restaurant. While the view was lovely and the staff excellent, neither could make up for the almost inedible food. The recommended duck served many ways was neither hot or crisp when it should have been and progressed to slimy an inedible by the last course.

Amazingly excellentgood mood good breakfast good view (especially one side for Tokyo Sky Tree, the other side for Mountain Fuji.)Also the fitness center is really nice. staffs were very kind and warm.

We made arrangements to spend one night at the Tokyo Mandarin Oriental during our Christmas trip to see our son. He's stationed at Yokosuka Naval Base. It also happened to be my wife's birthday. We had booked a standard room w/roll-away for our son. After traveling from Yokosuka we arrived about 12:30pm and decided to check-in and just leave our bags so we could see parts of the city. The staff at the front desk was highly efficient, warm and friendly. They suggested that if we would like to have a seat in the lounge, they'd have a room ready for us shortly. Also, anything we wanted to eat or drink would be "on the house" due to the short wait. Wow - didn't see this coming! Sure enough, after about 20 minutes one of the front desk staff came escorted us to our room. And by the way, they mentioned that the Mandarin had upgraded us to a full suit with their compliments! Wow #2! When we arrived at the 34th floor suite we were blown away. It was the size of the entire first floor of our home in the US. Two large rooms, artwork in niches, 2 baths, beautiful view of Mt. Fuji and the Tokyo skyline. Words can't describe it, really. Tokyo is expensive. So, I knew this suite must be in the thousands per night. But it's no wonder this particular hotel is rated so highly. Well, we still had some of Tokyo to see, so off we went for some chopping, site seeing, and eventually dinner. When we returned to the Mandarin we were greeted by a special desert delivered to our suite in honor of my wife's birthday. We briefly mentioned it at check-in as part of why we chose the Mandarin. On the coffee table were 3 beautiful glass covered strawberry shortcakes and a written card wishing my wife a wonderful birthday - signed by everyone on the front desk staff! Wow #3! We've traveled quite a bit in Europe. But this was our first 10 day trip to Japan. And this night at the Mandarin tops them all. We could not have been more delighted with the venue and friendly, "over-the-top" staff. I asked for a feather pillow at check-in. We got 3! And it would be easy to list all the other pluses about this hotel. Our stay, for one night only, was superb. But, we had a bullet train to catch to Kyoto. Sorry to leave this hotel behind, but the memories are nice to relive.

Whoever designed this location maximized the view....even the spa sauna and bathrooms have floor to ceiling windows. It is stunning. The room was gorgeous and provided everything we needed and more. Too bad we were only here at the end our trip for one night.I spent 3 hours in the women's spa before flying home.... it was grand.  We did have nice cocktails in the bar, however our young server did not know anything about the sake on the wine list. The hostess in the bar went out of her way to see to it that we were well taken care of.We opted to not eat at Tapas because we have something similar at home. We ate at Sense. It was ok. With all of the amazing places we ate in Japan, Sense was not special and the portions were meager even by Japanese standards. The accommodations made up for it!

I had stayed in a number of business hotels in Tokyo before, but not in the Mandarin Oriental: It's simply a cut-above. The service is impeccable (they will remember what you had for breakfast the previous day, and ask you the next morning if you would like to have the same), personal (everyone seems to remember your name), and inconspicuous (rooms have a "drop box" where papers or other small deliveries can be deposited without disturbing the guest). Add to that the internet service (better than 80 Mbps), the great location (30 minutes walk to Ginza, 40 minutes to Fish market, 20 minutes to Imperial Palace, etc.), the great views in every direction (our view was Mount Fuji every morning), and it makes for the best place to stay for fun or work in Tokyo. PS: Will also upload a picture of the little "gift" presented by server at breakfast on the day of our departure; memorable service and impeccable attention to detail!

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo has a lot going for it but given that it is one of the most expensive hotels in Tokyo, I feel it is let down by a few things. Let me start with the positives:- The common areas definitely have that 'wow factor'- While the breakfast spread is limited compared to other 5* hotels I've stayed at in Asia, everything is very well executed and the view of Mount Fuji (on a clear day) from the breakfast table is a great experience.- The view from the sauna overlooking the city at sunrise is one of many great memories I will take from my time in Japan.- Customer service at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is one of the best I've experienced anywhere- The location, while not the most exciting, is very central and it is very easy to get anywhere one could possibly wish to get to in TokyoHowever....- The room, while spacious, is underwhelming does not compare to the common areas and could do with an update- I ate at one of the restaurants, and while it was good, it was extremely expensive for what you get, even when compared to other fine dining experiences I've had around the world, including my home (and comparably expensive) city of London- The use of the sauna etc is only complimentary for hotel guests early in the morning. A bit of a niggle given how much you are paying for a night here. However this appears to be common in Japan (in fact other hotels I stayed at didn't even have any complimentary slots for hotel guests)- Wifi is not free unless you book directly with the hotel. This is a policy of the Mandarin Oriental group of hotels and an annoying one if you (a). have things you need to organise while you are away and (b). wish to book through a hotel booking website in order to collect air miles / loyalty points etc. I find it a bit of an odd policy given the price point of the Mandarin Oriental hotels and that these days wifi is generally included by other hotels for free.

We stayed at three different hotels, because we wanted to find out, which one is best. The first one was Shangri-La, the second one The Peninsula and the third one Mandarin Oriental. We stayed at all hotels for three days, a total of nine days. I booked all hotels through GrandLuxuryHotels and have been very pleased by the service offered and all the upgrades we received. The Mandarin Oriental has beaten all expectations: after check in we asked, if we could receive a bigger room. We have been told, the first night is fully booked (New Years Eve), but there is a possibility for the next day. January 1st, we have been upgraded to a huge corner suite with two separate rooms, a huge bathroom plus a separate bathroom for guests. Breakfast, high speed internet, two loaded PASMO tickets (ach Yen 3'000) and a USD 100 Credit was complementary. The view from our room was breathtaking, the service level imperial! We had a great New Year's Eve dinner at Signature (French Restaurant) and they even reserved seats for us at the bar afterwards. The two other nights, we had dinner at Sense, the Cantonese restaurant. Those two restaurants are highly recommended (see separate evaluation)! Breakfast is being served in two different restaurants: one with a nice buffet, the other one is served: try out at the second one the egg Benedict with lobster... The level of service is at its best and we regret, not having stayed longer at the Mandarin Oriental. Thank you all: the management (especially Raul Levis, Kai Jansen and Fabio Testa), the concierges (Ana Gervasio) and every member of the highly efficient and always super friendly staff! You treated us royal and showed us, that quality has a new name: Mandarin Oriental... We will be back for sure - thank you!

I've stayed at a lot of hotels ... this property stands above most for its utter all-round excellence.Our checkin experience was as smooth as could be expected, in spite of our booking (via TA) providing incorrect details to the property. Reception is located on Level 38 - right at the top of the property, and it has outstanding views over Tokyo .... it's hard not to be somewhat distracted during checkin! Our room, on L35 enjoyed some great views looking out towards the Tokyo Skytree.The room was generous in its size, but where this property excels itself is in the attention to detail: every little thing that the traveller may require has been thought of and thought through: from the simple items such as providing mouthwash, through to the extensive range of stationery all set out in a beautiful little drawer set. Even the room service menu is a work of art with the way the hanger has been cut into the paper.My partner and I loved this property - it's in a great location and very easy to get to either the subway or the Japan Rail network - both services are within meters of the hotel, and are accessible via the underground pedestrian mall that is connected to the hotel.The concierge provides an excellent service - we used them a few times for recommendations on where to eat and were not disappointed on either occasion. One of the bellhops even walked us to a place she had recommended for breakfast that was a couple of blocks away as it was a difficult place to located ... that she did so in the cold wind of December reflects their dedication to great service.I can't imagine anyone being disappointed in selecting this property when staying in Tokyo.

We took a 2 week trip to a Tokyo. Love to eat. Stayed at the MO, Pennisula and AMAN. MO had the best staff, English oriented. They did fail to get us best reservations. We give that credit to the AMAN. The room quality is dated. In house breakfast etc is good

The hotel is nicely located next to Mitsukoshi dept store, and also next to a subway station.Service can be improved. For the price I paid, it seems lile they to save costs in their amenities and towels.No swimming pool and small gym - the major drawback of this hotel.

We arrived at this amazing hotel yesterday and have been blown away by the attentive staff and the gorgeous rooms. From the initial interaction the staff has been superb. We were greeted at the taxi by 2 bellmen who whisked away our luggage and escorted us promptly to the front desk. Upon check-in, Kodai explained all of the amenities that were available to us and then gave a gift to both of our children. He then ordered a PlayStation to be brought to the room to entertain them. He personally escorted us to our rooms and spent 10 minutes explaining everything that our rooms had to offer. We have never had such personalized service!We have stayed at some of the finest hotels in the world, but so far the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is by far the best.

I stayed at the hotel between Boxing Day and New Year's Eve. This is a five-star property from a highly respected global firm and it meets or exceeds the standards expected at that level. I particularly appreciated the ability of the staff to recognize my habits quickly, e.g., room service breakfast order, and anticipate me. The hotel makes an excellent base for getting about Tokyo and Japan: there is a metro station below the building, and it is a ten minute walk to Tokyo Station (Nihonbashi gate).

From the management down to every last employee, there is a clear dedication to excellence and ultimate service. It starts upon arrival when I was greeted by four different people and escorted up to the rooftop lobby (gorgeous views, and a very lovely scent, what a great detail!) and forget the check in counter they brought me right to the room despite it being well before check in time and they served me a cool tea while I relaxed in my new room.Before I go into the details, many thanks to Maria for making me feel welcome from the very beginning, to Raul and Masumi for help salvaging a near disaster situation with my sushi reservations (the purpose of my journey), and Ai and Saturi in the spa who just made for a lovely day and experience. 1) Rooms: very spacious even at the entry deluxe king level and magical views of the city day and night. Great wooden accents and open bathrooms equipped with rain shower and extra size jacuzzi. No complaints, small nit-pick is that soundproofing seems light though my neighbors were very respectful.2) Food: Raul insisted I try the hotel's own sushi restaurant in addition to the more celebrated ones I was trying around the city and I must say it was fantastic, if not better than the other more well known ones I tried. Will review this separately but incredible that the sous chef Hojo San stacked up favorably to Michellin starred chefs out on their own. Breakfast was also a pleasure, best French toast I've ever had. Although word from the wise, their pancakes aren't really pancakes as any one else would know them, so make sure to specify.3) Spa: simply divine and will forever spoil me as I don't think I'll ever get a massage or personalized experience any where else. The water lounges overlooking the city are simply mesmerizing.4) Service: team was very helpful in securing my reservations at all the restaurants and despite some trouble at the last minute they were able to save the day. Staff across the board are super friendly and aim to please. You won't be disappointed. Incredible how even the masseuse at the spa knew about the purpose of my journey, and Maria in guest services knew I was on my way to Manila after Tokyo, they really do take the time to make it a personalized experience and I doubt I was spending as much as many of the patrons there. The only choice in Tokyo, I've been to all the others, even compares favorably with the new Aman but at a fraction of the price. I know where I'll be staying when I come back.
user_name:
Anonymous760D
New York City, New York

review_body: The Mandarin Oriental really sets the standard for fine hotels. It is beautiful inside and out; the service and attention to detail start the moment you arrive; the bell person asks your name once, and from then on, all the staff address you by name. The lobby and restaurants are beautiful. The food is incredible, every day the breakfast "buffet" seems like a holiday celebration. Do not miss the spa and fitness area.The rooms are divine: comfortable, chic, and with everything well thought out. The service was flawless.

The Mandarin Oriental is a superb hotel, conveniently located in the center of the city with direct underground access to the subway system and the Mitsukoshi department store. Check-in is on the 38th floor, where the guest is warmly welcomed and then takes an elevator either to rise further or descend a few floors to the guest bedrooms. Our room had a direct view toward the Ginza district with its shopping and night-life, as well as the main railway station and the cross-town expressways. The room was exceptionally comfortable, with electronically controlled lighting and drapes. The one disappointing feature was that there were no drawers in the room to store clothing, which was inconvenient for anyone staying more than a few days. The restaurants were very good, as one would expect from such a deluxe establishment. Different restaurants served Japanese and Western meals. There is an excellent business center, although it is located on the third floor and hard to find. A guest needs to seek directions from a staff member. The service throughout the hotel was superb.

The views are incredible, but the outstanding feature of this hotel is the service. Every need is faultlessly catered to. The location is quiet at night in the financial district and it is 45 mins from the entertainment areas but there's always something interesting close by in Tokyo.

Visited recently for two nights with my wife and 7 yr old daughter. We had limited time and therefore needed some advanced planning which the concierge desk (via email) was instrumental in helping coordinate. When we arrived they greeted our daughter with a gift and checkin was a breeze.The staff met all of my expectations after reading the reviews here, many of them remembering us by name even after only one introduction. Breakfast was phenomenal with a plethora of western and Japanese options and a wall of baked goods to die for. My wife and I dined in their Cantonese restaurant for dinner one night and the food was fantastic. There is a subway station in the bottom of the building which was extremely convenient.Highly recommended!

My new favourite business hotel, anywhere in the world. Location is great, service exceedingly good and rooms large and very well appointed. I look forward to staying there again in the not too distant future.

There is no such thing as a bad room at the Mandarin in Tokyo. North, south, east or west you get a 'Blade Runner' view of the enormity of the city.Rooms are spacious with all the amenities. Food options are solid although room service can be very expensive if you start getting hungry; 1200 yen for coffee (about 11 usd) I think is a record high in my experience anywhere.The staff are awesome as well. I almost feel bad making such extensive use of the concierge helping out with all kinds of obscure things....almost.Complaints, not really. They changed their soap a couple years ago and would have preferred they kept what they had (or started using some local product like Tomanohada). I wish it was more affordable. That is about it.Mandarin Tokyo is my favorite 'large' hotel anywhere in the world.

we stayed 2 nights in this luxury hotel in Tokyo. The staff was friendly and helpful. The room was elegant , large and with all modern comforts. the price are high but you know that you are in a luxury hotel and you have to pay for the service they offer you

As a part of a wonderful 14 day tour of Japan we were fortunate to be able to use the Mandarin Oriental as a base of operation for the final three days while getting to know, if only a little, Tokyo and surrounds. The Mandarin is, in every way, a spectacular venue from which to absorb the energy, beauty and cultural importance of Tokyo to the Japanese people. With the lobby on the 38th floor and guest room floors just below, customers enjoy expansive vistas regardless of what direction their room faces. As wonderful as the hotel facilities and central location are the thing that impressed us the most was the attention to detail, work ethic and genuine desire to please exhibited by every hotel staff member we had occasion to interact with. One example - leaving our room one morning I unknowingly turned on the do not disturb sign. When we arrived back late in the afternoon we noticed the room had not been cleaned so I called for service. I was informed why it had not been done (DND light on) and that they would send someone right up. Two ladies arrived within 5 minutes. I apologized and informed them that we just needed new towels and the trash removed, nothing else was important. The ladies insisted, politely, on doing a complete cleaning. Then, when they were done one of them, in her best english, thanked us for our patience and said that "it was an honor to be allowed to serve you". WOW, we were overwelmed by her genuine and heart felt remarks, made even more impressive by the fact that I had really inconvenienced THEM. What a positive example of true customer service!This experience, and a few others says to me that management must be doing everything right to attract, train and retain such dedicated employees. Most impressive.We whole heartedly recommend the Mandarin Hotel experience.

My stays at Mandarin Oriental Tokyo Hotel are always warm and comfortable. It is luxurious but the people are so warm and helpful. They always remember your faces and names which make M.O. a difference. The view there is extremely stunning and impressive.

We stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo on our last two trips here, but decided to try the MO this time round, having heard so much about it. The accolades are true - the customer service here is superlative. Peninsula service tends to be much more impersonal and perfunctory. There was almost always a queue at the Peninsula concierge desk which necessited us having to wait to have a query answered. In contrast, the MO staff take the trouble to find out and remember your name, and in almost every interaction with them, be it reception, concierge or housekeeping, I was addressed by name. The concierge service is excellent. They were really responsive to our emails before the trip when I sought their help with restaurant reservations. There were a few staff members manning the concierge desk and we seldom had to wait, and if we did, it was a short wait. Even housekeeping was fantastic. They have the most extensive pillow menu I have seen so far. When I asked before coming if they had a power transformer so that I could use a 220v electrical appliance in the room, I was assured (somewhat to my surprise) that they did, and lo and behold, I found it waiting in the room, all ready for use, when we checked in. Little touches like a lovely essential oil scent and mochi during turndown added to the experience.The only downsides to this amazing hotel, in my opinion, are first, that there is no swimming pool (if this matters to you), and second, the location. It's located in the financial district next to the rather stodgy Mitsokushi department store. While it is true that it is located above the subway, I much prefer the location of the Peninsula in Ginza.

This is a very good hotel , with known quality and service standards widely recognized ! With the advantage of a great location which permits walking around to some nice restaurants and great shopping.!!

Excellent customer service. Really excellent staff - although sometimes you need to tell them you're a hotel guest to get differentiated treatment from local visitors looking to use the amenities (i.e. the bar). Slightly aging facility, but great MO hospitality.

I am always a fan of Mandarin oriental. And of course, Mandarin Tokyo is one of my most favourite hotels of all time. The lobby reflects how the genuine lobby should be. The guest room is refined. The breakfast room is lovely and private. They serve the most scrumptious egg Benedict in the world! Gym is great. The staff and service are superb! What else do you want?

I would like to start by saying that its a beautiful hotel with a good location.I just don't find it right that they still charge you for the internet in 2016 when is free internet almost everywhere.The room is big, with a nice view, the service is amazing. The only restaurant that we tried is Sushi Bar which was very good, and amazing service.Probably if i will go to Tokyo again, we will stay to a different hotel.Also under the hotel there is a metro station, so its easy to travel.

Great staff and their English skill is very good. Everything about this hotel is great.They have beautiful view in the lobby and your room. Subway station is just downstairs, very easy to access. I'll definitely come back

I have stayed at many 5-star hotels throughout the world, and the Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo ranks among the middle of the pack. The reception and service staff were top notch, however, the hotel was a bit dated, and the build quality was behind the times. The rooms weren't very quiet - footsteps could be heard on a daily (and nightly basis) which made it difficult to relax. Also, it seems that their billing practices could use some work. I was charged for a mini-bar item that I did not use (which I did not notice until returning to the states), and was charged daily for internet access (however the room description was deceptive making it sound like the internet was included). These three issues (noise, and charges) make me rank the hotel is mediocre.

Enjoyed my stay at the Mandarin, stayed a few days while traveling for business. The staff is very friendly, the room had an amazing view of the city and spacious. A little dust in my room had my allergies going. Other than that, the food was great, the location is quite central, and the facilities are exemplary.

Everything about the Mandarin Oriental is superb. We checked in after a long flight at 11.30pm, and yet a manager escorted us to our room and explained every facility offered by the hotel in a courteous and committed manner. The rooms offer gorgeous views over Tokyo, starting at around the 35th floor. The breakfast could not be faulted, nor the service thereof. The public areas are gracious and designed with remarkable imagination. The staff are unfailingly helpful -- for example, in arranging for our luggage to be sent on to Kyoto or ordering a taxi. Thick carpeting gives all corridors and rooms in the Mandarin Oriental a hushed, luxurious feeling. This is an hotel to which one wants to return again and again.

Nothing can go wrong with this hotel except for the location of the property. Beautiful rooms with view of the city. I am a cab person, so personally this hotel does not work for me when it comes to traveling to places of interest like Shibuya, Shinjuku etc as the cost is extremely high if you are not taking the metro.

Great food along with great service and would definitely recommend. Did I mention the exceptional view of Tokyo. On a clear days view, you will be able to see Mount Fuji. Those who are familiar with Mandarin Oriental's reputation know that it come with a price tag. For the budget conscious, please beware.

Elegant, energized, stunning, disciplined, and brilliant. That’s the summary. Here are the details (in no specific order): Ice buckets always filled without asking, stunning views from everywhere, magnificent suite (one of the nicest city suites we have very stayed in), elegant bar, great jazz, fantastic whiskey selection, superb restaurants (we loved Sense), peaceful spa, fabulous massage, incredible breakfast buffet and, of course, the exceptional staff -- gracious, courteous and always helpful.Special thanks to the concierge desk. Masumi Tajima extended herself in every way. She is very knowledgeable, patient, and the top of her field. My wife and I are so grateful to her. And to concierge Ana Gervasio and guest relations manager Jihyun Yee, who has terrific taste in flowers, thank you both for all your help during our stay. (The only negative was the quality of the caviar in the hotel bar. Sound absurd, I know, but it is far below the quality of the hotel. Charge more, or don’t serve it at all.)A+ Mandarin. Keep it up.

Perfect service. Immaculate rooms. Quiet, friendly, attentive personnel. Fabulous views from room, lobby and dining venues. Very helpful Staff. Location is quite good and its connected to the train and a mall.

This hotel is my absolute favourite worldwide when travelling on business. Period. Located in the Nihonbashi Mitsui Tower in Tokyo’s historic Nihonbashi neighborhood, close to Tokyo Station and Tokyo Stock Exchange and surrounded by many shops and restaurants (many good restos in the Corrado Nihonbashi buildings across the street). MO is a short cab ride to many favoured Tokyo destinations including Ginza, Ueno Park and Roppongi (if one must). It's also a short distance to the Imperial Palace gardens for a really pleasant run - easy run there/back. Facilities are truly superb - rooms, spa (spa facilities recognised by the travel press as a top destination globally) and dining/drinks options. The bar on the 27th floor has many seating options, excellent jazz and a warm, relaxed vibe. I should note that smoking is allowed at the bar, which is my preferred seating. Rooms are spacious and I like the open shower concept (not to Westerner's liking but this wet room concept is very common in Asia). Beyond the globally consistently high MO standards, it's the staff who truly distinguish themselves in Tokyo. From the moment one arrives MO staff provide incredible care and attention. I have observed this care on many occasions as guests have every need or question expertly addressed. This MO standard is well-above and beyond what might expect in Asia, a region known for hospitality and attention to detail. Housekeeping, Room Service, Gym, Spa, Dining - incredible care and attention. Prior to my arrival I spent two weeks coordinating several dinner reservations with the MO Concierge (most high-end Tokyo restos require hotel confirmation for out-of-region guests). Concierges Daisuke Hikota, Ana Gervasio, Asuka Kon, Yuna Choi were incredibly helpful to secure preferred dining reservations, offer-up alternative recommendations, provide directions and other insights, including museum and sightseeing options. Importantly, MO staff ask many questions to ensure that their guidance is appropriate.We saw Maria Yano nearly every day during our stay. She was incredibly helpful providing further insight into Tokyo, thankfully steering us away from tourist/expat neighbourhoods towards areas where we could really enjoy more of the local colour. She was genuinely interested to hear of our daily exploits and always had a fresh idea or recommendation on- offer. I am in Tokyo on business 4-5 times a year and always stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. It has a level of charm and simplicity that resonates w me on all levels.

Wonderful hotel experience. Lovely, very comfortable room. Quiet, friendly, attentive personnel. Fabulous views from room, lobby and dining venues. Very helpful consigliere.We were celebrating my husbands 50th birthday and we wouldn't have picked a better hotel for our first time in Tokyo and our special occasion! We loved everything about this hotel , the service was outstanding , The room was specious and beautiful .. The restaurants located in the hotel are amazing specially the Italian one. Staying in this hotel made our visit to Tokyo extra special !

Among quite a number of luxury hotels in Tokyo that I've had the pleasure to stay at, this one has effortlessly moved up to the top.The luxe factor starts at the understated elegance of its 38th floor lobby, designed to make it seem like it floats above the city's sea of skyscrapers. Given the city's reputation for having among the tiniest of hotel rooms in the world, the rooms at The Mandarin are very spacious, beautifully appointed with Japanese charm that blend with modern decor and conveniences. The latter included a personal favorite : Bang and Olufsen Philippe Stark Bluetooth speakers that paired instantly with my smartphone. Blinds and curtains that drew open in the mornings with a switch were a favorite of my companion as it gave him a spectacular view of the city's skyline including the iconic Tokyo Tower. Service was extremely efficient yet genteel, particular kudos go to the concierge team for assisting us with our multitude of requests and inquiries in advance of our stay. Three of the property's restaurants, Signature (French), Tapas Molecular Bar and Sense (Cantonese) have all deservedly been awarded with Michelin stars.The hotel's very central location among two major subway lines gave us immediate access to the city's overwhelming delights. The five minute cab ride to Tokyo Central Station easily linked us to the country's other wonders. Next door is the swanky Mitsukoshi Department Store. Gourmands will more than be satiated with the dining options that abound the neighborhood.My companion and I celebrated a very special and important occasion on this trip and the hotel's integral involvement made it all the more memorable.Internationally, I have stayed at quite a number of Mandarin hotels and this property makes it no surprise why I'll continue to be a huge fan.

This hotel is wonderful. We have been frequent guests and always are made to feel at home by the outstanding staff, clearly expertly trained to give the best possible service. We have yet to have a room that did not have a gorgeous view. Having the metro station on site is a huge plus. Definitely our first choice in Tokyo. Highly recommend.
user_name:
travelpro10000
New York City, New York

review_body: Mandarin Oriental is the perfect hotel. Located in the perfect area, train in the lowest level.Views of Mt. Fuji and the evening city lights..Hotel is gorgeous and a real 5 star property. Every detail done to perfection.Excellent in every way.

In Nihonbashi District, the centre of Tokyo. Metro station on Ginza line is below the hotel and Central station a 10 min walk away. A high rise hotel giving great views of the city from public rooms, restaurants and bedrooms. Reception on 38th Floor and rooms are on the seven floors below. Excellent service with Japanese style and grace. Rooms are immaculate, good size and very well appointed. Great restaurants too with Tapas Molecular a real treat. See separate reports.

This is a great hotel for exploring Tokyo. The room we had was spacious, well-equipped and had a spectacular view. The staff were helpful and couldn't do more to help. House keeping was through and efficient and the cakes and coffee waiting for our early morning arrival were hugely appreciate. The position of the hotel made it perfect for using the very efficient subway system. There is a station under the hotel which allows you to travel around the city very quickly. We didn't have breakfast in the dining room but did start our day with a coffee and croissant from their very good gourmet shop on the ground floor. If we return to Tokyo we would book here again in a flash.

Located right on the Ginza line a few stops from the shopping district itself the MO offers nicely appointed rooms and a very good level of service. Views of the city thrown in because of the rooms being on a couple of floors below the 38-floor lobby. If you want to dine at the Sushi restaurant book (well) ahead since it is tiny and difficult to get into.

What can I say - Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo with excellent Japanese service. My husband had been on a business trip and stayed at the Mandarin Oriental. When my husband and I arrived several months later to stay, the Concierge greeted my husband by his name and welcomed him back to Tokyo. Good memory - rooms are wonderful. Location of the hotel not as convenient if you want to get to Ginza, but it is in a nice part of Tokyo which is starting to evolve. The Mandarin Bar and staff are superb; the Molecular Tapas Bar is also a must visit. Helpful staff always with a smile.

The MO Tokyo is by far the best place to stay. Convenient to most areas, great location, and staff. All that you would expect from a luxury hotel. I highly recommend the experience while in Tokyo. Friendly staff, excellent dinning, and all around superb stay.

Nice rooms, good restaurants, very friendly staff, excellent location. Nothing to complain about in the entire weeks staying there. This is not our first Mandarin Oriental stay, we also used the one in Prague, which is much smaller and even more elegant.

The hotel is absolutely gorgeous with service to match. The rooms are spacious and well appointed with every need met before you now you have one. The concierges were extremely helpful and spoke perfect English. There are several restaurants to choose from and the breakfast served in the buffet was varied and scrumptious!

On our first three nights in Japan, why wife and I decided to begin a 20 day tour, we'd start here. Incredible and magical in person, we were overwhelmed initially. The service was impeccable and our room wonderful. Everything was great until around 1:00am, I started hearing tapping noises. Kept me from a sound sleep. Next day, once again the hotel met all our needs. Breakfast was fantastic and the lobby bar at sunset became an instant lifetime memory. However, at 1:00am again, the tapping started. And again, I had a restless night. This time, I addressed the manager about providing a solution. He assured me that at breakfast, we would be informed of his options. 20 minutes later, he suggested that we pack our bags(3 large suitcases) and than be moved to an upgraded room on the top floor. The notion of changing to a better and quieter room was the incentive to spend the time to pack to move. Hours later when we returned, rather than be escorted to our new room, the staff told us they had made a different decision. They had solved the problem and we would remain in the room. Never an explanation of the solution nor an apology. As I have learned in my visit to Japan, ones offer of an apology is integrated in the society. Our original plan was to return for our final two days to the Mandarin. That would be a true test of its greatness if the had made any effort to make us satisfied. Since that did not happen, our itinerary was altered and we switched to The Palace. Glad we did because the snobby and unprofessional attitude at the Oriental was replaced with gracious and precise service.

I recommend this hotel. The staff is excellent. The location is really good and the access to the metro is in a few meters if you don't use the taxi. The restaurantes and bar are comfortable and the attention in those places are excelente,.

When I see Mandarin Oriental, I would usually runaway because well I always believe it would be out of my budget. A friend of mine opened my eyes on my stupidness :)Having a pretty unique sunset over the entire city, a damn good cocktail and, a jazz concert (after 8PM only though). Total cost 16 euros... People would pay 5 times to get stuck in the traffic, and see their idol who just want her/his night to be over ASAP and still have a great night... Totally worth to go! A concert, a sky's creeper sunset and a drink... Think twice... We went 3 times actually (once with a friend, as a couple and with family)

I was lucky enough to have won this trip through my company. It was without doubt the best hotel I have ever stayed in. Everything was spotless, the views were incredible, the staff were the most polite, helpful staff I have ever experienced. I would recommend to anyone.

Wonderful staff make wonderful hotel. Every staff in Mandarin oriental hotel is wonderful! Every one is so genuine and helpful. Beautiful location. Wonderful services. Delicious food. Beautiful views.

The Mandarin in Tokyo has been rated the best in the world a few tiimes It meets this expectation in every way Location Ambience accommodation food and sesrvice There is nothing like arriving at a Mandarin after a long flight or a long day You will feel important and pampered

I stayed a whole week and I cant express how top service I was treated. Located conveniently, and I used the subway and the car with ease. The food was great, the room service were nice. Also near there was a street with cafes and izakayas and malls in a walking distance. The earthquake was an experience there as I my suite was on 31 floor :)

The hotel is in a great location, close to the Tokyo station, on top of a subway station, close to Ginza district, etc. The hotel is gorgeous! The room was quite large and comfortable with a great sitting area for reading an working. Fabulous bathroom. Room was great for sleeping as I like it very dark. Huge floor to ceiling windows with a great view of the Tokyo and the Tokyo Tower. Service was out of this world good. They were on top of everything. Free shoe shine service. Helpful with reservations and recommendations for restaurants, car service, etc. Great bar area for evening drinks overlooking Tokyo. Good buffet breakfast.

Exceptional service, hotel staff was extremely attentive through and through. Loved the room, you can stay there all day just for the view. The hotel location is very convenient, direct connection to the subway in the basement. Walking distance to Ginza shopping area. What more can you ask for? oh, yes there is a pillow menu too.

No question this is a top-notch luxury hotel, and service, food, and room were very fine, but it's those pesky little details that keep this from getting five stars. There were numerous places on the woodwork in my room that needed repair, including a big gouge in my closet door. The carpet was coming up where it meet the wood floor (or had been poorly repaired). My tea at breakfast didn't come until I was almost finished (and it was before 7 and not very busy). Finally, the valet woke me early every morning when he delivered my paper to the valet box. For this price, and for Japan, these things shouldn't happen.

My room on the 35th floor had an impressive view of the city around. Room was very spacious for Japanese hotel standard, and fully equipped with amenities. Staff were helpful and courteous, well up to one's expectation of a combination of Japanese and Mandarin culture. What really impressed my wife and me was their attention to details and the personal touch. They noted down what drinks and eggs we had in our breakfast on the first morning, and asked if we would want the same on the second morning, before we ordered!Expensive but well worth it. We'll be back on our future visit to Tokyo.

You know when you stay at a Mandrin Oriental it will be top notch. The rooms are very well appointed with everything you could possibly need. The bed is hard but they seem to be all over Japan. The service is excellent. It is quite expensive but a great experience.

The Peninsula in Tokyo was always my favorite until I stayed at the Mandarin this month. 5 star service doesn't even do it justice! They nailed every request and reservation. Gorgeous, spacious rooms, great bathrooms and products. Beds in Japan are usually on the firm side and this is no exception but its not terrible. I would like to see a proper coffee machine in the room, like a Nespresso, etc.

I stayed here because Peninsula Tokyo was full. The hotel is perfect, amenities were great. They even provided my room with Yoga mat, first time I see this in hotels. Breakfast is perfect as well. But for the price I paid, I think location is not the most ideal as it is far from all the major shops, except for one department store next door. Overall, no doubt is a nice hotel. But for the price, location is not no 1.

Great hotel, well located, near a train station, absolutely beautiful and the people that work for the hotel are amazing, very helpful and extremely nice. The room was beautiful with big windows and amazing view of mount Fuji. Highly recommended.

Next time i'm in Tokyo I will definitely be staying here again. All in all incredible hotel, with staff who go out of their way to help you. Views, food, rooms all great. Especially loved the bar with live music, which was buzzing in the evening and a perfect place for a nightcap after a busy day.Also, there is an underground station exactly underneath which is very convenient.

The location used to be just a financial district with a few very old shops, now the hotel is surrounded by many new shops (in the COREDO 1/2/3 buildings next door) and restaurants (the old 100-year old stores are still there and worth exploring). Of course, there is always the Mitsukoshi department store next door (the food hall at the basement is a must visit). If you want to venture out more, ask about the local bus which offers free rides and loops around the area. The hotel is also situated conveniently above the subway (Mitsukoshimae station). All rooms are very spacious. All you need are provided for …. a large bed with pillow menu, his/hers kimonos, hot water kettle and coffee makers, Bottega Veneta bathroom amenities, etc. I only wish they had 2 sinks in the bathroom. Mt. Fuji mountain view is nice to have but not a must if you’ve stayed here before (in fact when we were there, the mountain was covered with clouds for days). The hotel is at the top 9 floors of the 34-story Nihonbashi Mitsui Tower, so all rooms got amazing view. The spa offers a spectacular wet area (steam/sauna/jet pool). Hotel guests can use this area for free before 9am in the mornings. The restaurants/bars/lounge in the hotel all seem to be doing very well as they are full most of the time. Make sure you book ahead! Suggest to try the Japanese set breakfast, dinner at the Tapas Molecular bar, afternoon tea at the Lounge (like all the Japanese ladies do), pizza at the café, weekend wine brunch, and taste a rare Japanese whisky at the bar! OR, there is also the MO cake shop and the super high-end fruit store Nihonbashi Sembikiya at the ground floor.Excellent staff at the hotel which truly distinguishes this hotel from the other 5-star hotels in Tokyo. Special mention to Concierge Masumi and her team. Masumi seems to be at the Concierge desk 20 hours a day and still manage to be very professional; greeting and helping all guests with a smile, and following up on all requests/enquiries promptly.

We stayed at the here for a quick mini-break to explore Tokyo and enjoy a luxurious break after a very busy and stressful year. It was the perfect choice. Rooms are beautifully appointed - functional and very, very well maintained. Views are spectacular - particularly from the spa (treat yourself and do at least one treatment there - and make sure you go an hour before to enjoy all the amenities. Even though it's expensive - it's an experience in itself and just fabulous!). All staff completely excelled in predicting needs and delivering the highest level of luxury service we have encountered since The Lodhi, India and our last stay at the Mandarin Oriental, HK (sadly, Australian service is usually disappointing even at the luxury level - so we take our much needed relax travel overseas when possible). I would highly recommend this hotel and it is unlikely there would be a need to look any further on our next visit to Tokyo. It's that lovely. Expensive - but lovely.

A beautiful hotel with sincere and gracious service. Having stayed with several of Tokyo's top tier hotels, the MO is hands down the best for overall product. I really enjoyed the early morning complimentary use of spa facilities.

We spent a lovely two nights here on a whirlwind tour of Tokyo. The hotel exceeded our expectations in every way. The room was beautiful and comfortable and lacked nothing. The service was impeccable, and everyone was so friendly and helpful. The restaurants were great. We had the breakfast buffet both days, and it was one of the finest we've experienced anywhere in the world. We ate at the sushi restaurant one evening, and had a lovely time, and we also tried the pizza bar and had a great pizza and salad. The location was great with the train station in the basement of the hotel - it made touring simple. We'd highly recommend the Mandarin and would stay here again.

Service oriented to the max . Right in the luxury area of Tokyo . Great rooms with spectacular views of the city . On a tour and don't know op rices but I am sure this doesn't come cheap but is probably worth it
I stayed this hotel for 3 nights.Staff are very professional and friendly.View is great and location is also good.Spa massage was relaxing and breakfast was delicious.Turndown service was fantastic.

Exquisite property, rooms, great service. Located in banking center of Tokyo, also central to other points of the city for tourism (public transport is excellent though you should avoid peak hours if possible on some lines).Two negatives: despite using concierge to book a restaurant months in advance, we almost missed due to 'change in restaurant booking policy'. Perhaps can't blame the Mandarin, but it was a 3 star Michelin restaurant, presumably known to be in demand, and we ended up with a 10pm dinner seating. The taxi, though given printed directions in Japanese from concierge and guidance from the Mandarin staff, took us to the wrong location (within a couple blocks), even stepped out to point us in the right (wrong) direction. It wasn't the last of taxi issues with explicit directions in Japanese, maps, etc. Google Maps and familiarity with where we were going is the only reason we made it to the last 3 meals (every taxi goofed).

It doesn't come cheap, at around USD 900 for a standard room, but MO Tokyo does deliver a very high standard of luxury which almost justifies the price. Like the Park Hyatt, it is situated on top of an office block, with the lobby on level 38 and the rooms on the levels below this - a little disconcerting, as you need to go uo to the lobby from your room before changing elevators to go down to street level, however it does allow for some spectacular views, and a beautifully designed lobby/bar/restaurant area.The rooms are large by Japanese standards, and very comfortable, although becoming a little dated and will require updating soon, and service was impeccable as expected from a MO property.Disappointingly, MO Tokyo does not offer a club level with the inclusions that come with the Oriental Club. There is also no in-room ironing board or iron. In room wifi comes at a cost unless you have a profile set up on the MO website or have it specifically included in your package. The "vitality pool", whilst visually spectacular, is available to guests only between the hours of 0630 and 0900 - after that, you will be charged JPY 7000 to use it - rather outrageous on top of the already high room rate (apparently to "avoid congestion with people paying to use the spa treatment facilities").These are small annoyances, and overall the MO Tokyo is still certainly a very pleasant place to stay. If the vitality pool was available in the evenings as well as at dawn, and if their was a Club option, then I would be very happy to return.

My wife and I stayed here for a part of our honeymoon around the world. I won't make this review too long because everything was so perfect it would get old saying that a million times. The important things to know is the hotel is absolutely beautiful. It is located perfectly right in the middle of shopping and very close to all the sites you would ever want to see. Tokyo in general is an amazing place filled with great people but the Mandarin took it a step further. The staff was so nice and so helpful. They did so many special things for us for our honeymoon that was not expected but really made our time here special. The rooms are clean and large, the views are breathtaking. Even the bathrooms in the lobby are amazing. The conceriege made all of our travel seamless and we had a car pick us up and take us to the airport which was all set up by the hotel. There are a bunch of places to eat in the hotel, all are amazing and all are so different. The views in each will take your breath away. The mandarin not only made us feel special they were so beyond professional and they thought of everything we could have ever asked for. An amazing hotel. It is not cheap but if it is in your budget I would suggest the mandarin over any other in its class. It was something to remember and we will def be back. The lobby, last but not least was stunning and everywhere you walked you felt safe, comfortable and enjoyed every minute!

Where do I start - perhaps at the sky lobby, located high above the bustling streets, and overlooking the expanse of the city - did I mention the view of Mt. Fuji on clear days?? Then theres the rooms - virtually ballrooms by Japanese standards, the rooms are huge, and hugely comfortable. Ours overlooked the Tokyo tower among other highlights. Then theres the selection of restaurants - so sublime. And I haven't even started with the spa (worth the splurge) or the amenities or the sky high levels of service... totally AMAZING!
user_name:
shinyshy
New York City, New York

review_body: I am not sure where to start... It was absolutely amazing in every single details.We went there for our honeymoon. We spent there 4 days and trust me, it was not enough, could have stayed there weeks.The service is one of the best I had in my life. Every single person we spoke to or cross in the hotel, knew it was our honeymoon and had a kind world, knew what we did the day and ask kindly if we enjoyed it. So many little attentions... That I cannot write them all. The spa is to die for. This is actually the best sauna I've done in my life. why ? So spacious, with an 160degree view of tokyo that make it so spacious, and catch your eyes that even after 15 min, you forget you need to get out!Their massages are amazing with beautiful treatment room with views on tokyo.The gym is very good, everything you need. Their fresh detox juices are a must.Then, the restaurant, 2 recommendations: DO NOT MISS for any REASONS, the Tapas Molecular Bar, and book it a lot in advance. The experience is magical, won't tell you anything about it, better if it's a surprise but dont miss it. We were very touched at the end as the chef did something special for our honeymoon that of course he knew! The other restaurant YOU HAVE TO GO, is their pizzeria, We didnt want to eat anything else than japanese, we wanted only japanese food during our trip, but one of friend really insisted that we go. So the last day, before going to the airport, we booked the bar counter of their Pizza restaurant... and OMG, you cannot miss that. That was the best pizzas ever, even better than in Napoli! Order the truffle one, so good : )Mandarin Bar is another must, every night we finished there until 2.00am, jazz music with live musiciens every night that are all always very good. The responsable of the bar is so kind and careful with everything. They even offer us some drinks for our honeymoon the last night.This hotel is just so perfect and so details oriented, it makes it a wonderful and unforgettable experience.

It's a truly beautiful place. Service,restaurants,rooms everything is impeccable. The Italian restaurant is fabulous. We were on a tour of Japan and finished off here. Really missing pizzas and pastas, and this was the best place to have. Hiroyuki Shioji and Yuka Sankoda really made the dining all more enjoyable. Both of them went out of their way to cater for us the perfect dinner. Thank you Kai Jansen for your help with wooden plates and showing around the most expensive fruits. ( we really enjoyed the grapes). On the whole it's an amazing hotel with the best service. The only thing is they don't provide complementary wifi in the hotel and the use of the spa for the hotel guests is for very restricted time only. We have stayed in many of the Mandarin Orientals worldwide and none of them have it like this. In Japan wifi is free at most of the places. But to conclude we are really glad that we stayed here. Couldn't have had it better anywhere else.

Very cozy and nice hotel with gentle staff. Third time we stayed here..Very good location, spacious room and perfect service.Had a very nice and pleasant stay all in all..Hope to come back!Thanksvery positive!! I would recommend to my friends and colleagues

Upon arrival, we were greeted at the ground floor and escorted to the 38th-floor lobby. The staffer had already put the form with my name on the counter when I got there, which was a pleasant surprise. The kids got toys as gifts. They were able to put a rollaway bed in the room, even though I was emailed this was not possible upon booking. The staffer efficiently made a reservation for us in one of the on-site Michelin-starred restaurants. The room was very clean and modern. The drapes have remote control. It could have been better if there was tablet control. The complementary blend tea was very tasty. In-room dining was fast and world class.The bathtub could be too deep for toddlers when water is fully filled. When my two-year-old sat down, water was above her forehead.

Beautiful hotel with impeccable service. The staff were incredibly responsive on e-mail in the lead-up to our stay, helping to make all of our restaurant reservations and offering alternatives when bookings weren't possible, and accommodated us making two shorter reservations in the middle of sakura season (during which time there is a longer minimum stay requirement) so that we could spend two nights in Hakone and Kyoto. We received just as much care and attention from our arrival, with the concierge even noting my husband's birthday from our check-in details and having cake sent to our room.My only hesitancy in re-booking would be the location, we found ourselves to be much more enamored with the vibrant Shibuya and Shimokitazawa districts, which were a fair distance away to travel each day. Nihonbashi in which the hotel is located is purely a business district and did feel a a little lifeless in the evenings, even in spite of its close proximity to Ginza.That being said, the hotel itself cannot be faulted - a 5* experience and then some! Anyway, who needs bars and restaurants down the street when the ones in your hotel are already the best in the city?

It is one of the best bars in the Tokyo, with a pleasant ambiance and good coctails. The personnel was very kind and it is open till 2 am. By the way I belive it was the bar that all American celebrities love to visit at their Tokyo trips.

Super friendly staff, great location, spacious room & excellent food, specially breakfast!! great buffet with many options of food and the service is just great, they make you feel like in home!, I would definitely will come back!

Loved this hotel! The staff was amazing! The rooms are incredible, service is impeccable! The view is incredible! Especially in winter u get to see mt. Fuji! They have a gym. And spa which is lively, u fortunately even as a hotel guest you have to pay to visit it! Found that quite strange. As well as the wifi! Always wonders me in hotels like those, when u have to pay the 10€ on top the 500€ for the Internet. But it didn't smear my impression of the hotel. The consierge is amazing too!

Fabulous hotel. Good location, first class service. We had breakfast and everything were tasty. The hotel is very near (ca. 100 m) to a nice and big shopping mall. Around the hotel are many good restaurant. The concierge were very attentive to all our needs and booked all nice restaurant we visited. We will stay at the hotel if we visit Tokyo next time.

Simply put: my wife and I travel quite a bit for business and for vacation -- and the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is the best place we have ever stayedWhere to even start:- The rooms are extremely well-appointed, clean, and have great views- Service, from the valet staff to the concierge, is friendly, helpful but not intrusive -- the perfect balance- The bar has great cocktails, whiskey and wine lists, and an awesome bar food menu (try "Le Burger")- We didn't have a chance to try the restaurants at the hotel -- because the concierge had nailed every one of the dining reservations we were hoping to getJust an awesome, awesome stay -- and we were really sorry to go!

Rooms are spacious, elegant, and high tech. And the views from our floor to ceiling window were a high point. The facilities are excellent in a superb location and impeccable service.  It's nestled in a quiet area with many traditional shops restaurants and lots of shopping; close to tokyo station which made it convenient to go places.Service, as expected is incredibly good. Restaurants we opted to tasting the best Tokio had to offer so I can't really say much about them.Rooms are very comfortable with a Japanese touch that make them different.

The Hotel is excellent, very good attention to details , even the very personnal one. spa was a great experience, the facitlity, therapist nothing to complain about.I was there for a conference, even the event facility , the catering was so good.
user_location: Emirate of Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates
user_name:
Ikram0408
Emirate of Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: Excellent facilities, superb location and impeccable service. The entire staff made us feel at home and went above and beyond to make our stay enjoyable. For example, we wanted to have lunch at a local restaurant nearby and since we did not speak Japanese, Maria at the front desk personally took us to the restauranr and ordered for us in Japanese. This is what I call first class service!!

I have booked in this hotel this Summer to stay for more than a month and the staff therealmost spoiled our summer vacation for me and my family.As I have booked a Suite with a connected Bedroom plus another Room. everything was right as I have made my reservation few months earlier, until I called to reconfirm my booking and make Airporttransportation arrangement, I found that my Booking was canceled for no reason.They used excuses which I did not believe! Like I have not confirmed my reservation, which was not true. I have given my CreditCard details and all what they asked for. They made a mistake and they tried to solve it by promising me that they will try to find me another options, but they didn't comeback even though I called many times.Thanks for Ritz Carlton Tokyo, I have found Better Hotel.I have stayed before at other Mandarin Hotels include Mandarin Oriental NY last year formore than 15 days, But I have never had this bad experience as the one in Tokyo. Ifyou want My advice!stay away and find another Hotel as they might use another excuse to cancel you reservation.RitzCarlton and Hilton are good option.

It's a wonderful hotel under every aspect. The service level is unbelievable. The staff is always present and they are so caring that you end up surprise every time by the level of kindness they have. The hotel structure is also amazing. Rooms are huge and have a wonderful view with floor to ceiling windows. They are furnished with any thing you might need. You have something like 6 resturants and two bars. I have tried only the sushi one and was and amazing tasting experience. I will definitely recommend this as a place to stay in Tokyo.

This is possibly the best hotel we ever stayed at! We had a long flight from India and a decent ride to hotel in their chauffeur driven car, from the moment we arrived in hotel, we were surrounded by sincere and welcoming warmth,we did not expect the level of service that was beyond anything we have ever experienced in any other hotel of this class. We stayed for 2 nights. being vegetarian the staff knew our preferences and made us feel like visiting royalty. The concierge staff were remarkable -The Spa is THE BEST I have ever been to - with floor to ceiling views of Tokyo from the 37th floor. why would you ever consider staying anywhere else???

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo did not disappoint. I spent a week at the hotel in August and was made to feel like I was a very special guest.. The level of service, attention to detail, and professionalism was spectacular. The concierge staff answered every question I had with detail and made many reservations for me during my stay. They were wonderful! This hotel will be my first choice when visiting Tokyo in the future. It was all so amazing, I did not want to leave!

I stayed 5 nights at Mandarin Tokyo and I do recommend! Everything from service, decoration, technology, food...everything amazing! They took care of me, and I felt very happy with everything! If in Tokyo, please choose Mandarin!!

We arrived at the hotel around lunch, four hours early for our reservation. For those unfamiliar with Japan, it's all about punctuality. They were extremely apologetic about the room not being ready when we got there which was our fault for getting there so early in the first place. And were also extremely apologetic when it turned out there were no tables available in any of the hotel restaurants for lunch, which was again not their fault. They set us up with a young intern, local to Tokyo, who recommended a delicious yakitori restaurant across the street, and even when so far as to lead us to the restaurant and order our food for us. When we got to our rooms their was a good sized box of complimentary sweats from the hotel pastry shop, waiting for us, with a note once again apologizing for the room not being ready when we got there. Other than that the rooms we spacious, elegant, and high tech. And the views from our floor to ceiling window were defiantly a high point. Perhaps I'm too accustomed to the American version of hospitality, but this place was amazing.

Perfect stay in Tokyo. Service was without fault. I will definitely return. Great location near the Financial district and for getting to tourist sites.My only suggestion would be to make a bigger fitness center with room for more weight machines - the basics are covered and there are free weights but limited.

2nd stay with MO, enjoyed the location, good size room and bathroom, with magnificent view, quiet area with many traditional shops restaurants and shopping. closed by to tokyo station which made it convenient to go places.i was surprised with the room services, usually did not expect much, i ordered three times, they were all good food. also visited their restaurants, the wagyu beef burger was excellent and the french fries, it was a bargain with 3900 yen. my partner had the lasagna and tasted much better than lasagna we had before. sushi sora was good and flesh, tasty especially the sea urchin. the special green tea tasted so good, the chef was friendly, I called him king chef. and the lady was very helpful gave us direction to visit some historic stores and extremely MO cafe downstairs also had good pastries, the curry bread and blue cheese bread and sweet pastries were yum yum. We sat there almost every morning to eat before we explored to other places. We even brought some to airport during our departure day. also a fruit store across in the same building carried very high quality and tasty fruit. it is a very good hotel to stay, i got a good deal this time, so totally worth every penny of it. sure you will enjoy if MO is your next choice.

We live in Tokyo. And for a sort of a summer holiday, we stayed here as we did last year. We liked this hotel very much last year as the room has higher ceiling, clean and very quiet, and we could feel as if we were in a resort hotel. Such wonderful characters of the hotel have not changed this year as well. For dinner, we tried the Chinese restaurant, which was really good and much better than the French and the Tapas restaurants. One dissapointment is that the package included a buffet breakfast, and it couldn't be replaced with a Japanese in-room dining breakfast. As the superior quality of this hotel is the tranquility and serenity of the guest rooms, we prefer to stay longer in the rooms especially for breakfast.

I stayed at this hotel about 3 times before in the first two years it opened. While the physical plant is beautiful, service back then was wanting. I am happy to say that is no longer the case and service is now excellent, making this our new favorite. The location has also improved since they developed a couple of buildings across the street that offer a huge selections of restaurants and shops. This hotel also has the best work out room in the city if not the world. Really large for Asia and the view is incredible. Their spa is also top notch. We used to love the Penninsula but since the last GM retired, service wise, things have really deteriorated. This is a very glamourous property and not as kid friendly from a physical plant perspective but very from a service standpoint. Comfortable rooms but the bathroom design may be off putting to some.

I usually stay at the Peninsula but it was full so we stayed here instead. Will give comparison on the two hotels below after my review of the MO Tokyo:Pros:- Really great service, the concierge, front desk, reception were all very friendly and helpful. One of the best services I have experienced.- Great view of Tokyo skyline- Next to Mitsukoshi department storeCons:- Bathroom is a bit small- Did not like the fact that we had to first go up to the lobby then change elevator to go down to the roomsComparison with Peninsula Tokyo:Mandarin wins in service and view.Peninsula wins in room size and decor, and location proximity to Ginza.

I booked Mandarin on my first trip to Tokyo and the hotel is unbelievably gorgeous, on another level. We were treated exceptionally well with perfect attention to detail and made to feel at home. Thank you to the manager for our upgrade in room as well. The food was amazing spectacular, our room was modern and huge with gorgeous views. If I could go back I would in a heartbeat.

Mandarin Oriental is not by far the cheapest hotel you can find in Tokyo, but it's a really good stay if you want a totally hassle-free stay. You are within just a few minutes walking distance from Tokyo station, where the bullet trains stop. The service is excellent without being too attentive or intrusive. The rooms are spotless and relatively large by Asian standards. My room had an almost spa-like bathroom with separate shower and a huge bathtub. I really love the breakfast, where you have a huge selection of both western and Japanese style food. The only minor complaint I have is that the French style restaurant is not 100%, but that's something they share with most western style restaurants I've visited in Tokyo. I would have much preferred if it was a Japanese restaurant. But OTOH, there's an excellent Sushi restaurant just across the street.If you're not used to Japanese hotels it might be a bit confusing that the hotel lobby is not located on the ground floor. So upon arrival you take the elevator to the lobby and then there are separate elevators to move around in the hotel.As part of an international chain, the Mandarin can feel a bit sterile - If it wasn't for the staff it could even be difficult to realize you are in Japan. You have to decide if this is a good thing or a bad thing.

We recently stayed at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Tokyo for 5 nights. The room was very nice, with floor to ceiling windows, nicely decorated, and affording a terrific view from the 35th floor. The shower was a highlight with an open layout with relaxing decor and a rain shower function. The 38th floor reception area is beautiful and dramatic and is accompanied by two wonderful bars on the 37th floor. As a person that usually stays in 5 star hotels, I was very impressed with this hotel in many, many ways. The location was perfect for us as it is literally at one of the subway stops (Mitsukoshimae-next door to the the all-purpose/fun to visit department store Mitsukoski) on the "orange line" that can easily connect you to Shibuya (also a short taxi ride to Ebisu), Ginza, Ueno, and Asakusa-all super interesting places to visit. The highlight of this hotel is the service. The check-in was fantastic. The concierge service was amazing and extremely helpful. We did not take any tour and explored Tokyo on our own and had a great time. We worked with many of the concierges, but Tomoya Mori was one of the best I have every worked with-great job Tomoya! The breakfast was amazing and thanks to the over the top service by the breakfast manager, Niccolo Brachelente-our visit was very special indeed. Niccolo treated us like royalty and we really appreciated his attentiveness and 6 star service. He introduced us to the Mandarin Oriental lychee tea-delicious. I cannot say enough about Niccolo and his staff-great job Niccolo!I highly recommend the Mandarin Oriental and after reading the other Trip Advisor reviews, it seems that my experience was not just good luck.

I love mandarin oranges, but I love this mandarin even more. To start with, the level of service in Japan, is a cut above anything else in the World, but even within Japan, this is a cut above the extraordinary. From greeting to departure, the level of non-intrusive warmth and hospitality is impressive. Management is outstanding. Note, that in the corner rooms, which are for the most part suites, you may hear some traffic sound, while the in line rooms are quiet. As well, the location is business centred. The restaurants that we experienced, including the Molecular tapas bar, are wonderful.

This is our second stay at the Mandarin Tokyo in 8 years. My only nit to pick is that the decor is getting slightly worn, but it is still very clean. The spa was brilliant, and we were treated like kings for the duration of our stay. Also love the convenience of a Metro stop under the hotel and a luxury department store next door. Will definitely return1

This has to be one of the best hotels I have ever stayed at. The hotel is clean, quiet, and the service is impeccable. The rooms are warm, beautifully appointed, the bathrooms are luxurious, the beds and bedding so comfortable, and the views spectacular. The staff tries to accomodate you in every way possible. For example, I left a an empty waterbottle next to the bed. The next day, I had a fresh waterbottle, and a clean glass on a coaster next to the bed. Every evening you find fresh fruit in your room. The suites are huge and feel like a home. The food in the restaurant is delicious. Views from the restaurant are amazing as well. I would stay at this hotel for business or for pleasure. The location is also perfect. Overall, a true luxury hotel. Highly recommended.

I have been very fortunate to book this hotel after the new year. Our room was very spacious, clean and very comfortable. We had the glass window overlook to the stunning view of the city where you mind and soul are placed in different planet. This is best hotel in the world from my opinion, I will definitely come back during my next trip probably in Dec.

I have been to this luxurious and amazing hotel with my family for 6 visits now. There is absolutely no flaw in this wonderful place. I love every aspect of the beautiful hotel from rooms to the high quality service you could expect from a Mandarin Oriental property.

We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental at the end of a Tauck tour. Located at the top of an office building, the hotel does not have a grand presence or especially impressive lobby. The elevator situation is confusing as you have to go up to the lobby and down to the room. The rooms are very nice but not spectacular. The food pretty good. So why the five star review? The staff at the front desk is beyond amazing. I had left my camera charger at a previous hotel on the tour. The tour director tried to find it and couldn't. One of the young ladies took pictures of my camera and the battery, looked it up on the internet , ordered it from the best camera store in the city and had it delivered to my room! We wanted to buy authentic baseball caps of the Tokyo Giants. They called the stadium to make sure the store was open and they had what we wanted. We had trouble printing our airline tickets to go home. They completely took it over and with a smile did it for us. I wish I could take them home. The Italian restaurant is good and reasonable. The breakfast buffet is a hoot with red yolk eggs. The location of the hotel is excellent with walkable departments stores on all sides.
user_name:
travelartist0
New York City, New York

review_body: Of course MO is a destination brand wherever they operate. And their management is nearly flawless. This hotel is becoming slightly dated and I was surprised to see any wear marks on room furnishings (usually their rooms always look totally spotless). That said, no complaints, nice breakfast and really good room service food. After a previous stay at the Peninsula Tokyo, this would be my number 2 choice. Haven't tried Four Seasons yet.

I went back and forth on whether to stay at the Mandarin or the Park Hyatt for our recent visit to Tokyo. I was very glad I choose the Mandarin. The service far exceeded my expectations. We were picked up at the airport with their car and immediately met when we arrived. Check-in was in the actual room which is so nice. We were even there quite early and they had everything ready for us. We had an amazing view of the Skytree. The room was perfect.Everyone makes a point to know your name at this hotel. They will run ahead and press the elevator button, ask you if you need anything and take care of your every need. The restaurants and bar were amazing. We had lunch in their Japanese restaurant and dinner at the Tapas restaurant. The bar scene was lively and fun.I was worried about the location of this hotel, but my fears were eased when we could easily get on the metro/subway in the basement of the hotel building.
