When we arrived we just sat on the sofa for almost half an hour taking it in.Restaurant for breakfast was super – I don’t think you could wish for anything else (get the pancakes). We also ate in Sense, which was above par and came away feeling like we’d never need to eat again. The bar environment is lovely, although you do have to get in early to get the good seats!We also were married in our suite with help from the MO wedding team. Delightful and helpful throughout, we couldn’t have wished for a greater day.

I felt so relaxed and historical elegance.I was deaply impressd by all essence of Mandarin Oriental Tokyo.Memory of extreme Tokyo city view from my room is unforgettable.The hotel has atomosphere of historical elegance and luxury, but all service staff were so kind and friendly.

Overall excellent stay and service from the staff, especially the concierge. Location is good for business and I guess you could say sightseeing as well. Outside the immediate the is not much to go if you want to go out for a late night stroll, but it is only 2 stops from Ginza, 3 stops to Akihabara and 1 stop to Tokyo Station, you could actually walk there in about 10-15 mins.I was somewhat disappointed with the room, I felt like it was lacking something give it the wow factor of a 5 star hotel. The bed is pretty firm and after the first night I woke up with an aching back. I asked them if they could do something to make a little softer and at first they weren't sure if they could do that, but when I got back my room they left a note apologizing about the bed and put some extra padding on it and the rest of the stay was able to get a goodnights rest! On plus side room had floor to ceiling windows with a nice view of Tokyo Skytree and night could see the city lights and get a feel of how big Tokyo is. Was torn with giving a 4 or 5 star rating as rooms were somewhat underwhelming, but service made up for it.

The hotel is more geared for business travelers, nonetheless, my wife and I had a great stay there while we were in Tokyo for pleasure earlier in the month. The services were good, the quality of the food and the presentation in the French restaurant were much to our liking, and we also enjoyed the facilities at the spa.The night view of the city skyline from the room was beautiful. However, the amenities in the room were somehow inadequate, no coffee capsules were available, and there was no free in-room wifi which is offered by many 5-star properties in the world nowadays. We also noticed heavy cigarette smell through out the reception floor, it should perhaps be eliminated for the sake of international visitors.

Simply put the hotel and it's staff are the finest in the woorld. There is no comparison to any other hotel in Tokyo. This hotel makes the Ritz look like a glamour horror and the area is traditional Japanese with an extremely refined character.
user_name:
drjleeand
New York City, New York

review_body: The Mandarine Oriental in Tokyo is by far one of my favourite hotels in the world. Brilliantly located in central Tokyo it is easy to get to from the subway, and only a short hop to Tokyo Main Train Station. The room I experienced was exceptionally well designed with floor to ceiling views of gorgeous Tokyo. The bathroom was thoughtfully designed with a wonderful shower and bathtub. There was even a vanity mirror for the ladies that was a whole desk sit down area enabling for a comfortable self beauty session. As one would expect, the bed was comfortable, but the robes and slippers were even better. I ended up getting a robe from the business centre, and keeping the slippers to continue the fond memories of the hotel at home. Sushi Sora was probably one of the best sushi experiences I have encountered. Using of course only the freshest fish from the Tokyo Fish Market, our sushi chef prepared beautiful dishes. It was also the best uni I have ever tasted! Not surprising since it was rated number one in quality from the market. Staff are what one would expect from a Japanese top hotel, attentive to every detail, and seeking perfection. Well worth the price, and will always be my first hotel of choice for Tokyo.

Stayed at Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo on my recent trip. Initially, the concierge screw up my restaurants reservations, but they manage to amend the mistakes. Great location and the service was impeccable. House keeping does a great job in keeping 'my' room spotless and clean !!!!The only downside is that the room lacks of personality compared to other 5 stars or equal standards. Besides, the concierge needs to be more proactive and attentive when replying emails from guest.

Spent four days/ three nights at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo with my Husband. We always love the Mandarin brand and this is probably one of the best mandarin we have ever stayed at. We booked the Mandarin Grand Room which was very big especially in Tokyo standard. The room had a nice walk-in closet which was great for luggage and shopping. Service was top-notched with hand-written greeting card, delicious welcome tea, extremely helpful concreige. They even put nicely blended essence oil next to the bed which made the room smelled really nice & relaxing. Location is excellent. It has a subway station right underneath the hotel building. Department store right next store and shopping centres right opposite. It's only about 10 minutes taxi ride from the heart of Ginza. Breakfast was very good. Although not with the most choices I have seen, but they were all fine goods with choices of organic items and all. We had dinner at Tapps Molecular Bar. Amazing experience and it was just fun with delicious food. We also had lunch right before we left at Sushi Sora, again very good sushi with beautiful view. If you are looking for a luxury 5-star hotel in Tokyo, you will not be disappointed at Mandarin. We would definitely stay there again if we visit Tokyo next.

Not only the overall facilities are with high standard, the team's service is excellent, their service are cozy and warm that is more than you expect.Highly recommend to experience the Japanese restaurant.

We stayed at The Mandarin Oriental on our way home from skiing in Niseko. The hotel is beautiful and the service from all staff second to none. The breakfast buffet is one of the best I have eaten at. Could not fault this hotel on anything. The views from the rooms are breathtaking and the amenities all Bottega Veneta.

good quality, good location, excellent servicerooms are spacious and well decorated, the view is niceI especially enjoyed the bar. Friendly service, good live music, and smokers are welcome too:). The only handicap: One needs to switch lifts at lobby level in order to access the room or exit from the building

From the cleanliness and the functionality of the rooms, to the quality of the services, this is probably the best urban hotel in Tokyo and probably in the world.The views are incredible from everywhere: the rooms, the spa, the gym, the restaurant.This is the only place I want to stay in Tokyo.

Great location. Next door to train station & dept store and just a 15/20 minutes walk to Takashimaya and Ginza. The room was big and I can see Tokyo Sky Tree from my room. Service was exceptional. And the dinner in the chinese restaurant was simply amazing. I will definitely be back.

Late review but our family stayed at the MO in Sept at the end of our trip in Japan.Shinkansen from Osaka put us in the Tokyo station where we took a quick taxi ride to the hotel. The hotel is on top of an office building with a side entrance. Our bags were immediately taken and we were shown to the elevators that took us up to the lobby.Entering the lobby, we were impressed by the staff who welcomed us. Check-in was quick and we took another elevator down to our room (card key needed which I find a pain fumbling for my card). We had 2 twin beds with a view of Tokyo Skytree. The room was quite spacious and a fresh fruit plate welcomed us. We did find a lack of drawer space for our stuff (after 3 weeks of traveling in Asia, we had lots of stuff). Wifi was free as part of our rate and was consistent throughout our stay. The location of the hotel is excellent. Business area so quiet at night. Lots of shopping close by with Mitsukoshi next door (we picked up plenty of food gifts), Takashimaya and Tokyo train station all in walking distance. The building has a food court in the basement which was quite crowded during lunch time and is connected to the Ginza and Hanzomon subway lines. Taxis were abundant at the hotel but the subway in Tokyo was really efficient to get around the city.We used the gym while we were at the hotel which is tiny. Equipment was nearly on top of each other. There was no floor area to stretch. Disappointed in this area.We did not eat at the restaurants but did have the breakfast at the hotel every morning. What surprised me was the need to wait for a table on two of our days at K'shiki. They actually asked us to sit in the Oriental Lounge (which serves a quick Continental breakfast) and wait. Overall the buffet was good and service was good. We had asked the concierge for help prior to our trip to Japan. I was surprised at how slow responses were and how they misread some of my questions. I asked for information on N'ex to NRT in an email as I had an early flight and wanted to plan ahead. They sent me a response on Transportation options from Narita to the hotel several days later. They also mixed up a restaurant for me offering me a lunch slot when the restaurant is only open for dinner. Every email response required a few days for a response. I'm not sure if they are overwhelmed or prioritize based on requests that are closer. Check-out in the morning was fine with the bill correct. Bell boys helped gather our luggage and put us in a taxi to Tokyo station for our N'ex connection to the airport.Overall, I enjoyed the hotel but of course remember the negatives. I love the MO and this was my 4th MO in 2015. Considering my stays in Osaka and Kyoto were better and Tokyo has several wonderful hotels, I'd probably shop around next time.
user_name:
johnathome
New York City, New York

review_body: Rooms are amazing with a great view. City center, walking to shopping and if you came for business, it's in the financial district. Near Ginza, if you came for serious shopping. Service is tops. Very attentive to clients needs and very personal. They even remember your name.

The service provided by Mandarin Oriental was very personalised and fantastic. The rooms were spacious and luxurious. The hotel does not have a swimming pool but they have an excellent jacuzzi similar to that of the onsen that overlooks Tokyo city and an excellent gym with state-of-the-art gym equipment and facilities, topped with excellent juices and beverages to finalise the gym session. Highly recommended!! Definitely will stay here again!!

This is a review about a hotel (and a company) that "gets it" and one that does not. For the past ten years we have been visiting Japan at least once a year. Prior to this year, we stayed at the Peninsula for 6 or 7 consecutive years. Every summer, very large suite, no less than 8 days total. Absolutely no complaints about the room, the location - all wonderful. But every year we visit, we are treated like total strangers. Total. No "welcome back", no "nice to see you again", no special welcome for our young daughter who has spent 7 of her 9 years of life visiting that hotel, no nothing at all. And every year it has kind of bugged me - after all, we spend a lot of money and have been very loyal customers. (I get that this is what you might call a first world issue and I do not pretend that any of this matters in the scheme of things). This past summer the hotel was booked up so we were "forced" to stay at the Mandarin Oriental. We only stayed three days because we were off to somewhere else in Japan. Everything superlative. SU-PER-LA-TIVE. And believe me, that is not a word you get to use too often these days. This morning we received a thick envelope covered in Hello Kitty stickers from the Mandarin Oriental. It contained a handwritten note to my daughter from the breakfast manager who remarked how she was looking forward to seeing her again and making her chocolate chip pancakes. It included a lovely MO calendar on which she is doodling on right now. So where do you think we are staying next year?

The suite has an breathtaking view.Mandarin Oriental Tokyo made me fall in love with Tokyo even more.Staff in Japan is always nice and helpful and here they are outstanding.I can not vouch for this hotel enough. This is my favorite hotel In Tokyo.

This is our second stay at this hotel. We chose it again because it is easy for shopping, being right next to the huge department store Mitsukoshi, where we enjoyed looking at the huge basement floor displaying fantastic Japanese food items. There is also a subway station right underneath the hotel, with another huge shopping area (underground) called Nihonbashi. Since we had only 2 days in the city, a central location was critical. The hotel is also just a 10-minute taxi ride (even with traffic) to Tokyo Station, where we caught a bullet train to the countryside. Ginza (with even more night lights around Christmas) is also just 10 minutes away by taxi.The spa is just fabulous. It is on a high floor with a fabulous panoramic city view. There is a huge jacuzzi pool/tub with a clear glass surround where you can see your own reflection in the wall mirror through the clear pool glass. My 18-year old daughter thought it was just so much fun. My daughter and I had a 2-hour couple massage in a corner room with an amazing city view. The price tag was high, but it was just heavenly, especially after a 15-hour flight plus hours of taxi and wait time door-to-door from our home to Tokyo. The rooms were also fabulous with all the amenities and zen beauty. The room size was very large even by American standard.We loved the refined buffet breakfast with huge assortments of delicious items. The crab egg benedict with the orange color egg yoke (due to special foods fed to the chicken producing the eggs) was tasty and interesting. We also tried the a la carte breakfast in another dining room, and the service was amazing. We had dinner one night at the 8-person Sushi Sora (again with an amazing view and lovely zen environment) and another night at the tapas molecular bar (also for 8 persons only). The taps bar was creative, fun, and delicious.Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo is like a mini resort within just one building in the heart of Tokyo. For a short trip where we wanted to fit in lots of activities and fine dining, it was simply superb in every way.

I stayed at this fine hotel in Dec 2015 for 2 nights, after having spent 3 previous nights at Park Hyatt Tokyo.Commendable points: 1. Hotel location - Convenient despite being in the quieter side of town, but Mitsukoshimae Metro station is just underground, and Tokyo station is just a pleasant 10 min walk away. There are many high end shopping complexes around MO.2. Hotel grounds and room -The lobby is located on the 38th floor with a commanding view of Tokyo. On one side, you can see the Tokyo Skytree, while on the other, Mount Fuji (on a clear day). Rooms are well-sized and the design is modern with a touch of Orientalism. The shower room has a bathtub and 3 choices of shower heads to choose from. Toiletries are from Bottega Veneta. 3. Service - Outstanding service from check-in to check-out. A staff introduced the room and hotel amenities upon check-in with a welcome bottle of Oriental tea. Turn down service came with a set of yukata and aromatherapy oil. 4. Breakfast - Breakfast could be enjoyed at either K'Shiki allday dining restaurant or Oriental Lounge. We had it at the former which had a good spread for its continental breakfast. The quality of food was good. The could be improved points:1. Hotel gym -I am an avid gym goer so the gym was too small and had limited equipment for a decent weight training session. However, free beverages like juices and Pokka Sweat, and biscuits were available. 2. Wifi -My biggest grouse would be that Wifi was not free. In all, MO Tokyo was still a great stay and I would recommend it over Park Hyatt on the other side of the city. I will surely come back again!

Having stayed in luxury hotel worldwide including other Mandarin Oriental hotels, we can truly say that we have never had better service. Somehow the staff manages to be both warm and professional. One always feels that one is welcome. At the same time the staff is very efficient. Added to this is the fact that the hotel has, to our taste, truly elegant Japanese design in the rooms and the public spaces. And the hotel rooms are large and comfortable. One doesn't need to go up Tokyo Tower nor Skytree as the views from the hotel are panoramic. The Chinese and Sushi restaurants would be star quality as stand alone restaurants; therefore it was doubly nice to have them in-house. We did not have a chance to eat in the French restaurant and so cannot speak to it, Breakfast in K'shiki is delightful and it turns out that the restaurant does pasta in the truly Italian manner. If you like your lasagna with béchamel rather than tomato sauce, order it here. The hotel is centrally located and having a subway station in the basement means that getting around Tokyo was easy.
user_name:
levity
Washington Dc, District Of Columbia

review_body: We had the most fabulous 3 night stay here. We booked through Grand Luxury and were so well looked after by Maria in guest services. We were traveling to Sydney, then back to Tokyo and Kyoto via bullet train, then back to Tokyo, and Maria could not have been more helpful in providing advice and making arrangements for us including taxis, train tickets, etc. We enjoyed all aspects of this lovely hotel including incredible buffet breakfast, room service breakfast, fitness centre, spa and cocktails and light food in the bar area. Our room accommodation was extremely comfortable and well appointed, and we had a direct view of Mt Fuji. Can't say enough great things about this hotel, the service and especially Maria. Recommend very highly!

We had a very excellent and pleasureable stay in Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. I am very impressed with Japanese hospitality and customer service. Location is convenient. I am particularly impressed with the concierge service; they are very helpful for all our needs.

We spent 4 nights in this establishment. Other than the concierge, whose service level is inconsistent, we were attended to sincerely and professionally. Special mention goes to Ms Seong Park and Ms P Mui; they were attentive, gracious and very helpful. The elderly housekeeping female staff who took care of Rm 3511 was also wonderfully attentive. We liked the location of the hotel too. The Ginza line is conveniently located right below the hotel. Shopping and food are also readily available (across the road is Coredo with many restaurants and down the road, less than 5 minutes away, is a big mall). The room is generally well appointed although I did not like the bathroom. The sink is too small and the shower area does not have a proper door. We really liked the bed. I slept extremely well because of the mattress. I am particular about these things because I've gotten up in the morning with backaches in other hotels and so really appreciated the comfort. All in all, we are happy with the hotel but I have to say that the concierge is rather disappointing. To be fair, one of the female staff (her name starts with N) was very helpful and went out of her way to get us the information that we needed. The other staff, especially a young gentleman whose name I cannot recall, was frustrating to deal with. We were given a Japanese map (we are foreigners who can't speak or read Japanese), we were told to look for the email address of a cafe on our own, we could not get any information on how to rent an ETC card. The concierge is the main reason I gave this hotel 4 stars out of five. We had a corporate rate so we had good value for money, but if we had to pay the published board rate, the level of service rendered by the concierge would really annoy me.

So the hotel was nice & since we opted for the suite, the room was spacious. Cultural differences made it challenging at times to get what you wanted from concierge. 30 minutes to have them remove erroneous wiifi charges and another 30 minutes to remove breakfast charges. The woman helping us seemed irritated and treated us as if we were trying to get freebies out of her. We wouldn't be staying in a suite if we were these types of people! It was very insulting the way she coldly dismissed us only to have it corrected when we asked fir management. She reminded me of the typical stern & cold personality that is of the old Japan. We were expecting them to be accommodating the way they were in NYC when we had our wedding at the NYC location but was frustrated when they were cold & unwelcoming. They pretty much wanted us to get out upon checking out noted by the way they were surprised that we asked to leave our bags with the bellmen while we had a drink at the bar. I got the feeling that they thought we were rude american tourists. This really made our stay extremely uncomfortable. We are fans of the mandarin but this location definitely soured my affections for the chain.
user_name:
GlobetrekkingFun
New York City, New York

review_body: Wonderful views and classic MO service. The children's slippers, cookies and child-proofing of our room made our stay with a four year old and seven year old a breeze. Their nano-block toy presents on check-in made the children 'fans' of MO at once. Don't miss the mango yoghurt at breakfast, a real hit with our boys. And concierge recommendations were all excellent.

Mandarin Oriental absolutely gave me the best service I've had anywhere, and I commend their staff for their efforts. To be honest, I'm an introvert so found their extreme attentiveness rather annoying, and just wanted to be left alone, but I appreciate their efforts.The quality of the hotel in its entirety is excellent - absolutely loved the bar experience! But I felt ripped off when it came to the room. It's an unfortunate side-effect of staying in one of the most space scarce cities in the world, and they attempt to make up for it with amazing views and quality furnishings and amenities. However, I still cannot reconcile that price with the size of the room and amenities available.Additionally I was underwhelmed by the quality of the breakfast, and the selection. I just wanted a plain egg and toast, but it was a choice of toast, or order the chef to make a lavish breakfast that I had no stomach for.Overall I just can't justify the Tokyo Mandarin's price for what you get, and wish I'd chosen to go to the Hyatt instead.

I can see the sunrise and sunset and concierge team is very good service.concierge team help me to book some restaurants.The skytree view is beautiful and the location is good.and I can get the free wifi when I make the room booking of official website

Excellent views. Excellent food. Excellent service.Very conceintent metro access attached to the hotel. Good shopping close and in Ginza a few stops away. 15 minute walk to either Tokyo Station or the Imperial Palace.

The hotel is located fairly centrally, a short walk to Tokyo station. Check in was a little soulless, but was at least prompt. The lobby has a great view of Tokyo as does the lobby bar.The rooms are great, well appointed and huge. The hotel spa is "free" for hotel guest to use from 6 to 9am(ish)..which is kinda off for the price one pays for a room here... But the spa facilities is pretty awesome. I loved soaking in the onsen and sitting in the sauna looking down into Tokyo below. Concierge is pretty lame, asked for help for dinner reservations but got nothing but babble.

This was my first time at a Mandarin Oriental hotel, so perhaps I had really high expectations. The hotel and service were really good, but with such other good options in Tokyo this was unfortunately not as good as others. I think I prefer the Park Hyatt or the Conrad which were truly excellent. Check-in was a bit slow and the room was not ready when I got there, on top of that, for some reason the girl at the reception was giving me a lot of attitude (which is not something you're expecting after a 12-hour flight, specially in Japan!). When you check-in, they 'offer' you the chance to use the jacuzzi and spa for free from 6:30 to 9am! I never heard of a luxury hotel charging for using their jacuzzi when you're staying with them!The hotel gets really crowded during lunch time and on the weekends, which makes elevators and taxis difficult to come by. The fitness center is rather small for such a hotel. It was empty every time and there's all the machines needed but the room is so small that all the machines are really close to each other. For laundry service, they are supposed to have a special notification system that alerts them when you need them to pick up laundry but it never worked and it took them a while whenever I needed them to pick up my laundry. They also forgot to leave new laundry bags everyday. The concierge service is a hit or miss. Some of them are quite good and they really go out of their way to truly help you, while others are just not up to the standards of a luxury hotel. The first one that 'helped' me seemed a little bit lost, I had to ask for specific places instead of him recommending. And I noticed the same thing happening to several other guests during different times of my stay. On the following day, one of the concierge recommended the biggest rip-off restaurant I've ever been to! And it turned out to be some sort of a deal between the concierge and the restaurant because when we arrived to the restaurant they mentioned we had the 'special price' for clients of the hotel. Next day the concierge kept saying no places were available at night instead of finding solutions for a restaurant that could be open until late; which I knew from my previous stays at the Park Hyatt or the Conrad that while difficult to find in Tokyo, they exist and are quite good. The rooms themselves are actually amazing!!! Good size, perfect decoration; although it can feel a bit stiff. TV is slightly outdated, but that's jus me been picky. As a plus, you have all the toiletries and desk accessories you didn't even know you needed.

This is the best hotel I've stayed at, and possibly the best Mandarin Oriental in the world. The lobby is on the 52nd floor and has sweeping views of Tokyo. The rooms are very large, tastefully decorated and the smallest details looked after. The staff is excellent, friendly, and very attentive. If you want the best hotel experience in Tokyo, there is nowhere else to go.

The location was convenient to Tokyo Station (cab) and the subway station is located under the hotel. Hotel rooms and amenities were as expected for this class of hotel. The fresh fruit plates were a welcome treat. The service is what sets this hotel apart from other five start hotels in Tokyo. My beverage preferences and food allergies were remembered by the staff at each restaurant and bar. When I inquired about the business center, on of the attentive staff members stopped what she was doing and took me to the center herself. On my last few hours before leaving for the airport I inquired at the front desk where I could purchase local uneboshi and the assistance at the front desk again was stellar, even making sure I had a picture to help with my communication. The stay was simply wonderful.

Rooms are large, tastefully appointed, cannot ask for more for amenities. Great Chinese and French restaurants. Lots of selection in the room service menu. Service is excellent. Comes with a price though!! Changing lifts to go up to the room is real pain though.
user_name:
Masaichi H
New York City, New York

review_body: This is probably the beset Mandarin in the group, run to Japanese standards of cleanliness &service. The overall design of the hotel is fantastic and there's a real atmosphere in the bars and restaurants.At the current room rates value is only fair and it's not the greatest location.

Even the room rate is kind of very high, I loved everything here. Free fabulous fruits and tea serve in room, the deluxe room is kind of huge already. Please get up early for spa(warm) pool from 6 - 9 am at 37 floor. Fabulous breakfast with the best Egg Benedict ever. Convenient connected to the Mitsukoshi mae station. Recommended!!!!

Location is perfect for visiting anywhere in Tokyo, 5 mins walk to the metro station. The room was fabulous, incredible clean, large bed with great bathroom. Friendly, thoughtful staff who cared and took great care of costumer. Will return there again.

My third stay here. Location fantastic. Less than 5 minutes from our room to the Ginza line platform. Tokyo station within walking distance, Ginza and Shibuya only few minutes away by Ginza line.Room nice and clean but after 10 years updating is needed; we ve liked Andaz better in terms of size, views, bed, pillows, nespresso coffee machine, complimentary water and juices, the large shower, the deep soaking bathtub..Breakfast, however, stands out from any other hotel in town at Keshiki –service, especially, kudos-. The small but well arranged buffet is everything but standard with many selected Japanese foods like honey, ketchup, artisanal balsamic vinegar and soy sauces. Pastries also outstanding -better than Paris-. Perhaps only cheeses were quite average. Do not miss their delicious eggs benedict: 2 farm eggs on one English muffin with asparagus and king crab, which come with the buffet.A special mention goes to Nicolo, the Italian gentleman overseeing the restaurant, all the times truly outstanding at guiding and directing his few staff when the restaurant is literally overflowing of guests: better to go there before 8 or after 9 30 for a nicer table –but again service is super efficient even at peak times, truly rare in Japan-. They also offer a breakfast menu at the Tapas lounge on the same floor which is not as impressive: eggs benedict with lobster and pancake were nice but service slow and a bit on the slack side that day, we thought.Check out was also busy and it took some time but altogether another great stay. See you again before Christmas.

Stayed here for 2 nights when Noma set up their pop-up restaurant (if you can it that) at Mandrin Orential. The hotel is beautiful and located at a very convenient part of the town. The personalized butler service is great whom gave us a very helpful and thorough walk through of the room amenities. What I loved the most is the motorized black-out shades!

We were two adults, stayed at Mandarin Grand Room for Six nights. Hotel is at an excellent location. Shopping areas and restaurants are within walking distance, in addition to excellent streets to take long walks. At the Basement there is a Tokyo Underground Metro Station and some restaurants. Staff is very friendly and always take initiative to offer assistance. One night I had a headache and a staff member noticed that without me telling her that I was kind of disoriented, she approached me and walked me to my room which was about three floors down. Hotel is very secure, we liked that so much. There are two restaurants that serve breakfast buffets but guests can also ask for item(s) if not included in the buffet. In fact I was impressed with the friendly atmosphere restaurant staff members were demonstrating. Thanks to Raul Levis, Director of Rooms and Takehiro Hosoi, Senior Hotel Assistant Manager, Both demonstrated their care by always asking us about our comments and needs to ensure that our stay would be pleasant and relaxing. Niccolo Brachelente, K’shiki Restaurant Breakfast Manager always took extra steps to serve us in a very professional yet friendly way by following up on us when we were having our breakfast, he would always offer his readiness to have anything prepared for us without us even asking. We will definitely go back to this hotel when we visit Tokyo.

We had a nice stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. The hotel is beautiful and the room was large, new and clean. The bathroom was exceptional, especially the giant tub and the awesome heated toilets. The bed seemed a bit small and the nightstands had a lot of sharp corners (which matters when you are traveling with a 1 year old). I was kind of annoyed by the placement of the lobby and the need to take multiple elevators everywhere.Our experience was a bit mixed because we felt the service was mixed. Two of the staff members were exceptional and really went out of their way to help us when we had questions or requests (unfortunately I lost the paper where I wrote down their names). One porter even walked us all the way to the subway and helped us to buy our tickets. But I was pretty disappointed in the concierge on more than one occasion. One person really could not speak English (and I don't think I'm being a whiny American when I am traveling to a luxury hotel in a major metropolis and the person I am speaking to is in a role that means he or she needs to interact mainly with tourists and out-of-towners), one person had no clue how to give us directions to the Tsukiji Fish Market (a nearby, major attraction) and the last person recommended a very smoky (not to mention far away) restaurant to us for our dinner reservation when she knew we were bringing a baby.The quality of the room service food was amazing but we did need to wait an insane amount of time (nearly 2 hours) when ordering at dinnertime on a Sunday.I think this hotel is more geared toward business travelers - I would return on business but perhaps not on a leisure trip.
user_name:
guest81256
New York City, New York

review_body: Now this must certainly be one of the few perfect hotels of the world...Rooms, location, ambiance and atmosphere, but above all food, restaurants and service are peerless.If it had a pool, it would be paradise...

We came from Kyoto by Shinkansen bullet train, took a taxi at Tokyo station, he left us in the right entrance of the hotel.The location is great for shopping (if you're looking for quality) - right across the street from Mitsukoshi and Coredo buildings. Also very close to Tokyo station and good access to metro/subway system. and you can go to everywhere.We had a beautiful room on the 34th floor, with a great view of Mount Fuji and was visible on clear day !!Electronic controls for lights, blinds, and curtains !! Bedding linens and pillows were so comfortable!!I heard no internal or external noise, I think is almost impossible hear any at 34th floor !!!!!The best staff of any hotel that we have ever experienced. Every staff member wants to help you in any way possible !!Concierge helped us with our train travel to Hakone/Mt Fuji with maps and a good orientation about all the sightseeing!!!They was also happy to help you with directions in busy Tokyo !!!We booked the bed-and-breakfast package, I always enjoy the breakfast time, Mr. Niccolo Brachelente was perfect, thoughtful, gentle, attentive to every detail, he try to looking after everything and everyone, even when we were !!!!The bell desk is fantastic, there was a man (sorry I don't remember his name) he was so happy when he saw us every time, making us happy to see him too!!!Everyone remembered my name, and always asking about my day, if I had fun !!Do not miss the eclair at gourmet shop by MO on street level !!!The only imperfection for me is that I can smell the smoke at check-in floor (38 floor), which made me a little uncomfortable. It is part of Japanese culture-smoking environments such as bars and restaurants.The Mandarin is, without a doubt, the best Western-style hotel I've stayed in.

If you are looking for an exceptional experience, Mandarin Oriental is the answer. We stayed for 3 nights at Mandarin Tokyo and the service was amazing from the time we arrived. We tried the restaurants and Bar as well and we were also impressed. for example, the breakfast manager remembered how we like our coffee and prepared it for us on the second day!

I had contacted the concierge a few weeks before my trip and they were able to secure 2 out of my 4 restaurant requests for dinner. One of the restaurants was closed during the timeframe i was visiting. The concierge arranged 3 other restaurant reservations for me and they were top notch as well. in addition they provided suggestions to purchase souvenirs and Japanese sweets. They even showed me pics of the sweets i need to be looking for while at the store. Their maps for restaurant was the most exhaustive i saw- it showed the forms of payment accepted at that restaurant. Since in japan some restaurants;even fine dining; still use cash or add surcharge on credit cards; this was extremely valuable. The room was nice except that i am not a fan of open showers. The shower head at times can be at an angle when you turn on the water and it gets into main room which can be a pain.Breakfast at buffet restaurant & ala-carte restaurant was excellent. You can't beat view of Mt Fuji from restaurant :). I found service at restaurant overwhelming when they would request to bring the milk & cereals you selected to the table but totally appreciated their service when they bought a spoon for me to eat the yogurt i had picked. i had not picked spoon to eat yogurt- the server noticed that and without my mentioning brought it for me. That's service.MO is known for their service and hospitality and this property certainly delivers that.

This is truely a top-knotch hotel. Travelling a lot I would wish other hotels had this level of service and the friendly staff. From you chekc in to you check out your need are looked after and taken care of. The rooms are high quality, clean and spacious. The restaurents and bar are superb, in fact you do not actully need to / want to leave the hotel.

This was our third stay at a Mandarin property, and all three had attitude issues. Pity. This could be a great company, and the Tokyo hard product has so much to work with: nice rooms, fabulous views, excellent breakfasts, and good location. But, that's where the good news stops. Service wise, from housekeeping to front desk, they dropped the ball again and again. I have absolutely no idea why all three locations (Tokyo, Bangkok, and Hong Kong) respond to all interactions with a superior attitude, as if they're doing us a favor by responding to our questions or requests. Plus, I was always waiting in line for assistance even though there were several staff members available, yet the moment my husband walked up they jumped all over him. I'm the one who booked the rooms, I was the one who was paying. Very short sighted regardless of cultural norms. You know, maybe upper management should go spend a week or two at Vana Malsi Resorts in India to learn about true customer service. If I were to base this review strictly on the service team (apart from the restaurant servers who were very good), I would be rating this a one star property. There's so much potential, it's a shame, especially since Tokyo is full of great hotels. Actually, we had outstanding service at the Four Seasons just a few days prior to our stay at Mandarin. Next time, we'll return to the Four Seasons, they've earned our business.

It was a very successful hotel with a great serviceIt was a great view. Service and speediness was good., Strongly recommend and wiil tray to stay again in any other Mandarin if i had a chance.My overall rating of this property is excellent.

I am truly happy that we chose this INCREDIBLE Hotel for our week's stay in Tokyo. Located on top of a bustling Metro Station, adjacent to the signature Mitsukoshi Store and opposite many dining establishments, The Mandarin Oriental should be your 1st choice of Hotel in Tokyo.Right from the minute our taxi arrived at the entrance of the Hotel, every time we left or returned to the Hotel, at literally every turn in the Hotel, we were greeted warmly and treated like royalty. The moment we opened our room on the 1st day of our stay, we were surprised to be greeted with cake slices, chilled Japanese tea and a fruit pizza for our kids (disguised in an actual pizza delivery box)!Even though we stayed in the Hotel's base category room, no compromises were made. The room was spacious- comfortably accommodating myself, my husband, our 2 children (14&9 yrs) and an extra bed! The huge picture windows offered the best views of Tokyo 24/7 (especially the Sky Tree). The more than generous bathroom area with bath tub, rain shower and quality toiletries ensured we were relaxed and refreshed every day. The best part is that housekeeping refreshes your room, twice a day and puts in a lavender essence every evening, to ensure restful slumber.The delicious and varied breakfast buffet we were treated to daily was top notch with smiling servers and tables that offered bird's eye views of the Tokyo Station with high speed Shinkansen trains zooming in and out at frequent intervals! As Tokyo is a city with many interesting aspects, a hotel with good concierge services is a must, to help you plan your day. In the case of this Hotel, I would give the Concierges an A++! There was an instance when we were in a store and my daughter wanted something that was out of stock, I immediately called Mandarin Oriental's Head Lady Concierge who literally within minutes located another store in our vicinity that had the product, reserved it for us and ensured I found the store and managed to pick it up, all in a span of half an hour, directing me the whole while on my cellphone!On the last day of our stay, we celebrated my Birthday. After an enjoyable day in the city, I got the biggest surprise when I returned to our room-the Hotel Staff had covered the walls with streamers and banners. The room's writing desk had hand written greeting cards from them, 4 party hats, candles, matches, 4 plates, 4 cutlery sets and a huge delicious freshly baked cake. What a way to end our stay!But the true icing on the cake was seeing elusive Mount Fuji on the last day of our stay from one of the Lobby's picture windows!We have stayed in many good Hotels during our travels, but for the first time we have experienced an Hotel that made us want to quickly finish with our day in the city, and return to its environs and our comfortable, beautiful room.----Felicia Variava Albert, Managing DirectorPS: A special mention must be made of Sammy Satomi Kashima from the Hotel's Front Desk, do ask for her when you visit. She will ensure you have the best possible stay! I know, I did!!

I stayed here earlier this year with my partner and both he and I loved it. The Interior design of the hotel and rooms was stunning, it really felt luxurious and complimented with skyline views of Tokyo it was something special. The service I cannot fault, I wish I could remember the name of the bell boy, he anticipated our next move and even had sparkling water in the car before departure for the days activities. We stayed here because of Noma and will most certainly be back! amenities and food are fantastic. Love it!

PERFECT : the room is big and beautiful, location is great, the hotel itself is SPLENDID, the staff is like you expect it to be in a 5 stars hotel... everything from the welcome to the goodbye was perfect, will come again anytime !!!

I had one of the most satisfying experience staying in this beautiful and well-managed hotel. It is right above the Metro so this makes it much more convenient than its competitors. The service is impeccable, and their breakfast is wonderful with lots of choices from the east and west. A special thanks to one of their restaurants manager Mr. Niccolo Brachelente whose service is so personal and caring that it is unmatched, even by the high customer service standard that Japan is known for.One little complaint is this hotel charges for wifi service which is now so commonly provided free everywhere, even in small inexpensive hotels.

Everything about our stay at The Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo was perfect. The room, the bed, the bath, room service, Signature restaurant and the view were superb. The staff especially were very gracious and warm and made you feel good to have picked The Mandarin as the place to stay in Tokyo.

First, this is a boutique-y hotel using only 6 floors. We got upgraded to a a suite which was lovely. The room was great and the TV had a nice selection of channels. The breakfast buffet was a true experience especially as my first meal in Japan. It was unbelievably good.Many compared this place or ranked it near the grand Hyatt. I stayed there as well, and the overall feel of the mandarin is heads and shoulders over the grand Hyatt.

This hotel has restaurants and service that has to be experienced to be believed! In the building itself there are world class Michelin restaurants. Tapas Molecular is absolutely amazing in showmanship and taste. Top Sushi at Sushi Sora and Signature the French restaurant is as good as any 3 star in Leon! The concierges are so good at what they do we were teary eyed in the lobby when it was time to depart. Indescribable experience for those that can afford the very best.

Stayed here 3 nights at end of tour. The room was excellent, great size for a major city. Bed and bedding excellent. View of Tokyo from floor to ceiling Windows amazing. Great location. Breakfast buffet very good. Was disappointed with dinner. Was really expecting a gourmet dinner and got a veal cutlet! Even tho this was the last night of tour dinner, it should have been better. I'm sure the Michelin star restaurant was better, had to be.There are little restaurants in basement. Had a quick dinner at one and it was good.

Everything in the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo was excellent! From the moment we step in the lobby we felt very well taken care of. The rooms (incredible views), spa, and restaurants are exceptional. My only criticism would be the no access to free wifi in the rooms and common areas. For the price of this hotel, I would expect wifi access to be complementary!

We spent 7 wonderful days and nights at Mandarin Oriental. Great base for discovering Tokyo. Great location in Central Tokyo with very easy acces to both metro and taxi. We enjoyed the many excellent restaurants at Mandarin Oriental. We had the best sushi ever at Sushi Sora on 38 floor.

Great Hotel, Great services, Great views on the city , excellent breakfast and very good restaurants. Excellent bed and wonderful bathroom on the 32nd floor with an amazing panorama on the city. Room is furnished with great taste adn with everything you may need.

This hotel has great rooms, wonderful restaurants, terrific staff and service and a good location. It is very near to the Nihonbashi bridge, the zero point of measurement in Tokyo. You can walk on the Ginza, shop at Mitsukoshi department store ( visit it just to wander about if not shop) , wander on small side streets. Public transportation-many options. Plenty of restaurants at various price points are nearby. We've stayed at some very nice hotels, and this is the best we've ever been in.

Placed in what could be called a kind of cit center, this hotel ha made a priority with the service. The rooms are big, décoration is nice. Bathtub short but deep as Japanese people are used to. The location is where you found the fish market some times ago. You have typical restaurants around.For a professional stay of two nights it has been really perfect.

My daughter asked to go somewhere interesting before her junior year started at Stanford, so I suggested Tokyo for a week. So off we went on a new AA 787 in biz class. What a great flight by the way. When we arrived in Tokyo the MO had a limo waiting at Narita which quickly whisked us to the hotel. Upon arrival, we went to the Sushi restaurant and, well, I thought I was a sushi expert, but their sushi bar was beyond belief, basically a Michelin 3 Star restaurant experience. They were making wasabi right in front of us on a piece of shark skin. The tuna selection was amazing and the sake was rare,unobtainable and delicious. Our rooms had a great view, and were ultra clean and comfortable. As newbies to Tokyo, we relied on the concierge to arrange for private tours with an english speaking guide. Well they, again hit a home run with our guides as we went to the Tuna auction at 3am and toured off the beaten tourist track neighborhoods and experienced an authentic tea ceremony in an area of hidden gardens where the bonsai trees were hundreds of years old. But wait!!! then we wanted to take the bullet train to Kyoto for the day and they arranged a guide to meet us there which of course was essential as she took us to temples and the bamboo forest and a fantastic non-tourist lunch. However, on the way to Kyoto, the MO bell staff sent a super nice young man to the train station with us and he took us to our train and the specific car and made sure we were seated in OUR seats before he left the station. This attention to detail was over the top. The MO Tokyo staff went OUT OF THEIR WAY 24-7 to make sure we made the most of our time in Tokyo and made sure our experiences were FIRST CLASS and unforgettable. The facilities, from the bar, to the restaurants, from breakfast to dinner catered to our picky tastes. The spa was 2nd to none and the wine cellar was superbly stocked. We had a bottle of Ai from Kenzo in Napa Valley on our final night. We put our trust in the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo staff and they exceeded absolutely ALL of our expectations. There is NO question we will be back soon. It really doesn't get any better than the MO Tokyo! David MacNeil, Hinsdale, IL

As a fan, I like to take this opportunity to thank you all the staffs for giving me another wonderful MO-experience; simply can't wait to go back. As a traveler, MO remains my number one choice always (however, i'm sincerely hoping that MO will issue a membership or loyalty program soon).

My husband and I we were staying at Mandarin Hotel in Tokyo 12 Nights end of September for Holiday, We both enjoyed very much , Mandarin Hotel Tokyo it's much higher stander services , all of staff very very pleasant, The Michelin Franch restaurant provide very good quality Franch food , which is my husband and I like it very much ... Especially Breakfast fruits are very fresh and lots of very good quality unique choices food plus very well trained staff , they are keeping all the time smiling , even they do check tea or coffee is cold and change to Warm one .... They are excellent service ! The Manager Nicclo who is most busy guy at restaurants, He try to looking after everything and everyone, even when we were ( Japan Silver Week Holiday ) the time hotel fully booked , breakfast still managed very well , keeps everyone happy ! We have to thanks a lots to Miss Jenny Miu from front Desk ,She is from Hong Kong , She provides to us lots of very valuable information , Much easier for me given I was fist time to visiting in Tokyo,  The room is very comfortable and nice food .... Whole Hotel very well Management ,it's grea location, it's much much relaxing place to stay . Enjoyed it very Much . We love the Hotel very much, We have already booked Christmas and New Year ! We are looking forward going back the Hotel !

This is my fifth stay il this hotel and the service is always perfect . I especially recommend the sushi restaurant and the spa with great massage.Here, every staff has a deep and real welcome attitude. The buiding is very nice and it is a real pleasure for the eyes in every detail.Really, a must go for me.

This was our 2nd time staying here while in Tokyo and I can't imagine staying anywhere else. The staff is incredible- so warm, welcoming and very helpful. The rooms have fantastic views, the beds are very comfortable and the shower is amazing. It is such a treat to arrive here after a long flight. It is definitely worth including the breakfast with your reservation. A big surprise was how good the pizza is at k'shiki. We wouldn't normally eat this in Japan but it is a serious wow. It is very expensive to be sure but absolutely worth it if you can afford to splurge. I've also stayed in MO's in Singapore and HK but MO Tokyo is the finest.

I took my mother for a girls trip for two nights and three days, as we always love Mandarin Oriental and also this time I booked Tokyo MO. Generally the hotel is very nice position and transport convenient, but I have to say this time MO disappointed us very much. We stayed in room 3303, at 10:30 in the night time, we were at bed and we hear big noise from the floor upstairs, they were a couples fighting and screaming for more than half hour and We get scared about the loud and I have to call the concierge to complain, after a hour and more the gentleman called me back asking if we want to change another room, at 11:45 pm!!! I refused and ask what happened, he just informed they have called police to settle as I believe someone was injured. In the day after when I check out, no one of the hotel asked us if we were fine and they are sorry for what happened. I believe MO service should be much much better then we received

Stayed here my first night in Japan and I arrived very early and was offered an early checkin as I requested before hand. The room had amazing view of the Tokyo Skytree. Everything about the room was perfect. With amazing dining choices and a really nice breakfast, the service was excellent and a lot of attention paid to guest comfort.

We just returned from a week long vacation in Japan. We spent the first 4 nights of our stay at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo. Having stayed in many of the best hotel chains around the world (including Four Seasons, Ritz-Carlton, Rosewood, Peninsula), this particular stay was more of a life-changing 'experience'. From the moment you walk through the door, you are treated like royalty. We have never come across anything like it, we loved it so much, we plan to return to Tokyo just to stay at the property. We spent the last 3 nights of our trip at the Hyatt Regency in Kyoto, which although very nice, was nowhere in the same galaxy of luxury and service that we received at the Mandarin. The only unfortunate element to staying here, is that it will spoil you for life and nothing else can compare... the only one negative was that smoking is allowed on property in some sleeping rooms and the Mandarin bar. We were very surprised by this and as such, we have evening drinks at the Oriental Lounge off the lobby area which is also fabulous and smoke-free.

Take the best hotel chain in the world an pout it in the country with the best customer service on the planet an not surprisingly you have a better hotel experience than any other city.Hotel si MO style- modern but classy. The Italian and sushi restaurant were a treat and the breakfast was over the top. Location is great for me (tourist) and I assume it would be good for business as well.I thought it was a very reasonable price as well

What an outstanding establishment. Great location - close to train and walkable distance to up market shops and a myriad of quality bars and restaurants. The best though is simply an outstanding level of service and attention to detail. Nothing was too much trouble and staff thought ahead as to what I might require. Great bar, views and outstanding Chinese restaurant . I'll be back!

We had a weekday lunch at Italian restaurant in this hotel.The voew from our seating was spectacular,especially it was beautiful day.We enjoyed our 4 course lunch ,started with alcohol.Actually food itself was not impressive but the service and the ambience was good.About $40 includes tax and service fee was a bargain.Worth a try.

We had a great stay at the Mandarin Oriental Hotel. Room is nice and service excellent. The spa and treatment is spectacular. Breakfast was excellent every morning. Overall an excellent visit. The location of the hotel is also excellent. Access to subway is very convenient. I recommend this hotel highly.

Can't fault the hotel or facilities in anyway. Pricey, but worth the extra! Location is slightly away from the Tokyo station and the other city centre buildings which makes for a great skyline view at nights.

Not much left to say about this amazing property. But I'll try... Location is great, service is outstanding, rooms are modern and very well kept, 3 Michelin star restaurants on site!, super cool bar with a world class view & an awesome gym.  What really stood out was the service, from the greeting to my departure every staff member I encountered was well trained and friendly. It doesn't get much better than this.

Everything about this hotel is fantastic. The location is just wonderful, high up, overlooking Tokyo from your room, from the breakfast, from the fitness, from the spa. The staff is most friendly and helpful. There are two breakfast restaurants, with service or with buffet. The breakfast buffet is excellent and if you're lucky, you can enjoy the view of the rising sun, with Mount Fuji in the back ground, whilst sipping your coffee or tea. Would go back anytime!

We loved our stay. The Mandarin Tokyo had breathtaking views as well as impeccably appointed and laid-out rooms. Every line and detail seemed to have been considered -- the right amount of space, light, technology, toiletries, electrical outlets, sitting room, storage space, you name it -- whatever we needed was there, and nothing was frivolous. Our dining experiences wanted for nothing, as the food was delicious (and sensibly portioned) and the service was outstanding. Again, those views.The staff -- always courteous, helpful, and friendly -- gave the sense that they would genuinely try to accommodate any request. And though they made us feel recognized and appreciated, somehow we still felt like we had complete privacy and anonymity.I could go on. Bottom line, strongly recommended for a stay in Tokyo.
user_name:
bubenhalsi
San Francisco, California, United States

review_body: My friend and I had an afternoon tea at the Oriental Lounge and absolutely were blown away by the professionalism of the staff, especially the Manager – Eita, and the hostess (do not remember the name). The view is to die for, the selection of teas is incredible and we were able to sample a few different ones. Definitely experience not to miss!

Five days in the MO Tokyo.Everything about this hotel was bliss. The service, the food and the view. We had a drink in the bar every evening, and breakfast every morning. Every single time we had a seat right by a window.For the first five days we were in a room with a view towards Mt Fuji. It wasn't clear enough to get a view of it while we were there. From talking to the staff, it is possible but perhaps only 15-20 days a year. The views on the other side, are just as excellent (if not better as they're towards the Sky Tree). We stayed on that side for one night at the end of our trip.The hotel gym is small but perfectly formed, the dumbells max out at 20kg, but there is a place to do pull ups and everything is in perfectly good order, plus being the MO there is of course complimentary pre & post workout drinks.All in all, an excellent stay in a city and hotel I very much want to visit again. The advice from a member of staff to visit Nara was very much appreciated and it turned out to be a trip highlight. Do however avoid their laundry, £70 or so for half a dozen t-shirts and pairs of underwear did bite a little.

The location is fantastic, the staff were helpful and friendly (as I would expect from a MO hotel)but also that everyone, from reception to the concierge, bellboy, etc spoke very good English - not something that is true in Tokyo even for 5 stars hotel.The rooms were very big also for Tokyo standard and were of very high standard, from furnishing, amenities to it's unbelievable view over Tokyo.The facilities were great as were the restaurants.The only two things which I found inconvenient were the lack of a pool in-house and also the fact that you had to go up to the lobby before you can go down again to leave the building - a small inconvenience, but one nonetheless.

Beautiful hotel, impeccable service and the most impressive views over Tokyo...what else do you need? Just arriving to the Mandarin Oriental is an adventure itself- the breath taken view of the reception desk on the 38th floor, the beautiful and peaceful Mandarin Bar and the great selection of top restaurants is the perfect home for top Tokyo experience. Just love it!

My third stay here and it must be said it keeps getting better. The level of service here is up there with the world's best. I was treated very well, no request was too much. Friendly, warm, knowledgeable staff throughout. I found my initial room, a Deluxe Corner Room, a little cramped. A couch facing into the room at the window (with great SkyTree view) was ridiculous. A HUGE television at the other window blocking that knockout view, also unnecessary. Great bathroom though, with a view from the huge tub. I was upgraded to a Mandarin Grand Room the next day and the extra space was considerable.The food and service in the restaurants was excellent. I felt like a special guest here and most staff I came across knew my name. This is still up the top of the tree of hotels in Tokyo. Really excellent.

I was warmly welcomed upon entering the hotel the first time and every time I left and came back. Check in and out was a breeze as the staff at the concierge desk was extremely efficient. My room over looked the city with Mt. Fuji in the background, beautiful sight every morning. Room was comfortably furnished and well stocked with towels, paper and pen at the desk, bath condiments and other toiletries. There was a wonderful spa and a workout area that was easy to access and clean. Food in all the restaurants was excellent and in the eveningI would relax in the piano bar with a cigar from their extensive cigar menu. Only downside to this stay was that I had to leave and return home.

With its 6 stars, perched on the 38th floor, the Mandarin will stagger you with its quality and service. I have not stayed anywhere that makes you feel more welcome or offers such attention to detail, 24 hours a day.The second you arrive, you see the quality. The finish of the hotel is excellent. The main reception area offers staggering views of Tokyo as you check in. The rooms are of the very highest standard. Our Deluxe room featured wonderful east facing views, a luxurious king size bed and a beautifully finished bathroom with wet room shower and a huge bathtub. The amenities offered are also of the best qualitiy, from the laundry service and complimentary shoe shine, to the restaurants, bars and fitness centre. The little touches are what makes this hotel great. Like never having to get up at the breakfast buffet to recharge your juice. It is simply done for you. Like never having to offer up your name and room number when signing the bill. They already know who you are. Like having your own valet cupboard in your room, accessible from the outside, so that you are never disturbed when laundry is collected or things are delivered. Like the staff placing a bookmark next to your bed because they can see you are reading a book. Over the 5 nights my wife and I stayed here, I never once had to repeat myself or ask for the basic things to be done. It just happened. It's this that makes the Mandarin Tokyo a home from home. You never have to worry about anything as it is all taken care of for you, without you even asking,My favourite area of the hotel was the bar. A dark but comfortable and luxurious area serving incredible cocktails and snacks. The staff here were the best for sure and are an indispensable part of this hotel. Live jazz and a great atmosphere had my wife and I returning here night after night. I also highly recommend a visit to the Tapas Molecular bar, where you will be dazzled by culenary delights, in an intimate environment. One of the best restaurants I have eaten in, for sure.I have seen the General Manager, Anthony Costa, talk about this hotel a number of times on TV, and it's one of the reasons why I chose to stay here. He has hit the nail on the head and I congratulate him and his team for creating, what I consider to be the best hotel on earth. I cannot recommend the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo enough and I will be staying here on every return visit to Tokyo.

We arrived late at night after a long, long drive back from Zao (see previous review) and frustrating labyrinthine circuits around the airport to return the hire car. We were bedraggled, tired and hungry when we arrived, but the welcome at the hotel was faultless.Our room was incredible and lifted spirits immediately. High up in the towers, we looked down through floor to ceiling glass at the tiny car lights snaking their way far below. Indeed, I had a moment of existential bliss watching the lights of Tokyo as I lay on the enormous bed, with a proper mattress and gorgeous pillows. A proper bed. No rice husks. Yay. And a distant view of Mt Fuji in the daytime. The bathroom was beautiful and well equipped, with a separate shower area and good amenities and toiletries. The toilet was full on Japanese high-tech, with heated seat, all manner of confusing (and sometimes amusingly unexpected) jets and automatic flush. But it wasn’t as clever as it thought it was – when using it during the night you can fool it into not flushing automatically by hovering over it at just the right angle. I was very proud of this discovery until Mr BL pointed out the button that switches the automatic flush off. We ate in the Italian restaurant: fantastic food, friendly service and great wine. The Chinese restaurant is excellent. Go for afternoon tea as well – if you sit next to the windows, you get the dual thrill of delicious little cakes and simultaneous vertigo. The panoramas from this hotel are mesmerising – I ended up leaving nose marks on all the windows as I stared at the hypnotic unfolding distant scenes below. I’m probably not doing this hotel justice with this description – everything was perfect in every way and we are definitely going to return; I just seem to have run out of superlatives.

A room that has the whole view of Tokyo! Amazing and quick service provided by the hotel! The concierge is very helpful in term of helping us to do the bookings, help us to find a way to hang around Tokyo due to the fact we do not speak Japanese... They made things easier!

The Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo has some of the best views in town. I stayed here for one night in 2014 and was pleased overall. The check-in process was disappointing as my room was not ready until past the check-in time. The restaurants were all fantastic. The spa was nice although I did utilize it (I did not feel like paying extra just to use the steam room for 30 minutes). In terms of value versus price, I thought the Four Seasons and Shangri-La offered as-good if not better accommodations and service for less money. With that said, if money is of no concern then it is certainly worth a visit. If you can afford the MO but still care about the value versus cost, I would recommend the Four Seasons or Shangri-la.

The hotel itself is beautiful and provides the best view of the city. Access to the Ginza line right under the hotel. Breakfast is delicious with many Asian and western options in the buffet restaurant. Nicolo is a host at the restaurant and he is wonderful, so kind and cheerful. The bar is great and busy every night. Very well crafted cocktails and wide selection of Japanese whiskey and sake. If you're a Centurion member make sure to book with Amex for additional perks. The staff did so much to make us feel welcomed and special for our anniversary trip with a cake and signed note to congratulate us. Cheers.
user_name:
Lisa A
New York City, New York

review_body: We stayed in a Mandarin Grand room for our first three nights in Tokyo. The room was very generously sized and had a great view, except it rained the whole time so we couldn't see too far! The service was top-notch and the location was truly great. The hotel is located on top of a Tokyo Metro stop and it is 2 stops to Ginza. Being Americans, we were a little scared of using the Tokyo Metro but it was very easy to manage, with color coded and numbered stops and was impeccably clean. The hotel's concierge was great about making reservations for us for a half day tour and restaurants via email in the months leading up to our trip. The room had a HDTV but did not permit us to hook up an HDMI cable from our computer. The lobby and bar (it is on top of a building) are very cool with a significant water feature and good dining choices. However, the hotel bar did appear to permit smoking, which was a bit unexpected. Overall, we had a great time there and wish we had returned for our last night in Tokyo!

Excellent hotel on all accounts!Stay here if you can. Marvellouos views, excellent staff (very very attentive), excellent rooms/beds, good breakfast and an excellent gym. Lounge areas are quiet while still in the midst of the lobby.A hotel not to be missed

In Tokyo at the end of a long Japan tour- walking and sightseeing. Both the room, with all its fabulous amities, the view over Tokyo complete with binoculars!) and the elegance of the hotel relaxed me immediately. Incredible service and even a sampling of after dinner drinks in the bar. Great place to come back to after a day of sightseeing!

Location is the king as right downstairs is a subway station and located at Ginza. Room size is large with good skyline. Services always unexpected. There is a side door that concierge passed stuff with no interruption. There are multiple pillow options which are unexpected. Services is about attention details and even you hv expectation on japan and mandarin oriental. still be touched by their exceptional services.

Beautiful hotel.. Beautiful service..Lobby hotel building room.. Everything is 100% satisfied!!!! Foreign staff in the breakfast restaurant, really kind and give me good service.. Every Japanese staff is very very polite... I can't ask I want.. Because they already know.. Thank you very much! ^^

This is our second time at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. We love this hotel. Fantastic location, directly above the Subway station Ginza Line, a short walk to the Shin-Nihonbashi JR station, Coredo 1,2,and 3 across is full of wonderful and all kinds of dining options. Mitsukoshi connected by the subway station and right next to the hotel. The concierge helped me book all the restaurants I wanted and even made some great recommendations. We stayed for business and leisure this time. The Business Center and Front desk helped us alot with sending a parcel back to Hong Kong. The bell desk is fantastic. Housekeeping is professional and anytime we needed something, they would provide it and bring to our room in minutes. Absolutely perfect stay. Quiet, and beautiful. Excellent Service. Luxurious. Will return again during our next visit to Tokyo.The only thing that some may not like is the WI-FI is not complimentary in MOTYO but I didn't need it because we had our own pocket wi-fi device.We experienced the earthquake at 5am, and it was only a few seconds. That was quite an experience. Thank you MOTYO, we will be back soon.

I guess with many positive reviews and being under such a luxury brands, there are not much to add to the great things of this property. In fact, I had a chance to meet Christian Hassing, a very kind gentleman, briefly in August when he was visiting Tokyo. However, this review would hopefully show things that could be improved. The heat and water area was definitely a highlight as I got to see a pretty dramatic sunset. The gym was not big, but sufficient with nice refreshment (I just don't understand why female spa staff kept crossing the gym area to deliver trays with wine bottles, at least 4-5 times even I was there working out for roughly an hour, an explanation from the management would be helpful).Now to the constructive feedback from my interactions with the concierge on 10 September evening. It was past 9PM so I came over and asked for places to purchase champagne nearby. He explained that the Mitsukoshi mall has closed so I could only try the convenience store on the basement. Then I asked if any supermarket around as they often carry a better selection of alcohols than convenience store, the answer was no supermarket around the area at all. Guess what, later I pulled out my phone and realised there was a Maruetsu supermarket just 200m away, as well as, some wine cellar that open late in some of those COREDO buildings. While on my way, I also asked for delivery of champagne glasses and ice bucket to the room, and got white wine glasses delivered instead.There was also a popular event nearby called ECO EDO Art Aquarium, which is literally just right opposite the hotel, but both telephone operator and concierge staff couldn't provide much information when asked. I wondered and asked if there would be a long line if we get there at 10PM, and they were not sure and told me to buy tickets at 7-11, to skip the line, but the nearest 7-11 store was 5 mins away. Ended up going there and found no queue at all. I can understand if it was a concert far away, but if such a popular exhibition happens across your hotel that you cannot provide exact information, then it becomes such a disappointment.Anyway, I already had a reservation and will be returning for Signature at the beginning of October, and hope the constructive feedback would be helpful in some ways. Always love the MO!

This is possibly the best hotel we ever stayed at! From the moment we arrived after a 12 hour flight and a cab ride, we were surrounded by sincere and welcoming warmth.We expected beautiful rooms and wonderful amenities -- what we did not expect was the level of service that was beyond anything we have ever experienced in any other hotel of this class. We stayed for 5 nights. After the first breakfast, the staff knew our preferences and made us feel like visiting royalty. The concierge staff were remarkable - sending a taxi (w/o us even asking) to obtain train fare to Nikko for us for the next morning after they were unable to reserve them on line the night before, and then giving us such perfect directions that we did not even need to askanyone at the station. The Spa is THE BEST I have ever been to - with floor to ceiling views of Tokyo from the 37th floor. When compared to others in its class, Mandarin Oriental Tokyo leaves you with only one question -- why would you ever consider staying anywhere else???

I travel a lot and this is by far and away one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. Staff is great and service is second to none. Check out Frank who tends the bar. Big Mets fan and a great guy. Will always stay here when I am Tokyo

People make businesses and they had the best people I have ever encountered. I particularly loved the sr breakfast manager Niccolo Brachelente who made us and everyone else feel like VIPs. This is the best hotel I have ever stayed at. Great location, great food, great people.

The Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo, (MOTYO) is not to be surpassed. All of the hotels we stayed in during our Japan trip are luxurious and intriguing but the Mandarin has a way of treating its clientele that was unequaled by the others. I have already joined its clubs on Twitter and Instagram. They sent up a cake on my birthday! One example of their hospitality: We would return from a day's activities, encounter a staff member, and they would say to us something like, "How did your day at Disneyland go yesterday?" Apparently the staff shared facts about their clientele with one another. It was a very welcomed touch to a stranger in a strange land. The only minor negative for the MO-Tokyo is its confusing East-West angle on an otherwise North-South city grid. I had a very hard time finding my way back to the train station each day and was unable to orient myself by the compass. This must have been due to jet-lag or fatigue. It wasn't until the very last day that I realized there was a subway stop in the basement of the building! Ha! Ha! At any rate, please stay here. You will absolutely have a great time.

While the hotel rooms and facilities themselves are top of their class already, what impressed us most is the level of impeccable services provided by the entire MO staff team. From checking in to provide flexibility for our anniversary stay, to the warm and unintrusive but always there services anywhere you turn. The attention to details is otherworldly and makes you enjoy every moment inside of the hotel and wishing to be back soon after you leave. We will certainly come back and stay here next time when we are in Tokyo.

My wife and I just took our first trip to Japan together, and staying at the Mandarin Oriental was one of the highlights. The international staff made us feel right at home. The only other Mandarin Oriental we had stayed at before was in Las Vegas, and surprisingly, our room in Tokyo felt bigger (we got the least expensive rooms with king-sized beds at each location). The furnishings were beautiful and we loved the rain shower in the bathroom. Plus, we could see Mt. Fuji from our window.We booked the bed-and-breakfast package, and the breakfast buffet was outstanding. It included made-to-order egg dishes, luscious fresh fruit, pastries, Japanese dishes, dim sum, and a dedicated gluten-free bread corner that was perfect for my wife (who has celiac disease). The staff went above and beyond in general service and helping with my wife's dietary restriction -- especially Nicolo, the breakfast manager.The hotel is also conveniently located, with easy access to the Mitsukoshimae subway station (and the flagship location of the Mitsukoshi department store). We walked to both Ginza and Akihabara. Without question, we'll choose the Mandarin Oriental again on our next trip to Tokyo.

The hotel's concierge and business centre provided great assistance during my recent stay at the hotel - it made all the difference ironing out communication issues that are usual for visitors to Japan. I had a very tight time schedule and the staff were incredibly efficient and friendly which was a huge help. Most other hotels there have good business centres but not the sort of support that the Mandarin offered.

We stayed here for my birthday celebration so I don't know the pricing. We had a huge room with amazing views of the city lights. The room has all the amenities including a fold up vanity. Their yukatas are very comfortable but there are regular robes if you prefer. Service is impeccable and unlike some other hotels, the service was not snobby. There's a pillow menu too although they were out of the horsehair pillow!

We stayed here a couple of years ago and my review from that visit can be found in the Trip Advisor archives. We loved it back then and loved it just as much second time around.The rooms are beautiful with incredible views, the staff wonderful and in their Molecular Tapas Bar they have one of the finest and most unique dining destinations anywhere on the planet. Why it only has one Michelin Star (particularly in a City where the Inspectors seem to throw them around like confetti) amazes me.
