One item that really bothered us were the fact that we (like anybody else staying here) paid a big price for the rooms but only to realize when we went to use the sauna and the spa area it's not included in the room price (only if you go between 06:30-09:00 am). Honestly, when I pay $800 a night I would appreciate to be able to use the sauna or the steam room without an additional charge.

The Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Tokyo is fabulous--the best place to stay, luxurious, beautiful, spacious and the food is excellent! The rooms are gorgeous and comfortable, and the attention to every detail by the staff it truly outstanding. I will be back!! The views of Tokyo's skylines are extraordinary from every direction.

Stayed here for eleven days over Christmas. Found the service in general to be unfriendly, I have generalized social anxiety disorder and am admittedly an awkward fellow, so this likely has something to do with it but still unacceptable. I did like breakfast in the mornings at K'Shiki, good food and pleasant service, and the concierge was pretty helpful. I would also say that the hotel's location is the best in the sprawling city, with very easy access to most of the best restaurants in town. But still I could not recommend it. I visited the Aman Tokyo several times during my stay in Tokyo for the amazing restaurant and bar, and the difference in friendliness between the two hotels was night and day.

We were blessed to be staying here, the public spaces are tremendous and we enjoyed Noma Tokyo during their recent residency. The views from the 37-38th floors are fabulous and we got to see Mt. Fuji (a rarity in from Tokyo 60km away). Staff are friendly and professional, the lobby restrooms are also spectacular views (if Northwards). You won't be disappointed, you'll be a Fan...Good luck and enjoy!

A staff that anticipates our every needs, one of the best jazz bars in the world, and fantastic food. Every element of this hotel is carefully thought out to the extent you just never want to leave it!

The staff at the Mandarin Oriental all help to make your stay as effortless as possible. The Concierge desk was very helpful in suggesting and booking excellent restaurants and they printed off the directions/details without being asked so you could give them tot eh taxi drivers.My room was lovely - lots of space with everything I needed. Unfortunately I was looking away from Mount Fuji (which showed its face one day)Breakfast (either the buffet or the seated service) were both excellent - very relaxing!

Returned here after a number of years. Hotel was still wonderful, and our room seemed bigger than I remembered, and faced Mount Fuji. Both the twin beds were large and comfortable.Wifi was free, and the desk was large enough to fit a lot of stuff on, and there were two swivel chairs so that two people could work at the desk at the same time.The bathroom was as nice as I remembered. The only issue I had was that the Bottega Veneta toiletries provided was too strong in terms of the scent, which ended up interfering with my sense of smell when eating out.Otherwise service was absolutely faultless.

Location might not be the greatest but still fairly close to all the action but the SERVICE was simply SUPERB! The rooms was beautiful and spotless with good views of Tokyo. Restaurant was good as well. Concierge and receptionist speaks fluent english and was really helpful and made my first visit to Japan (back in 2009) a memorable one! Can't wait to go back!

spectacular hotel ....fabulous rooms and views to die for over the city with Mt Fuji in the distance on a clear day. But what truly sets it apart is the service....not one single element wrong ....from reception, housekeeping, roomservice. Nothing was haphazard or not thought through. It truly is a standard for the rest of the hotels to aspire to.

This time we stayed for 5 nights at the Mandarin Oriental. Having been at the hotel for dozens of time before, we can only congratulate as the quality of accommodation, service and food was better than ever.

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is the perfect balance of calm and city. The lobby is breathtaking and the rooms are sophisticated, comfortable and boast incredible views of Tokyo from high above. The service is exceptional. They really go above and beyond to meet the guests needs. We will absolutely stay here on any future trips to Tokyo.
user_name:
saul1220
New York City, New York

review_body: In an amazing city like Tokyo, there are many options to consider and a lot of 5-star hotels that are an interesting option. Having had a great experience at the Mandarin Oriental in Las Vegas, we thought we'd try this Mandarin since it is their flagship hotel. There is not a thing I would change about our experience at the hotel. It was simply amazing. The staff are courteous, friendly, and provide 5-star service. The room butler was a lovely bonus, and the breakfast buffet is the breakfast buffet that will make all others pale in comparison. We will absolutely stay here on our next visit to Tokyo. Tip: try the wood-fired pizza at the restaurant at lunch - delish!

First I have to mention about it's washroom with electronic sprinkler for wasting and unique shower fittings. Then there is easily operable curtain raisers. Huge room. Good food though all are not very attractive to Indian palate. But if you think this whole building is hotel then you are wrong. Only a few very upper floors are hotel. Though there are many lifts you need to practice to get to used to.

If you are looking for a hotel to splash out on in Tokyo, then we would recommend a night or two at The Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo. We always base ourselves in Shinjuku, given the many excellent department stores (Takashimaya, Isetan, Lumine) nearby and the ease of moving around (via train), but the Nihombashi area in which the MO is based is worth exploring as well. The MO is conveniently based above the Mitsukoshimae station, serviced by the Ginza line. The hotel itself is gorgeous. We stayed in the Mandarin Grand Room, which was an exquisite blend of Japan meets West, with views of Mt Fuji on the horizon. The room is spacious, the pillow menu lots of good fun, and turn down was something we looked forward to.Service at the hotel was also exceptional. The concierge was wonderful in helping us organise dining reservations at external Japanese restaurants, and the staff were all warm, attentive and personable.Dining wise, we had the buffet breakfast at K'Shiki - an excellent selection of Western, Asian and Japanese - and enjoyed the drinks and views at the Oriental Lounge (which has some rare spirits on offer). We also tried the Tapas Gastronomy Bar on a previous stay. There is, possibly, better food of that genre to be found in town. However, it is still a fun, delicious and intimate experience with elements of theatre thrown in, and a great place to dine if you do not wish to leave the hotel. The hotel is within walking distance to Tokyo Station and the Imperial Palace, and some excellent shops can be found just across the hotel (including the Coredo department stores). Given it's history, the department stores in the area (Mitsukoshi, Takashimaya) are a little dated compared to their Shinjuku counterparts, however, the luxury shopping strip of Ginza is just a couple of stops away on the subway.

By far the best hotel we stayed in in japan (far superior to the Park Hyatt). Arrived at 8am to drop bags and immediately given access to our room. Fabulous, immaculate and recently decorated deluxe room. Concierge service was outstanding throughout (they got us impossible tickets to the Sumo titles). Breakfasts that we still think about with one of the best buffets ever (and we don't particularly enjoy buffets). The service throughout hotel, but particularly the manager at breakfast was phenomenal. Bar is pretty awesome with amazing views. Spa is well worth a trip especially the sauna overlooking Tokyo!Only downside to the hotel is location - its a bit away from all the sights, and the best shopping, and the area is a bit dead at night, but with a metro just under the building its not a huge issue. The Mitsokoshi Department Store is next door with the most amazing food hall on basement level providing for awesome snacks, lunches to take back to hotel.We will definitely stay here every time we visit Japan!

Greart hotel with excellent, friendly and helpful staffs. Surprised to see the luggage already in the room before I did after checking in.Location a bit off the centre. Bathroom with one washing basin a bit incovenient for a couple sharing the room; also the closet area a bit small.Good breakfast

a perfect hotel for business purpose. The only thing you have to think about is your work. the rest is taken good care of. never been in a better hotel in my life. the price is in line with the sevice and standards though: high..

Experiencing hotels in Japan is always a truly remarkable indulgence, the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is hands-down the greatest stay I've had. Takeshi and the hotel staff genuinely welcomed me into my temporary home and anticipated my every requirement. 10/10 my first choice in Tokyo city.

Was at the MO Tokyo because of Noma, we wanted to be able to roll in & out of bed before & after the meal, but as always the MO does not disappoint, good service from the staff, we got an early check in, breakfast was great, the rooms were a sanctuary & a home away from home, wifi was free & quick, location was close to the financial district but not as central as ie the Peninsula, some of our other friends stayed at Roppongi's Intercont instead due to better location. Overall we had a fantastic stay at the MO & I would come back

I stayed at the MO for one night in January for my Noma lunch. The hotel is located at the top floors of the building, but the guest rooms are below the reception floor meaning you'd have to take up an elevator to the 38th floor to change to the elevator going down to the guest rooms on floors 30-36.Anyway, the welcome was great and even though it was clear that the hotel was packed to the max due to the Noma packages (for dinner it's required to take at least one night at the hotel) my check-in went smooth although I had to wait until the afternoon getting my room.My room was on the 30th floor and had all the amenities you can imagine. And then some. I enjoyed the Bottega Veneta toiletries.I had the concierge book a great tempura restaurant and even had to move my reservation in which they happily assisted.There's a fantastic boulangerie (The Gourmet Shop) at the ground floor. Their croissants and pastry is on par with the best you can find in Paris.The subway is in the basement so it's quite easy to get around even if you'd have to change trains here and there.I tried the spa (but not the gym) before checking out in the morning. There are male and female spas. It's quite small, but has relaxation pool (3 loungers in the water) and a whirlpool + a steam bath and a dry sauna with the best view I have ever experienced in a sauna. Ever.

I only just checked in, and I have to complain already. I booked the MO for 2 nights here since I got a reservation at Noma. The event isn't til tomorrow, so I don't know how great Noma is yet. But this is what I can tell you - I arrived at 9am this morning and the room wasn't ready - no complaint here, so I said I would walk around the department stores nearby, waited Tim around lunch time and asked the concierge desk to book a table for lunch. I had hand picked a few unagi-don restaurants and asked the concierge to try to book me a table at any one of them that's available and not too far from the hotel. The guy took one glance and called up a place. He confirmed later on that he booked one of those on my list, which he said is 10min away. I thought "wow that's great". But of course life isn't so straightforward. As it turned out, he just booked a random restaurant, gave me a different address and sent me to some overpriced restaurant in the neighborhood. Maybe he thought I couldn't read the restaurant's name in Japanese or Kanji, so he thought he could get away with it. Wrong.... I couldn't find what I had asked him to book and I left. Upon further examination of the instructions/confirmation he gave me, I realized he booked a different place with a different number and different address. I'm not sure if the names are different - and there is no way for me to tell because they are in Japanese. This happened on Jan22-2015 at around 11am. Thanks to the MO staff, I walked in the rain for 40minutes until I noticed that the whole thing was not arranged as per my request. Maybe the rest of the hotel is spotless and perfect. But I will only leave MO after my Noma meal wondering if I will ever come back. Very disappointing indeed.

As always, the Mandarin Oriental lives up to its reputation. From the moment we arrived, to the time we left, everything was impeccable.The hotel is beautifully renovated, its lobby located on the 38th floor offering a spectacular view of the city. The well equipped gym and the spa also share the wonderful view. As usual, we are provided with our gym shirt, shorts, socks and shoes. It's a joy to work out at the gym and relax at the jacuzzi and steam room later.As we do not speak Japanese, the concierge helped us with our reservations and printed helpful details with a map to help us get around.All our arrangements and needs were taken care of with such meticulous detail that made us felt like home. The restaurants on the 38th floor, Sora serves excellent Japanese food, and K'shiki was where we had breakfast, the spread included many wonderful pastries and high quality food, including the fragrant Iwate honey. Needless to say, we love it here!The hotel is located right on top of the Mitsuoshimae train station and can be accessed via the A7 exit, it is just two stops to Ginza if I recall correctly.Overall, this is a wonderful place to be in, we will be back!

I was lucky enough to have booked the NOMA Package with a Grand King Room. The room is what you expect from a 6 star hotel. They are very large and comfortable in what you expect with a MO. Perfect. The only issue I had was the sleep quality. There were some noises coming from the floor above at night but it was for a very brief moment. I am being picky yes but you expect perfection here. Free WIFI I believe is only for the Grand King Room and above. It will depend on your package. The cheapest rooms do not come with free wifi... View: The hotel is perched at the top of an office building so you have a bird's eye view of everything around you. One side of the hotel have the Mt. Fuji view in the distance and the other side have the Tokyo Sky Tree. Remember to request which side you want during reservation. Service: Impeccable. This is only what you expect in Japan but the MO Tokyo take it up a notch. From the always smiling and energetic bell captain to the restaurant staff. Everyone is ready to help and assist. They will bend over and make things work for you. The only issue I had was the check in staff. She was a bit cold and didn't make me feel that good. The excellent staff that escorted me to the room was perfect. She made the difference to my check in. The checkout staff was perfect. Breakfast: I need to mention about the breakfast at the K'shiki restaurant. Perfect view of Mt. Fuji and prefect selection of pastries. The highlight was the Eggs Benedict with crab meat. This is probably the best I've had. Ask about where the eggs came from and you will be in awe. Location: If you do have a chauffeur and need to take the public transport, the hotel is connected to the Tokyo Subway network. Down the basement of the connected building and you are in the Ginza line in 5 minutes. 25 minutes to Shibuya. Narita have a direct airport limousine bus to the MO. Check the schedule because the last bus leaves Narita around 9pm. If you are coming from Haneda, there is no direct bus. You need to take a bus to Tokyo Station and hop on a 5 minutes taxi. Of course, you can always take a train. Private transport can be arrange to/from Haneda for about 9000 yen on a taxi van. A good option if you have lots of bags and a bigger party. Ask the hotel to arrange for you. I just wish I will have another opportunity to stay here again in the future.

fantastic location and acommondating staff. Breakfast was a highlight for sure. My only niggles were the pay for wifi ( outragious ) for any hotel let alone one so expensive...and the paper i requested when checking in never arrived. i would stay again and recommend

One if the best Of the world!Raul, the Brazilian manager, is so kind and take care of your guests that is impossible don't mention him. Hotel beautiful , service, rooms , everything is absolutely fantastic. You feel at home. I'll be back for sure!!!!!

The hotel was beautiful and centrally located. We had an amazing view overlooking Tokyo from the 35th floor and could see Mt. Fuji in the distance! The staff could not have been more attentive or accommodating! If you asked where something was, they would personally escort you there....even to the subway which was located below the hotel. It was a wonderful experience and would highly recommend this hotel!I don't like paying for wifi at an expensive hotel and there was no complementary coffee in the morning....we had cappuccinos sent to the room in the morning at $15 each! Just little things but annoying!

What a treat to coordinate my trip to Japan with the visitors from Denmark. It's a testament to the hotel to attract the world's number one restaurant. It did not disappoint. Noma provided a once in a lifetime experience. Bravo Noma! Bravo Mandarin Oriental Tokyo!

I travel about 7 months out of the year, staying at amazing locations and what I believed to be fantastic hotels. I have to state that the Mandarin Hotel Tokyo has taken the prize for the absolutely best service possible. Thank you for an amazing stay.Elizabeth
user_name:
E A B
Lake Tahoe (Nevada), Nevada

review_body: This was my first time in Tokyo and Japan and this hotel was the best welcome I could have had. The service at all times was amazing and I was lucky that on the first morning I woke up to lovely views of Mount Fuji. The rooms were huge (and I only had the basic room), with plenty of space to sort everything out... I liked the shower and the fact I could watch TV while having a shower... All in all a lovely place to stay.Oh beware of Mitsukoshi department store next door - I spent a fortune in there!

I have stayed at this hotel on 4 separate occasions in the last 3 months and can't rate it highly enough. The high level of friendly and efficient customer service is second to none and the hotel is fitted out to a high quality with good sizes bedrooms and facilities. The hotel is in a good location (5 minutes from Tokyo Station if you are going to travel around Japan) and the views from the hotel are incredible. Stay at this hotel if you want an outstanding experience.

I stayed 3 nights there and it is probably my favorite city hotel in the world : the view was breathtaking (the hotel is located between the 32nd and the 38th floors of a tower), the breakfast incredible, the concierge perferct ...The location is great with a subway in the basement of the building.Luxury, simplicity, good taste and world class service : it is how I can resume my experience in this hotel.

+ in a very nice location, lots of locals in the area so not crazy touristy, corredo 123 across and a takashimaya beside is of course a big plus. hotel is very nice and has a great view. gym, restaurants are all superb. room is well appointed and has a decent size. service is great as what you would expect in a MO hotel. the manager helped us settle in our room explaining everything and he gave us a welcome drink of that special apple juice from nagano twice in one day. room view is breathtaking. left the curtains on one night cause of the very nice view on th 36th floor where my room was.- only negative for me is the bottega venetta toiletries, the bathroom (shower area) design that didnt have an enclosure so it kinda felt weird and lastly the bathroom fixtures felt old and tired.but all in all i like it here and will definitely be back

Amazing experience and the perfect place to stay when visiting Tokyo. Luxurious room with a great view which was spotlessly clean, well stocked and nicely fitted out. Friendly staff, fantastic service and special little touches such as the gifts from the gourmet cake shop which were left in our room each day. Only complaint (which really wasn't a problem) was that the 'do not disturb' was ignored and the room would be serviced once we left. Overall a fantastic experience and I would definitely stay at this hotel again.

This hotel has too many great things to mention, but above all the service was once again phenomenal and the restaurants and spa were amazing.I definitely recommend getting a spa treatment if only for the views from the facilities. I will definitely be back. Big thank you to Raul and team for making my 30th birthday stay magical!!!I'm a fan.

This was probably one on the best hotels I've stayed in. The hotel is reasonable walking distance from the train station (though if you have big bags, it is worth the cab ride). The service was incredible, from the check-in to the guided tour of our room and hotel amenities. They went above and beyond to assist us in making our travel arrangements (bought our train tickets for us). The city views from the hotel are incredible. The room was equally impressive from the heated toilet seats to the touch screen telephone. I would certainly stay here again on a future trip to Tokyo.

I have been lucky to be able to travel for both work and pleasure and I can honestly say that the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo is the best hotel I have ever stayed in. Every element of the experience was flawless --from the enormous, luxurious room and perfectly equipped bathroom -- to the most attentive and accommodating staff. This is my first time in a Mandarin Oriental hotel and it will certainly not be my last!

The MO ( Msndarin Oriental) is always a pleasure to stay at this Hotel.The location is great and the train ( directly connected to the basement of the hotel), covers all the main areas for shopping and great restaurants, including Ginza.We stayed 4 nights and had many parts of our trip that needed assistance.Firstly we were furnished with maps for all the restaurants that they helped us to book prior to our arrival. Secondly we were going onto Kyoto from Tokyo. The MO bought our bullet train tickets in advance on our behalf and helped us to send our luggage onto our next hotel as there was no space in the train for large pieces of luggage.This made our onward journey easy and the luggage was there before we arrived!

Amazing hotel, staff are really well trained, Ms. Masumi is the best concierge I've ever seen, breakfast is delicious (try the "pastel de Belém" it is only compared to the original one in Lisboa) and the view is breathtaking! Easy access to Metro too.

The hotel Mandarin in Tokyo has a fantastic view of Mount Fuji you can admire the highest mountain of Japan from almost everywhere in the hotel. My favorite spot to view this beautiful mountain from Mandarin Tokyo was the spa! It was amazing see the photos! The hotel is a little far but it was worth the subway rides. Love Mandarin Hotels!

The best Hotel of Tokyo,The accommodation booking, I was through the travel agency for help, that might be a mistake, I book one person, king bed,but the front desk staff told me was booked, two person twins bed, this problem will soon be solved quickly, and also arranged me for Skytree view,this is beautiful view.I also have some restaurants booking,when I check-in at the front desk,the concierge join together and told me about the restaurants booking,that is very warm.The location is very good,I can get the metro near the hotel.In the last night stay,they have a essential oil,I can sleep very well when I leave Tokyo.I stay five times to Park Hyatt Tokyo in the past.But I think I will not visit again.It is because I love Mandarin Oriental Tokyo.

Staff are well informed and very professional. Service is fantastic without being too intrusive. The rooms are tastefully designed and the daily breakfast is adequate.Concierge is very experienced and can recommend restaurants according to our taste.This has overtaken the island shangrila Hong Kong as out favourite hotel in the world.One world to describe this hotel - superb!
The only thing to be improved or adjusted is to provide free internet connection and free WiFi to the hotel guests. This is almost a "must" criteria when we choose a hotel.

Let's say that having missed a connecting flight in Dubai and arriving a day late I wasn't in the best of moods when I checked-in at the Manadarin Oriental during mid-October. My mood soon lifted when I discovered that because we'd been delayed there was already an emergency pack waiting in the room. Better still I wasn't charged for the nights accommodation that hadn't been used.The service at front-desk and in the restaurant at breakfast was amazing. Almost too attentive. After travelling further around Japan I just realise that's part of the culture/custom and something that it's very easy to get used to.The size of the room was excellent and the quality of the fixtures and fittings were as you'd expect for this upper tier of hotel. The view from the room and the restaurants is almost worth the money alone, it's quite nice to open the curtains and see Mt Fuji in the distance!We only ate in the hotel for 1 evening meal and the menu wasn't particularly easy to understand for a westerner on their first stay in Japan, later in the trip it would have posed little problem. My only slight gripe with the restaurant was the couple of steps that had to be negotiated, as a wheelchair user that was a bit fiddly but there was a portable ramp.An excellent hotel and if (when) I next visit Tokyo I shall again split my time between the Mandarin Oriental and Park Hyatt.

6 stars across the board. Heaven on earth. The room, food, service etc is all so amazing it's truly laughable. They only hire genuinely happy and incredible people. Best hotel stay anywhere ever. (Request mt Fuji view and be sure to eat their brunch)
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
Brian B
New York, New York, United States

review_body: I stayed at the MO Tokyo recently and I thoroughly enjoyed myself. It's well-located, opposite to 3 buildings full of restaurants, just above the metro station, and next door to a department store. The rooms are big, well-decorated, with great views.However, what sets this hotel apart is their truly first class service. They are friendly, professional and courteous, and respond to their customers with such high standards and enthusiasm. 2 examples: 1) My friend saw the alarm clock at the bedside table which he really liked and wanted to know where to get it. He rang the front desk, who was unsure of the answer and said he would get back to us. After we had gone out for the day and returned to the room, there was a letter on our desk, giving us all the information about the clock and where he could get it from. 2) On my day of departure, I was chatting to the Concierge about my trip, and I mentioned to her that I hadn't organised my hotel and restaurant bookings in Nara 3 weeks later. She offered to look into it for me and even though I had checked out of the hotel, she kept corresponding with me via email. In the end, she made a booking at a hotel for me, with several restaurant recommendations.I think the service at this hotel is really amongst the best I've experienced, and some of what they do is almost beyond their call of duty, which makes it all the more impressive. I must congratulate and thank the whole team in making this hotel so special, and I had a most enjoyable stay. It is highly recommended and I'll certainly return to this hotel whenever I'm visiting Tokyo again.

エントランスから手厚いもてなし若干やりすぎかな？と思うような過度のサービスは苦手なんだが相方はチェックインもスムースで、好印象を受けてた廊下は狭い。天井も低い。スカイツリー側だったので景観もgood部屋は50平米あるのか？と狭く感じたけど飾り枕とかファブリックは好みアメニティはボッテガ無料のティーバッグ（烏龍茶・煎茶・カモミールティー）はルピシア製さっそく着替えて宿泊者無料のフィットネスへ。貸出ウェアは全身アシックスでフロントロビーを通らないと行けないのはちょっとどうかと思う。導線どうにかならんかったんか。そしてジム。ここは行く価値ナシ。狭いし、受付も誰もいない。景観だけはスカイツリー側でGoodマシンとの間隔狭すぎだし備え付けの果物とポカリ、生ジュースだけは良かった。スパ・ジャグジーは宿泊者は休日7000円平日6000円の利用料ただし朝6時半～9時までの入室は無料とのことで翌朝GOここは価値アリ！スカイツリーを眺めながら朝日を浴びて入る風呂は最高！！でもぬるい。朝イチだったからか分からんけど、多分38度くらい。でも、サウナ二種は素晴らしい。マンダリンのスチームサウナスカイツリーが見えるサウナはこれまた低温。多分45度くらい。ケシキの朝食、冬は富士山がキレイに見えてパンも豊富、飲茶もあって、エグベネも美味しくって感動。コンフィチュールも美味しくて高級調味料もあって、カットフルーツも素晴らしかったです。部屋に戻るとルームキーが開かないトラブルが発生。10分くらい待たされて謝罪のひとつもなくカードキー交換…これで6ツ星はあげれません！Location★★★★★★Spa★★★★★★ExcellentGym★☆☆☆☆☆WorthlessBar★★★★☆☆K'SHIKI breakfast buffet★★★★★★so goodOur room 3317Dulux TwinBath★★★★★☆goodbed&pillow★★★★★★comfortablelandscape★★★★★☆nicesurvice★★★☆☆☆I can not award six stars.

This hotel is well located, the rooms are great, huge with spectacular views ... However there are many hotels that can offer this in Tokyo, what differentiates the Mandarin vs these and possibly any other hotel I have visited globally is their unbelievably high standard of customer service. They greeted my mother and I by name through out the hotel. I wish I could return the respect and favour by naming every staff member who made our stay so warm and welcoming but alas I have not developed the same skills! The concierge organised everything for us from Kabuki tickets to organising luggage transfers to and from Kyoto so we wouldn't have to take them on the train. I was also extremely impressed when they would suggest I buy certain tickets directly myself in order to save the service charge they add - never had that happen to me before ! The tour guides they organised were informative and spoke very fluent English. Every recommendation was one I'm glad we followed. Thank you MO team for an incredible stay. We shall most definitely return.

After staying at Park Hyatt, Peninsula, and Mandarin Oriental, I must say that this hotel was my least favorite. Don't get me wrong, it is a beautiful hotel with wonderful service, but I just didn't fall in love with it and here's why:- Location. While this is theoretically a good location, in reality there was nothing that was walking distance around the hotel versus at the Peninsula you walk out and are surrounded by restaurants and shops. - Room layout. This was the biggest issue that I had, While the decor of the room was nice, I disliked the layout. We were in the Deluxe Premiere room and as you walk in the bathroom is to your left. There is a sink with sliding mirrors that does not give you a complete separation from the bedroom. Honestly if I'm sitting in bed watching TV the last thing I need to hear is someone using the sink or brushing their teeth...Everything else about the room was nice, but missing the extra touches of Peninsula and Park Hyatt. Park Hyatt had ice sitting in the bucket for you when you check in and Peninsula has a console for everything from closing the curtains to the temperature and wind speed outside. I must say that the concierge was wonderful at the Mandarin Oriental and helped us figure out a number of reservations. The lobby and bar area was absolutely beautiful. Perhaps I will try this hotel again but get a different room.

4 day business trip to Tokyo and this hotel has it all. Rooms, amenities, location, view, service, food, healthy club...they don't miss a thing. World class hotel. Dinner in the Italian restaurant was excellent. Pizza over bar is nice option. Breakfast was civilized -- great service again. Health club is top rate -- open 24 hours full amenities. Look forward to staying again at the MO-T.

A very good location if you travel for business in Tokyo station area. Convenient location and good access to shops, subway/train stations and major business building. Excellent amibence and top class facilities and services. I enjoyed my stay in this hotel very much.

The staff is so helpful and courteous they really went above and beyond for us for everything. The location is perfect for me I came for business and had a great stay. The rooms were always clean and attended to. This is the place to stay in Tokyo.

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is, for lack of a better word, outstanding. From the moment I arrived, I was treated with the utmost courtesy. Having been informed by my previous hotel of my impending arrival, the staff greeted me by name the moment the taxi doors opened. In the space of a minute, my luggage was out of the taxi and I was whisked away to the hotel lobby on the 38th floor. The check-in process was rather quick and arrangements for a departure taxi a few days later were reconfirmed. The Front Desk has a great view of Tokyo and I was almost reluctant to leave until I got to my room, and was rewarded with a similar view. Being able to see the Tokyo Skytree from the comfort of my room, is just a great way to start and end the day. The room itself is a little dated but still excellent. Bed is a bit on the harder side but still provided a good night's rest. The amenities provided were great, much like any other high end establishment, although I think this was the first time I'd seen a hotel provide a Yoga mat. Great for travellers who practice it. I was provided with a welcome refreshment and a lovely fruit platter, while the Front Desk staff gave me a brief explanation of the room. The bathroom design is rather unique, with the shower on the inside and the bath adjacent to it. As the shower area has no door, using the rain shower sometimes led to a little water reaching the wood flooring outside, a minor issue though. I must commend them for providing not only a rain shower but also a regular fixed shower head and a hand held shower. The shower gels and lotions were from Bottega Veneta, first time I'd seen that in a hotel. Closet area is reasonable in size and I liked that there's a small service compartment attached to it, meaning newspapers and letters could be delivered there and I wouldn't have to open the door in the morning just to take them in. A little indicator at the control panel near the door informs guests when something has been placed in the service compartment. I did have a slight issue with the toilet though, there was a trace of foul stench which housekeeping tried to rectify but even after 3 days, there was still a hint of it. Not a major problem though as it was not unbearable. As with most of my hotel stays, I generally don't dine in-house with the exception of breakfast and in this case, I must certainly praise the quality of the food provided. The selection was pretty good although I did wish that they had changed some of the staple meats and vegetables. By the third day, it was getting a little boring. Having said that, indeed the food was of good quality, fruits were fresh, bread rolls soft and tasty, juices tasty (not a fan of the carrot and ginger blend though). Special praise to Restaurant Manager Niccolo, who was even on hand to recommend the eggs benedict to me and boy was it a great recommendation. A beautifully poached egg, sourced locally, with a perfectly gooey and liquid yolk. I've never been a fan of poached eggs but that was fantastic. He was extremely attentive throughout a busy breakfast service and took quick looks to make sure my breakfast was going well. He was extremely hospitable but not intrusive. In terms of location, it's hard to find fault. The hotel is right above exit A7 of the Mitsukoshimae station on the Ginza Line, has underground access to the flagship Mitsukoshi and their excellent food hall, it is also a short walk to the JR Shin-Nihombashi station. This makes it rather easy to get around much of Tokyo. Food options in the Nihombashi area are decent but more along the typical restaurants in office buildings than small establishments. I was able to make my way to Disneyland within 30 minutes or so (including a long walk through Tokyo Station). Now to get to the point of this review, the service. The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo, has provided me with the finest service I've ever experienced in a hotel. Having stayed in the excellent Ritz Carlton Kyoto less than a week before arriving at MO, they had quite some standards to live up to. Well, they surpassed it. The arrival portion was efficient but it was from the tiniest hiccup that I took notice of their service orientation. Having had some luggage forwarded from RC Kyoto to MO, I was surprised that the luggage was not sent up after I checked-in, especially after I mentioned it to the bellman. After calling down to the Bell Captain, the luggage was promptly delivered with apologies for the mix up. Now here's where I was impressed, the next morning, when I was at the Bell Desk for a little assistance, the supervisor/manager on duty apologised again and asked me if everything was in order, and I had not even mentioned my name or room number yet. Then on my second morning, Restaurant Manager Niccolo, prior to recommending my breakfast order, also asked me again if I found everything ok, as he had been informed of the minor mistake with the luggage and again apologised. That was quite something, I would expect the Bell Captain would apologise as it was handled by their department but that they took the effort to try and recognise me, I'm certainly grateful. The restaurant manager following up on a luggage issue, wow! There were no words to describe how impressed I was. Besides that, whenever I approached the Front Desk or Concierge Desk, I was given the utmost attention and questions were answered immediately. All the staff I interacted with, speak excellent English, which really helped me, as I have no understanding of Japanese. When I was shopping at Sembikiya Fruit Store in the same building, I had difficulty communicating my concerns to the staff there, so I walked over to MO and asked the Bell Desk if they could get a staff to assist me for a few minutes. Immediately they sprung into action and within 30 seconds, they pulled a member of staff over to follow me to the store and help me translate. One of the concierge on the Night shift, was also extremely helpful in assisting me. She helped me make arrangements for a package to be sent to Hong Kong and liaised with the Business Centre on my behalf as well as kept her colleagues updated. Unfortunately I forgot the note down her name but I was again very grateful.I cannot stress enough, how good the service was. I did not want to leave the hotel when it came time to check out. The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo deserves every bit of praise they get and more. At the side entrance to the hotel, there sits a plaque on both sides of the door, stating that they are a 6 Diamond award winner from The American Academy of Hospitality Sciences. I'm not sure what the highest rating is, but as far as I'm concerned, 6 is not enough. One thing is for sure, I hope to go back to Tokyo soon and I already know where I'm staying.

What a spectacular hotel, located a short walk from the Tokyo Station. The lobby is on the 38th floor; my room was on the 30th floor, reached by the guest elevator, with an incredible view over the city. Print out the hotel map and use the names of the department stores and banks to easily find your way to this spectacular property from the train station. Don't miss their breakfast so beautifully served--I had crab eggs benedict with eggs from chickens fed special flowers to enhance the yolk's red color. I have stayed at Mandarin Hotels in New York, Las Vegas, Bangkok, Geneva and Hong Kong and this one topped them all. The room was spacious and comfortable and I was often greeted by name. The concierge had terrific maps of the entire subway and train lines and the local area around the hotel. Don't forget to check out the food department in the basement of next door Mitsukoshi Department store--unbelievable! Lunch at hotel's italian restaurant was also outstanding. Thank you MO for a wonderful stay!

The Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo is a glamorous, beautifully-designed hotel in the central business district of Tokyo. The staff is incredibly polite, willing to assist and user-friendly. Guests are warmly greeted upon arrival and departure. The lobby bar and lounges are elegant, well-designed and have amazing views of this sprawling metropolis. The rooms are elegantly appointed and the beds are comfortable---which is an important feature for jet-lagged guests.

Location: Directly above Mitsukoshi-mae Metro Station, underground connects to Mitsukoshi department store and Coredo malls. Excellent Location with many restaurants around .Service: Overall service is good. Bell on ground floor entrance and the Lobby Floor staff on 38Fl. are courteous and prompt.  Yet the concierge staff (except the two experienced ones) gave wrong info about Tsujiki Market and holiday. Oct 10 wasn't a public holiday, one concierge lady told me Tsujiki fish market closed for it's a public holiday and many Kaiseki and sushi restaurants closed that was not the case that confused us for we only had that day to explore among the busy meeting days. We did visit and eat at the Tsujiki market. We also had disappointed check-in experience.Room: Hardware is good, we had a panoramic view, though this trip was not the view with SkyTree but view was sweeping from Rainbow bridge to Shinjuku Highrise.. One morning with Fujiyama in sight. Pillows were too soft but the pillow menu was not in display. Requesting for additional teabags (English breakfast teabags not available) was slow since working long hours in room.Laudry service was very efficient.Restaurant: Great breakfast at Lounge . The American breakfast has fresh and sumptuous selection. Signature (French) with the open entrance, not quite fine dining. Food is ok not commensurate with the price.

Best service and efficiency I've ever come across, attention to detail was incredible, I would highly recommend this hotel. Location is excellent, breakfast and choice of food was good. I've stayed in many luxury hotels in my life, this was the best overall experience

Just returned from a 5 days trip to Tokyo with husband. Half Business trip and half relaxing getaway trip. We always try to stay at the Peninsula Hotel or the Imperial Hotel. This time, it was a very last minute arrangement, for some reason, 95% of the hotels in Tokyo that are of this category are full. Unbelievable.Luckily, after many tries, my travel agent found ONE last room at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo for us. I read the reviews, and didn't hesitate to book it. This hotel is so beautiful. We didn't want to leave. Next time we visit Tokyo, we will definitely stay here again.The location is in a quieter area. But because it is right above the Metro Ginza Line, everywhere we wanted to go was so convenient. Mitsukoshi department store is next door. There are plenty of restaurants around it, lots of convenience stores, number of coffee shops, airport limousine bus stops right in front of the main entrance. We took the NEX from Narita, arrived by 930pm, it took 5 minutes by taxi from Tokyo Station to get to the hotel. The hotel's check in lobby is on the 38th floor. Stunning view at night and in the day time. You can see the Skytree! Upon our arrival, the staff and bell captain took care of our luggage, and took us to the 38th floor. Check in was smooth, and the concierge was fantastic. I requested some restaurants that are michelin starred for reservations by email. She confirmed my reservations, and arranged all the confirmation papers, and maps for us upon our check in. Our room was on the 35th floor. Nothing to complain about. Beautiful. Love it. EXCEPT.... the pillows are TOO soft for our preference. Asked for harder pillows, gave us the memory foam kind, it was fine. Bottega Veneta Amenities in the bathroom. Love the fluffy slippers. Bottled water provided daily. King Size bed.The only complain is yes, they charge for Wi-Fi. So, before we arrived, I ordered a pocket wifi device from Rentafone Japan to deliver to our room. It was great to have everywhere in Tokyo. Often even in subways, on roaming, there is no signal from Docomo. So it was great to have it.I left by airport limousine bus to Narita early at 625am. Nothing was opened for coffee or breakfast. As I waited for my bus to arrive in the main entrance. The bell captain took care of my bags and luggage. There was a table of goodies like pastries, and coffee, tea or water for guests waiting. That is very considerate. As I waited, the bell captain offered me fresh towel, and newspaper. The bus arrived on time, and I was sent off by the staff with utmost professional manner and politeness. I arrived at Narita airport in about 1 hour and 15 minutes.Thank you Mandarin Oriental Tokyo, we will return very soon.

This is my 6th visit to MO Tokyo this year alone and I'm pleasantly surprised each time with there attention to detail in every aspect. The level of service, consistency and quality of food is truly unmatched. On average I spend 3 weeks of the months in a hotel and traveling all over the world, MO Tokyo by far is my most favourite hotel and city revisit.

Having stayed here three times over two years this has been well-maintained and consistent in quality and service. The rooms are clean The hotel is wonderful and the staff were really excellentoverall quality was great for the price!

Recently stayed 8 days from October 31st to November 8th at this hotel and it was absolutely heaven. The room, the view, the amenities and the staff will pamper you so you won't want to leave, ever! You feel like royalty! If you left your exercise gear behind..no worries - they have workout shoes (your size) and exercise outfit (if you need one) sent up to your room and the workout room has amenities and a view unmatched by any other. One of their staff has really long strides that no matter how hard I try to outrun him to the elevator, he still gets to it in time to press the button for us and bows until the elevator closes. :-) When you take a taxi, the staff makes sure the driver takes you to the correct address. When you're laden with shopping bags, the staff will run after you to take all of your bags up to your room! What I will miss most about Tokyo is Mandarin Oriental.

How could you ask for better?Room on floor 33 was had a large king bed, sitting area and desk. Bathroom had every amenity possible and a very large tub.View at night was staggering and yes, on two of our four mornings we managed to see the snow capped Mt. Fuji between two skyscrapers.Staff were wonderful. Concierge helpful and knowledgeable , house keeping was efficient and kept the place spotless, waiting staff were polite and remembered your name and what drink you wanted at breakfast.Location, with the metro in the basement and stores along the road, was perfect.Charged for wifi was the only, but very minor, niggle. That is unnecessary these days.Would we return? Absolutely.

On a clear day I could see Mt. Fuji from both my room (31st floor) and from the restaurants (38th floor). On a cloudy day and at night views of the city were spectacular. Being above both the rail lines and the major freeway, I was entertained without having any noise to interrupt this serenity.The staff was more gracious than one could imagine. All that deep bowing, running to hold an elevator, knowing my name at the front desk, the restaurants and in the downstairs lobby where you wait for taxis. But these next two situations explain why I felt cared for in a foreign country.As a woman traveling alone, I appreciate the fact the Mandarin Oriental always sends another woman for whatever needs I have. When I arrived, I realized I had come away without some of my medication. I made a list of what I was missing and took it down to the front desk, asking for help. They made some calls and had a young member of staff accompany me and to serve as translator to both the doctor's office and then to the pharmacy, both of which were in the same building. We spent at least 2 hours together. And it was delightful to be with a Japanese woman who, although part of the staff of this hotel, was filling me with conversation about Japanese home life.  And then I misplaced the 2 rings. And even though when I took them off after I returned to the room from breakfast, I couldn't find them when I was ready to leave the room for lunch. The front desk sent a woman immediately to help me look. Nothing. We looked high and low, on every surface top, in the bathroom, in the drawers. She left to check the waste baskets which were emptied during that time. When came back with another woman,they stripped the bed, used flash lights under/behind/above furniture.  We became desperate, and then they found the rings behind an assortment of boxes on top of the refrigerator. The three of us had tears and hugs all around. They didn't give up, even though I had. Both of these situations were my fault. But I was never made to feel foolish, thanks to all those quality people at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo. They just go above and beyond all expectations.With Love and Joy.

My family and I stayed here for four nights in October. Everything about the hotel is very nice. The rooms are well furnished and have fantastic views. The fitness center is well equipped.The concierge was very helpful during he stay but also before we arrived. I emailed back and forth with them trying to get restaurant reservations and they were always responsive. One of the restaurants didn't take reservations for another 2-3 weeks after my original email to the MO. I called the hotel on the day the reservations opened and they were already on it. Overall the staff is trained really well. There is ALWAYS someone around every corner in case you need something. My least favorite thing, and it is more of a MO thing and not just Tokyo, is that getting to your room from the street requires two elevators. This allows he lobby to have that wow factor but after a while it gets somewhat annoying.The location is nice in that you can get out and walk to interesting places. Tokyo is very spread out so as a tourist you're going to be getting in a taxi or public transportation to see other things. There is a subway station in the basement of the building which is very convenient.I've stayed at the Four Seasons as well and you can't really go wrong with either.

Perfect in everything : - modern large rooms with wonderful views ( Mandarin Grand room "offered" us the most spectacular views day & night ever on the mount Fuji and the skyline of Tokyo )- 3 excellent restaurants, all with amazing views, especially for dinner- service at its best, worldwideIt is the best hotel we ever visited in the world !

The obvious is that this hotel is flat-out gorgeous -- the design is modern yet warm, and the sprawling height of the lobby overlooks Tokyo through giant floor-to-ceiling windows. On a cloudy day it feels like you are above the entire city. The rooms are very spacious and tastefully appointed. Bathrooms are roomy, clean and modern. The service is the best I have ever experienced in any hotel in the world - period. From the bell desk to the front desk to the restaurants and concierge: everyone went above and beyond to make sure our stay was enjoyable without being intrusive. Everyone was kind, respectful, and polite. I have stayed at dozens of "5-star" hotels throughout the world, and can say with confidence that the service of the staff at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo is the best I have ever experienced.

The hotel provided a 5 star service throughout. Great place to return home after a busy day in the city. Excellent restaurants, the only slight letdown was the breakfast which was good but have still seen better at this class/level of hotel. Standard Rooms are decent size although not huge, but well equipped and with a fantastic view over the city day and night. Would not hesitate to recommend staying here.

I have just returned from a stay at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo, which I have to say is almost perfect. Sitting on the 30-37 floor, it has amazing views over Tokyo, and exudes a quiet calm, that only great hotels achieve. The service is achingly good, from bell boys' to operate the lift, to a concierge that is happy to deliver to your every need. The whole team of staff keep you at the centre of their attention, with the perfect courtesy and manners, one expects in Japan.Our room was large, and had everything one could ask for... at no point did we have anything to ask for twice or complain about.If there were any faults it would be that the hotel allows smoking in the bar, which I am told is customary in Japan. Coming from the UK where smoking is seen less and less, the ability to smoke, and odour it produces, is something I had happily forgotten. Also the hotel doesn't have a pool, which I think for many would be an expectation of a property like thisThis said these minor issues wouldn't stop me staying again, and it must be up there with one of the best 5 star hotels I have stayed in.

As longstanding fans of the MO group we had high expectations of this famous property and were not disappointed . As one always expects with the MO group , the standards are very high indeed but what sets this hotel apart is the warmth and exceptional professionalism of its welcome and service , the breathtaking views and very handsome surroundings . It is also very conveniently located and I'd highly recommend it for both business and leisure stays

I rarely if ever write reviews, I get home from a trip back to my daily life and don't think about it again. This is one of those times I feel compelled to write a review just to say the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo was the best hotel I have ever had the privilege of staying at. Every possible detail was taken into consideration. The service could not have been better. Every dining option at the hotel was a culinary experience not to be missed, when is the last time you could say that about a hotel. The spa is one of top rated in the city. The rooms have more amenities than I have seen in a very,very long time. They anticipated my needs before I even knew what they were, just incredible. The word "No" not in their vocabulary. I would visit Tokyo again just to stay here.

Cleanest place I have ever been. Absolutely perfect service, room had view of city below and all the twinkling lights and Mount Fuji.staff were polite, discreet and helpful. The food was beautiful....

My husband and me stayed a second time at MO Tokyo to celebrate a special occasion. Upon arrival, we were met with a series of heartwarming surprises ... room upgrade, cake, champagne and congratulations from the staff. Above all, we felt the hospitality of the hotel is just not only perfect but also with personal touches. Highly appreciate the ethos behind!Quality of hardware is guaranteed despite 9 years old. Staff always serves with professionalism while leaving guests comfortable personal space. Food is excellent; we simply loved the French restaurant, Signature, and also were so much satisfied with K'shiki and Oriental Lounge where we had our breakfasts to begin a day. And, we hoped we could have more time to taste every cake at Gourmet Shop which was a piece of art.We are already looking forward to another stay.

The views from behind the check in desk are jar dropping. After a few days there, I stopped being quite as stunned each time I walked by, but when we checked it, I could hardly concentrate as the city spread out in the distance from the giant windows behind the check in desk.Great location and on the top floors of the building that has a subway stop in it. We used the subway to get everywhere. It was very easy to use once you figured it out. We did download an app on our phone though because there are so many subway lines, it is hard to know how to get from point A to point B. Our room was amazing with similarly amazing views. We didn't us the concierge often but they were very helpful when we did ask them our couple of questions.Not sure if I have ever stayed in a hotel that high, but it was pretty cool. Also a great location in the middle of town. For a moment in time, we had looked at staying a the Park Hyatt and I would recommend the Mandarin Oriental over the Park Hyatt. The Park Hyatt is way on the west side of town and doesn't have a convenient subway stop and the subway is definitely a shockingly easy way to get basically everywhere.

Stayed here several nights with my husband - rooms are beautifully decorated in soothing shades with exquisite woodwork. The reception and concierge staff were not only extremely knowledgeable and efficient but also incredibly caring. Make sure to access the spa - a soak in the relaxing pools is a great way to start the day.

You check in on the 38th floor. Most buildings in Tokyo are relatively low due to the risk of earthquake. Not so The Mandarin. Its a giant in the area and therefore had incredible views across the city.As you check in, the views behind reception are breathtaking. We stayed on the 36th floor (2 down from reception) and we just stood and looked out of the window for about 10 minutes.The hotel itself is on a very busy main street, but of course very quiet due to the height. It's a bustling neighbourhood with its of top quality shops and restaurants. Even the fan shop that designed The Mandarin logo is only a couple of hundred meters away! I also strongly recommend Zohiko, a shop of the Japanese lacquer company established in 1661, which is just across the road from the hotel. Beautiful stuff and a great thing to take home to remind you of your trip and Japanese culture.The room itself has everything you expect of a Mandarin property and we liked the darker wood and bathroom used here than the brighter, more modern look at The Peninsula where we had stayed a few days earlier.The bar has amazing views in the evening. We eventually managed to get a window table and it was perfect. Apart from the smoke! They have to do something about smoking in bars and restaurants in Japan.Also, you have to pay for WiFi!!! Really? In this day and age? About £3 for an hour or £12 for 24.Apart from these annoying distractions we actually thought it had the edge on The Peninsula which is a shame! We spent 4 days at The Peninsula and only 1 at The Mandarin.My 2 cents? Go for The Mandarin, although of course, neither will disappoint.Oh, and a special mention for the lady at The Concierge desk at The Mandarin. She was excellent and sent us to the best beef restaurant and meal that I have ever. And that's saying something.

Possibly the best hotel I've stayed in yet. Spent 2 nights in a corner suite, and 4 nights in a standard room later on in our trip - even the standard room felt spacious and luxurious. The whole hotel in fact is light and airy, thanks to floor to ceiling glass everywhere. The bar and lobby are jaw dropping. Top notch service and staff, fab breakfast, doesn't really set a foot wrong. Had one dinner at Sushi Sora, which was really great. English speaking chefs prepare everything in front of you and explain what they're giving you, which adds to the experience (some meals in Japan we didn't really know what we were eating, which is fun in a different way). It will also go down in my personal history as the place in which my eyes and tastebuds were awakened to the good sake. I was offered six to try before picking one - all were very different, all delicious, and all unlike anything I'd ever had before. It was an education.If I had to pick quibbles: towels could be bigger and fluffier; DVD player but seemingly no DVD library; room service menu a bit limited. Binoculars in the rooms are a nice touch.

Great hotel, as would be expected. The concierge, Setsu, was a fantastic resource. She helped us to plan specific activities before our arrival and continued to help us during our stay. The one problem with this hotel - they charge for internet. It's amazing that hotels of this caliber are nickel and diming their guests. At this point in the 21 century, charging for the internet is like charging for hot water - I suppose it's an "extra" but it's a necessary extra for the stay to be seamless and enjoyable. I found this extra charge to be offensive, as I imagine others do too.

Mandarin Oriental Tokyo means hospitality industry at it’s best. In my opinion, MO Tokyo is the best hotel of the Mandarin Oriental chain (I’ve been to many of them) and most definitely one of the best hotels in the world. To me it's No. 1 in Tokyo. We spent three nights in early October in a beautiful Mandarin Suite and I would like to thank all of the highly motivated, warm hearted and perfection seeking staff for making this an unforgettable and faultless hotel experience. Unfortunately, Tokyo is not a holiday destination. If it was, I’d stay there all the time.

stayed at the Mandarin for 2 nights after the Suzuka grand prix , the staff are amazing very helpful and nothing is too much trouble. The hotel has great rooms with large bathrooms and a stunning view over the city - all rooms are on floors 33 and up so everyone gets a great view of one side of the city or the other. Neatly situated not far from central station this hotel is a classy joint.

We onlye went to the tea corner and it had such a beautiful views! Is the best viewer to see all Tokyo, it has a clean view of the Tokyo tower. The blend of the teas, as well as the service were impecables. Mandarin oriental are never disappointing.

Mandarin Oriental Tokyo was the third Mandarin hotel I've stayed and for sure it has the best service. Mandarin Oriental is well known as an impecable hotel with excellent service. In Japan it's better than ever. Japanese are very polite and kind people. The hotel is very beautiful with a modern decoration and has an icredible view from the Tokyo city. At the check-in reception you can get a glimpse of what is going to be your trip in Tokyo. The city view is amazing from the reception desk. The room is large enough for a couple and it has a beautiful view of Mt Fuji. The room has a lot of tecnology from the curtains to the toilet. I highly recommend Mandarin Oriental for those who love luxury and impecable service.

My family and I thoroughly enjoyed our stay. Every staff at the hotel was so warm and helpful. Will be back. Memorable! There's always a buzz in the lobby yet it feels relaxed and easy going. I loved the view of the city from the WC's. Stunning! F & B outlets excellent. Stunning views. Proximity to Ginza also great.

Service was amazing. Thank you to the European chap in breakfast for making us feel special.Location is great. Very close to Ginza, which was my favourite spot.The level of English was okay as I find Japanese accent very hard to understand.Rooms could have been better furnished, but hey that differs with taste.I gave this hotel 4 stars just because of one reason, and that was the TV. As a Mandarin Oriental located in Tokyo (the tech hub of the world), one would expect a new TV. But if you still use a TV from 10-15 years ago, that to me is being plain CHEAP! Charging those prices, you would get your money back for the new TVs within two months!

The service at the hotel is truly remarkable. I had never experienced anything like it before. The staff member that checked me in was very kind, and walked me around to give me a tour, and walked me all the way to my room and inside. Being new to Japan, I tried to tip her but she refused to take it very politely. The level of English of the staff is much better than other high end hotels in the area.To give another example of the high level of service: One morning I had breakfast in one of the restaurants and ordered an egg white omelet with asparagus. The next morning, I ate in the other restaurant that serves breakfast, and the server there asked me if I would like an egg white omelet with asparagus! Keeping track of customers preferences between multiple restaurants goes above and beyond expectations.I had one of the corner rooms which had great views from the 36th floor. The long rectangular shape of the room did make it feel a bit smaller than it actually was, however still a decent size. The bathroom and shower were great. I remember being impressed at how quickly the bath tub could fill with water.The restaurant and bar areas were wonderful. There was a live Jazz at night, and the views simply make the place a pleasure to be at.

Beautiful hotel and stunning room and views. The decor and little touches were lovely as was the huge soaking tub. The only complaint is that front staff/reception was a bit cold, seemed odd. Had dinner at tapas molecular bar which was also fabulous although a very light meal and very expensive. Drinks at the bar were delicious but also expensive. Would return!
user_name:
maryanne007newyork
New York City, New York

review_body: Our stay at MOTYO was an absolute delight. Whilst the luxurious touches were expected, it was the service that took this hotel to another level. No question was too trivial for the staff, and no request too much trouble.The staff that we encountered were stellar across the board. Special mention goes to the knowledgeable and helpful concierge desk staff who were generous with suggestions and printouts of the areas that we were planning to visit. We received such a warm welcome that our children didn't want to leave! They were ushered into the lobby with a selection of plush toys - both chose an adorable panda bear in a liveried Mandarin Oriental uniform. This star treatment continued in the bedroom with fresh cookies and a box of popcorn laid out, along with chilled milk in the fridge. The bedroom itself was spacious and beautifully appointed, with 2 beds that were just slightly smaller than a queen bed. A pair of binoculars was provided to take full advantage of the stunning view of the Tokyo Sky Tree from the floor to ceiling window. Another thoughtful touch was the bottle of lavender scent provided at turn down. The bathroom was large and well laid out. The unique Japanese WC experience was new for our kids and they couldn't get over the washing feature and the warm toilet seat. What a joy to come back to the large bath tub with bath pillows after a long day of exploring Tokyo. In-room dining was impeccable - the noodles with vegetable tempura, corn soup and macaroni and cheese that we ordered were delicious. The variety and quality of the food at the buffet breakfast was likewise excellent. Upon hearing that we were vegetarian, the gracious manager arranged for vegetarian noodles to be prepared for us. The solicitous and polite service received was most appreciated. The location of the hotel in a business district suited us just fine. We found it convenient to take a taxi to/from Tokyo Station when using the subway system, or to use the Mitsukoshimae station in the basement when using the line going to Shibuya. Taxis can be found waiting along the road next to Mitsukoshi, which is just next to the tower that houses MOTYO. The astounding food hall in the basement of Mitsukoshi is a must-visit when staying at MOTYO!

Good size comfortable room with great views over Tokyo especially at night when the city really comes into its own. Breakfast was okay with good choice of western and Asian dishes, the food was generally good quality. The interior lobby looked great with beautiful flowers and decor and the staff were exceedingly helpful for every request during our stay.Recommend the little coffee shop where you can sit outside at street level and watch the world go by....

This room is beautifully appointed, and the amenities and extras have been better than other top hotels. The room has an incredible view of Tokyo, especially magical at night. There are automated blinds and curtains... Really enjoying my stay, one of the best hotels that I have stayed in and my expectations have been exceeded!

it has all been said before...from my personal observation:-pluses- lovely facilities, comfortable rooms, excellent service, remembered earlier email requests for late checkout minuses - smoking in bar area, french fries were served cold, cocktails were not good, I didnt like the toiletries providedoverall - excellent.

I was blown away by this hotel! This was my first visit to Tokyo. I have always heard that Asian luxury properties were amazing; in the case of the Mandarin, this is absolutely true. I have stayed in a number of luxury hotels in the states, but this was more than a step above.  The staffs in the hotel and the restaurants I ate in were incredibly accommodating without being intrusive. I was very pleased at the way they anticipated what I needed. The house keeping staff did an incredible job, with little touches like putting a book mark in a Lonely Planet guide that I had left out. The room was immaculate. One thing in particular that I liked was the hotel and room smelled very nice, without being over powered by heavy scents. My room, 3525, was beautiful. I wanted to take the bathroom home with me! The tub was decadently deep. The shower had both an overhead "rain" head and a regular shower head, along with a hand held attachment. Yes, what they say about Japanese toilets is true! The bed was beautiful, the linens exquisite. I toured several hotels in Tokyo (I am a travel consultant), and the room size at the Mandarin is much larger than the typical luxury hotel in Tokyo. The view was jaw dropping, with the Tokyo Sky Tree dominating on my side of the hotel. I can not recommend this hotel enough!

I love the Mandarin chain of hotels. Every time I have stayed at one of the properties, I have been rewarded with absolutely exceptional service, stunning facilities, and unforgettable experiences. The brand is strong and consistent across the board, and Tokyo is no exception.This was my first trip to Japan, and though I have limited knowledge of Mandarin Chinese (useful for signs!) I know zero Japanese, so I was a little bit overwhelmed while planning the trip. The Mandarin truly put us at ease:(1) Before arriving, I sent an email to the concierge to have them help me make restaurant reservations and other bookings. Not a problem. When we checked into the hotel, they provided us with detailed information about our reservations and directions on how to get there. (2) Checking-in, we were greeted warmly by reception, who also personally walked us to the room and explained al of the amenities and features of the hotel in general and our room specifically.(3) The room was incredible. It was spacious with unbelievable views over Tokyo. The bathroom was small, but still had enough space for a separated toilet, a full bath/jacuzzi, and a shower. The amenities were fantastic—they provide you with hair brushes, head bands to keep the hair out of your face while you wash, toothbrushes & toothpaste, mouthwash, etc. Turn down service was also great. They provide you with a fresh bucket of ice and purified water in your kettle, complementary bottles of water, as well as some chocolates on your nightstand.(4) The beds were superb. I slept like a baby the first night there, despite the jet lag. (5) The fitness center was great. Opened 24 hours, I would come down here bright and early in the morning to enjoy a quick morning workout while enjoying the sunrise. Fresh juices and fruits are also provided to you for a rewarding post-workout snack.(6) Restaurants and lounge are superb. We ate at the Tapas Molecular bar our first night, which was an incredible experience. The food was fantastic, but more importantly, our chefs had so much personality and truly felt passionate about what they prepared that they made the guests feel truly at ease and have a joyful experience. We also enjoyed afternoon tea here a couple of days, which is an incredible experience as well. The desserts are delectable and the service is exceptional.(7) Excellent spa facilities and wonderful service. I received the Aromatherapy Associates facial while I was there, and I was absolutely glowing afterwards. I was surprised at how great my skin looked for the next few days! The specialist doing my facial was very professional and kind, and she also gave me a great massage while I was wearing my masks. Facilities are beautiful as well, as are the amenities provided for you. Very expensive though--much more than I would pay in the US, and if you are expecting extractions, it doesn't seem like this is what they do for facials.Only downside is location. It was at least 20-25 minutes to many of the prime tourist and shopping areas (with the exception of Tsukiji, which is relatively close). However, you're on the Ginza subway line at Mitsukoshimae Station, which makes it pretty convenient to get to the Sensoji temple at Asakusa station or Shibuya and Harajuku going the other direction. To get to Shinjuku, you can take the JR trains from the Kanda station or take the Ginza metro and switch trains.

This hotel was great! The rooms were really nice and lobby has a nice waiting area. The staff was so helpful with all our needs. This made the world of difference, since once we got into the city no one on the street was helpful with directions.

The suite in room 3215 is simply stunning. It has the view of Tokyo, so beautiful. The bed is large and comfortable, and the bathroom is so spacious that it can fit in the entire family!The staff are so friendly and forever willing to help.This has been one of my best stays so far

An exceptional stay ! an amazing staff, from reception, concierge to restaurants without forgetting the lounge ! This is my third stay and I sincerely hope not to be the last. I highly recommend this hotel for travelers of high expectations like me. The Japanese luxury experience with elegance and utmost kindness. Thank you ! and congratulations to management who has definitely done a wonderful job to make us feel at home away from home. Domo arrigato gozaimachta !!

I have stayed at a lot of expensive hotels, but no other hotel have made me feel the way Mandarin Oriental does.The service level in Japan is high by default, but the service here is spotless. Doesn't matter if you are just arriving to the hotel, checking in at the reception, asking the concierge for restaurant recommendations or getting your room cleaned. They all do their job 110% and with a big smile and a kind heart. I have never been treated so well as at Mandarin Oriental Tokyo.The rooms are big with a Japanese touch that I really like. Room has a lot of features and gadgets that are helpful and you won't be missing a thing.Breakfast is splendid and the hotel have some of the best restaurants in the area, if not in Tokyo.If I could afford it I would live at Mandarin Oriental for the rest of my life.

We stayed here four nights and the hotel, the location and service went beyond my expectations! Can warmly recommend this hotel, as you will get a customized service and experience in the center of Tokyo. The hotel is on top of a metro do you can go anywhere. The concierge paid attention to your needs and made spot on recommendations if restaurants, shopping and sightseeing, and even arranged everything for you. We will most certainly come back!

We stayed in Mandarin end of July for a week. I have visited few Mandarins around Asia, I think this one is one of the best.1. Amazing service2. Good location. Ginza area, many restaurants, shopping malls and metro station.3. Amazing food. Breakfast choice not so high (quantity), but quality of the food is perfect. I recommend amazing Benedict eggs with a crab meat for the breakfast!4. Big rooms (for asia).Only disadvantage , there is no pool.P.S. Special thanks for Ludmila (I think she is from Moldova), she is a russian speaking person working on the reception. She was extremely friendly and helpful, explaining where to go and how to reach the place. For example, she went with our friend to metro and helped him to purchase the ticket (not so easy to do it for the 1st time in Tokyo:) ). Next time in Tokyo we will stay in the same hotel.Regards,Denis and Tania

I was at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo last week end and I had a really experience. As usual with Mandarin Oriental rooms are beautiful, chic and comfortable. Staff are experienced, smart and fully dedicated to delight customers and there you really feel like a guest! The lobby view is stunning. The hotel location is highly strategic for shopping! I had 2 concerns that will need to be considered:1. Price was really high while it was clearly impossible to get a couple of hours late check out! They were saying during the booking the hotel was full was it was not.2. They made a pre-payment with the credit card I had presented at the reception of the double amount of the the cost of the two nights I stayed without informing me when they did it. I got the the information from the bank who contacted me few minutes after the check in! I believe it could have been smarter and professional to inform me about this transaction.

I have to say that this is one of the best hotels I have stayed at in Tokyo, and one of the better ones I have stayed at anyplace. I have been to several of the MO properties before and I have never been disappointed, and this stay was no exception. The level of service from everyone that you deal with was high, even by Japanse standards. Check-in was quick and easy. The room was perfect and the view was outstanding. Everyone that you deal with, from the greating at the entry until the time you leave wants to make your stay perfect.It is hard to pick out anyone to comment on, because everyone did such a good job, but my intereactions with the concierge, who when contacted before our stay via email, was even more outstanding. I was so happy they were able to secure a very difficult reservation at a wonderful restaurant (Sukiyabashi Jiro) and were great to talk with. Thank you. The location of the hotel was a little bit away from Tokyo Station, about a 15 min walk. This did not pose a problem, but is worth making note of. If you did not feel like the walk, cabs are easy to come by.This will become my new Tokyo hotel and I am looking forward to my next stay.

My review basically echoes what others on TA have said, but I think it's still important to get another data point out there. This hotel is truly fantastic. From the minute you arrive at the hotel the service is second to none. I only had to give my name once during my entire stay (well I had to give my room number the first morning at breakfast too, so maybe twice for 5 days). The staff strikes the perfect balance of being warm and friendly (as opposed to stuffy) and being incredibly attentive without being intrusive.Breakfast is my favorite example of this. The buffet is simply fantastic, the selection and quality is top notch. I'm not exaggerating by saying the service at breakfast is better than every high-end restaurant I've been to in the United States, including per se. The manager/maitre'd instantly appears after you sit and offers coffee, juice, and eggs including their amazing eggs benedict with crab. If you don't want eggs he will come up with other suggestions for you! When you start filling a plate the staff will bring it to your table, and if you get up they will clear your plate and fold your napkin, every time without fail.
