We had a stakeholder’s conference there last month and everything was perfect. The rooms are truly luxurious, comfortable and really beautiful. My experience was flawless and I think this hotel delivers the expectations we have of a five star hotel. The staffs are very friendly and the service excellent. The restaurants are awesome and server some of the best dishes in Tokyo. Built above an office block, this hotel offers spectacular aerial view of Tokyo. This indeed a great hotel and I will give it a five star rating and recommend it to anyone looking for a luxurious place to stay in Tokyo.

I stayed here for one night whilst in Tokyo and it was fantastic.A great room, an amazing view, super staff and an all round awesome place to stay. Lots of shops and restaurants nearby and great transport links too!Would thoroughly recommend it!

I've really enjoyed my stays at this Mandarin property. The staff go above and beyond every time and I am surprised by some of the reviews however, I do not mind some of the issues mentioned in previous comments. Overall, I look forward to staying here and the location in Tokyo is perfect for my needs.

A fantastic hotel with great facilities and impeccable service. The hotel experience from the food to the rooms to the gym are all top class. The only drawbacks are: (1) location is not great, especially if you plan to spend time in Shinjuku, Roppongi, Shibuya areas - either an expensive taxi ride or a walk/subway ride, and (2) two elevator rides, one up and one down, to get to your room.

I just finished writing an email to the Chief Executive of Mandarin to express my gratitude, not only for the amazing accommodations and service, but for the additional care and attention provided to me on a recent stay.Mid-way through my business trip I needed emergency medical attention. The staff of the hotel went beyond, to connect me with an excellent doctor, to ensure I receive all my personal belongings and additional items to guarantee a comfortable hospital stay. Following my discharge, I stayed an additional two nights, while waiting for a flight back to USA. The warm welcome back and genuine concern were expressed in the most wonderful ways by the Mandarin team.Looking forward to my next stay at the Mandarin, hopefully under less eventful circumstances.

Mandarim Oriental is the best Hotel I have ever been. It worths every penny. It is perfect on each detail. I would not chance anything even if I could. I will be back at Mandarim Oriental. It is beyond expextations.

The mandarin Oriental Tokyo is absolutely Stunning, divine, and beautiful,we stayed there for a week and had the most amazing experience. It is a true Five Star hotel. the experience was absolutely flawless, the people working in the hotel, the restaurants, the breakfast, the rooms, which are really large for a city like Tokyo, with the amazing Aroma Therapy products in the bathrooms, but also the Spa with its incredible with the view on Tokyo. I also love that the location in rigth in Ginza.Clearly one of the top five best luxury Hotels in the world (equals One and Only, Cipriani, Taj and Oberoi). Truly Beyond perfection, flawless, a true Diamond. Unfortunately both the Mandarin Oriental in Hong Kong were not as nice.

Have stayed at all the nice hotels in Tokyo. I thought the Peninsula was the best (probably still has the best location for work). But when it comes to design and service, nothing touches this mandarin. The people are incredibly helpful. Had a couple of business issues flare up. And the staff were very helpful and gracious. The bar on 37th floor is great. Views are spectacular. And the drinks are perfect. Highly recommend.

I spent 2 nights in Tokyo for business trip. This is my first time for staying Mandarin Oriental. The room are extremely nice and big. Comparing other hotels in Japan, I already expected the room will not be as big as the standard around the world. But this hotel is out of my expectation. The staffs are well trained. A mandarin speaking staff was arranged immediately even I didn't ask to. The dining experiences there are nice too, although it's quite expensive and I could find wider range of food just outside the hotel. All in all, nice stay here!

I stayed for 11 consecutive nights. My partner and I arrived late in from KL so I asked the hotel to arrange a driver for us. From the moment we sat in the Mercedes until we left the experience was flawless.Nothing is to much trouble and the staff are very friendly and always remembered to call us by our family names.The bar and the restaurants are 10 out of 10, special mention to Sushi Sora... The restaurant only has 8 seats so be sure to book in advance. If money is not an issue, please only stay at the Mandarin Oriental while in Tokyo.

For sure the best hotel I ever been.Facilities, staff, location...Impossible to do not take profit of the spetacular view to the recent oppened tokyo sky tree or the city view from the 38th floor or from the wide gkass walls of the rooms.Please go to the 38th floor and see the restroom. The best toillet in the word I assure.

This is a truly unique location. Built above an office block, with Reception on the 38th floor, all the rooms, restaurants and bar command stunning views over Tokyo. The Bar on #37 has waterfalls, a pool with a sofa on an "island" and a great atmosphere. The rooms are luxurious, including heated toilet seats in the en suites.We ate in several of the restaurants, where service was flawless and food excellent quality - western menus widely available if you don't fancy the sushi! It is not cheap, but you get what you pay for. Being right on top of the Metro station makes getting around easy, and the department store across the road is ideal for shopping.We had a slight misunderstanding on Checkout, but the way the hotel dealt with it was great, which is always a key measure for me. I would thoroughly recommend this hotel, and go there again if we return to Tokyo.

Located at a more quiet business oriented part of Toyko not far from Ginza, it definitely a luxury choice if you don't mind the slightly off location, still convenient with Metro station right below the hotel. Hotel is of the high standard you would expect from a Mandarin. Room is spacious and service was generally attentive. And their Japanese restaurant is a must try!

We greatly enjoyed our stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. We loved the restaurants, the fitness center, the amenities in the room, the views and the extremely helpful staff. Location was very convenient (we were there on holiday) and close to the subway. Have nothing but nice things to say about our stay (except that I wish we could have stayed longer!)

Just back from a great holiday in Tokyo, having stayed in this hotel. Can't fault it in any way, great views, excellent concierge (especially Eriko) and our bedroom was probably the best one we have ever stayed in. I would thoroughly recommend this hotel.

What a great way to start and end our holiday in Japan. A first class hotel with good restaurnts offering great choice. The hotel accomodation was fantastic as was the service. Views of Tokyo from the room, restraunts and reception are amazing.

I have been to many hotels around the world including some Mandarin Oriental and even tough I was disappointed with them in Hong Kong and London, in Tokyo I was astonished, the hotel is beautiful with beautiful views, the restaurants and room service are great (A special award should be given for breakfast and especially to the breakfast manager), and everybody in the hotel is so nice and helpful that it is nearly incredible. I cannot wait to come back !

Second stay for me there after a short trip a few years back.Stayed 5 nights on a business trip where I brought my wife and 8 months daughter.Initially was offered a room with 2 twin beds, called the hotel the day of our arrival and managed to get a room with a king size bed, and a crib for our child.Took us 25 minutes from Haneda airport to get there, staff took care of us the second we came out of the taxi and by the time we checked in our luggages were already in the room waiting for us.Can't get any better than this. luxury hotel combined with Japanese quality of service (used to live in Japan for a few years but still amazed me).Great room with a great attention to details, view on Marunouchi (financial district), the imperial palace garden, and more important we were facing the Mount Fuji.Everything to make sure that my daughter was well taking care of, from the crib, the baby bathtub, the baby lotions and a small toy.Food and room service was great, had dinner in our room couple of times and never disappointed. Try the bento box, will give you a good Japanese experience, and good deal even for USD50 per bento.Restaurants at the hotel includes a French restaurant which I never tried, supposedly very good and expensive.Otherwise, a more casual place where they serve breakfast buffet, great food, views, service,... And not overcrowded, even on a week end. We also had lunch in the restaurant near the front desk with couch, good food but limited choices, better place for a cocktail or to have tea. i tried the molecular restaurant before, tasty and fun, but probably not cheap, and I tried the Chinese restaurant which was nice. The bar on the 37th floor is nice too. On one night, we left the baby in our room with our former helper for a dinner out, we wanted sushi on a Sunday night (which is usually difficult to find), went to the concierge who suggested SeaMon right across from the hotel (Coredo building). Great pick, small sushi place that can seat 10 people at most. We had the omakase ( chef's picks menu, JPY15,000 per person), a bit pricey (if you add Sake) but great experience. Our chef spoke a bit of English which helped. I would recommend it.Ideal location if you come for business and/or you work in the financial industry.Overall a great experience, but not a surprise for me, this is Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo, so this is as good as it gets. You get what you pay for.

The MO was without a doubt one of my best hotel experiences. From checking in, making reservations for restaurants and ease of using Tokyo's metro service this hotel was so good I can't even verbalise how good. Breakfast is delicious and tasty, the size and comfort of rooms is unparalleled (and I stay in five star hotels a lot). The staff are courteous, polite and go out of their way to help. A special mention needs to go to one of the downstairs bellboy staff (I think his name was yoshi) who was so helpful (directions, help in wrapping a screen i wanted to bring back), his English was amazing and his friendliness made the stay extra special because he had a knack for remembering who you are and asking how your day went (but like he actually cared!).The views are spectacular and after visiting the New York bar in the park Hyatt I would say the bar in the MO is far more fun, classy and drinks of a higher quality (sampled quite a few cocktails.... All incredible!).The hotel room has fantastic views, is spacious, functional and has some gadgetry but not enough to overwhelm. Thoughtful chocs and complimentary water daily. Beds are super comfortable.... Wet room and deep bath as well as fancy toilet.I never made it to the spa (for shame but this means I can come back)... Be warned that you can only go at certain times if you are not having a treatment and still have to pay for the privilege! Other than that I would recommend this hotel for a different piece of luxury. Yes it's not in the busiest part of Tokyo but its a hop, skip and a jump away from those areas. For what you are getting at the MO I think that it's worth going for to make your experience of Tokyo the best it can be! I plan to go back very soon! I loved it

We were greeted at street level by management and felt privileged. The hotel lobby sits at the top of the building on the 38 floor. It provides stunning views of Tokyo. The concierge was outstandingly helpful. Our room was beautifully appointed and comfortable. The bar area was separated into groupings so it felt private. The breakfast was a feast.

The hotel provided an excellent services similarly to Shangri la. The receptionist accompany me to the room with complimentary lemonade. The room was quiet good and comfortable. It is very close to Ginza street which is a plus. I really enjoyed the Hotel.

The Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Tokyo is (literally) way above the rest. Not only does it physically tower over other hotels in Tokyo, but in every other way, this awesome hotel caters to your every whim. The service is superb, the spa is a welcome respite from the stresses of travel and every thing from the delicious buffet breakfast to bedtime is a treat. This top notch hotel also offers a great location

The Mandarin Oriental in Chun, Tokyo certainly fits the pattern of a luxury hotel: the views are magnificent, as the hotel rooms are located on the top floors of a Tokyo tower with views to the city center. The rooms are spacious, extremely comfortable, luxurious and every detail is taken into account. However, the star of the hotel must be its fabulous concierge staff: every request is attended to diligently and successfully. We traveled as part of sizable business delegation and had many last minute requests and changes to the agenda: all of these were received with a smile and given the utmost attention until they were solved. Congratulations to the staff and keep up the good work.
user_name:
Jorge C
Dubai, United Arab Emirates

review_body: ..... which is that it has two lobbies, one at ground level and one at the 38th Floor which is where check-in is. This can be confusing when arranging to meet "in the lobby" even when it is a fellow guest. That said the hotel is otherwise superb with amazing views and excellent rooms.

What an exceptional hotel. Convenient location, easy walk to Ginza and right above a subway station to get you further. Staff were perfectly helpful, without being intrusive. Only ate for morning breakfast, which was a nice, if not small buffet, but it had enough for us. I would have given 5 stars, but having to pay for wi-fi in a hotel of this standard loses that rating.

Amazing. Every single staff person I encountered was gracious and helpful. I've decided when I win the lottery I will just move in here permanently. I am a spa junkie and I can say the shower in the rooms are top notch! I would not hesitate to stay here again, and again, and again. I would definitely 1000% recommend this hotel to all my friends & family.It truly is like heaven here :)

For 40 years the Mandarin Hotels have been my first choice. Since its' opening the Tokyo property has been a stand out voted the best hotel in world by the Financial Times recently. During my last stay I was once again Mandarined. When used as verb it means the hotel out did itself in accommodation and service. There was not a request I made that was not fulfilled promptly and correctly From the airport pick-up to the greeting to the room to the food to the drop off at the airport everything was excellent I complement Mr Costa and his fine staff

My husband and I recently travel to Tokyo and Kyoto, Japan as well as Seoul, South Korea. During the Tokyo leg of our tour we made the Mandarin our home base and I am certainly glad we did! To begin with, we were exhausted from our 13 hour direct flight from Houston so to arrive at such a wonderful place certainly helped ease our exhaustion. The rooms are wonderful, the staff is amazing, the breakfast was perfect. Honestly, we did spend almost every day out and about, but it was so wonderful to come back to. The concierge was incredibly helpful with dinner suggestions, travel directions to Kyoto and anything else we could have needed. The service at breakfast every morning was impeccable. My husband and I have stayed in our fair share of nice places around the world, but I believe the Mandarin provided the most seamless and perfect service I have ever experienced. The old saying, "you get what you pay for" certainly rings true. While it isn't cheap, I do believe it was worth every penny for the comfort, quiet and service that it provided.

We did a three day stay here in September and still remember it fondly. The good-Excellent breakfast buffet that puts most others to shame. It was inventive, delicious and a beautiful sight to dine at in the morning. My wife wished there were more Japanese breakfast items though. I was satisfied with the well-made dim sums.- attentive porters and bell hops. Kind and friendly and always around. -.pillow bedtime menu. Choose your preferences for a good nights sleep- free jazz event on Saturday nights with more.creative food in Asian tapasThe Bad- take a cab from Tokyo station. It's farther when you have bags in hand but not a bad walk from the Nihonbashi Yaesu exit.- housekeeping does great work but they should have left when my wife and I were getting ready for a function. It's only common sense that you vacate when the guests come back in.- Spa is small and an extra charge.We liked the MO but there's others in Tokyo to check out on our next stay.

I am normally a budget traveller under my own steam, however I ended up with some amazing luck and was able to stay at the Mandarin Oriental as part of a work trip in August. What an experience! The staff were friendly and attentive from the first moment I stepped in to the moment I left, which fitted exactly with what I had heard of Japanese culture. The staff around the 37th floor bar and restaurant area would even remind us to watch our step everywhere around the area (a few steps around). We were taken by individual staff members and went through the check in process in our rooms! I found out later they normally do this for VIP's and celebrities, so I felt quite special! I couldn't get over the view from my room (which, even though was a standard room, was quite large), the cityscape is amazing and I slept with the curtains open! We had a cocktail reception outside the Chinese restaurant and the canapes were great, good selection of wine, and the breakfast buffet was fantastic. My only... ONLY... complain is that, as a non-smoker who is not used to smoking inside, is that from the reception area on the 38th floor you can smell the smoke from the bar area on the 37th floor. I don't mind too much, but I know other non-smokers would kick up a massive fuss about this. There are some great little local eateries around the Nihonbashi area, and although the hotel is walking distance to the Imperial Palace gardens, there is a rail station right underneath the hotel so it makes it really easy to get anywhere.

This hotel is absolutely brilliant! The rooms have a great view, good facilities, and are of a great size. The staff are very polite, efficient and good humoured, they also helped out when we were had a hitch to our travel plans due to the typhoon. The breakfast selection is outstanding. We ate in a couple of restaurants, which were very good and obviously the service is excellent.

My husband & I started our 2-week Japan holiday with three days at the Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo. We'd never been to the country before and, knowing how jet-lag hits when flying East, thought we'd truly treat ourselves while we re-adjusted.Tokyo is as vast, loud, neon and crazy as we imagined it might be, so the Mandarin Oriental, located less than 10 minutes walk from Tokyo Station, became our haven.It took us some effort to find the hotel entrance the first time, located in what otherwise seems to be an office building, but after that it was easy. Perched some 30 floors up, it has incredible views of the city. We didn't bother going to the SkyTree in the end, as the hotel view was so good. We've never been to a Mandarin Oriental before so I have no frame of reference relatively, however, I'm usually suspicious of anything that's part of a chain, no matter how small and luxurious that chain is. I was very pleasantly surprised - it had the feeling that all the decor was unique for that location - and, true to Japanese form, decor was beautiful. Our room was huge, which I wasn't expecting. Service was as gracious as we experienced throughout Japan - your bags always carried all 30 floors down and to the front door. Any negatives? - we enjoyed drinks at the bar when we returned from dinner - fantastic ambience, better than anywhere we could find out. But, cocktail making isn't their forte. Hendrix and tonic served with lime, not cucumber and one spicy cocktail I had to send back because it was burning my mouth. It's a minor point. Also extras are insanely expensive. We just couldn't justify the spa costs. But then again, this isn't trying to be a budget-friendly choice. Just felt these were over-priced, even for a luxury hotel.Overall - absolutely wonderful, perfect start to the holiday, would absolutely recommend.

I have stayed in most of the five star hotels in Tokyo and the Mandarin Oriental is now my new favorite. The ambience is lovely, the service is superb (just ask, and whatever you need is promptly provided), the rooms are spacious, elegant and comfortable and the location is excellent. There is no bad view from the hotel. If you aren't afraid to take the subway, the station is connected to the hotel. Even better, Mitsukoshi, with its over-the-top food hall, is connected underground to the hotel. The hotel's food is extremely expensive, but the wonderful comprehensive breakfast buffet (everything from flaky croissant to dim sum) is well worth it.

The greatest hotel in Tokyo, excellent service, food, amenities and service. The staff will pamper you at the maximum. The view that the lobby and the rooms have is breathtaking. Any assistance you might need as a japanese non speaker the concierge will sort it out for you and help you with anything you might need. From the momento you book, everything runs smoothly, you kind of feel sad to leave the place when you check out.

We've stayed in other Mandarin Oriental hotels and have always been very impressed with the excellent level of personal service, however, we felt the Tokyo MO didn't live up to our expectations. The staff were friendly when we checked in and out, but for the majority of our stay they did not interact with us at all. I think there was only two times during our 4 day stay that there was someone at the lifts or entrance to the hotel. Normally, that wouldn't matter to us but we do expect more from MO.The room we were in had an excellent view of the city that was even more spectacular at night. Other than that the room was nice and comfortable with pleasant amenities. I thought the bathroom could have been more nicely designed though. I was not a fan of the shower since it seemed rather cold and breezy without a door. Also, the water pressure was not very good and the rain head was completely useless because of the size of the shower. The room service we ordered on one night was really excellent though. The staff member that brought it was very nice and conscientious, even down to being concerned that the burger we ordered had slide and the bun and some of the toppings had shifted. Honestly, I think she might have been the one staff member that really lived up to the high MO standards we have seen at other properties.Overall, our stay was pleasant but it wasn't as spectacular as I had expected from a Mandarin Oriental. I will say though that the price represented a very good value. The hotel is impeccably clean and while not outrageous spectacular, was very nice.

We were so excited to spend 4 nights here during Holy Week in a suite only to be sadly disappointed in the end. This is the only Mandarin Oriental I have been to in the world that I will not be returning to. Pros -- Beautiful views from the room and lobby, Breakfast and the personalized service of the waitstaff during breakfast. Subway stop and restaurants right underneath the hotel. Cons -- everything else. All other Mandarins are very accommodating and they don't really say "am sorry we cannot ____" to their customers, they generally do all possible to accommodate requests. Here they could not give us an upgrade (even if our reservation had automatic upgrade if available, they were giving us a smoking room even if I mentioned that we had a toddler and requested non smoking, in the end they gave us a non smoking room with a so so view ), they could not give us a late checkout, they could not give us a bill where the billing format matched the confirmed rate we booked (they are the ONLY hotel in the world that I could not for the life of me understand the bill). They did not tidy up/fix our room properly -- the curtains were always hanging on a piece of furniture in the living room and never fully closed or opened (so we had to fix this every time we came back in the evening). Our toiletries and other items by the bathroom sink were never organized and left unkempt (I thought all hotels generally fixed/tidied up all items in the bathroom). Our TV did not work for the first day and on the last 3 days, you had to point the remote control literally about 5 inches from the tv for it to actually work. So I could not watch tv in bed, I had to get up each time I wanted to change the channel. They did not have pillows for my toddlers crib. For room service the items we ordered were miniscule - they looked like amuse bouches instead of main courses. Even my easily satisfied toddler was hungry after his meal. For a supposedly 6 star hotel this should not be happening. We frequent Japan and have stayed at the Conrad, Park Hyatt and Hyatt Regency in Kyoto and we felt much more special during our stays there. I am not a fan of this Mandarin.

We really liked our stay at the hotel. What we liked most: service, good restaurants and bars. What we thought need some change to make the place perfect: (a) a wall between the room and bathroom is made of glass with wooden shades which do not block the light from the bathroom coming into the room, which makes it difficult to use the bathroom if somebody is asleap in the room, (b) there are not enough personnel to greet guests and excort them to tables during the breakfast time, (c) extremelly overpriced spa (I am not sure if it was ok by Tokyo standards which is infamous for being expensive, but nevertheless...) and (d) that is it! We found everything else simply perfect. Just for fun if you use 220 v voltage equipment ask them for a converter. You will get something really amusing. Big, heavy and looks as if it was made in 70s (Note to the hotel management: please do not replace this thing with something new, we would like to use it again next time we stay in your hotel!:-)

This is one of the nicest hotels I've stayed in. The service was beyond amazing and thoughtful. The manager introduced himself to us and greeted us everyday. The concierge was extremely helpful and the staff were always friendly and ready to jump to help in any way.There is a subway stop, restaurants and shops right below the hotel so traveling around the city was easy.The views are good as well, the hotel lobby is on the 38th floor and the rooms are below (maybe 30 - 37).

I've stayed at a lot of nice hotels and this one is in the top 5 in terms of service, attention to detail, and luxury. LOCATION:- In Tokyo's Nihonbashi business district, the Mandarin occupies the top floors of a business building and has gorgeous sweeping views of Tokyo (and Mt. Fuji on a clear day).- 10-20 minutes by taxi or subway to Ginza, Roppongi, Harajuku. It is located right next to the subway station - Across the street are 2 buildings with just about every type of Japense food you could want- sushi, yakitori, teppanyaki, ramen, and more- Just steps away from the huge department store Mitsukoshi (think Macy's but even better) which you can reach by underground tunnel if it's raining outside.ROOMS:- We were upgraded to an executive suite which had a separate living room area which was very nice to relax in- The bath was huge with a separate soaking tube, huge shower, and walk in closet.- Each afternoon when you return from sight seeing/shopping/eating, you'll have a small snack of cookies/chocolates awaiting you.SERVICE:- It's really the small things that matter- like the concierge who made restaurant reservations for us and subsequently sent a map with directions to our room (restaurants are notoriously hard to find in Tokyo), the bellman who made sure the taxi driver knew exactly how to get to the restaurant, and the housekeeper that lined up my toiletries and folded all my clothes for me every day.FITNESS/SPA:- Gorgeous fitness center on 38th floor directly above spa. The treadmills face out so you can watch the sun rise over Tokyo while getting some cardio in- so beautiful it almost made me want to run another mile. Almost.- The spa on the 37th floor has a large hot tub that also looks over Tokyo but is not co-ed so I had to enjoy it without the hubby, which would have been fun. Treatments are pretty expensive, but definitely worth the splurge.You will not go wrong staying at the Mandarin Oriental- I've stayed at a few of their properties and this one is by far the best!

Recently, I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo. It is an outstanding property located in the heart of Nihonbashi. Convenient to all major areas and a beautiful setting, Mandarin Oriental offered a wonderful stay, great environs, terrific food and beautiful decor. The rooms and view were terrific and as a five-star hotel, I would clearly recommend it as one of the very best.

This was my 4th stay in this hotel. I came with my family and stayed for 10 days. We all loved it, the luxury, the service, the attention, the cleanliness, the view, the pillow menu, the breakfast buffet, the spa, the everything !!!! The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo remains the best hotel I have ever stayed in. Highly recommend it. The only thing missing was a swimming pool !

Genuine hospitality and flawless service throughout our 8 nights stay in this great hotel with wonderful views of Tokyo city. The moment you arrive to reception, to daily morning breakfast, housekeeping, fitness center, and restaurant / lounges - your experience will be wonderful for sure.Housekeeping and amenities, bed comfort, room space and decor are excellent. The amenities were constantly replaced and serve good products (Apivita). Score is excellent.Be pleasantly surprised with afternoon treats like chocolates or petite cakes when you return after shopping or work. And delicately served in true Japanese style. Score is excellent.Meals at the hotel are excellent, K'ishki for breakfast is delightful, the head waiter and staff aim to predict what you like and want; and are knowledgeable of the wide array of international breakfast. Eggs Benedict with crabmeat excellent (apparently the chicken are fed with infused herbs like rose hip etc). Suggest the delicate white tea. Score is excellent.The lounges have an extensive cocktail list (pity it allows smoking though). Score is excellent. The fitness center equipment and service serving fresh juice etc are excellent. We had a wonderful and restful hospitality experience, the staff deserve congratulations for their excellent service!

We stayed at the mandarin oriental tokyo from jul 30 to aug 4 and thoroughly enjoyed it. The service is almost comically good; the staff at the breakfast buffet set the tone early and checked in on us about 10 times through the course of our meal, one wonders how often they would have come over if it wasn't self service! The front desk even helped us mail some luggage home as we were checking out. Our room was quite spacious, especially so by tokyo standards. The venue itself is stunning, as the views on all sides 38 floors up are straight out of a movie. We had a good time at both the bar and Sense cantonese restaurant downstairs. Tapas molecular bar is particularly noteworthy as a one of a kind dining experience that shouldn't be missed. The neighborhood is walking distance to ginza and the imperial palace, a bit different than shinjuku craziness. Honestly, my only suggestion would be to include a card to all guests upon check in to hand to cab drivers that says mandarin oriental and the address in Japanese on it so they know how to take you home. Other than that, a flawless stay as always at the MO.

We always love staying at the Mandarian Orientals and look for them in whatever major city we visit. We also try to find out when they are opening new ones and where. We had a wonderful stay! Room was perfect, everything was perfect. The extra security to the 38 floor for the reception and then a separate set of elevators to the rooms was commendable. The staff were friendly, receptive and respectful. When we first arrived in reception, everyone was professional and conversed with us as a couple. English was perfect, everything we would expect from a Mandarian Oriental. However, on two separate occasions I felt uncomfortable when I asked a question at reception and the answer was deferred to my partner. No eye contact and I became invisible. The first time it was culturally amusing, however, the morning of our departure it was not acceptable. We prefer to stay at any Mandarian Oriental whenever we travel. The rest of the staff was exceptionally professional and could not do enough to make both of us feel welcome and comfortable.

As expected from a Mandarin Oriental, the facilities and room are tastefully and beautifully appointed. Service is beyond exceptional. The staff at the front desk make an effort to remember your name and will greet you during your stay. The concierge was fabulous --- I had them on speed dial in case I ever needed a translator “on-demand” while touring the city. Nothing is too much to ask of them. Other hotels could learn a thing or two about service from the MO service standard. I had never mentioned that it was my birthday, but they must have noticed when they were checking us in and saw my passport because they sent up a personalized card with a birthday treat to my room much to my surprise. The spa facilities are amazing - I recommend using them in the morning when they are open to all hotel guests even if you do not get a spa treatment. If this hotel were located in a better part of Tokyo, I’d easily give this 5 stars; but because of its location I think it falls just shy of 5 stars. Don’t get me wrong, the location is fine --- it’s next to a major department store, conveniently located for many business travelers, and public transportation or cabs are easy to get from here; but ultimately, it’s located in a primarily business district. Staying as a tourist, you may want to stay in a different area. Nonetheless, this is a small detail that shouldn’t deter one from staying here. The Mandarin Oriental is truly a beautiful facility with extraordinary service that you won’t be disappointed. I would most certainly return to stay here.
user_location: New York, New York, United States
user_name:
ptn4
New York, New York, United States

review_body: Corner Room is the best. You can see Sky Tree and Tokyo Bay. Most importantly, you can take a bath while seeing fantastic Tokyo's city views. It is because the bathroom has a super big window!!!The package is called "plan early, stay longer". The staff provided professional customer services, esp. Mr. Reden, Mr. Takeichi and Ms. Tajima. I really enjoyed what they had provided while staying in this hotel. Room: Corner room with the view of Sky Tree and Tokyo Bay. Lucky enough, I could see the fireworks in Hanabi.Bed/ Sleeping quality: excellentBathroom: The best! Taking a bath while seeing Tokyo's night city views is incredible.View: Magnificent city viewsRestaurants: Sense is excellent/ Mandarin Bar is stylish!

Mandarin Oriental lives up to its reputation with this hotel.The architects did an amazing job here. We found the Park Hyatt in Shinjuku pales in comparison to the Mandarin.The location is great, in the center of Ginza, even if it’s not our favorite neighbourhood in Tokyo.We booked a mandarin suite and loved the view from our bed and from the bathtub.The bar is a great way to start the evening with live music and probably the best cocktails I had in my life. Try the signature cocktail : Nihonbashi.The concierge was always prompt and helpful. For a sukiyaki dinner, try the zakuro restaurant just across the street. It was recommanded by the concierge and it’s still the best sukiyaki we have eaten so far.For the breakfast, try the crab eggs benedict. They are to die for…

Great hotel with an stunning design. The rooms are spacious and well equip with all the tools and techs you would expect from such a hotel the view from the room was wonderful, such a peace sitting in the room and looking over tokyos skyline. The staff was very friendly and attentive. Great experience.

Once again the MO blows me away with the wow factor lobbies and stunning rooms. Worth gong to the men's toilet in the lobby to see the urinal with the best view. The view from the room at night was amazing has a sort of blade runner feel to it.I loves these make as much mess as you can japanese bathrooms. The service was faultless. Special note should go to Eriko at the concierge desk who went beyond the call of duty to help us sort out fruit picking and ryokan experience. Sushi restraint was great I had a 7 year old who would not sit still, chef himself came down to my room to set up the sushi. Room service food was good but kids menu a but limited and not very tasty, macaroni cheese and spaghetti bog tasted like it came straight out of can. My kid left the food. In the end what let's the place down was in the evening if you are traveling with a family and want to take a wonder around the block,the place is like a ghost town. Nothing to see or do, which is why we shifted to Roppongi. Another disappointment was the lovely looking pool with huge windows are not open to children under 16. If you are young free and single and love great looking rooms then this the place to be.

I spent a night here after a few hectic days partying in Tokyo. Very relaxing vibe. The usual MO level of service - i.e. very attentive. The spa was over hyped and certainly the mens side was a bit disappointing. Views from the rooms and the bars/restaurants were great. Cocktails and bar were fantastic. Rooms were large and had all the necessary facilities. Overall a really relaxing experience.

Taking advantage of the commemoration of our 25th years anniversary trip, as well as our honeymoon, following our wedding thanks to the new French law about marriage for all, we decided to inform all the hotels we had booked of the purpose of this trip and our civil situation.We were greeted at the reception with congratulations for our wedding, and found in our room a very kind message from the Director, with special fruit preparation.The MO Tokyo is really perfectly localized in this gigantic megalopolis. Close to Tokyo train station, with a subway station access in the same building, connected to two strategic lines : it’s very important in this city as transports are a key element to understand and enjoy it.The hotel occupies the top of a high building with breathtaking views. Our room was spacious, very nicely decorated with Japanese delicate influence, and we had the same dramatic views over Tokyo at our feet. At night it’s really magic. Unfortunately, the weather not allowed to see the mount Fuji…I had a massage at the SPA (beautiful place), highly recommendable: very sweet and relaxing.Breakfast buffet is of the highest quality, with a smooth and professional service.We had dinner two times at the Asiatic restaurant, with very tasty options, and some cocktails at the lounge, with outstanding views and great service.As it’s almost a tradition at MO hotels, we always enjoyed to be greeted by our name in the lobby when coming back from our visits, with appreciated personal reference to our honeymoon: this kind of attention makes you feel very special!In general, the care for details and personalization is a trademark of MO hotels, and this one didn’t escape from this rule.Minor critic, but more linked to Japan: the hotel still allow smoking in public areas and, despite a highly sophisticated system of aeration, you may detect smoke presence. Resuming, amazing hotel, amazing service, amazing localization, amazing food: perfect to end a memorable honeymoon.

Exception five star hotel.Would definitely stay here again.Concierge made any request very easy and worry free.We were able to send our luggage ahead to our next destination as we set out for Mt Fuji.The Spa was exceptional and breakfast perfect.

Our favorite hotel in Tokyo used to be the Park Hyatt. We have a new contender after our recent stay at the MO...although they are pretty close!First, the room. The view is excellent (although with large buildings near by on the west side, we don't really get a clear view of the Imperial Gardens and the weather while we were there did not give us a view of Mt. Fuji...next time, we may stay facing the east side, which gives a more unobstructed view and also of the Skytree Tower). There are almost an endless list of conveniences...a lot of small details that make up for a great experience...for example, scent oil at turndown service. The bed and pillows were very comfortable. The bathroom was fabulous...the only negative was that the shower had no door. Water splashed if you were not careful...onto the wood floors.Service was the best we have experienced. Everyone was so helpful, friendly and courteous. The turndown service was something else...it took two housekeeping staff quite a while to get everything ready...again with attention to a lot of details.The fitness center was adequate. Very nice views while working out...but the space was relatively small and equipment/weights were limited. The juice after workout was a nice touch.The best part of the hotel is the lobby area and the restaurants and bars..all located on the top two floors. Everything was open, elegant, and with great views. We tried Sense Cantonese and K'shiki restaurants...both excellent! We did not try the other great restaurants because we figure our 12 year old son would not really appreciate them. The bars were great with live jazz every night. Because everything was open, you can hear the music from many of the bars. Two of the bars had fine cigars, which I really appreciated.The fact that you had to go to the lobby level to switch elevators was a bit of an inconvenience but it seems to be a growing trend in some hotels...we got used to it...it was an excuse to go to the fabulous lobby area.The location was ok...Nihonbashi is mostly a business area, but there is a small neighborhood with many small restaurants and cafes on the east side of the hotel. The Mitsukoshi department store next door is worth a visit just to see the giant sculpture of a dragon in the middle. On the west side, there is a currency museum next to the Bank of Japan. Mitsui museum next door is worth a visit. The immediate neighborhood was not too exciting but the hotel is centrally located to many of the great places to visit.
user_name:
SixpackDC
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental for just over a week, when in Tokyo with the supporters of the Royal Ballet tour.The hotel occupies the upper floors of a large office and shopping complex building, a block away from the huge Mitsuokoshi department store. The basement level gives direct access to the Mitsukoshi-mae station on the Ginza line of the Metro - very useful for getting about the city.Our room on the 32nd floor was large, luxuriously comfortable, and equipped with everything that we could possibly need - wi fi, a kettle and tea/coffee making equipment, kimonos, fans to take to the theatre, even binoculars.The service was, as usual with the MO group, exceptionally helpful and attentive.Breakfast was served in the K'shiki restaurant, on the 38th floor - a full buffet with a wide choice of western and oriental foods on offer, and (on clear days) a view of Mt Fuji. At times other than breakfast, K'shiki usually serves Japanese food for sharing. The hotel also has a Michelin-starred French restuarant, Signature, a lounge, a fine bar (also with spectacular city views), a spa,fitness room and pool.It made a great base for our trip.Two minor points. First, the bathroom in our room was a triumph of style over function. It looked very elegant and stylish: but the lavatory was in the bathroom, and separated on 2 sides only by misted glass, so could not comfortably be used at the same time as someone else was using the sink or shower. Also, the shower was a walk-in, with no door to separate it from the rest of the bathroom, so the water from the shower went all over the place.Secondly, the lift system is idiosyncratic. To get from the ground to our room on the 32nd floor, it was necessary to go up, first, to the 38th floor, before crossing the lobby and then going down in a different lift to the 32nd. Leaving the hotel required the same procedure to be followed in reverse, which added 2 or 3 minutes to every trip.However, these were minor niggles. The MO essentially provided all that we could reasonably have hoped for, and we greatly enjoyed our stay. We would certainly stay there again should we return to Tokyo.

Everything about this hotel is luxurious and of extemely high quality - the service, the rooms, the amenities, the buffet breakfast, the lobby area with its incredible views. Although this is a fancy hotel - the staff were extremely friendly to my young children and the concierge was very helpful in planning our sightseeing. Our family of four had connecting rooms (a deluxe and corner) on the 27th floor facing east/southeast, staying for a week at the end of June. I preferred the deluxe room with floor to ceiling windows, which was more spacious and had a better view, than the corner room with windows on two sides, which was more expensive. The corner room did have an amazing view from the bathroom though. We had jet lag coming from the US and spent hours in our hotel room waiting for morning to arrive - made better because of the luxurious and extremely comfortable surroundings. We should have gotten the bed and breakfast package since we were always up so early. Staying in this location means a lot of walking - although Mitsukoshimae subway station is downstairs and Tokyo station is nearby, we ended up using cabs a lot because the distances were sometimes too much for tired kids. The Nihonbashi area is not compact as the area we stayed in Shinjuku later in the trip. The hotel is on a convenient subway line (Ginza) for the traditional tourist spots.

From the valet to the concierge to the bar, everyone is amazingly wonderful. I loved this hotel and absolutely would stay here again.The view is beautiful, the breakfast is outstanding, the rooms are amazing but again, the staff make your stay just absolutely wonderful and make you feel both appreciated and warmly welcome.I will absolutely stay here again and would gladly tell anyone else to stay here as well.

My partner and I stayed four days in the Mandarin Oriental, and everything was absolutely perfect. The staff were polite and helpful. The rooms are fantastic, with everything you could possibly need. We especially found the concierge to be great, who had maps and information for everything we asked about. This hotel isn't cheap, but you definitely get what you pay for. Perfect for business trips, and holidays alike. This stay has put Mandarin Oriental top of the list for me!

We stayed here as a family during a 10 day city stay. Right in the Center with views all over town. Imperial garden and sky tower. The 36. Floor is under the lobby which has an amazing view. Suites are good, modern and amenities are there a lot. The restaurant overlooking Tokyo is very good, forgot the name. If you go outside the hotel you have shops close by. The only thing missing was the pool, which with kids has to be. We really thought there is one. :(
user_name:
aivlys570
Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates

review_body: After many trips to Tokyo and experiencing many hotels, my third stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo confirms that it is still the best. Service, location, food, amenities -- all superlative! Here are some of the things I think are great:Pillows -- so comfy that I actually went to the hotel store and bought four to have shipped home. The only problem is that they are an irregular size, so you have to buy the pillow cases, too. But so worth it!Shower -- normally you have a choice between hand held shower, wall shower and rain shower -- but at the MO you can have two at the same time. A bit extravagant, but so luxurious.]Bar -- the young ladies at the bar can make some of the best drinks -- particularly the mojitos. A must try!Mitsukoshi -- just a block away (and accessible underground from MO) is the flagship and original Mitsukoshi. The 7th floor has traditional artisans demonstrating their crafts -- broom making, bamboo goods, wooden housewares, glass making, fans, etc. Not only educational but great for shopping!MO is pricey, but worth the splurge!

If you want to be nickel and dimed....come here. The place is a total rip off!!!!! The wi fi is 50.00 usd for 3 days which i think is disgusting. If you enjoy tea which is usually compliemntary prepare to pay 9.00 a bag from your in room mini bar. I think for this level of hotel it should not feel like a motel 6 where every extra is a huge cost. We were also kept up from 1am to 3 am by a wedding party above us. Beware the rooms have hardwood floors so if by change you are as unfortuante as we were to have a heavy footed wedding party you will be very tired the next day. Checked in and out in less than 24 hours as the park hyatt is wonderful we have stayed there twice before and never felt so abused. The staff upon check in was snarky and rude when I asked what were the options for the view choices. We loved the Four Seasons and The park Hyatt sad to sad the Mandarin needs to just be better to compete with the other top hotels or more guests will be checking out just like us. I also plan to email or contact corporate for a refund.

We can't imagine why anyone would choose to stay at another hotel in Tokyo. Great location right by the metro and near everything, wonderful facility, consistently excellent service, a great concierge team, reasonable restaurants ... Our favorite.

Recently spent three nights at the MO Tokyo to finish up our two-week exploration around Japan - and what a grand finale it was. The location was excellent with access to the subway and not far from Ginza and other shopping areas. We loved Mitsukoshi which is adjacent to the hotel. The hotel is a bit challenging at first to navigate as it sits on the 30-38th floor of an office building - and the lobby is on the top floor. But it wasnt difficult to figure out. There are many restaurants - all amazing - we ate in K'aiseki (?) for breakfast each day as well as dinner one night - andloved it. The public areas are beautiful and we loved having drinks by live jazz next to the 25 foot tall windows overlooking the Tokyo skyline. WOW. And our room was large and had every conceivable ammenity. Service was exceptional - especially the concierge team - they helped us with meals and shopping and fun things to do with our teenage daughter. No complaints anywhere - a fabulous stay in a fabulous property.

Stayed in a standard room for five nights starting May 9th. Arrived late after a very nice flight on ANA from JFK in First Class (used USAirways miles to “buy” that ticket). Incredibly efficient path through immigration and customs as well as on the NEX train from NRT to Tokyo Station. Had some difficulty communicating with the taxi driver outside of Tokyo station, but finally found the telephone number for the hotel. Should have been better prepared.Bellman at the hotel grabbed my luggage and subtly noted my name on the airline luggage tags. He conveyed that to the people at the check in desk. Check in went smoothly although I would have expected that to happen privately in the room. Brought to the room by a bellman. Was not really given the usually tour or explanation of the room’s facilities. Was disappointed in the small bowl of strawberries. After a long flight I was hoping for something more. I ordered a sandwich from room service. It arrived promptly and was very good.Room was very nice, clean and comfortable if not a bit starkly decorated. Bathroom and amenities were excellent. Not many channels on the TV, but I wasn’t there to watch that. Bed and linens were top notch.Breakfast, included in the price of the room, was excellent with very good selections. Eggs were an odd reddish orange because of what the chickens were fed. Hard to get used to that. Ate dinner twice at Signature, once with the wine pairing. Certainly deserving of its Michelin star although the explanation of each dish could have been better.Used the Concierge to acquire a ticket to the Tokyo Symphony and for a train ticket to Kyoto. Very efficient service.Location in this sprawlish city is as about as good as any hotel because the hotel sits on top of a subway station. The train station is within walking distance, as is the Emperor’s Palace, although finding one’s way walking can be difficult. The subway system is excellent, only made complicated by the fact that there are several private lines. As a frame of reference, when in Asia I have stayed at the Peninsula in Hong Kong and Bangkok, Raffles in Singapore and Beijing, and the Shangri-La in Shanghai and Kuala Lumpur. The MO-Tokyo holds up well to all of those although I found it a bit lacking in character. I think that might be typical of Japanese hotels, but I am not sure. If I were to return to Tokyo, I’d probably try out the Peninsula, not because of any fault with the MO, but just to experience something different. I certainly did not regret in any way my choice to stay at the MO on my first trip to Tokyo.

Wonderfull view and wonderfull location for a week-end. Rooms are great. However, a few things can be improved : room service and especially room cleaning should be maintained differently : there is a problem with towel stocking, we missed towels, and as a consequence, we received twice on the following day. The hotel team could also improve its own touristic knowledge of the town (especially concerning museums locations)...

The verdict is in. After, the exceptional stay at MO- Macau, we altered our plans to stay at Mo-Tokyo. As the cartoons would say.... Wooomp! Womp! The Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo was a bit of disappointment. Most of the shortcomings are in the service area as the facility itself was at least on par with others. The positives: room size was adequate with the bathroom cleverly laid out. No door on shower yet no monsoon in the bathroom. Cute. The location on Nihonbashi was in proximity to Tokyo Station and a lovely department store, Mitsukoshi, that reminded me a bit of the English Sitcom "Are you being Served?" The location was Not party central which is likely not what is being sought anyway. Here are the concerns we have with the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo:Service was Mediocre. met the minimum standard but certainly nothing extra. The rooms were sparsely supplied with basic amenities. Bottled Water was always in short supply. On several occasions, we had to call housekeeping because somehow, they forgot to leave complimentary bottles of water in the room. Bath soaps were not consistently restocked. A hotel of this caliber should note the unspoken preferences of its guests and adjust the routine accordingly. Noting that we never used the shower gel and consistently used the soap for the shower, even moving it from the face basin to the shower stall, one would think they would accommodate by restocking the soap. That may be too picky but at this altitude in the hotel hierarchy one expects fastidious attention to detail.Perhaps our expectations were set high by the reviews and the positioning of the hotel itself. The staff did not appear to be well informed about many standard things. If they were well informed, then they certainly could do a better job communicating that knowledge. When asked simple connection and location questions, we were automatically greeted with recommendations to take Taxis. We were advised to take a Taxi to meet a tour at Shinjuku. On the return the tour guide simply instructed us to stay on the train 4 stops further. Imagine the surprise, when we got off the train at Tokyo Station, to realize the hotel was about a 15 minute walk. Imagine the annoyance when we were told by the Information Desk that there was a FREE shuttle from the station to the Mitsui building. (where the hotel is). Now the concierge may very well have adjudged a taxi to be quicker, easier or better for whatever reason, the impression we were left with was that reason was.... easier, quicker and better for her. Acknowledging guests by name is a common "punch list" item that 5 star hotels check to demonstrate their "5 Starness" We are a family of 3 and certainly are distinctive in certain parts of the world for a myriad of reasons. It usually takes 2 times to have even unaffiliated personnel recognize us. Another small but instructive point is we were not acknowledged by name once throughout the stay.Concerns addressed with the staff yields sympathetic responses but the implications appeared lost on them.A point that I noticed duplicated in other reviews but that certainly bears repeating. The amount of smoke wafting into the lobby from the bar area is egregious. My son who is asthmatic ate in the room most nights and was kept away from the lobby as it truly is overwhelming. I am unsure that much can be done by the hotel about this, but at minimum it should be noted by other travellers who may have respiratory/allergy issues.Suffice it to say, the service we got came no where close to what we would expect from a hotel that had won 6 Star Diamond award many times. You will not be miserable here but don't expect to be blown away. The staff have clearly been trained but are unable to consistently transmit the benefit of that training in a way that benefits the guest. The experience crystallized for us what we describe as "IN service rather than OF service"We noted this particularly with the front desk and concierge staff as the restaurants SENSE and K'SHIKI were staffed with gracious, proactive personnel. An aside On the F&B front, The cocktails neded work both times we tried to have a nightcap though the Mandarin Miracle at Sense during dinner was well crafted.

Service is top notch. Surroundings are beautiful. The rooms are comfortable and luxurious and the food is amazing. They do Asian and Western food well: lots of choices. This is the best place to stay in Tokyo and truly one of the better hotels in the world.

It just has what you'd want. Michelin starred restaurants (you can even get their food room service which is cool when you have a 13 months old), fab service and good location. Love it every time. When we booked restaurants ahead of arriving the hotels food and beverage manager even called us to make sure our little son would be ok.

Stayed here a week on business, everything is as advertised, service, rooms, dining, everything was spotless. If possible, request a room facing mt. Fuji, they book faster. Also the neighborhood was very quiet, not much to walk to, aside from imperial palace. If you are looking to be in the center of all the action, stay in Shibuya.

What to say, it is perfect just very expensive! The rooms are very thought out, the spa is wonderful and dining is impressive and the views are amazing-mt fuji on a clear day! The service is second to none!

Amazing! It's probably one of the only in this category i'm ok to pay this price. My second time there, and it was as impressive as the first. Stellar breakfast and dinner. Spectacular, complete room. My personal number one, I'm a fan!

I stayed with my family for a week - on holiday and it was a fabulous experience. The rooms and the views are great. Interesting bars and restaurants. Spa is superb. Gym is functional - though not big. Service is wonderful - from the bell desk, to concierge, restaurants, spa - anywhere... you find exemplary customer focus. Truly a great place to stay in Tokyo

One of the most amazing hotels I've stayed at. Amazing rooms, amazing views, top quality service. Not cheap, but absolutely worth it. Nicer than the other Mandarins I have stayed at (HK and Geneva). The only drawback -- and it's a huge drawback -- is the cigarette smoke in the lobby/bar. Sushi/coffee tips:Sushi Nihonbashi across the street from the hotel has absolutely fantastic (and quite reasonably priced) sushi.Omotesando Koffee (in Omotesando) is a must-visit coffee place for coffee lovers - one of the best brews in Tokyo served in a slightly surreal setup.

The location is superb, thanks to Mitsui's total rejuvenation of the new business area. The service is impeccable, which is par for the course for Mandarin properties. The fitout topnotch. The gym, while not huge, is well thought out and equipped to cater to exercise/fitness needs (the complimentary health smoothies should not go untried!).The F&B in-house faces stiff competition from the greater Ginza area. That said, the jazz bar is a nice scene in the evenings, enjoying good music, ambience, and views of the city from the high floor in the building.What should be a top priority is to visit the abundant food halls nearby, whether above ground or via underground walkways: Coredo Muromachi (some of the best Tsukemen can be found on the 3rd floor at Tosa no Otoko ga Tsukutta Tonkotsu Ramen Ore-shiki), Mitsukoshi(s), among others. It is a complete foodie feast.

The hotel is not inexpensive, but you get what you pay for. Beautiful, spacious room and luxury bathroom. Location is great for shopping. Great city views at night. The service was wonderful: we came in late the first night and wanted dinner. The informal restaurant was booked, but they were able to make a place for us with minor delay.

Conveniently located in the heart of the city, Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo enjoys a bird’s eye view of the breathtaking city skyline. Surrounded by the chic shops and offices of Nihonbashi, the hotel exudes crisp, cutting-edge style with state-of-the-art technology, a renowned spa, award-winning restaurants and impeccable service.With a covetable Nihonbashi address, they are closely located to some of Tokyo’s most prominent business addresses and attractions.•Walking distance of Tokyo's main shopping and entertainment destinations•8 minutes from Tokyo Station•Basement entrance to “Mitsukoshi-mae” subway station•Easy access to the city’s most famous sights including the Imperial Palace gardens•Five minutes from Tokyo Stock Exchange90 min from Narita Airport the Shuttle Bus service is effortless Check-in is on the 38/F overlooking Tokyo's Skyline, what an amazing way to arrive They up graded us to a "Premier Grand Room" and the room didn't disappointThe luggage was already within the room once we arrivedA welcome amenity with a hand written Birthday Card from staff was a nice touch, the amenities changed daily and seemed to out do one another each timeThe room was spacious to say the lease, with ample wardrobe spaceThe bathroom was sectioned with shower area, bathtub & toilet Bathroom amenities & products all by "Apivita" with nice touches like Lip Balm, Mouthwash, shaving foam & real hairbrushMini Bar was well stocked with Premium Products The food & beverage options was endless, breakfast located within K'shiki with jawdropping views of the city while you sip your morning coffee is the only way to start your day.Every detail of the hotel from arrival to departure has been carfully reviewed & perfected Personalised service is the aim & achieved at every turn

We spent two nights at the hotel and these are our best experience staying in a similar hotel so far. The location, room, lobby and restaurants were perfect - with a specially pleasant breakfast buffet - but most of all, service was specially attentive, personalized and aiming to make our stay even better. Mandarin Oriental is renowned for the good care it's staff takes from guests - but we really experienced it in Tokyo as never before. Enjoy your stay.

Stayed here late in 2012. Occupies the top half of a commercial building in Tokyo and so check in is way up in the sky.....Everything achieves the highest level in terms of service... which is tough in a market where services levels and expectations are already so high. We asked for food from the sushi restaurant to be served in the cafe.... no problem. Help from the concierge to locate the japanese toy for the kids...... no problem..... Even have a fluent Japanese speaking Italian waiter working the service in the breakfast room. A top quality property that really makes you feel very special for every minute of your stay. Bear in mind the location.... not the easiest for tourists, but great for the business traveller.

Spent two nights here on business. Staff were very helpful from arrival through to departure. The room was luxurious and well equipped with great views over the city from the 30th upwards. The gym is very good and the bars and restaurants were lively. Highly recommended.

We spent a couple of nights at the MO to start our short break in Japan and, armed with high expectations, were not disappointed. The rooms and decor are just as you would expect from a property of this standard. All the comfort and amenities you could wish for and some stunning views - particularly from the higher floors (we were on 36) - which were a sight for jet-lagged eyes. We found the hotel ourselves having braved the JR Express from Narita Airport and then 1 subway stop from Tokyo station to Shin-Nihombashi and a 5 minute stroll. We later discovered that the hotel is directly above another subway station (Mitsukoshimae on the Ginza line) but the bottom line is it's remarkably easy to find considering how daunting the Tokyo transport system might seem to the first time visitor. It's actually very easy and good fun too - grab a JR East 'Suica & Nex'deal at the airport and you'll be zipping around the place like a local in no time. But back to the hotel.The layout is a little upside down because you travel to the 38th floor for Reception and then back down (using different lifts) to the rooms but you soon get the hang of it. All the public spaces make the best use of some eye-popping views that look fantastic by day or night. We enjoyed a stunning meal at the Molecule Tapas Bar one evening (you really need to try this but with only 8 seats you need to plan for it in advance) and wound up spending too much time (and money) in their bar on both nights, drinking in the views and some interesting concoctions. If I had a gripe about the MO it would be that the bar prices are at the high end of what could be considered tolerable - the cocktails are probably the best value options because at about £15 a pop they compare favourably against a draught beer for £8 or a gin for more than double that. This is not a place for happy hours or penny pinchers and I was also surprised to be charged handsomely for WiFi in one of the worlds most technically advanced countries in the 21st century. These are however minor gripes in the scheme of things.So where does the MO really excel? Japan sets the bar extraordinarily high for Service and the team here are are amongst the best that we have ever experienced. To be fair, the service began a couple of months before we even arrived, when I reached out to the Concierge team (via e-mail) and asked them to sort out some restaurant reservations. They were more than happy to clarify my requirements and engage in a lengthy e-mail conversation across time zones. They ended up giving me some options to choose from and for one day that will live long in the memory, managed to secure us a lunch booking at the 6 six seat, 2 Michelin Starred 'Sushi Sawada' and dinner at the 18 seat, 3 Michelin Starred 'Ryogin' - a gastronomic experience that was as expensive as it was enjoyable. Not only were the restaurants booked, dietary requirements confirmed and so on well in advance (as they need to be for places like that) but on check- in we were presented with individual confirmations and maps with directions/journey times for getting to them via various means of transport. This was an incredibly thoughtful/helpful touch and I doubt we would have ever found the Sushi restaurant without it, tucked as it was on the 3rd floor of a tiny building tucked down a side street in Ginza.  Overall, we got the sense in our all too short stay that nothing would have been too much trouble for them and I actually felt quite guilty on check-out knowing that we were going to be 'checking out' The Peninsula Hotel in a few days for our last couple of nights in Tokyo. When I mentioned this to them they took no offence and said it would be nice for us to try somewhere else. I don't for a minute think this sentiment was anything but genuine - we shall see how their illustrious neighbour compares in a couple of days and whether, at the back of their minds, they felt we would ultimately miss their 'sanctuary in the skies'. Yes it costs a lot to stay (and play) here but we would be back in a heartbeat....

Well, this is the latest in a number of reviews I've done on this hotel, and I'm sorry to say that this time it wasn't as great as I've always found it to be. The room was the same, and I enjoyed being in it for a lot longer than I ever had before. The view was just as great, the appointments were just as fantastic, but service? It just didn't measure up to the many times I've been here before.Perhaps I was expecting too much, and perhaps there were factors I hadn't been exposed to before, but almost from the time I checked in I was less than perfectly satisfied.To begin with, I think it's time to point out that I had been in Japan for nearly two weeks staying at a great variety of hotels and this was the absolutely FIRST TIME in all my travels that I was charged for internet access, and it wasn't cheap, either. Next, I had a lot of trouble with the staff and the service in the restaurants, with one exception, and I'll mention that later. Here's the trouble: I think if you're paying huge amounts of money to stay in a room at a hotel, you, as a customer in an executive type room should have executive type amenities in the rest of the hotel. To be told you can't sit by the window in a restaurant known for its view because someone not staying there has priority, just is not acceptable. I spent a very miserable time trying to get a good table at the Oriental Lounge and the K'shiki restaurant just because it was a Saturday afternoon and the tables (which were totally empty when I was there, by the way) were reserved for some sort of "ladies day" gathering, none of the ladies staying at the hotel. Another problem I had with service this time was the housekeeping staff. I don't think one should have to call the housekeeping people at 4:00 p.m. because the room had not been made up! That is totally unacceptable, especially when you're paying over $1,000 a night for the room even with the three for two situation. So these were the issues I had. Otherwise, everything was as expected in this, my favorite hotel in the world. By the way, this has now dropped to second place in Tokyo and third place in Japan. The Tokyo Station Hotel far exceeded the Mandarin's service this time, and the Hakkoda hotel near Aomori slips in just because of its great setting and service, where they go way beyond expectations. And by the way, both of these hotels have FREE internet connections!!I will have to give high marks for the included breakfast buffet which was really great, and the restaurants I attended. The aforementioned K'shiki (where they had the great breakfast) had wonderful lunches and dinners, and the French restaurant was truly elegant with really super food. My waiter was also fantastic, spending lots of time with me and giving me great service.Another disappointment was the "spa discount," an 8,000 yen credit for a spa treatment. The only spa treatments that were included in this were those that cost well over $600, and added to that were tariffs and taxes that upped the price to well over $800 per treatment. I just can't see spending that kind of money on what amounts to a rubdown. I ended up having a massage in my room which was just fine.To sum up, I will have to give careful consideration as to whether I'll stay at MOTYO again the next time I come to Japan.

The first elevator takes you to the 38th floor reception area, and then the second elevator takes you down to the rooms on floors 30-36, with additional restaurants on 37. This is an elegant five-star property, and the views out the picture windows in the room or public areas will amaze you. The room was spacious, with a couch and desk with two chairs. There was ample drawer space. Items to be found in the room: binoculars; business kit with scissors, stapler, sewing kit, etc.; safe; touch screen telephone; 3 oranges, replenished at intervals; pilates mat; and a pillow menu. We had a lovely dinner one night in the Cantonese restaurant. There are also a sushi restaurant and Asian restaurant available. The hotel staff was unfailingly courteous and helpful.

#1. This lobby reeks of smoke. They cannot filter this out though I am sure they try. It is very noticeable and a big setback for the environment of the lobby. As we have children, for us it meant we avoided the lobby as best we could. Don't know how the workers can deal with this. We held our our breath each day while there. This also meant we were loathe to ask for assistance from the concierge bc it was oppressive to stand in a lobby reeking of smoke while waiting for directions etc. There is no avoiding the lobby because one has to cross it to get to the elevator bank to get to the rooms. Details: The day we checked in the gentleman handling our room had a terrible cough, hacking the entire time. While he was apologetic, our first impression of the hotel was that of an obviously ill employee. He looked like he was running a bit of a fever as well. He could barely finish a sentence and could not stop coughing and was sputtering all over us. In a country so attuned to spreading germs with every man woman and child donning a surgical mask routinely, how can the Mandarin Oriental let this employee interface with guests checking in from abroad? #2. day 1, Housekeeping did not clean our room until our second outing in the mid afternoon which was a surprise as we left the room by 9am and indicated it via button. While the room was tidy and the bed made, the crumbs from the orange goldfish crackers our kids snacked on were still on the carpet which was obviously never vacuumed. This is a 'no no' for a 6 star hotel. This is a beautiful hotel, sterling lobby and the amenities and address to boot. We stayed in a Grand deluxe room with a lovely view of Mt. Fuji. The room is spacious with floor to ceiling windows and nicely integrates technology with automatic blinds and curtains and touchscreen phone. We would not stay here again however, as the details that comprised our stay were off putting and for the price we can go anywhere else we choose.

First class all the way.SERVICE - the concierge offered great recommendations for dinners and gave detailed directions on how to get there. We had luggage transferred from another city a days before our arrival and it was delivered without a hitch to our room. The hotel is connected to the subway, which we didn't know at first, and when we asked how to get the subway, the guy at the front desk walked down to the station with us and showed us how to buy tickets. My husband wanted to buy a Japanese musical instrument in an out-of-the-way shop. We were concerned about not being able to communicate with the sho-powners but a (different) front desk guy gave us his card and offered to have the store call him for help in translation, which we didn't end up needing but still what great service.DESIGN - beautiful designed with great thought given to functionality and natural light. I immediately felt like I moved right in. Rooms were spacious with fantastic views.

Beautiful room; We had a corner room, very spacious, lovely bathroom with a very nice bath. View over Tokyo was fantastic. Really comfortable bed had the best sleep out of our stay in Japan.From the moment of check in the staff were extremely friendly and made this feel like home.At the bar they knew which restaurants we had booked during our stay in Tokyo which was most unusual but made it a really personal experience.Had dinner at the molecular restaurant we really enjoyed this, breakfast was great.Great location, subway underneath the hotel, not far to anywhere.Again service was top notch. Would definitely stay here when next in Tokyo. Great Experience.

We had a few days here around the easter weekend. A great hotel with personal attention and service starting on arrival at the front door and not stopping till you're in a taxi on route to the airport again. The room was superb, clean spacious and with coffee and tea maker, and good wifi. The bed was perfect for a good sleep and the bathroom was like heaven with 3 shower settings and the delicious japanese toilet with heated seat. Break in the main restaurant was delicious with good choice of american/ european and asian breakfast classics. The concierges where great! they pointed us to Seamon sushi across the street where we had a great meal when the sushi restaurant of the hotel was fully booked and also to the excellent Mitsukoshi sep. store next door and to several specialty shops around the area. The hotel is near the JR station the palace and the royal gardens and the Yasukuni shrine. The Tokyo tower and the Sky tree are a short taxi or metro ride away. Ginza is a short stroll on the sunday morning when that street is pedestrian only! The tv offered enough channels for the none japanese speakers. The room was spacious and offered a great view over the bank of japan and towards the palace gardens. It was nice to have special hotel lifts between the floors of the hotel and separate lifts to down to the street level. All staff where wonderful friendly, polite, friendly and helpful. this is the place for us to stay when we get back to Tokyo!

Fantastic hotel both for buisness and holiday.Based on top of a large deparmentstore and Ginza linje subway- only 10 min away from Tokyo Station etc.Direct bus from the airportVery good service in a high tech room.Ask for a room overlooking mt.Fuji

Top class hotel. Service is of the highest standard and what you would expect for paying top dollar. Very conveniently located above shin nihombashi metro station and to shopping in Ginza. The room views are spectacular. Newspaper and laundry arrive in your in room elevator contraption. Slept like a baby - sheets felt like butter. Didnt try the spa it was overpriced. We just came from Thailand where a one hour massage was $15 tops for a quality massage so it seemed extortion to pay $400 for the same in the hotel. Would definitely highly recommend this hotel experience to businessmen and tourists !
