Tokyo MO was the 9th in the chain I have stayed in and is perhaps only 2nd behind the mother ship of Bangkok in my view - and that's high praise indeed. The style and design of the public areas and the rooms are beautiful. Seeing Mount Fuji from our room at daybreak was a real extra treat. Dinner at the Molecular Tapas bar was excellent, fun and expensive - but worth it. However, the prices for treatments in the Spa are sky high compared to other 5 star hotels in the city and also at other MO hotels - so steered away from the £300+ massage! The subway station underneath the hotel is on the Ginza line which is one of the best for access to night time haunts such as Shibuya. The service levels are very high, but why oh why are they still charging for wifi access? It was free in the Shangri La, so MO management need to get this sorted.

Spacious room, comfortable bed, great view of the room, excellent service, attentive staff, best concierge team.The hotel is near by the JR Tokyo station,charged only around 800yen by taxi from the hotel to the JR station , is very convenience to take the Shinkansen. Would stay here again. They really made my trip perfect.

+ the rooms are beautiful with stunning views+ gorgeous bathrooms+ beautiful bar and restaurants + consistently exceptional service ( I have stayed here half a dozen times)-ve there really aren't any other than the fact the hotel is inverted such that you check in at the top level and travel down to your rooms which takes a little getting used to

Fantastic service. Concierge personnel go over and beyond expectations to get us tickets and reservations to restaurants even during the busy holiday season, they have this fantastic burger that you can order thru room service. Just a block walk to Mitsukoshi . It was easy access to subway

Everything I expect from a 5 star hotel - but not quite enough to make it out of this world (which everyone seems to expect from Mandarin Oriental).Excellent service with staff who were helpful and friendly.The hotel provides a nice questionnaire to ask guests about their preferences (e.g. when you want the room to be cleaned and when you want it turned down). Although not too sure how effective that is as the time the room is turned down is not actually correct on the one day I could check.Views from the rooms were stunning and the amenities were excellent.The Gym was equipped with state of the art equipment, and clean, although it was a little small.The location of the hotel is excellent, being on top of a metro station (mitsukoshimae) but private enough given the unassuming entrance of the hotel.However, the whole package is let down a little with some of the following criticisms.No Pool available, when pretty much all other 5-star hotels will have an indoor pool.The daily newspaper did not seem to arrive in the early morning, it appeared on my desk at the end of the day for the 5 days I was there.The breakfast buffet at Kshinki (sp?) was a little disappointing and expensive in comparison to some of the other buffets offered at other hotels. I ended up selecting a la carte menu items.No complimentary Wifi, daily cost of Wifi is pretty expensive (1800 Yen) for 1 day.I've stayed in the Shangri-la and the Park Royal hotel in the general area, and I would have to admit, I would prefer both to Mandarin Oriental. The only reason I would choose Mandarin Oriental over the other 2 is the location (less of a walk to work) which makes a difference during the cold Winter :-)

Traveled on business, this is my second time staying in this hotel. Service is outstanding and it's one of the most beautiful hotels I have ever stayed. Very conveniently located as well. I missed it already.

You can't beat the location, service or 5-star comfort of this hotel. It is modern, has beautiful views and the MOTO concierge is fantastic. They helped us figure out our trip -- over e-mail before we arrived -- and offered impeccable service when we were there. Our entire experience was fantastic -- they beat expectations when it came to luxury and service. The rooms are well appointed, all with great views. We had a Mt. Fuji view -- but arrived late at night on the clear day and the fog prevented us from seeing it while we were there, but the view was lovely regardless. The beds are dreamy and the rooms are spacious and efficient. The area is more "downtown" business feeling -- but you can walk (or quickly cab) to the train station which will take you anywhere you want to go in Tokyo or the rest of Japan. This was particularly useful as we took a day trip to Nagano.

Service is sensational. When you arrive at the ground floor level, the staff in the 38th floor reception area are immediately on alert to welcome you to the hotel. There was a genuine warmth and empathy emanating from the young woman who welcomed me at the entrance and literally whisked me up to the top floor. And the panoramic view of Tokyo from behind the back of the check-in area is "sharp intake of breath" inducing, it is so eye-catching and spectacular.I booked a Grand King Room on the 35th floor. It was one of the most serene habitats I have ever experienced. Apart from the panoramic view from the floor to ceiling windows, the bamboo floors coupled with the comfortable floor mats and the capacious extra-large bed put me in a "Japanese state-of-mind". I felt like I was a shogun (at least for two days!). The hotel also has a number of Michelin-starred establishments, two of which will serve food (at not too exorbitant prices) directly to your room. There's also a Japanese-style bathroom to die for, divided into separate compartments encapsulating a sunken bath, a wet room with a shower, a separate wc and sink area (with all the usual high end toiletries). For social interaction, it's difficult to beat the bar of the hotel on a weekend night. If you sit at the bar, you can watch the bar tenders mix taste-filled cocktails with great style and brio. Or, if you are in a romantic mood, you can adjourn to the banquettes at the back of the bar, where you can sit with your loved one/hot date and take in the amazing panoramic view of Tokyo, buzzing with life, hundreds of feet below you. Admittedly, this hotel set me back about Euro 1,200 for two nights there. But it was worth every single cent of my expenditure. An outstanding place.

We had high expectations for this hotel having been familiar with Boston's Mandarin Oriental and every single expectation we had was exceeded. This being our first time in Japan we were amazed at the hospitality of the Japanese people, but the staff at this hotel took it to a new level. Every single interaction we had with the staff was genuine, extremely friendly, and exemplifies the best service we have ever received anywhere. The room was glorious... extremely comfortable, with all the amenities you would expect from a 5 star hotel plus a few you wouldn't. The view looking over East Tokyo was stunning, and despite being in the middle of the city only steps from a metro station it was unbelievably quiet. We also ate at one of the restaurants after checking in and that experience was equally amazing. My only regret is not booking far enough in advance to have stayed for the entire duration of our trip as they were fully booked for the weekend, and understandably so. If there was a way to score extra credit on tripadvisor, this hotel would be the one to get it.

This hotel is worth every penny and then some. From the friendly staff to the amazing rooms and the views ... It was a perfect stay! We dined at Sense and had the Peking duck 3 ways ... Every course was perfect, and some were prepared table side!

We stayed here 1night, 2 ppl. Omg this hotel is fab! We arrived at the downstairs lobby and the doors were opened for us, bags taken off us, escorted to the lift and taken to reception on the 38th floor. We didn't even see our bags as they were taken st8 to the room while we checked in. The checkin was fab they couldn't do enough for us and were very friendly.The checkin staff accompanied us to our room after asking if it was ok, we got to our room on the 31st floor and the view was amazing, best view in tokyo! The staff showed us around the room and asked us if we wanted a welcome drink which we gladly accepted, we was also asked if wanted transport for the following day when we needed to get to the airport which was so nice to ask.The bed was so comfy, the bathroom was clean and contemporary...the room was really nice! Couldn't of asked for more.My partner went to the gym a few times and he said he loved it as staff would come round and ask if he wanted water or a towel, so he was really impressed! I wanted to use the jacuzzi but you had to pay for it which was a bit silly to say you pay £300 upwards for the room, doesn't matter weather it's part of the spa or not. So I didn't bother in the end.The service at the hotel was amazing! U can't asked for more, I want a residence here. Hmmm wishful thoughts! The location of the hotel was really good literally has a tube station in the same building, there is a really good department store 2 mins walk also, only problem what we found we couldn't find any western restaurants around!We checked out and spoke to a lady in the lift who must have been finishing work at the mandarin and we got talking to here and she even knew where we were travelling to next! Omg amazing! Such a fab team.Overall I would stay here again if I could afford it lol, prices are a bit high which I know is due to the service and High standards of the hotel but I sure if they do something to help this more ppl will get to see this fantastic hotel! 2nd best hotel I ever stayed in.Fab! You couldn't fault anything apart from the charges for the jacuzzi and sauna.

Mandarin Oriental is always my favorite. I like the taste of the decor, the view, the service, and of course the Spa. Very convenient to go outside, the subway is just a minute way. I'll definitely come back!

A flawless experience from check in to check out. Started when they took our bags and greeted us at the downstairs lobby; I didn't even have to tell them my name (think they saw on the luggage tag) and they escorted us up to the front desk where all our check in materials were waiting (just needed to sign). Was escorted to the room, where our bags were already laid out perfectly, and asked if we needed anything. I made a dinner reservation at their sushi restaurant that night which was amazing. The above check in experience was a sign of things to come, and the hotel lived up perfectly. The different concierges were always very helpful with anything we wanted to see or do and made great dinner reservations for us. Room was perfectly decorated and the overall hotel atmosphere is trendy but very comfortable. Everyone there is so nice and always trying hard to make sure you have everything you need. The breakfast at the hotel is great and provides a lot of options. We will definitely stay there again when in Tokyo.

What a great hotel, the service, the rooms, the food all fantastic. Also the views from the rooms and the hotel bar are to die for. The service is second to none and everything is catered for. We took our 11 month old son and when we arrived they had organised a cot, with a full safety inspection, and left him a baby bath and baby products for us to use.The rooms were very spacious with lovely views over Tokyo. This was our last stop on a 10 day tour of Japan and we both said how nice it was to be able to just kick off our shoes and relax at the end of a great adventure. A perfect hotel to finish a perfect holiday.One small downside - no swimming pool

Staying here on occasion, this is truly professional service. Personally it was the perfect experiance for me because i was at an important moment in my life, the excellence of the hotel put my mind to ease and i was able to reach the right conclusion, amazing days and nights. You can't complain about anything, they met, and exceeded the expectations at every turn. I now live not long from here it's nice, like having stepped into a dream, it stays with me now.

Last time I went to Tokyo, I was struggling to afford any hotel. Some years later, it was a matter of which 5 star hotel would give me the best experience Toyko hotels have to offer. For me, it came down to a choice between the Park Hyatt (in Shinjuku), the Peninsula or the Mandarin Oriental. I spent a lot of time researching these fine hotels. Having had a drink at the bar in Park Hyatt (the same one that Bill Murray drank at in "Lost in Translation") last time I was in Tokyo and realising that the Park Hyatt really is stuck in the middle of nowhere a 15 minute walk from Shinjuku station in the middle of Govt office buildings that are dead at night (and not wanting to stay in such a deathly boring location), I chose the MO over the Penisula. I still don't know if I made the right choice, because so many reviews of those other hotels talk about how good they are. I have not stayed at those other hotels so cannot comment on them. However, what I do know is that the guest experience I had at MO Tokyo was one of the very best hotel guest experienes I have had anywhere in the world (and I have stayed at some fine hotels around the world), so those other hotels would have to do an absolutely amazing job to exceed the experience at MO Tokyo. Concierges - these guys were absolutle winners. Setsu, Eriko and Yoko were brilliant. I started emailing them as soon as I made my reservation - weeks before I arrived at the hotel. They emailed me itineraries, Japanese phrases that I requested, organised baseball tickets for me got me dinner at an Iron Chef restaurant (Chef Michiba's in Ginza - Rokusan Tei - hint, I did not enjoy it and would not go again). When I arrived, they were constantly helping me while I was there. These guys are legends. Some of the best concierges I have ever encountered. MO Tokyo should double their pay checks. The hotel itself sits on the top 8 or so floors of a modern office tower in Nihonbashi, right next to the Japanese central business district (as opposed to the ex-pat CBD in Ropponggi in mid-Tokyo). As soon as you catch the lift to the reception floor you will be captivated by the breathtaking views of Tokyo that you can see from the floor to ceiling windows all around you. Even the well-equipped and modern gym (which faced north to Akihabara) has that amazing view out the window. The restaurants are wonderful at MO Tokyo. We tried all of them and had great experiences at them. The Swiss Italian guy who is one of the Managers in the breakfast area provides wonderful service to foreigners, but so do all the other staff members. The Cantonese restaurant was first rate - couldn't imagine that it would match Man Wah or Lung King Heen (both in HK) but it was right up there with them. Very impressive, given that it's in Tokyo not HK. The rooms - I have read some varying reviews on Tripadvisor of the rooms at MO Tokyo. We stayed in one of the better and bigger rooms - an Oriental Suite. This was a wonderful room on the corner of the building with 270 views from west through north to east. I would recommend a westerly view as it gives you a view of Mt Fuji. Only problem was we were there in June. I had not realised but many Japanese people told me that is the one month it rains a lot and you cannot see My Fuiji. Sure enough, I never saw it, but I saw Fuji-san in August many years ago when I was previously in Japan. Hint - if you want to see Mt Fuji, don't go to Japan in June. The Oriental Suites are beautifully appointed rooms, just lovely. The showers have 3 shower heads, there's a huge bath and everything you need, even a pair of binoculars for a bit of people spotting! But I cannot comment on the more standard rooms, as I did not stay in those rooms. There is even a MO Tokyo cake shop downstairs selling amazing pastries, cakes and breads and chocolates. Other than the fact that my room was beautiful and the bar and restaurants were amazing, what sets out MO Tokyo as memorable is PERFECT LUXURIOUS SERVICE. The Service at MO Tokto was incredible. Nothing was too difficult for anyone. See above regarding the concierges. There was allways a friendly welcome for us when we left and returned to the hotel. When we arrived from Hakone on the bullet train, 2 MO Tokyo staff members met us at the platform and helped us take two taxis from Tokyo train station to the MO Tokyo. They are not based at the train station. They came from the hotel to meet us after I called them saying I was not sure how to get to the hotel. Now that's service!Right underneath the hotel, there is an escalotor down to an underground train station on the metro network. It could not be closer. It is in the same building. Kanda, the nearest JR train station is barely a 5 minute walk away. Mitsukoshi's flagship department store is just across the world. It's a perfect location.Cost - MO Tokyo is an expensive hotel If you are budget conscious (like I was on my first trip to Tokyo) then don't even consider this hotel. However, if budget is not as much of an issue, then this hotel becomes an option. MO Tokyo has left me with a dilemma - when I next go back to Tokyo, do I try those other first rate hotels or do I go back to MO Tokyo? The problem is that I have been to so many nice hotels around the world that I know when I have found somewhere that is amazing. And that's the problem. MO Tokyo is amazing. As much as I would like to try those other hotels, I cannot imagine going back to Tokyo and NOT staying at MO Tokyo. I love this hotel so much that it will pull me back next time I visit Tokyo. This is surely one of the very finest hotels in the world. Dear readers, how many times do you say that about a hotel?

Hotel lobby ison 38th floor and they only have abt 100 rooms so the hotel is both classy, big abd yet exclusive. Hotel is or least looks brand new. We had booked a corner suite attached to a twin room and we had great views from our windows on all sides. Tokyo sits below us sprawling all the way to the bay. The service was prompt, fast and yet exclusive. By the 2nd day, they seem to know all of us by name. Throughout our stay, the service conntinues to be first class. Concierge was friendly and knowledgeable about things and services in Tokyo. They even helped us to book our complete hakone tour and onsen accomodation, transfers etc. Room had a modern decor and offered 10 kinds of diff pillows. Also offered 3 diff kinds of shower heads in their walkin shower. Rooms were large and spacious. Only complain we had was that there were no english movie or cartoon channels or even sports or golf channels at a minimum. The gym was small but state of the art,,,throughout my stay, i was the lone phantom of the opera togther with the trainer. Location : in the midst of bustling nihonbashi surrounded by shopping and more shopping, it was both convenient as well as plenty of food choices around esp at the Credo building directly across. Served one of the best shabu shabu in tokyo using their own famous pork. 7 courses of porky heaven. The hotel bakery which my girls frequented was if a high gourmet standard. the breads and cakes were both pretty and yummy. Room service (though more expensive than the tons of restaurants immediately outside) was fast and superb. Prepared a full dinner for 4 of us in 20 mins in peak dinner time. Something i could never concur at all our usual 5 star hotels we are so used to.We have stayed previously at the suites at Park Hyatt in Shinjuku and Grand Hyatt in Roppongi but this hotel's service beats them hands down,,,

after a couple of weeks hiking in the Japan Alps and sleeping on the floor in little Japanese inns - the charm quickly wears off - my sister and i checked in to this hotel.It is on the upper floors of an office building, and I can hinestly say that I cannot faulty it in any way...sure, its downright expensive (dont use the mini bars or restaurants ) go out, and use 7-Eleven to buy provisions...but in all else it is wonderful.Ni complaints at all, and the views are spectacular over the wonderful city of Tokyo.

I cannot fault this hotel. The staff are second to none. Especially their Concierge, Setsu Waga. I needed to get tickets for a gig while on holiday in Japan. However I could not find a website in English to purchase them and when I asked the hotel how to go about it, Setsu Waga offered to purchase them on my behalf. The trouble she went to was surely above and beyond her job description. She was meticulous, going to the trouble of mapping my journey, explaining how long it would take, printing out my seating and giving me directions. I cannot say enough good things about her.The hotel itself is perfect and we had a superb view of the city. After 16 hours in the air, the bar was fantastic to relax in and get a bite to eat. Try the crab cakes!

The best service in any hotel (Budget, Luxury, Resort, you name it) we have ever encountered so far. Everyone went over and beyond to make us feel at home. At the end of 3 nights, we felt they were part of family. Number of staff members even came to our cab to send us off. The concierge was ready with all the details we had discussed prior over email. Another plus; the location of the hotel is awesome; Lot of interesting stores nearby and has a very bright/fresh vibe. The subway is right in the basement and so very easily accessible to Ginza, Asakusa, Shibuya, Harajuku etc. without even having to transfer trains. The breakfast spread was one of the best and taste of the Japanese options and the fresh chocolate croissants was phenomenal. We also stayed in 'The Peninsula' and also visited 'Park Hyatt' during the same trip. The service levels there are unmatched to that of MO-Tokyo. The rooms are a bit underwhelming for the property of this stature.

The only reason I stayed at the Madarin Oriental was because a colleague dared me to break my habit of staying at the Four Seasons. Staying at the Mandarin Oriental broke that habit … for good. This place is amazing. The level of service is unsurpassed. From the warm greeting you get as you step out of the cab to the flawless in-room check-in to room, the service is flawless. The staff is polite, friendly and unobtrusive and makes every moment relaxing and enjoyable. The room is well designed with a large sofa, working desk and very comfortable bed. Turn down service leaves the room ready and waiting after a long day at the office with relaxing music and aromatherapy oils creating an oasis of tranquility. The bathroom has a large soaking tub and walk-in shower with plenty of towels, comfortable bathrobes and useful amenities (particularly if you forget shaving foam!) The best part of my stay was when I walked into the room to be greeted by the sun setting behind Mount Fuji. I have seen Fuji on many occasions but this view is literally beyond description. The buffet breakfast was excellent with plenty of choices and the usual perfect service. I didn’t dinner eat at any of the restaurants but have promised myself to try them on my next visit. Room service food was excellent. Try the mild Japanese vegetable curry … yummy! The lounge was also very comfortable and served a good selection of wine and cocktails. It was a bit smoky but that is just one of those things. I’m going back to Tokyo next week and have already canceled my booking at the Four Seasons … I’ll be staying at the Mandarin Oriental from now on.

WOW!That pretty much sums up our experience at the Mandarin in Tokyo!Amazing location, amazing lobby, fantastic rooms (we got upgraded - twice!), incredible spa, great bar... and the best service we've ever encountered!Food was great, but not always excellent... the Chinese restaurant was so so - but the special Sunday dimsum lunch was out of this world!

My trip here in luxury was breathtaking... from greated with by the side building to the lift then it opens up to a scenary of exclusive Lobby area viewed by the city lines...simplly in Zen Lifestylethe rooms : are speachless, though u can get TV everywhere even during nature callsit had side small door to acess for room service or sending letters if u wish not to be disturbedroom service was promptit was LUXARY in HIGH RISE..Tokyo style

As most other reviewers we were really delighted during our 3 night stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo.Our room was facing the sky tree and the view at night was just breathtaking. The room itself was just huge and we were really surprised by the size of it after being so used to small rooms in Tokyo even in higher end hotels. The bathroom was just awesome with rain shower,a huge bath and loads of space. The design of the room is slightly outdated compared to very recent hotels but the quality of it still makes up for it. The staff was top notch, not only polite and efficient but also friendly making us feel really welcomed. The spa facilities were great with 2 separate baths and 2 different saunas. The only small downfall we could find would be location, again depending on what you are looking for.First, being in a business area, it is mostly surrounded by premium shops, department stores and banks. So if you are in for local type of eateries, there is need for some walk towards the JR Kanda station and its surroundings . Yet it is quite a reasonable walk, around 10-12 minutes at most. Now if you are in Tokyo to shop at Shibuya, Harajuku or Shinjuku then it is quite a distance with a over 35 mn JR ride to these places. We did it a couple of times and it was much more tiring than we would have thought. But overall this is just a great hotel and if you take in the size of the rooms, the view you get and the level of service that goes with it, we wouldn t even think that the price can be considered expensive by Tokyo standards. We would definitely recommend this hotel except for those whose main objectives are based in the Shibuya-Shinjuku area.

This Mandarin Oriental is probably the only one that blew me away compared to the 2 properties in HK and NYC. Very detailed room, short 2 night business trip so that was a very nice perk. The bathroom had maybe 1/3 the space of the entire room and amenities were most complete I've seen even compared to some NYC 5 star hotels double the price. The location was excellent, a short walk to the Tokyo station and Mitsukoshi department stores. Didn't have time to do the tourist sights but 10-15 min walks were enough for a Tokyo first timer. The staff was very helpful in helping me get directions, had the airport train schedules printed out, and was overall very attentive. Kshiki breakfast quite nice, although not as massive a spread as Mandarin HK properties. The bar was pretty good too. The only strange thing was I arrived at 11:30 pm and the main door was through an Office building and I couldn't get in except from the back door which was a bit hard to find save for the fan in a discreet location. Also agree with a prior reviewer that the lifts were a bit time consuming.Other than that, nothing else seemed unsatisfactory. Views from both the room and the restaurants were amazing. Will definitely recommend for business or solo, not sure it's baby friendly because I did not see a lot of small children as this was the business district.

MO.Tokyo provided me a very comfortable stay, helpful staffs and spotless services. I've got four nights in this trip.--A few Cons--It's all about typical Japanese limitation,((Room)) In this price, feels that I've got smaller room than any other Mandarin Orientals. But I realised that it's almost same size with MO.HongKong or Landmark MO. HongKong. That's not a problem.((Lobby area)) In weekdays, it's seems to be luxury as usual. In weekends, I've met a lots of Japanese families at the lobby.--Lots of Pros--((Location)) Ideal location for business, not too far from shopping (my wife got few things from Tiffany & Co. at Mitsukoshi, two minutes away walk from the hotel) and very easy access to Tokyo Metro just below the hotel.((Facilities & Amenities)) Excellence as expected from MOs.((Foods and Drinks)) Very good quality of foods and drink list, I was enjoyed the breakfasts and late night drinks at the bar with my Japanese partners. ((Staffs)) Finest people in the service industry, they may have trained like a Jedi. Mr.Niccolo at the K'shiki restaurant was excel in his job. Great service mind and caring in every details for everyone on the table. Mr.Takashi at the guest relations was also helpful in everyday. He made me feel secure and providing me lots of informations about Tokyo. I've got a big smile every time I've met him at the lobby. All-day long enthusiasm to serve. And Mr.Sato at the lobby was also kind. Politely asking for our feeling in everyday we've met. It's not just 'how are you' but, he'll make sure that you're really fine.It's all I need from staying at home away from home.

I stayed for three nights at the Mandarin Oriental at the start of my trip and was knocked out by the panoramic views of the busy city below; only the view from the Tokyo SkyTree would be better. The hotel lives up to its reputation, the staff is impeccable and the rooms luxurious, although the style is a little nondescript asian international rather than japanese. The main irritation is the dual lift system needed to reach the guest rooms and the convuluted access to the metro system. The local area offers all the usual department stores and the imperial palace is fairly near.

wonderfull hotel, nice service , beautifull ameneties and welcome gift everyday, from fruits to choclates and goods , very attentive and hospitable , recpectable staff . a luxury hotel indeedcons : small rooms , complicated access and exit of the hotel premises and rooms (not something that can be fixed), no japanese standard of hospitality , kind of international standard , " meaning they wont go out of their way to serve you " but none the less they are very good.my ac in the room was not as cold as i wanted , i felt sweaty at night it didnt get fixedprice vs quality - a bit over pricedlocation is decently good , not the best though ...id go back there again.

Wonderful hotel, fantastic service and ambience. We called for a bucket of ice and (I kid you not) within 2 minutes the ice was in our room. Breakfast was great and the views even nicer. At the time we actually thought that the hotel was good - but not great - however having spent a few nights at other first class hotels after this stay - we realised how great the Mandarin actually is.

I stayed here in a rare moment of extravagance with a partner, and was impressed from the moment we walked in the door. The staff are just falling over themselves to help you, and the rooms are well-appointed and spotless. Sitting in one of the 38th floor restaurants on the first night watching the shinkansen trains come and go was a great welcome to Tokyo.There is only one thing I would 'criticise', for want of a nicer word: the staff appeared to make a big deal of us being a same-sex couple when we first arrived, though not being too familiar with Japanese customs I don't know whether "Is it one room or two?" translated as "We just need to confirm your booking" or "Two men? Are you serious?". But that was it. It's also primarily a business hotel so I guess 95% of men arriving in pairs are just colleagues!But I can't seriously fault the place - modern luxurious rooms, central location, incredibly helpful staff, great views day and night. You won't regret it.

Very nice hotel, as you would expect, but for me not quite the Top hotel in Tokyo. The staff were fantastic, but somehow the views didnt seem quite as nice and the rooms a bit old fashioned in style. Dont get me wrong, they are very very nice but felt a bit bland. Food was great and love the location. No pool and it seems a bit cheap to ask you to pay to use the whirlpool (you can only use for free if you pay for a spa appointment or get there really early). Also no pool.

This is a fantastic hotel. The view of the city is amazing and the staff are top notch. You just can not fault it. The sushi restaurant that takes 8 people is a memorable experience - not cheap though. In fact my wallet still has a hole in it. Such is life. There is little more to say than this the go to hotel in Tokyo.

This is the place to stay in Tokyo ! Fantastic rooms, Mount Fuji view and an upgrade after requesting a smoking room !The bar is very stylish, great service and Cocktails.Highlight was the Sushi Restaurant, only 8 seats served by 2 Sushi Masters and 2 Waitresses, again great view and delicious food !

This hotel is really lovely! The rooms were spacious and the views over Tokyo were simply amazing! The staff were also very pleasant. The food in the hotel was also very nice. We loved our kimonos provided to us in our rooms aswell.

We've stayed in other "5-Star" hotels, some that do rate such and some fall short. However, The Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo, far exceed our wildest expectations. Imagine being greeted, by name, without any introduction by either of us, in what we thought was the lobby. The ground entrance was stunningly beautiful and had numerous staff members available to cater to us. "No, Mr. McCrary, the lobby is on the 38th floor, your bags will be delivered to your room, let me escort you to our lobby." That was just a precursor. The "real" lobby's check-in desk (three desks, each with at least two staff persons) fronted two story windows overlooking fabulous downtown Tokyo. After our efficient check-in, we were escorted to our room on the 32nd floor. As we walked into the door, shades drew up, curtains pulled back, and beautiful Asian music began to play. The entry's drama was matched by yet another breathtaking view of Tokyo with Mt. Fuji looming in the distance. Our luggage arrived and after a "tour" of the room, we just stood there dumbfounded as we took in the view. But, no, our reception was not yet complete. A few moments later, we heard our doorbell. A gentleman brought in a spectacularly beautiful bento box of delicious fresh fruit and luscious chocolates (see photo). Our entire stay mirrored those fist few minutes after we arrived. The decor is Architectural Digest quality. The views, from the room to the lobby and restaurants to the bar, are like an observation tower. The huge, efficient staff was multilingual and responsive beyond belief--anytime we were headed towards and elevator, a staff person would run in front of us to push the call button, then enter (after us) to push the floor button! The room amenities were top shelf. We even had a choice between at least a half-dozen pillow types. I could go on... Actually, I'm surprised we ever left the hotel to see the rest of Tokyo. It was that good!

This is one of the nicest hotels I have ever stayed in. The service is top notch as well as the amenities. Within our room we kept finding all the small details that helped make the stay. We also were fortunate to get a view of mount Fuji one night. Definitely recommend and if back in Tokyo definitely staying here again.

From the understated but elegant lobby to the incredible view from the reception area, the beautifully appointed rooms and exceptional service this is a classy hotel by any standard. We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental for four night in August 2012 and found it to be an excellent experience. Everything about the hotel oozes class and sophistication, even though we are quite un-sophisticated, the staff were warm, attentive, welcoming and were always thinking a step ahead. The service from the lobby to the maid service was always exceptional and came across in a genuinely friendly manner. We stayed with a 1yo and the staff tripped over each other to make sure she was comfortable and attended to, including rushing a high chair and kiddies cutlery and dinnerware to our table when we ate.The breakfast buffet was abundant and of very high quality, from the juice to the pastries to the eggs prepared to order. There are two small gripes/irritations I had whilst staying here. 1. the restaurants are very good but expensive, the food is not too badly priced but the drinks are bit too much... mineral water $12 aud per bottle.2. the hotel is located in a predominantly business area, so bad luck if you're a foodie or like shopping, you'll need to catch a taxi.Overall I'd recommend it to anyone who can afford it, and... even if you can't, it's a great experience and worth flexing the fantastic plastic for.

this is a very modern hotel with top facilities and quite good location, the service is great as everything else there. My room had a nice view, really good bathroom with a round bath. Go there if your company pays!;)

Trust the reviews, and stay there. You'll be writing like other reviewers when you come back. In addition to what have alreayd mentioned, I would stress how 'unique' their service is. By that I mean they don't have arrogance and snobbish attitudes that you sometimes find in hotels of this level. Simply the best. Seriously!

The climax of my trip came when I stayed here. I can't believe it was that good!The services were professional. I didn't speak Japanese and they helped me reserve a table for the restaurant and a seat for my train. They also gave me the maps to go to these places, I felt so warm. The stationery was very useful as I had to use to wrap my gifts for my family and friends. Just one thing, the mirror was opposite to the bed and i could see the reflection from the bathroom. It was just a bit scary...Room: DeluxeDecor: wonderful! the room was just super largeBed/ Sleeping quality: goodBathroom: the bath tub was just very big, I believe I could swim there...View: Magnificent city viewsLocation: above the metro (三越, 10-min walk to Tokyo main station)Staff: professional customer services

I'm a brutal reviewer, and yet I can hardly find a fault in this hotel. I travel everywhere and yet have never experienced service like this hotel; perfect and yet very naturally friendly. The views are amazing, and they have a great bar below the lobby.The ONLY thing I didn't like is that the location requires you to taxi to see anything; there's literally nothing worth seeing in that neighborhood. Otherwise, it was brilliant.
user_name:
peneloperose
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: All Mandarin Oriental Hotels should be measured against MO Tokyo as the MO standard. Excellence redefined and they certainly know the true meaning of "attention to details". Apart from the stunning views, spacious accommodations, top-notch housekeeping, legendary service, and making each guest the center of their attention, not much else can be said about this faultless stay. We arrived in awe and left in awe... This is how the legendary MO way should be defined, but surprisingly, not all MO hotels are made the same.A truly impressive and most memorable experience... Congrats and two thumbs up to MO Tokyo!

8 nights in Mandarin Corner room with Skytree and Ginza viewPROs:Excellent location (15 mins walk) to Tokyo station, the main hub for the Shinkansen, close to Ginza, the Imperial Palace and Akihabara.The bedrooms have 2 large glass walls with excellent views over Tokyo.And surprise: another glass wall just near the bathtub, enabling a similar view of the Tokyo skyline, especially sweet while relaxing in the evening.Modern, elegant rooms, nice design.Dining: Sense is a good chinese restaurant, again with panoramic views. The Peking duck is remarkable.Sora sushi: a minimalist modern sushi counter with around 10 seats, serving the best Edo-mae sushi I've ever tasted thanks to the mastery of sushi chef Yuji Imaizumi. Thank you again.K'shiki is probably not in the same class yet again you should spend an enjoyable evening there as well thanks to the views and good service.Haven't tried Signature restaurant which I regret now. Haven't tried breakfast.The bar, with a nice design, is also excellent in atmosphere and vibe, serves a wide variety of cocktails, single malts, etc and is located in the middle of the floor below the reception, again with great views over Tokyo. Staying at the counter however is also enjoyable.The lobby design is an example of superlative modern japanese design. Outstanding service throughout the entire stay. Never heard the word "no". All the staff did their best to provide the best assistance and quality service possible. Concierge, reception, restaurant staff, ground floor team, everyone deserves a praise.CONsThe corner rooms are not very large. If not for the feeling of space provided by the glass walls, I'd say they are quite small.This place is not recommended for visitors with a budget. Expect 500EUR+ for a 2 persons dining experience and approx. 20 EUR minimum price tag for a drink at the bar.Everything is quite expensive even compared to similar establishments around the world.Really missed a nice swimming pool in the hot summer months of Tokyo. This is probably the single, most evident flaw of Mandarin Oriental Tokyo.All in one, I'd recommend anyone who has the opportunity to experience the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo. Having also stayed at the Mandarin Oriental in Singapore twice, I would recommend the Mandarin group as an example to follow in the high class hotel industry. One of my favorites, at least in Asia.

Astonishing view , location and service!In general, it's easy to feel free their hospitality from their transportation service ,doorman,front desk,concierge and restaurant. Especially concierge, they always methodize everything you request and kindly attach the map with information. In addition, they enthusiastically advise restaurant to provide english menu or any assistance for special event. It's nice to break through the language barrier.We're happy to choose the Mandarin Oriental hotel to celebrate our 20th wedding anniversary. Thank you for their thoughtfulness.

I liked- the amazing views (was facing the Skytree)- the central location for business - the good restaurants- the nice and professional staff - the very nice rooms (special mention to the bathroom and the electric operated curtains)- and above all the stunning design.This would make it one of my favorite hotels in Asia and in the worldBut...I did not like- the business center opening hours: for a business hotel having a business center just opened 10 hours a day is simply just not working. Seriously...- the two elevators and the entranceAnd when will five stars hotel understand that business travellers nowadays expect free wifi as part of a standard package and iphone/ipad docks in their rooms?

Very elegant choice, top notch hotel. Have stayed here a couple of times on business. Very convenient for business meetings, being located on the busy Nihonbashi street. Hotel facilities are excellent, and the lobby and rooms boast some of the best views in Tokyo. Rooms are as good as you would expect from a mandarin hotel anywhere. The best selling point of this hotel is the lobby overlooking the entire city of Tokyo, and the famous spa. For anyone wishing to spend top dollar, would recommend this place. Probably would not come back here on my own account though, having one of the priciest rates in Tokyo.

Stayed twice recently. Fantastic rooms, everything you could want and unrivalled views of the city. Great beds, robes, showers, tubs.... Couldn't really be any better. Service is wonderful and attentive. Staff went out of their way to welcome us, to help us and to ensure that we had a perfect stay. The bars and restaurants are all great. It's pricey of course, but you get what you pay for.

Shouldn't be surprising for anyone that a Mandarin Oriental Hotel is great. If you are willing to spend the $, this property does not disappoint with luxurious and comfortable rooms, top notch facilities (such as fitness room), stunning views (lobby on 38th floor and hotel rooms few floors below), and extremely pleasant and helpful staff. The technology in the rooms is also notable (phone and TV system, lights/shade control, bathroom) and rain style shower is a nice touch,If have to nitpick, food was generally very good but breakfast was a little lacking/bland for the price; lunch in the Chinese restaurant was delicious. Also, the location is more convenient for business travel as not that close to the major tourist sites (but easy cab or subway ride).
user_name:
Bucky6478
New York City, New York

review_body: Nice hotel, great service, lovely rooms,wonderful atmosphere, friendly and knowledgable staff. Highly recommended

We arrived before 11 am, but were allowed to check-in and go to our room which was amazing to say the least which is probably true about every Mandarin Oriental property. The views are amazing, the service is top notch and I can't think of one thing I could complain about.Only downside? The location is good, but not perfect (depends on what you want to do in Tokyo and where) - I am still giving it 4 out of 5. This is not the cheapest hotel in Tokyo, but hey, if you are asking how much it is, you probably can't afford it.Will definitely come back!

Everything is beautifully done. Impeccable service. View from the room is stunning. The real highlight is their spa - the Time Ritual is one of the best treatment I have had in my entire life - Highly recommended.

I have stayed here for years as it is become my "go-to" when Visiting Tokyo. I enjoy that it is located on the top floors of an office tower so all the rooms have spectacular views of Tokyo especially at night. Room decorations and bathrooms are top notch. Comfy beds and turndown service will oils is also provided....a lovely way to go to sleep with a nice relaxing scent in your room. Breakfast overlooking Tokyo was fantastic...watching the city wake up in the morning....and the quality of what they serve really is excellent, as was all the services. If I have one small complaint it would be that I asked for a "typical" Japanese restaurant for dinner alone and they sent me to one with no prices on the menu.....It was delicious, fun and interesting and they took great care of me.....The $300 bill for one was a sort of a shock, but hey....Caveat Emptor, I should have checked before. Live and learn. This hotel is located directly above a major train station meaning you can get anywhere in the city from here....it really is perfect. Cannot recommend it more. Safe travels to all! NYC

Arrived jet lagged from London, great welcome. Staff couldn't be more helpful. Real room with a view. Good sized, very good bathroom, a very inviting bed! Amazing view of Downtown Tokyo. The sushi bar in the hotel was excellent. Overall service couldn't be faulted. Will definitely return. Competes Very well with the Mandarin in HK.

This is a great hotel with a very helpful staff. Some reviewers don't like the location but we found it quite handy. It's down the block from the oldest department store in Tokyo that was great fun to visit. The hotel has a great bar with a jazz trio. Our room was beautiful, quite spacious with a large bathroom with a lovely view of Tokyo. Wonderful buffet breakfast.
impressive rooms, large bathroom with gigantic bathdelicious in room breakfastservice very delicate and discreet

If you are looking for the lap of luxury, this is it! I stayed there with my family in an adjoining room and it was fabulous. One room was on a corner with a gorgeous view of Tokyo and the other twin room for my children was spacious and also had an awesome view. I had stayed here before on business and had built up my family's expectations ahead of time. The Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo did not disappoint!

I’ve been traveling to Tokyo on business and pleasure for about 15 years and I’ve stayed in most of the high-end hotels in town. I discovered the Mandarin Oriental about 3 years ago and this quickly replaced my previous favorite, the Park Hyatt in Shinjuku for a number of reasons. First of all, and this may be obvious is location – Nihonbashi is a 5 minute cab ride from Tokyo station or a 10 minute walk. Its location also offers something else. There are plenty of restaurants nearby that are open on a Sunday night – important if you show-up late, jetlagged, restless and itching to explore.A comfortable bed, complicated shower, multiple TVs and work facilities may have become standard fare for this class of hotel but the designers of these rooms seem to have hit the right balance between homely comfort and trendier-than-thou styling. The view from all the rooms is fantastic but avoid the lowest floor number (30 I think?) as the wrap-around balcony and machinery for cleaning windows somewhat obscures the edge-of-a-precipice view of the city (ignore this advise if you are scared of heights).Breakfast is something I usually skip but jetlag does strange things and I often wake up famished. Other five star hotels in town often fall short, with a lack-luster buffet or itemized pricing which will make that sushi dinner in Ginza you were wondering how to expense look cheap. The Mandarin Oriental nails breakfast completely, regardless of your preference for Western, Chinese (dim sum) or Japanese style. Make sure this is included in your room rate as you won’t want to miss it.The service in this Mandarin is nothing short of legendary. Nothing is too much trouble and many of the staff go to the extent of remembering names even if you are there for just a couple of nights. If you bring young children, expect the staff to engage with them too. Having spent months in another 5 star hotel across town where I was always anonymous this is a very pleasant contrast and never gets to the point of being overbearing or invasive. One other important point – if things do go wrong – like the wrong room type or room rate the management team are quick to resolve the issue quickly and amicably with follow-up. In my experience what often happens in other hotels in town is the staff will apologize profusely, but no actual progress is made in fixing the problem.Other worthy mentions worth a visit are the bar (although the New York Bar at the Park Hyatt does win out as a destination) and the usually deserted but well equipped gym.
The concierge deserves a metal. She went above and beyond for us on several occasions, before and during our stay.The property is beautiful, and the service is top notch.
Fantastic rooms, Fantastic & Friendly Hospitality, Excellent & Good Value Food, Excellent location too! I would highly recommend this hotel and would definitely stay here again!

What I liked best about the room- It was spacious, had a fantastic view of Tokyo, an overhead "rain", traditional AND hand/held shower, comfortable bed (with choice of pillow filling) and tasteful furnishings. What I liked best about the hotel- the breakfast buffet. Both Japanese and American dishes were offered at the K'shiki restaurant. Everything I tasted at both breakfast and dinner was beautifully presented and delicious. Chatting with charming Mr. Brachelente, assistant manager of the K'shiki restaurant, very much added to our enjoyment of the dining experience. Ms. Yuko Sumida, one of the outstanding concierges at the hotel, always welcomed me with a smile, shared excellent advice about sightseeing "must sees", provided neighborhood maps and directions, telephoned shops in search of items of special interest to me, suggested and arranged luggage forwarding to Hakone and purchased train tickets for ongoing parts of my journey. She was always very pleasant, delightful and efficient, and her invaluable assistance is one of the main reasons I would book accommodations again at the Mandarin Oriental. Having stayed at the Mandarin Oriental, I can't imagine booking a room anywhere else on my next trip to Tokyo.
user_name:
Marw123
New York City, New York

review_body: Hands down - the best Mandarin hotel, and one of the best hotels I have ever had the pleasure of staying, period. It is beautifully decorated and has incredible 360 degree bird's eye views of Tokyo. It's like a palace in the sky. The service was OUTSTANDING. From the moment you are greeted at the door on arrival, to the very unconventional check-in process - we were taken not to the front desk but directly to our suite where we settled in seamlessly and comfortably while completing check-in details. This was a first!We stayed in the Oriental suite, a corner unit that was just incredibly perfect. A bottle of Moet and a bowl of cherries awaited us on the coffee table, sweeping views of Tokyo were visible from every picture window, along with Mount Fuji peering from afar. Room service and in-room dining were impeccable, we looked forward to brunch in our suite every day. The beds were a bit firm...this is my only criticism. Since we prefer a pillow top mattress we would order an extra duvet to use as one, plus extra feather pillows. Turn down service provides a unique "pillow menu" so you can order something as specific as you like! Plus, pajamas and aromatherapy are provided which is a nice touch.This was our first visit to Tokyo and I am so glad we made the choice to stay at the Mandarin. Chuo is a great upscale area, right next door to the Ginza shopping district and very convenient to the Metro, you don't even technically have to leave the building to get to the trains. Just a short escalator ride down. Unfortunately we were only able to visit for 3 nights, but most definitely are planning to return and will make the Mandarin our home in Tokyo once again!

We just finished our 6 night stay at this hotel and were overall very pleased.The service we experienced was very pleasant. Everyone was congenial and nice. The doormen always had a smile on their faces and were very quick to greet you as you entered the facilities. Also, the concierge was great. He was able to secure us reservations at the two separate, hard to get, 3-michelin-star restaurants that we really wanted to try even before we arrived at the hotel. When we did arrive, he made sure to send us a map and directions on how to get to the two restaurants since Tokyo streets are very confusing. The room's view was incredible and during the night, my husband and I would just enjoy sake gazing out upon the twinkling lights of the city and the Tokyo sky tree. The toilet was really high tech and the bed very comfortable. The TV was huge and the room was impeccably clean. There was only one sink however and the lighting made it hard to apply make-up. The location was really good, very close to Tokyo's metro (infact, it was right in the bottom of the hotel). It was also in walking district from great shopping and the Ginza area. Also if you like quiet, it was definitely quiet at night. Negatives for us: 1. No free internet. I always find this insulting at this caliber and expense of a hotel.2. Quiet area, while i realize this might be a positive for some, it was a negative for my husband and I as we enjoy going out on the town at night. When we went out at night we had to travel quite far away from our hotel and since the Tokyo subway stops running at around midnight, we had to always take an expensive cab ride home. It was usually ~$65 USD every single one way trip on the cab ride home at night from the popular "going out" areas in Tokyo. So this is something to be aware of if you are a young couple visiting Tokyo.
user_name:
luxurylover86
New York City, New York

review_body: Everything was right, except the Receptionist at check in was too COLD andmechanical, she could NOT make me feel at home.

We decided to splurge and stayed here on our last night in Japan, before flying out of Tokyo the next morning. The hotel, as expected, had an amazing decor, and the rooms were of a very high standard.They tried to upsell us to a suite upon checking in, which we decided to take after seeing both rooms. The standard room was more than adequate, and had amazing views of Tokyo Sky Tree. The suite was massive, and also had good views, although it faced away from the Sky Tree. Excellent city views seemed to be provided from most of the common areas of the hotel as well (lobby bar, lobby bathrooms, spa, breakfast, etc).On the negative side, we went for breakfast at 6am, which is the stated opening time, as we had to get an early flight. They were not ready for us at 6am, and we had to wait about 15 minutes before being able to access the buffet, and even then it was only partially ready. This was disappointing for a hotel of this calibre. Breakfast itself was nothing special as well.It is also a very expensive hotel, in terms of room rates, as well as meals, spa, etc, so be prepared to spend a lot. I'm not entirely convinced it is worth the high prices, but it was definitely a memorable stay, and one that I would consider repeating.

I'm always a huge fan of the hotels in the Mandarin group and the Tokyo Mandarin Oriental is no exception. It's one of the newest hotels in Tokyo and sets a very high standard for contemporary, refined elegance and the class-leading service (which is standard in Japan).The location, in Nihonbashi, is adjacent to the high-end shopping in Ginza and the business areas of downtown Tokyo. For tourism purposes, I'm not sure this is the best location (there isn't that much in the immediate vicinity of the hotel) but for business travelers or people looking to use the Shinkansen etc. - it's pretty great. 10 minutes from the hotel (on foot) you'll find yourself in Ginza as mentioned and all of the restaurants and shopping. 10 minutes in the other direction is Kanda which is like a totally different world and overflows with tiny little izakaya, ramen shops and bars.Many of Tokyo's most famous hotels (especially those in Shinjuku) have seen better days. For the money, the Mandarin Oriental is a clear step above. One of my favorite hotels in the world.

I had a city room view. Just amazing, perfect location and great lounge. Food is stunning. The best part is the gym, its on the top floor and has the city view, feels amazing working out like that. The spa is just how the spa should be!

This hotel is well located , well run and goes the extra mile. The food in the Chinese restaurant , whilst expensive, was amazing. You should try the Peking Duck.The rooms offer amazing views of Tokyo and the staff at all levels are great. Upon returning from a run at 7 am I was offered a towel and water at the hotel front door .
My third time to the MO Tokyo. It's still a beautiful property with top notch staff and service - highly recommended!

Surprised and delighted by my stay at this hotel. Service was truly exceptional. Our butler was fluent in our native tongue, very knowledgeable and very friendly. Food was exquisite. We even ate at the Michelin star restaurant, Signature. At night, I had a great time overlooking the lights of Tokyo, and drinking martinis. Wow.

We booked the "MO 634" accommodation package that had a view of Tokyo Sky Tree. The package itself commemorates the tower's reaching of 634 metres which becomes the tallest transmission tower in the world. The package comes with daily breakfast, free internet (not free for normal packages), a complimentary bottle of red wine and “Tokyo Sky Tree” welcome plate.They have really excellent staff services, all of the staff I've met could speak good English (not so common in Japan). They accompanied us from the moment we stepped out of the taxi till we entered the room. Three hotel receptionists accompanied us all the way just to show us the room and offering their help countlessly. It was fantastic.The room was spacious, very clean and had high floor-to-ceiling windows which gave us a gorgeous panoramic view of east Tokyo (Asakusa till Tokyo Bay).Location wise, the hotel occupies the upper floors of the gorgeous Nihonbashi Mitsui Tower which sits on top of Mitsukoshimae Station. Mitsukoshimae Station serves primarily Tokyo Metro Ginza Line and Hanzomon Line and it is linked to Shin-Nihonbashi station that serves Sobu Rapid Line. The hotel is also adjacent to Mistukoshi department store and some other restaurants, so there are plenty of food around.The only disappointment was the breakfast selection at K’shiki restaurant. They provided the same choices every morning, though the food quality was good. We've tried Sense restaurant, food quality was good as well but a little expensive for their standard.Overall we have enjoyed staying here and I'll be back.

We had a wonderful stay at the Mandarin Oriental. The rooms are gorgeous, the service is impeccable, but the food is from the hotel was horrible and outrageously expensive. There are two or three fine dinning restaurants in the Mandarin, but we didn't try those. I rate this hotel high because their service was just stupendous. The concierge is professional, quick and the information that they give you is precise and very detailed. Every question I had was answered and given to me on paper and personally delivered by the concierge herself, to my room at 10:00pm. That's service! I had an amazing view out of my room, I was not facing the Mt. Fuji side but this view was impressive and beautiful. Their beds are dreamy. And they have a pillow menu. Yes, a pillow menu. You can order from all different types of pillows and room service will deliver it to you at any time of the day or night. I felt so pampered in this hotel. The only bad thing that I would say about this hotel is that it's located in the business center, so there is no action after 8pm. You can however, find some restaurants if you walk around but good luck finding one with an English menu. But you can take the Ginza line (right under the hotel) two stops away and end-up in Ginza. That's where all the action happens. There is also lots of action happening in the lounge area, tea room, and restaurants, but i refuse to be confined to my hotel. I want to explore a little bit. I think this place is best for couples who want to be pampered and definitely for business people. There were lots of those in this hotel.

I know I've given this hotel glowing reviews before, but I want to reiterate what a wonderful place this is. If I ever think about staying in a luxurious hotel with all the amenities plus superlative service, this is what I think about.From the moment you arrive on the property you are treated like not only a king but a welcome, favored guest. Your bags are taken from you and whisked to your room, and the person who takes you up in the beautifully appointed elevator to the lobby on the 38th floor with its eye-popping views over the city of Tokyo treats you with suitable deference but also with enough friendliness to make you feel welcome.At the check-in desk this friendliness and feeling of welcome continue as the checking in process is completed quickly and efficiently, yet with that same feeling of welcome. Soon you're on your way to your room. And what a room it is! For the last several times I've stayed here I've super-splurged and stayed in their "Oriental Suite," which is more like a very elegant apartment! It's on the corner of the building, and you have fantastic views of the Tokyo skyline on two sides, from the railroad station on one end to the new Tokyo Sky Tree on the other. You have what amounts to five rooms, including the immense living room, the spacious bedroom, a bathroom that is easily the size of most hotel rooms in Japan with its separate bath and shower, a dressing room, an entryway, and even a second bathroom for use if you have guests coming to visit. And why would you not want to have guests come to visit and marvel at the luxury?There are TWO 50-inch flat screen TVs, a DVD player including several DVDs for you to watch, enough couches and lounging chairs to fill a small hotel lobby, a desk for working on your computer (the only negative thing I have to say about this room is that after paying a huge amount to stay here you still have to pay for internet use) and a mini-bar. I can't think of much else you could want to make your stay a wonderful one!The curtains on the windows are electrically operated, as indeed most everything in the room is, and you could theoretically just lie in bed and operate everything in either of the rooms! The bed, needless to say, is pure heaven, soft, wide, large and with enough pillows to make you comfortable no matter what.When I arrived at my room, behold, I found a nice bottle of expensive champagne and some fresh fruit with which to enjoy my stay. I'd have to say that just about EVERYTHING you could possibly want has been included in this suite.Now this does not come cheap, but if you can, you really need to experience the total luxury of this place.As far as the rest of the hotel, their fitness center and spa are state of the art. The o-furo (Japanese style bath) is a marvel. There are two big baths and a sauna that overlook the entire city of Tokyo, and the fitness center has every exercise possibility known to man. If you stay in a suite, these are all included in the room rate. I splurged a little and had an in-room massage which was truly a wonderful experience.If it sounds as if I'm totally in love with this hotel, you're right. If I'm ever in Japan and can possibly fit it into my budget, I'm staying here! Highest recommendation.

I dont usually review hotels I stay in in Tokyo because its pointless. Basically compared to hotels anywhere else in the world they are in a different league wether staying in a good one or a bad one. As such it makes almost no sense to do so. However as I have stayed in the mandarin a lot I thought I might as well review it. Went again last week. As usual everything is perfect when you get to the room. I dont particularly like the fact that the hotel lobby is on the 38th floor but then again the views are sepctacular. You can literally look into the emperors back yard.  Food is great, service is excellent. There is pretty much nothing bad I can say about it the only one little thing is that the concierge are if anything too helpful - I dont mind getting my own taxi just outside particularly when I am in a hurry. But then again that is Japan for you. MO have combined Japanese exceptional service with a hotel with brilliant rooms (very spacious with a couch in each and a separate super sized tub as well as a gigantic japanese and western combi style shower.  Its not unique but I simply cant fault it

The hotel is expensive as are most properties in Tokyo. The best part is the location: built over the Mitsukoshimae metro stop (Ginza line) and one block from Mitsukoshi and its basement food court. My suggestion would be to book direct;y with the property on their website to give maximum flexibility if you are not happy with assigned room at check in; then you can better negotiate a change or upgrade, at of course, a higher price.

This was my first trip to Japan. I am impressed by the Japanese hospitality and their respect for their own culture. LOCATION :The Hotel ...... it seems to sit right on top of the Mitsukoshimae Subway station , on the GINZA line. From Haneda airport we took the train to Nihonbashi station and then changed to the Ginza line, Mitsukoshimae was just one stop away. As you walk out of exit no 8 at the Mitsukoshimae , the first thing you see is the Mandarin Oriental Hotel .The Subway station has a family mart ( a convenience store chain in Tokyo ). Right next door to the Hotel is the Mistukoshi dept store Tokyo Station is very close by SERVICE :The top class service culture of the Mandarin Oriental was catapulted to new heights by the support of traditional Japanese hospitality In the ratings section at tripadvisor i have an option to rate the Service on a scale of 1 to 5 ...... i would like to give the service at Mandarin a 7 or an 8 out of 5.Every staff member in the Hotel made a genuine effort to make you more than comfortable and deliver their best . I noticed that the staff seemed to be trained to say only YES , to every thing we requested. If at any point they had to say a no , the staff member seemed uncomfortable .DINING :One afternoon , we came in late from a morning tour and were looking for lunch at the Sushi restaurant in the Hotel. We are vegetarian and we had not made any special booking . But the chef was happy to whip up some vegetarian sushis, served with fresh wasabi and a Vegetarian soup. It was a unique experience for us since they prepared everything from fresh ingredients right in front of you. The Sushi bar has a very cosy atmosphere and a friendly staff who engage you in conversation. All in all ,,good food and a pleasant experienceAlso their In-room dining service was good CONCIERGE SERVICE - THE HIGHLIGHT I cannot say enough about the concierge service. They were very knowledgeable and had all the information you may need , on their finger tips . They seem to be prepared for nearly all questions that you may have. Before i came to Tokyo i was not sure if i could make my way around on my own considering that many in Japan did not speak English . But whenever i asked for directions , the concierge would be ready for a few sheets in print , some giving a description how to take the trains , and what exits to take , and always with a map with locations marked both in English and in Japanese .This made things so easy that travelling from one place to another was a breezeWhat was amusing but very pleasing also was that one day the concierge had to research some information and give to us later . In the night when we returned , there was an envelope lying in the room with the information . But the interesting part was that the top of the envelope and the important points in the text of the note... was decorated with stickers of Cherry blossom flowers. It was very nice . It just showed how much pleasure and interest the concierge took in their job . I would like to name Ms Sumida from the concierge as someone who provided us with extraordinary service and helped us with a smile everytime we went upto the desk ...... and believe me that we visited the concierge desk rather regularly.......... The porters / bellboys were very very efficient . Always available and ready to help you. When we checked into the Hotel , while we were going through the formalities of check in ..... our luggage was alredy in our room GUEST ROOMS :Very large and spacious by any standards .... and as i understand the room is HUGE by Tokyo standards. Very modern rooms All amenities that you may need Very clean Good Soft beds ........ they also have a Pillow Menu if you like to make a choice of any specific type of pillow Huge Flat screen TV , Video player , Room Safe , Fantastic toilet , with a large Bath Tub ( nearly circular ) , separate shower area , heated toilet seat , Electronic controlled toilet and Bidet ....I can say this in conclusion ...... its not the cheapest of establishments .... BUT .... every small detail to design and every employee in the establishment makes an effort to provide good value for every dollar you pay . If the Hotel fits your budget .... this should be your choice in Tokyo

We stayed 3 nights at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. The lobby for the hotel is on the 38th floor of the building, and the rooms are on floors 30-36. This setup is a little inconvenient because to get to your room you have to first take an elevator from the ground floor to the lobby, and then walk to the other side of the lobby to take a separate elevator down to your room. However, that inconvenience is immediately forgotten after seeing the incredible views of Tokyo from the 2-story tall picture windows on both the east and west sides of the lobby. It is simply amazing.The lobby is perched above a couple of restaurants and a bar on the floor below which all share the same windows. Unfortunately, this means that the cigarette and cigar smoke from the bar below is readily noticeable in the lobby.The rooms are very nicely appointed, and are large by Asian standards. The furnishings, like the rest of the hotel, are very contemporary. We were on the 32nd floor and had amazing views towards Shinjuku, and when the clouds and haze finally lifted, Mt. Fuji was also visible. With all the rooms being so high, I'm not sure if there is such thing as a "bad view" in this hotel.Every night a tray was placed on the bed that had a portfolio that the TV remote was stored in, as well as a little bottle of aroma therapy scent and a small dish to pour the contents in. It was a great touch to make the experience in the room that much more special.The bathroom was nice, but has the weird glass wall in to the bedroom that can be made private by closing blinds. You can close the blinds completely for privacy, but it's just a strange concept. The water closet was behind a frosted glass door, and had the high tech toilet you frequently hear about. The shower was open to the tub area (i.e., no door) but amazingly there was no issue with water splashing everywhere. The bath products are some of the nicest I've encountered in a hotel.We dined each morning in the restaurant for breakfast which was included in our room rate - it's very expensive otherwise. It consisted of a nice breakfast buffet which included pastries, breads, jams, fruits, salad, soups, dim sum, potatoes, bacon, sausage, waffles, etc. It was a nice spread, and a nice mix of Asian and Western foods. Our breakfast also included a choice of egg, which is where things get strange. The eggs, though they taste relatively normal, are red. Apparently it is due to the diet of rosehip and chile fead to the chickens (a factoid on the menu we completely missed until the last morning). We also had dinner one night in this restaurant and the food was very good, with a view to match. The building the hotel is in is connected underground to the Mitsukoshimae station, though it is a bit of a hike (albeit out of the weather) to the Hanzomon Line. The Mitsukoshi main store is located one block over, and is definitely worth exploring. The store itself is beautiful, and the basement food floor is usually jammed full of people.I had a couple of small issues with the hotel, but were not enough to keep me from staying there again. First the aforementioned smokey smell in the lobby coming from the bar below. Secondly, the coffee in the room was instant coffee as no coffee maker was provided. Thirdly, and most disappointingly, internet access is not included in the room rate. For the amount of money I'm paying for this hotel, I do not expect to pay for internet access.The absolute best part about this hotel was the service. Every single employee was 'on the ball' all the time. They were always ready and going the extra mile to make sure we were comfortable and appreciated. The attention to detail was impeccable. For example, one day we left some of our travel books out on the desk. When we returned, housekeeping had placed a nice bookmark on top of the books for us. But I saved the best for last. Due to an unforeseen travel situation, our luggage was delayed from arriving for 24 hours. After checkin as they were preparing to show us to our room, we were asked if we had any luggage, and we explained the situation. About 15 minutes after we got settled in to our room, the doorbell rang and housekeeping presented us with an 'emergency kit.' The large box contained new t-shirts, boxers, and socks as well as hair care products and pajamas. The enclosed note even offered to overnight launder the clothing we were wearing. This type of service was completely unexpected, and was above and beyond the call of duty in my opinion. This moment - just 15 minutes after arriving in the room - was the defining moment that set the tone for a thoroughly enjoyable stay. I would never think twice about staying here again.

After trying a few Mandarin Orientals, and reading amazing reviews written all over the internet about this property, I decided to give MO Tokyo a try. I am probably the least fussy luxury hotel lover around but there are things that I seriously would expect from the so-called one of the finest hotels in Tokyo. Mind you, the price ain't cheap either. Don't get me wrong, MOTYO is amazing on it's own right, beautiful building, interior design, nice rooms, huge bathroom etc etc.. same old stuff.I was well taken care of although i arrived very early and our room was ready as we reached and we were escorted to our room, with our luggages arrived in first. Good one. However there's something missing here.. after a long midnight flight, i thought the hotel attendant would offer us tea, or something else.. But no, not a word on tea. Mind you, I was at Mandarin Oriental Landmark last month, and i check-in early as well and they served me tea right away since i looked groggy and tired. Not that its a must, but really its those small little things that put a smile on ur face. Welcome room amenities? 3 mandarin oranges, which comes in standard i think, and 6 strawberries placed in a plain bowl. Not sure whats so welcoming about that, but i've seen better welcome amenities, of hotels of the same range and calibre. Oh yes, welcome note came along too, but it was computer generated. Thank you :)On concierge, I asked 2 things. First, is there a place in the city itself that i can pre-purchase tickets to Disneyland Tokyo. She said, NO. I need to go line up in the morning at Disneyland itself early in the morning to get them. To cut things short, i bumped into a Disney store which she didn't mention, at Shibuya, and tada.. we got out tickets for our trip for the day after tomorrow. The queue at the entrance of disneyland on the said date was unbearable if we didn't prepurchase those tickets. How could the concierge did not know this? Secondly, I requested the concierge to guide me on how to get to Kawaguchiko and then from there to Gotemba. The Concierge said she will look it up and send it to my room, for the directions and all. Guess what? for the entire stay, it didn't arrive to our room. Thank God i got friends in Tokyo to help me. I did not expect upgrades or super duper luxury services. But seriously i was expecting too much or i just came on the wrong time on the wrong date with different staff. MOTYO is still worth staying, location is amazing, views are amazing, and most staff are very gracious and smiley. Just to share, Landmark MO HK sent me letter, emails, surveys after my stay. Just to see how was my stay and rectifying issues that arose during my stay there. Now that's a service you don't see everyday. I was hipefully to receive and email or two from MOTYo honestly, but its been almost a week, none came in. For the price, its really comparable to Peninsula and Park Hyatt which both also are my favorite brands. MOTYo could easily been these two, if they truly brush up their services a little bit more. and obviously, i expected too much :)

Not much else to say that hasn't already been said in all of the other "excellent" reviews. I just wanted to add my review to the mix. The amazing views won me over. I have a great view where I live in Kobe so I am used to having something to look at every day and the views from all around the Mandarin did not disappoint. From the tea room, you could see the new "Tokyo Sky Tree" tower dwarfing all of the other buildings in the city. On the other side of the building, we could see Mt. Fuji and the sunsets were beautiful from there. The room was great like everyone else has said on here and the people working there were always kind and helpful.The desserts in the tea room were gross though. I eat desserts every day and usually love them in 5-star hotels but the ones that they served almost made me gag.
