I even love to eat Japanese sweets called "wagashi" but the stuff they served tasted like medicine that was meant to be swallowed and not chewed. As a sugar addict, these could not even be eaten. My friend would not eat his dessert either. But the views and the service far outweighed their lousy desserts so I did not take off any points. I would not hesitate to stay there again even though they could use a quality selection of sweets.

The hotel is really convenient for business travellers, its right in the business district and social visits to the city as its right above the metro. The hotel has a lovely bar where you can sip yummy cocktails while looking out over the city with those little red lights, you know you're in Tokyo.The hotel goes from 33 floor (or around that) upwards so all the rooms have great views from high up.The staff are helpful, polite, everything you would expect from Mandarin Oriental.

Beautiful hotel with excellent views in a quiet business part of town. 20 minutes walk to Ginza and Imperial Palace. Subway station in the same building. Concierge and front door staff were amazing. Breakfast was excellent; great fitness center. Room is gorgeous with plenty of space. Only minor glitch was the discrepancy between what was advertised through American Express Platinum travel package what the hotel provided. When asked about this discrepancy, the hotel did not make it right by me but just asked that I accepted the discrepancy. This is not what I would have expected from the Mandarin Hotel group. Also, the internet was not provided as part of the room price. At the price of these rooms, it's a bit annoying to have to pay for wi-fi service. Other than those two issues, we enjoyed the stay and really appreciated the service provided by the front door staff and the concierge.

I have stayed in quite a few hotels in Tokyo, including Park Hyatt and Peninsula, but have never felt the need to write a review until now. My husband and I stayed for two nights, and from the moment we stepped through the door, the staff made us feel as though we were the only guests. The room was fantastic, with every thought put into the layout and amenities. We tried some restaurants: the casual Italian restaurant on the 2nd floor where you can try a bit of anything and everything. A good mix of cuisines - Italian to Asian- something to suit everyone. Nicola, our host, was top notch and offered the kind of service I find on cruise ships - he couldn't do enough for us. I'm not the demanding type at all, but he took clues from my comments and offered suggestions. For example, I wasn't sure which red wine I wanted so I told him what I like and he brought me two to try, one which I much preferred over the other, so I really appreciated the gesture. The Sushi bar is truly unforgettable, too. The simplicity of the interior is calming and soothing, so exquisite and stylish, just as it should be when you choose to experience up-close, the ancient Japanese art of creating sushi. How the chef shapes the rice, slices the fish and garnishes like they were creating a piece of artwork. During my stay I found the staff to be very helpful: if you have unusual but reasonable requests, you can be sure the staff will go the extra mile. If I ever stay in Tokyo again, then this is where we will definitely return to. Thank you once again.
user_name:
bohnamcarter
New York City, New York

review_body: I visited Tokyo in January with my husband as a special trip for the two us as we had always wanted to go. We booked the Mandarin Oriental through American Express. We arrived at the hotel at 5am in the morning and the reception on the 38th floor to the most incredible view of nightime Tokyo, it was breathtaking. The staff were lovely and our room was ready!! we were not expecting our room as check in is normally at 2pm in the afternoon and it was 5am! The rooms are spacious with lovely bathrooms and plenty of products. Breakfast was a real treat, great service, lovely food and again the views. I have to say the views of Tokyo at night are a lot better than during the day....Tokyo is a vibrant city and worth seeing BUT it is soooo expensive, we were really surprised and we foolishly ended up paying £10 for ONE cappucino in their French inspired department store so be warned...after saying we wouldn't go to Starbucks, guess where we went for coffee for most of our stay?? I did love Tokyo and if you are going please take the Bullet Train down to Kyoto for a day (or two) and visit The Golden Temple and Gion District. The hotel has a subway station right beside it which is great as taxi's are expensive....! I would recommend his hotel to anyone going to Tokyo, if I go back, it will be my first choice again. It made our stay amazing.

If you are wishing for the very best in luxury hotels, whether it be for business or leisure, the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is it.From the door staff greeting you, escorting you to the elevator and bowing each time you enter the hotel, to the 38th floor reception with views over the skyline, every moment of your stay is breath taking.Numerous award winning restaurants, the magnificent rooms, all better than any five star hotel anywhere in the world.The location is great, nearby Tokyo Station and a department store next door, the grandeur is unparalleled.Yes it is expensive, but if you are looking for irreplaceable memories, you cant go past this property.Thanks for the wonderful stay and I'll definitely be back.

I have recently stayed at the Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo for two nights. The reason brought me there was the hotel ranked # 2 in Tokyo, and # 1 in Chuo area in Trip Advisor. I usually stayed at the Peninsula since their grand opening, twice or three times a year. I am as well happy with Peninsula. However, Mandarin Oriental is my top choice now. Excellent service which I never had in any hotel I stayed, good restaurants, perfect room with beautiful view, I can see the Fuji mountain in the front of window, and the bay on the left side. The French Restaurant, Chinese Restaurant, and buffet are very good. Location is nice to walk around, I like Ginza area, but Nihonbashi area is interesting which close to the hotel,and lots of old history shops to see. A big department store Mitsukoshi right next to the hotel. walking distance to Takashimaya department store. I should stayed there for more nights but have to return back home. I don't know how to express my feeling about this hotel,simple word is "I love it".

I stay at the MO Tokyo whenever I'm in Tokyo for business, typically 2-3 times a year for 2-3 days.The MO Tokyo is my favorite hotel. The service is incredible. For example, I'm always impressed that when I walk up to the front desk to check in, they already know who I am, and have all the paperwork prepared (I think the staff on the ground floor must sneak a peak at my luggage tag and radio up to the check-in staff. My first time there, after having checked out, the woman accompanying me downstairs in the lift noticed my Cathay Pacific luggage tag, and asked me if I had registered for miles for my stay. I hadn't known I could, and as soon as I said no, she pulled out a pen and a pad of paper, took down my mileage number, and said "I will take care of it for you". Concierge is similar - all my experiences at the concierge desk has exceeded my expectations.I have only eaten room service, which was actually only ordinary, though still pretty good. Tapas molecular, the molecular gastronomy mini-Restauraunt is amazing. Service in the bar was also memorable. Gym is standard, on par with the rest of the hotel, a bit small but adequate. Room is Mandarin Oriental standard, which is to say very comfortable, and impeccable attention to detail. The welcome fruit is always delicious, especially my first stay there, where the large sweet strawberries dusted with caster sugar was out of this world.Location is perfect for my work. As a tourist, I would probably want to stay more west closer to shibuya, omotesando, etc, but the hotel is a hop and a skip from a subway station, so location is actually just fine.
user_name:
heehorse
New York City, New York

review_body: Amazing hotel. Service and manner of staff is incredibly. Everything works seamlessly. Stayed in 3209 with a view towards Fuji. Love the automatic blinds. Large room size. Thoughtful touches like stationary, stapler etc. Breakfast is devine on the 38th floor. The underground station is right below. Would definitely stay there again and worth the money in my view.

We stayed here in March 2011 and this was the best hotel we've ever stayed in anywhere. As we walked towards the hotel with our bags from Tokyo station, the bell hop ran down the driveway to take almost everything from us. The view behind the front desk was unbelievable. The rooms were all that we were hoping for as this was a treat for us at the end of our fifth trip to Japan.

Throughout the many years I have travelled to Tokyo, my stays at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo have always exceeded my expectations by far. Located a five min taxi ride from Tokyo Central Station (easy to connect via the Narita Airport express train), the hotel occupies the top 9 floors in a 38 story building. From the moment you enter the impressive lobby you feel in a complete different world. Attention to your needs is always there, spacious and luxury rooms with breathtaking views and yes, you will have to pay for Wi-Fi, but the signal is strong and covers the entire hotel, whether in the rooms, at the bar or in the restaurants. Staff is very courteous, extreemly friendly and will do all to make you feel at ease. Mind you that Tokyo is a very big city, an easy access to the Tokyo subway network downstairs in the basement is an added convenience. This is a hotel which won't disappoint. You really feel this place is your true home in Tokyo.

Stayed here and two separate occasions during Japan trip and rate it among the best in the world. Great restaurants and bars had an upgraded giant room with superb views. Once in a lifetime stay helped by wonderful friendly and efficient staff.

We stayed there a week, huge bathrooms, elegantly appointed rooms, profesional and courteus staff, luxury and high tech efficiency, excelent restaurants and an amazing bar and the views of Tokyo skyline are unforgettable
What an amazing hotel - great location (right over an underground station) and right in the heart of Tokyo. Special rooms, super service. Amazing views.

The staff make this hotel great. Very attentive, non-obtrusive and genuinely interested in the guests. I was amazed at how friendly in a particularly Japanese way some of the staff were. Also, it should be noted the morning breakfast staff were exceptional and completely charming. I still think about one gentleman and his attitude and how delightful it was to start one's day with.As far as the hotel and the room, generally no complaints except the bed was a bit firm. The bathroom was fine though the sink was, well, very design heavy. The big flat screen television was there, the water bottles, the multiple light switches. Check all the high end / luxury hotel boxes scorecard. There were beautiful views of Shinjuku from our room. The gym is also good as others have pointed out and much better than the typical 5 star hotel gym. I did notice that some of the carpets are in bad need of cleaning (especially downstairs) which most people would probably overlook (I focus that generally). All and all a great experience, though the staff gave it something special: a liveliness and heart in a temple of corporate luxury. Well done.

Why? Because I always feel at home. From my good friend Ishii san (a true treasure to the hotel) at the front desk, to the refreshing sound of the blinds rising automatically raising themselves when you first enter the room, all is good and right. Rooms are fantastic, service impeccable, and on those magic days when the weather is right, you can cast an eye out towards Fuji as you enjoy your breakfast.I have stayed here both as a business traveller (mostly) and as a tourist (sadly, only occasionally). The hotel caters surprisingly well to both traveling castes. Not to mention the enigmatic Johnny Walker, the de facto head of Tokyo's contemporary arts scene, enjoys his morning coffee there most days. For an entrance into aesthetic Tokyo, no greater Virgil can be found.So how does it compare to its peers in the city? Clearly, all excel in service with location an added feature for others (with the Ritz-Carlton and the Grand Hyatt nearly equidistant from the Almond at Roppongi Crossing). None are bad; in fact all are excellent. Each hotel, however, has its personality. With its warmth of its hospitality, and incredible attention to detail, the Mandarin is where I know I can truly be at rest.
Not much around the hotel apart from the noodle bars of Kanda but who cares. Easily the best City hotel in the world. The reception is outragious. Even if you don't stay there, go visit.

Awesome but not perfect. There's an element of squeezing the customer here which is just annoying at this level - charging for WiFi access room is a prime example, I don't expect to even have to think about this if I need to get on the net for a few minutes. I also expect free (and obviously free) water by the bed. The level of service in Japan in general is staggeringly good, so while the Mandarin is way way above the dismal levels you would find in London (for example) it's not at ryokan level. A little less over staffed breathless running around and a little more quiet attention needed here.

About the Hotel : Unlike typical hotels, this hotel occupies the top 9 floors of a 38 floor building. This makes it very interesting. The do have a private entry staffed up and the lower most floor but the main lobby is located at the 38th floor. What makes it great : The service, one cannot go wrong with the service here. The entire staff knows you name, makes you feel welcome and beckons to you every need. Location : Below the hotel is the Subway, there are two lines here but the more used one is the Ginza line (connects to most tourist places) No train change : Get to Asakusa (traditional Japanese Shrine)No train change : Get to Ginza (shopping, eating) 1 train change : Roppangi Hills, Shibuya, Shinjuku While I cannot say enough good things about Mandarin Oriental, if I were in Tokyo again I would certainly check out the Peninsula or the Grand Hyatt because of where they are located. The Park Hyatt I've head is a cut above but so are the prices. Here is the view from Mandarin Oriental : http://www.flickr.com/photos/yatharthgupta/6412231953/in/photostreamhttp://www.flickr.com/photos/yatharthgupta/6407417913/in/photostream/

The Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo is the kind of hotel you feel lucky to stay in. When you're there and you look at the surroundings, it's the kind of place that takes your breath away.Every little detail has been thought of here. The decor, which is a sleek and elegant Asian contemporary style, is just beautiful. The skyline views are incredible. The service is top notch. The restaurants, spa, lobby, lounge — you name it, this hotel has thought of it and perfected it. It's pricey, but worth every penny. This hotel is a must for anyone visiting Tokyo who can afford to stay here. It's simply perfect.
If you are traveling to Tokyo, just stay at the Mandarin. Everything said about the hotel if good is correct. Great service, food, spotless quality. A best of the world hotel.

The Mandarin Oriental is an exquisite hotel with beautifully furnished rooms. Mine, on the 30th floor had a great view of the city. What is truly exceptional about this place is the service.The staff does everything possible to please you. The one day tour they arranged for us was excellent, with an English speaking Japanese woman educated in the United States.This is one really efficiently run hotel! Congratulations to all the lovely people who work hard to make their guests happy. You really succeed.

Just a brief update from my last stay at New Years - i highlighed the few niggles (in more detail) to management both while i was there and after i got home - they certainly went well out of their way to apologise and explain the issues we had had - on our stay there in Sept they truly looked after us, with a room upgrade and a few other amenities thrown in - this time the whole trip was flawless - everything worked, the staff were superb, the room just out of this world (corner suite with two amazing Tokyo views) - the food was better than ever - i defy you to find better eggs! - and we had a very pleasant (if eye wateringly expensive!) in room meal - plus, once you figure out the underground, which is in the basement of the building, its actually very accessible for lots of the attractions - already looking forward to our next trip there.

What an absolute treat! Three Michelin star restaurants; extremely efficient and friendly service; and magnificent views of sunset over Mount Fuji from your room. Shopping starts right adjacent to the hotel and a pleasant stroll to Ginza (less than 2 kilometres in total) yields great Japanese tea shops, traditional fans and all the latest in Western brands. The Mandarin Oriental is the place to stay!

not very close to harajuku and roppongi at all- its at least a 4000Y ride to get to harajuku. Service is great and rooms are very comfortable. Food at the casual coffee shop was quite fresh for breakfast but not outstanding for dinner (bento box).

I stayed here two days with a comfortable price.The room was great and very well appointed with bathroom. The room was comfortable with beds and other furnitures. the staff service was consistently excellent, very friendly with their guests. The location quite beautiful feel like as in home.....

There is nothing to add on all the positive reviews. I loved the efficiency of the service. The staffs are very friendly and helpful. My only gripe which is not major at all, was the internet was not included. I've stayed in three star hotels in Tokyo; internet service was always included in the rate in all the properties.

I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo for 3 nights in October 2011 in a Premier Deluxe room. The room was spacious, about 530 sq. ft., and very well appointed with the usual gorgeous Mandarin Oriental bathroom. The bed was comfortable with top quality linens and the noise level was very conducive to sleep. Service was consistently excellent, somewhat over solicitous for my taste, but typical for very high end hotels in Asia. The room was on a high floor as is the whole hotel, but my view over the city was pretty unexciting, I would rather have had a room facing Tokyo Bay. Reception is on the 38th floor and the rooms on 30 to 37. One slight annoyance is that elevators from the ground level only go to the 38th floor and you then have to walk across the lobby to go to the separate bank of elevators that goes to the rooms. The health club was well appointed and spotless. The breakfast buffet was very good, without being remarkable.It is very expensive, rooms start at over $600 per night including tax, but a good choice for travelers on an expense account. And even after charging that amount, they still charge over $20 per day for internet access. The location is fine, but slightly out of the centre of the city/Ginza. Nothing about the hotel will surprise those who are used to Mandarin Oriental hotels around Asia, spacious and comfortable rooms, excellent service and high prices for everything.

Mandarin Oriental hotels never fail to meet all expectations, with this one being no exception. Located at the top of a sky scraper, the lobby on the 38th floor has amazing views. The guest rooms are really comfortable. All the usual creature comforts including a nice deep bath and a UK plug connect. Breakfast was an extensive buffet complete with the latest faddy vinegar drink that aids weight loss.
Another great Mandarin experience. Service was great, the room was lovely and the restaurants in the hotel were truly fantastic.
user_name:
Dina A
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: Our second stay at the Mandarin Oriental In Tokyo really met expectations.The professional and well trained staff gave us a very sincere welcome back, and after a long flight from the UK we were very grateful for an early check in without any problems. The room was immaculate. Well decorated and very clean, with amenities you would expect from this 5 star establishment. The menu of pillows was a nice touch and the "lavender aromatherapy pillow" was a great aid to a perfect sleep.II have recently stayed at the Park Hyatt, and the Shangrila in Tokyo which are also both excellent, but the MO just beats them. The restaurants are excellent (though expensive). The one thing I would give as a way to improve the hotel is to include internet in the room rate. When you pay £300 a night for a room it is annoying to be charged £15 a day extra for internet connection. Mainly based on the can do attitude of the staff we will definatly be back!
Cosy room, nice view, good oriental foods and the first class staff. We stayed in our 36th wedding aniversary and had the best memorial stay in Tokyo.

It wasn’t a great start to begin with but it turned out all right. Since it was a very special occasion for our trip I have been emailing them back and forth to make sure I have a perfect stay. But the service wasn’t up to standard at all, no responds at all or I’ll have to send another email to get an answer. (only reservations as the restaurant part email me back within hours)The check-in was simple and easy and they even gave us an extra hour for late check out free of charge, which was really nice of them. We booked the Premier Grand Room and it was reasonably big, room was clean and well presented but I did find a hair in the bath tub!! Not a biggie for me but my partner would have freaked out if he found it first!The facilities in the room were very good but the connection pack for iPod was nowhere to be found. Love the entertainment selection on TV, movies and radio, just wish I could switch the screen off when I had the radio on instead of having the big white screen in the middle of the room.The package we booked for has got free internet so it was great because I just couldn’t justify spending ¥1,800 a day for internet in Tokyo! (where it should be free in most hotels, even Park Hyatt) Unless your breakfast was included in the package otherwise I would definitely suggest you to try local restaurants for breakfast, what’s the point of going to a different country if you stay in the hotel all the time?It’s a great hotel and it has got a direct entrance from the Tokyo Metro station (via A7 or A8) but I don’t know if I was impressed enough to stay with them in Tokyo, but it was a very lovely experience.

I've stayed at a lot of hotels on business, and specifically in Tokyo: Peninsula, Conrad, 4 Seasons, Imperial Palace. But by far the best is the Mandarin.Some people choose not to stay here, but the only real objections I've heard are:1) there's somewhere closer2) there's a pool at the Peninsula3) the wagyu burger at the 4 seasons.those points aside, this is a wonderful hotel with exceptionally welcoming and friendly staff.The breakfast is also fantastic... I could stuff myself all day on the croissants.
Great hotel and we will surely be back. The hotel location is great right next to the twin towers. The staff are first class and we cannot wait to be back.

Quality that one has come to expect from the Mandarin.On the top floor of the building (reception is on the 38th floor).Rooms are typical size of Mandarin rooms in Asian cities - food and service as one would expect.What sets this establishment apart are the views over Tokyo from the rooms and bar area.Hotel is also well located for business travel around Tokyo.I only spent a night at the hoetl, but will be back.What

We stopped in Tokyo on our way from the US to Kyoto and for 2 days on our way back. Both times we stayed at the Mandarin Oriental. There are almost too many good things to keep track of. The staff was so friendly and helpful. The room was incredible with a view to die for! We could see Mt Fuji looming over Tokyo in the summer haze!We needed help getting train tickets to Kyoto and arranging ground transfers. The staff made all of these things work perfectly.Yes, Japan is expensive and certain costs were hard to accept but if you are going to be spending the money anyway you might as well enjoy the best.This is hands down one of the best hotels in the world. It is amazing for me since I find the Madarin Oriental in London so shabby and disappointing.....

The management staff in the restaurants seem to be more interested in the hotel profits than service of the guests. With so few guests in the already over-priced venues you would think that they would have time to see that you are served promptly and without error. New management should be found for this property.

We were very impressed when we first arrived at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo. We'd just come off the overnight flight from Sydney and were swept away by the attentive service and the amazing views. We were expecting to just leave our bags and wait for check in time to come around, but MO already had a room waiting for us. They happily accomodated our request for a booking that night at the Molecular Tapas restuarant and provided us with a map and some ideas for an afternoons sightseeing. Unfortunately the day we arrived was Friday 11 March, the same day as the earthquake. We were very fortunate in that we had arrived back in the lobby of the office building that houses MO just as the earthquake struck. Afterwards we headed into the ground floor lobby of the MO to try and find out more (at this point we had no idea that it was so bad), the very sweet young female staff member in the lobby told us that the earthquake was very big and would we please wait in the lobby as it was the safest place to be. She patiently answered our questions and calmed us, even though she must have been scared as well. The elevators in the building had stopped working and so we were waiting for them to be fixed. As we waited there were numerous aftershocks and at each time the staff would hold down any items that could fall and calmed those more nervous customers. The staff were incredibly calm and efficient. After about 1.5 hours, I started to get quite cold as it was winter, and at that point the very sweet staff member who initially answered our questions took us up one flight of stairs to the MO's cafe in the mezzanine area of the lobby, which they had managed to get power to and open up. As soon as we sat down they brought us warm cups of hot green tea, newspapers and took our coffee order. For which I was ever so grateful! When we were able to return to our hotel room, we were personally escorted back to the hotel lobby. The staff were so attentive and seemed geniunely concerned about us, we on the other hand were very worried for them and their families. Upon returning to our room we were told that the Molecular Tapas restaurant would not be opening due to the damage suffered in the earthquake, but we could go to the french restaurant. So we did. The food was superb - most amazing abalone dish I have ever eaten. Again the professionalism shown was outstanding, even whilst the building swayed constantly from aftershocks. I can't speak highly enough about the Chef, his team and the waitstaff. We ended up leaving the MO a day earlier than planned, and again service was impeccable, this time the concierge was so understanding and patient. He arranged accomodation for us in Kyoto, and whilst we went downstairs to pack, prepared for us a map of Tokyo Station so we could redeem our rail passes and get to the platform, and gave us a map of Kyoto marking where we were staying and what sights we should see there. In addition, he even told us which seats were the best on the train to get. The concierge then out of his own initiative very kindly cancelled our other Tokyo restaurant reservations that he had made on our behalf when it become clear that we were not returning to Tokyo. I couldn't recommend the MO highly enough. They made us feel safe and calm at a time when I'm sure they were feeling anything but. Thank you again to the staff at the hotel, you really are oustanding in your service and are genuinely kind. We are very much looking forward to staying at your hotel again - when we've saved up some more holidays!!

From the moment we arrived until the final bowed goodbye the service was fabulous. The hotel is very modern,clean with breathtaking views. We were even able to see Mt Fuji in the distance from the wonderful restaurant. The location was close to the train terminal and the airport shuttle dropped us of at the entrance to the hotel. Perfect.

A really great choice in Tokyo for business or pleasure. The hotel is absolutely beautiful, with very well appointed rooms and public areas. The real strength is the staff, who are always gracious, on hand and available. Everyone from the front desk staff to the cleaners and waiters were brilliant - for example, the waiter at breakfast occasionally brought me things that weren't available on the buffet just to let me try them. The restaurants in the hotel are also fantastic, and offer a great variety.

Great location in Tokyo's commercial district. The hotel employees have excellent guest service and they don't overlook the small details. This was my 1st trip to Tokyo and I will be sure to stay here again on my next!

The best hotel in Tokyo. Great rooms, great public spaces, awesome views over Tokyo and the staff are exceptional. Not cheap but worth the splurge. We booked a Premier Grand room, extremely comfortable, floor to ceiling windows, subtle design that doesn't assault the senses with all the luxuries you would expect. The Oriental lounge is a great place to relax, the Mandarin Bar has an intimate and clubby feel to it. Signature was the only restaurant we tried in the hotel, good but not exceptional.

Well deserved 6 stars hotel...The moment we step in to the main entrance we were assisted by a cheerful bellboy who then immediately escorted us to the 38th floor main reception area. We were greeted by the warm receptionist.. and within few minutes were were escorted to the room.. Our luggage was already placed in. Follow by the welcome drinks sent by room service.The rooms was huge overlooking the city skyline and the room equipped with all kind of sophisticated and modern technology... TV in the bathroom, luxury amenities, exclusive toiletries.. At night, the special touch of spa infuser are available and a small note to advise on the weather forecast for the next day was a great idea.. I love the Pillow Menu - try the butterfly and horsehair..All in all the hotel is just grand!! The hotel are located at the Ginza district.. it is a financial district so don't expect late restaurants open after 10pm.. and if you taking the subway, the automatic door connected to the building closes as early as 8pm where you will then have to walk out to the main street to enter through the main entrance...

I stay for two night with luxury break plan. some request are great and more over my expectation. such as highest floor of Mandarin corner room. goose down duvet and pillow that are 100% down so smooth and comfort. bed pad, I request with featherbed, they present to me with other higher quality type (feeling soft like lay down on new snow and more expensive,quality than featherbed) .  Transport with easy by using subway Metro Ginza line A7 exit is beneath hotel with elevator ,within 10 minute to Ueno station for take Keisei skyliner 44 minute to Narita airport.  Warm welcome with reception that can speak my native language, made me feel relax like at my home. Staff is very good in English (easy to listen) very helpful and concern with any request from me. Room was huge bath room with separate bathtube (big enough for lay down and compliment spa bath salt) with view of Tokyo bay, rainbow brige, separate shower room with three type of shower head. All amenities that you can imagine, shower gel shampoo/conditioner, lotion from Aromatherapy association with lavender fragrance,smart toilet however you can see dirt stain on marble (of 5 year old hotel). In the masterroom, television is wide 45 inch but very slow response . Automatic blind and curtain are sometime not smooth working . After turndown, with two bottle of water ,weather forecast, two yukata, with gift are Japanese fan and Lemongrass perfume. Egyptian 450 thread cotton linen is superb than any hotel ,and no goose feather smell of duvet and pillow. Food is high quality here. 3 mandarin golden orange per day in room and tank of ice cube tea/coffee. The breakfast although not variety of food but very high quality and all free serve of orange juce. Lunch I taste at all day dining (K shiki)restaurant that limited half hour that i have they can serve me on time that so amazing.  Conclusion The hotel made you feel free, relax as your own home. many beyound your expectation. Staff are spendid. 5 year old hotel had something to upgrade and renovate.Thank you very much from heart to heart with remembering experience of my life.

Stayed here over New Years - overall a very pleasant stay, though with a few nigglescheck-in was fast and friendly - lobby is amazing, great views through the two story picture windows - room itself was very nice, and very large for Tokyo - top view across the Tokyo skyline towards Mt Fuji, which we were lucky enough to see every day thanks to clear weather - bed comfy, tv good size (though had a few problems with it that they had to come and fix) - bathroom excellent - big tub, power shower, though sink area a little cramped for two staff generally very good, tried the concierge once and was frankly disappointed - and there was no 'lost in translation' excuse as my partner is Japanese - but only a small thing - the other bars are very good, all with great views - didnt eat in the restaurants, too many great places in this city to stay in the hotel to eat unless you have to - beware though that the lobby lounge in particular can be very busy, more than once there was no room even for hotel guests which was slightly frustrating - spa is amazing, with views from the sauna onto the city - no pool though, and beware that even if you are staying here they do charge for the use of it (though it was part of my package)location arguably better for business travellers than tourists - but there is a subway stop at the front door of the hotel, and given the size of the city no hotel is close to everything anywayoverall a great stay - i highlighted a few of the niggles and frustrations i had to management and they were superb in rectifying the problems, which is the mark of truly world class hotel

It's hard to know what to say about this hotel without seeming as if I was paid by the staff for my opinion. I've stayed here three times and each time it just gets better. From the moment you arrive until the moment you leave you are pampered and treated like royalty. Although I have to admit this hotel is the priciest at which I've ever stayed, I can only say that it's totally worth every penny (well...yen). My room was beautifully appointed, spotlessly clean and had a just fantastic view, including Mount Fuji when the haze cleared away. I've read some other reviews and don't understand how anyone could find anything negative to say about this place. The person who said there was nothing going on in the neighborhood didn't find some of the great restaurants and bars located just across the street, along with some mind blowing shopping. The folks who thought the spa was too expensive didn't take advantage of the fact that it's free from 6 to 9 in the morning and that if you use the fitness centre for even a couple of minutes you are allowed to use the spa free of charge. They even provide you with fitness centre clothes to use while you're taking advantage of this free service. Add to this the feeling that you are an honored friend the second you step off the elevator into the lobby, the total elegance of the setting, the tremendous views from almost anyplace in the building, and I would have to say this is as close to perfection you can find.I also would like to add my recommendation to any gentleman who wants a good laugh to visit the men's room in the 38th floor lobby. It's certainly the most spectacular place I have ever found to do one's ... ahem ... business.I also would like to recommend the Oriental Lounge off the lobby. It's a great place to have a nice drink while overlooking Tokyo, all the great train action (I'm a big fan of Japanese trains) and the Imperial Palace as well as, if the weather's right, Mount Fuji. So save up, skimp on other locations but definitely make it a point to visit this one-of-a-kind hotel experiences. I believe you will not be disappointed!

My wife and I thoroughly enjoyed our stay. Every member of the staff did a marvelous job at making us feel welcome and special. My wife also gave the spa very high marks. Great location with splendid views. Mt Fuji is visible if the weather is clear. Terrific amenities, well appointed and comfortable rooms and perfect service. Great centralized location. Definitely the place to stay in Tokyo!

My wife and I recently spent 4 days at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo as the capstone to a 3 week trip to Asia. We arrived fatigued and slightly under the weather. Thankfully, the staff were both omnipresent and unobtrusive. The building afforded the crucial needs that weary travels seek out with a pharmacy in the basement lobby, as well as a host of other shops (convenience store and a spate of small bars and light bites). That evening found us taking a brief cab trip from the hotel. Even though the area is primarily a business district, providence brought us to a brilliant small sushi restaurant operated by Shigemasa Kurosawa. The delectible sushi omakase was simply beyond words and even the late hour of our meal's conclusion would not be deterred by struggling to catch a cab back to the hotel. That night, we enjoyed spectacular views of the city and the serene opulence of the room. The next day found us reeling from the prior two weeks - and the room made for an exemplary refuge from the tumult of the city below. The extraordinary breakfast that was complimentary due to our booking the reservation through the American Express Platinum Travel Service proved to be sufficient to last the next day for our Shinkansen trip to Nagano to hike up to the Jikudan Monkey Park. That night, having returned exhilarated and weary from a day observing the famed Macaque snow monkeys, a Michelin star meal at the restaurant was appealing but not very practicable given our appearance (hiking boots and GoreTex). Again, the Mandarin came through with flying colors - room service with a selection from the famed pastry chef in residence (and a champion of the International Pastry Chef Competition). Our day of departure was again made equally pleasant and smooth; we planned to take a cab to Tokyo Station in order to catch the Airpirt Limousine bus to Narita. As luck would have it, the bus arrived as we loaded the cab. Without missing a note, the bell captain literally sprinted over, negotiated inclusion of our passage (normally requiring a prior reservation) and expressed all our heavy bags into the hands of the bus porters. The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo has made a customer for life! Itsumo osewa ni natte orimasu.
user_name:
TMO8320
Washington DC, District of Columbia

review_body: What can I say except this hotel is genuinely exceptional. During my stay, I fell very ill. Being a foreigner in foreign land and not much Japanese in my vocabulary, I did not know what to do except turn to the hotel. The duty manager Mr Heideko stayed with me in hospital all night until they released me. He was comforting, assuring and genuinely supportive. I felt better and enjoyed the rest of my stay thanks in a large major to MO. I can not recommend this hotel enough. The staff, the service is just way above anything i ever seen before and believe me I am a very frequent traveler. It gives me even a smile just to think of Mr Heideko. The rooms are spacious and Zen like peaceful. Great views over Tokyo. The gym and spa are fantastic and having afternoon tea in the cafe next to the lobby is wonderful. This hotel is in a class of its own.

We spent 2 nights in Tokyo at the end of our 2 week trip. We deliberated between hotels but couldn't be happier with our decision to stay at the MO. The service was impeccable. The concierges were extremely helpful, providing detailed maps, suggesting restaurants, and helping with transportation. The in-room amenities are amazing. Including automatic blinds, curtains, lighting, etc. The room was large and had a great view of the city since we were on the 32nd floor. They made sure every single little thing was taken care of providing adaptors, any forgotten toiletries, morning papers, turn down service, etc. We had originally been concerned about location as it isn't near any major tourist attractions but with the subway (ginza line) under the hotel it was super easy and didn't require taking any taxis.
user_name:
rogi8
New York City, New York

review_body: Have stayed in Mandarin Hong Kong, Bangkok, Singapore, Geneva, Manila, I have to say Mandarin Tokyo has surpassed my experience of a truly luxury hotels should be. Fantastic view over the hotel lobby on the 38F, the friendly reception staff who walked you down to the subway station, the knowledgable concierge who gave great recommendations for restaurants and bars, the extremely polite housekeeping staff who set up aroma oil for turndown every evening, not to mention the lovely mandarin bookmark left on my books. All the small details make a big difference. I am a FAN!

The front desk and concierge staff were the most professional and competent I have encountered, and they made my trip with fantastic recommendations and flawless service. The rooms are beautiful, the views high above Tokyo stunning. Brilliant hotel. I'll be back.

I stayed at both the Mandarin Oriental (MO) and the Peninsula (P) in Nov2010, and both were great. If I had to choose I'd probably pick the MO if they were the same price. Here is how the different attributes stack up, in my opinion:Location - P wins big, on the edge of the Imperial Gardens and Ginza. MO is a 20 min walk north from P.Rooms - P. P had much beds, bathtub and toilets (an artform in Japan). MO had much better shower and toiletries (incredible products, esp the bathsalts). The decor and layout were equally wonderful at both hotels, as were the views.Common Spaces - MO wins big. Though I am not a fan of the common MO setup of having the lobby on the top floor (requiring you to take two elevators from your room to the exit, one up to the lobby, another one down to the street), I loved the look and feel of this hotel - serene, lovely and efficient. Gorgeous views and architecture. P's setup is much more convenient, but the lobby feels small and chaotic with the restaurant planted right in the middle. Not a space where we wanted to linger in the least.  Service - MO wins big. P is fine, but MO goes above and beyond. The concierge staff at P was harried.Food - MO wins. The food at the restaurant in P's lobby was mediocre. The food in the casual cafe in the P basement is tasty but the location in the basement in not ideal. We didn't try "Peter", on the top floor of P, because the cigarette smoke was so strong.MO has five restaurants - four with incredible views, (including the all-day dining, more casual place which had a wonderful breakfast buffet) , three with Michelin stars. Gym - tie. P has a lovely pool, but the gym is small with no windows. MO's gym is bigger with great views, but no pool. Both had nice, new machines. Spa - P because of pricing. MO's is egregious, even for Tokyo.

We stayed at Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo for 4 nights. The hotel is simply amazing. Possibly one of the best hotels I have stayed at, and I have stayed at many. Aside from the fact that their service is amazing (example - we asked the concierge if it was going to rain and the bellman in the lobby was waiting with umbrella's for us), the rooms are well furnished, the lobby and rooms have a great view (we stayed in the deluxe room), and the food is great. I would recommend a second helping of the rice vineger at breakfast. There is a subway station in the basement of the building (Ginza line), which make it very easy to get around. Yes it is pricey, but I will stay here when I come back to Tokyo.

we have stayed at conrad, ritz, peninsula, mandarin and shangri-la in tokyo. MO tokyo is a beautiful hotel and has good service but we probably won't choose to stay here again because: 1) the location is not ideal (wandering around mitsukoshi is the most accessible thing to do), 2) there is no pool, 3) the spa is terribly expensive (i think a 1'50" treatment is 44,000yen). we booked an executive suite which had sweeping corner views towards the palace and the bay. the decor in the room is a little busy so i felt like i didn't know where anything was except for the bed. the bathroom is enormous, possibly the size of a regular tokyo hotel room. the newer hotels (peninsula and shangri-la) have better soundproof windows. we could hear some sort of rally/protest from the streets. the spa has a water room with jacuzzi, steam and sauna. there is no cold plunge for ladies but i think men's has one. soaking and sauna have beautiful views of the city facing the new sky tree tower. the steam is nice and hot and doesn't smell funky. regular entry to the water room is 6000yen. very attentive staff for spa check-in. the fitness room was a step above a normal hotel gym, with a rower, medicine balls, 2 pilates reformers. breakfast buffet wasn't bad but has great views of the city again. the eggs they use have very dark red yolks because the chickens are fed seaweed, rose hip, soy, and chili. however, i don't believe these eggs have a rich flavor as free-range eggs found at a farmers market. we liked these eggs prepared as an omelet the best. there is a dimsum selection and congee as well as western type stuff.

We have stayed in many hotels round the world but this is one of the very best. Exceedingly comfortable and extremely friendly and helpful staff. The Concierge was able to recommend trips and places for dinner and book them. All first rate. The metro staion is below the hotel and one of the reception staff came down with us to make sure we understood how to work the ticket machines. We really could not fault it at all. The loo was intriguing. Electronic with "front" and "rear" washing. There was also a button which said "oscillate" but that did not seem to add anything!

Recommended by Minmax Travel. this Hotel did not disappoint. All the employees were courteous and friendly. Room had firm beds and comfy seating in addition to internet attachment and twisted cord. Very comprehensive and tasty morning meal as well encompassed with the room. Bus Shuttle every 10 minutes to the centered locality in addition to coach from Hotel to airports. Good lighting in the room.Location is close to a very intriguing and gigantic buying locality with allotments of shopping and possibly the busiest train position in Tokyo with very simple get access to to other places

Well, I just dont understand all the great reviews posted for this hotel! I believe that many people do not know what luxury means. Stayed here in August 2010 for several nights. Room design & service is JUST ok! Nothing spectacular!! Breakfast was very poor! Really nothing to do with other luxury hotels I stayd in Asia, like Thailand for exemple! Ate 3 times in the chinese restaurant. Food was good, but expensive (of course!) Location is BAD! After 8 pm the neighborhood is dead! Nothing to do and nothing to see here, except Mitsukoshi (food floor is just great)! Its not just because you a have subway (metro) line under the hotel, that the location is great!!! The hotel does not have a pool! The spa prices are VERY high! Stayed also at the Shangri La Tokyo and it was better: cheaper, bigger room, nice design and the Shangri La had a pool! But what I really prefered for hotel in Tokyo was NIWA hotel: great price, very nice japanese design, new hotel, and nice staff!

From A to Z the MO in Tokyo provided me with a wonderful atmosphere and service. Rooms are modern, cool, very spacious (for Tokyo!) and wonderfully functional. Service is impeccable. The rooms are absolutely soundproof and being located on the 7 top floors of a high rise you're far above the hustle and bustle of Tokyo.The Spa however is ridiculously overpriced. No treatment justifies 400 USD per hour... And internet access should definitely be free in hotels of this category...

The wow factor kicks in here, big time. Absolutely flawless service, you get what you pay for! Luxurious bedding, and a bathroom shower to die for!Location is business district, the only drawback...but you're right beside a metro line.Huge rooms, even by Western standards.

The hotel has a very nice design. A highlight is the lobby on the highest floor. The view out of the lobby, bars and restaurants of the hotel is stunning. The rooms are spacious and nice. Modern attractive design. The personnel is friendly and efficient. Negative point: The spa is normally not included in the room price, ridiculous as the hotel is not pricy. Rooms price quite expensive. Don't miss the Terriyaki Burger in the hotel bar, even if you are in Japan. Sushi can wait for the second day....

We loved our stay 3 years ago so much that we decided to come back. The spacious room high above the hustle and bustle of Tokyo is great, with views towards the east to greet the rising sun. Still love the bathroom, with a nice shower setup that's semi-integrated with the bathtub next to it. Some of the fittings of the bathroom seem to have been updated.Service is still as wonderful as we remember, with staff who are very helpful and friendly.The spa pool is complimentary to guests early in the morning - before 10 or 10:30am I think...

It doesn't get much better than this. Rooms are great in all respects, especially the desk which has an option to put your chair facing out the beautiful floor to ceiling windows or into the room. Beds and pillows are amazing, bathrooms are stellar with solid water pressure and the box of all necessities on the counter is a nice touch. The gym is very good, with the best views I have ever seen (from a gym) and the juice drinks they have are one of a kind. Spa is very peaceful also with great views, but I find the services to extremely overpriced. The design of the hotel is what really sets it apart. It's no wonder this hotel gets such great reviews.

The Japanese pride themselves (rightfully so in my opinion) on their meticulous attention to detail and that's evident throughout MO Tokyo. While the design of the rooms might appear bit bland, the services was absolutely first class during my two week stay. I think Mandarin flourishes in Asia as the hospitality culture is more deeply rooted than elsewhere. Courteous professionalism and competency were evident at every interaction I had with the staff. Special thanks to the concierge team and Adam in particular and the amazing housekeeping.

Tokyo was the first stop of a round-the-world trip and we decided to kick it off with a nice hotel (friends hat stayed at the MO Tokyo before and recommended it). It was an excellent choice, everything was perfect. On the first morning, we nearly missed b/f because of the jetlag -- when we got there, it was literally 5 mins before their closing time. What did they do? With the most friendly, elegant and honest smile and a little bow, they apologized that b/f "would only be open for another 30 mins today" and what could they get us to make us feel better with all the jetlag. One word that it was actually our mistake? None. One expression that made us feel uncomfortable? Nothing like that, just perfect service and honest friendliness (that made it embarrasing enough for us). The rest of our stay was equally immaculate, they were very helpful in assisting us to find our ways and to make restaurant reservations. When we got caught out by pouring rain and returned dripping wet, the bell captain on the ground floor called reception while we were in the elevator up to the 38th floor and when the doors opened, two lovely members of the staff were waiting for us with towels. Need I say more? To top it off, the rooms are very spacious and the restaurants in the hotel are trendy and serve excellent food. A no-brainer from my perspective. Only downside I can think of: no swimming pool.

Just finished a 4 night stay at the MO Tokyo. Amazing experience and will stay there again on my return to Tokyo. Rooms are large even for American standards and service was impeccable. Breakfast was included in my rate, but probably would not recommend it if I had to pay. Small selection and nothing that every other breakfast in the world has – except for the view.Concierge was extremely helpful and they always gave out maps to help you along the way – the subway station in the basement is very convenient.

We were on our honeymoon and upgraded to a gorgeous corner suite! After a long flight from New York, the elegance and comfort of this beautiful hotel was a warm welcome. We were truly treated like royalty, and enjoyed every minute. the Room Service was fantastic, very high quality, even the cleaning staff speaks English and were quite friendly, and the amenities were truly sumptuous. We can't wait to go back!

Stayed three nights at the MO in Tokyo. One of the priciest hotels in Tokyo and service levels at the high level you would expect but the location is not great for exploring the city requiring an almost immediate change on the underground system. The line the hotel is on doesn't really head anywhere of interest in the city. In addition given the price paid, I find it very annoying that the hotel chooses to charge for wi-fi access!! Isn't this standard now especially at that level of hotel. Also there is no pool.The views are great from the rooms and whilst everyone talks about the spa, the facilities are only OK and the treatment standard but expensive (we had someone who appeared to be in training! which you wouldn't expect for a £400 massage..).I would recommend the Penninsula over this hotel. It is in an excellent location and was an amazing hotel (we stayed here later on during our trip).

After having an incredible experience at the Ritz Carlton, I was anxious to see how it would be like at the Mandarin. I can only describe it in one word: WOW. If you book a corner room like I did it will be triple WOWs, as you have amazing views from two wall to floor windows and also from the bathtube. Just like the Ritz, MO is linked to a subway station, which makes coming and going very easy. The only downside of this hotel is that they charge for internet (although I got a business plan which had it included).

It was our first time in Tokyo and we found the staff to be exceptionally helpful and welcoming. The views are amazing; we were lucky enough to see Mt Fuji in the distance. The food is great and we even had two dinners at the hotel. Location is easily accessible to the subway.
user_name:
Calty24
New York City, New York

review_body: We went to Tokyo to stay for 2 nights as we had just been to Niigata prefecture to drive around for 5 days. The service at the Mandarin was great. All the staff were very friendly and helpful. After I had checked in, many staff members remembered my name and they would say hello to me whenever I went through the lobby to return to my hotel room. Also, I had left my Blackberry charger at home and they immediately found me a charger that I can use in my room. We also got a lot of help from the concierge who helped us find sushi restaurants, hard-to-find shops. We even called the concierge on our mobile phone to help us find a good sushi restaurant in Ginza and they did not disappoint.The rooms were very large for Japanese hotel room standards and the toilet was especially large with a bench to sit on in the shower and a big bathtub as well. We got a corner room so we had a nice city view from our room. The TV was huge and the bed and pillows was very comfortable. The slippers were so comfortable I ended up buying another pair to bring home. We had room service breakfast and the quality of food was impeccable. Green tea pancakes were very tasty. One evening, we had drinks at the bar, which had a really cool atmosphere, a mini indoor waterfall and a live band to keep us entertained. Overall, the service of the Mandarin Oriental is always outstanding and that is why it is my 5 star hotel of choice. If you stay in Tokyo and don't mind staying near Mitsukoshi Mae metro station. Choose the Mandarin Oriental.

I wish this hotel could be copied and placed in other cities. Let me start with the service. It cannot get any better. It was absolutely perfect. I have two examples (of many). First, my wife and I walked to the hotel from Tokyo Station to get some fresh air after a 15 hour flight. When we turned the corner into the driveway area, the instant the bellhop saw us, he literally sprinted about 100 feet to get to us to take our bags. We were then walked to the reception desk where the front desk was waiting for us and greeted us by name. Second, we called for extra towels, and unlike most other hotels that take at least 20 minutes to bring the towels (even at other high end hotels), the towels arrived at our door in 2 minutes on a silver platter. As for the rooms they are great. Once you get to a certain level of hotel, it really becomes a matter of personal taste, but we thought the room was great. Though, I wish the shower had a door. It's not a big deal, but the shower feels a bit cold since its open to the rest of the bathroom. We really liked the "service closet" where the hotel staff can leave stuff for you, rather than having to open the door (e.g., mail deliveries, laundry, morning newspaper). The fitness center was great as well (with a good view!). The only real complaint are the restaurants. We had breakfast and dinner at the hotel, and the food was ok, but it was incredibly overpriced. Skip the hotel restaurants and go elsewhere. The location is decent in that it is connected to a subway station, but other than that, there's not much going on in the area of the hotel if you are there on holiday.

It was my familys first trip to tokyo , and i have 2 yougn children,therefore was scared this hotel would be too trendy for my little bratz. The conceirge staff were efficient through and through guiding us to all the great hot spots,child-friendly to do locations.I initially wanted to stay in the peninsula being in the prime location of Ginza.But the MO has the subway line right under the hotel,so we were able to navigate everywhere using the underground,and it was very safe and clean ,unlike big cities. And its a cosier hotel , i felt the peninsula was a very business like hotel.Very rushed .If you demand class and comfort,this is the place to go .And i cannot stress how amazing their conceirge team .They truly enchanced our enjoyment in tokyo with all their guidance.

By the time you are reading this review, I would have already checked-in and relaxing in the BEST hotel in Japan. I have just finished packing for this trip, it is 4:30 in the morning, and I have a flight to catch in a couple of hours. The packing process brought back a lot of fond memories I had during my previous stay in February 2010, and I just couldn't help but sit in front of my computer and finish writing this review that was meant to be posted a few months ago.........RESERVATIONS and PRE-ARRIVALI have previously written a review based on this aspect of my Tokyo experience, but there was more to it, while exchanging emails with the Concierge Team, I casually mentioned that I was going to rent a MPV for the trip but wasn't sure which one to choose from due to the size of the vehicles and the height limitation of various Car Parks in the Ginza area. Next thing I received in my email box was a map of the Ginza area, with all Car Park locations, vehicle height limits and operating hours clearly stated.ARRIVALWe arrived at the hotel late in the afternoon, after a 4 hour car ride from the ski resort, we were very tired, looking forward to checking in and have a rest, there were 7 of us, 16 pieces of luggage and 10 of them. No it was not a typo, there were 10 of them, we were in the room faster than anything I have ever experienced. (and yes, they checked us in in the room)That is NOT just it, a day prior to our arrival, my older son had a minor accident on the ski slope and scratched his face, there was this horrific patch on his face, one of the Guest Relations team member has suggested that we should get some cream for the wound. Well, guess what, the cream arrived before our luggage did.......TRAVELLING WITH CHILDRENIf you are travelling with children, make sure you tell them, you will be amazed at the range of child amenities they can provide, and did I mention the mouth watering sweets and snacks and popcorn at turn down? If you are travelling without kids, you might want to consider lying about it, it is worth it!!!!DINNER RESERVATIONS and MOREOne of the nights, the Concierge has recommended us to a Japanese restaurants in another hotel in the Ginza area, the moment I stopped the car in front of the hotel, I was greeted by my Surname, from the valet staff, door man, reception lady to all restaurant staff..... that was a very good dinner by the way.... but not as good as the surprises and the attention that we were given, for being a Mandarin Oriental guestAFTERNOON BUFFETWe went shopping on one of the afternoons, and for obvious reasons we have lost track of time and was late for a reserved seating for the afternoon buffet at Ventaglio in the hotel. By the time we got there, we were an hour late and was 25 minutes from the closing time of the buffet. When we were just about to rush out to the food table to savage whatever is left, the manager and his team started to assemble a mini buffet setup at our own table........ well, it actually wasn't mini at allIf I was to sit here and continue writing about all the great things that I have experienced at MOTYO, I will miss my flight in the morning.......... It takes the BEST staff to provide these kind of services, and fortunately, MOTYO has LOTS of them.

This hotel was absolutely fantastically perfect and at a great value. My mother and I traveled to Japan for two weeks and spent four nights in Tokyo at the Mandarin. I called the American Express Platinum Travel Service desk and this hotel came up. I have no regrets with my stay in Tokyo. The service even before we arrived was spectacular. The hotel's concierge desk was so helpful in helping us make train, dinner, tour, and other arrangements. By the way, the tour guide that the hotel recommended and hired for us for a day trip to Kamakura spoke such perfect English and knew so much about Japan and taught us so much about customs. The hotel in reality is not very enormous, so your service is personalized to the nines. Every morning we had a wonderful breakfast that was included in our room with a view that was so memorable and warm. The entire staff absolutely spoke wonderful English and tried so hard to please us. For those of you who hate staying in large buildings give this hotel a chance. I never for once felt like I was in a skyscraper. I felt more like a guest in someone's house the entire stay. This hotel is pure gold too for its location. Beneath you is a subway station that is so close to Ginza, Tokyo Station, and Nihonbashi. You cannot go wrong with this spectacular hotel for any occasion.

I have stayed in a number of Mandarin Oriental hotels and have high expectations but I left feeling this was the best I had ever stayed in. From the moment your taxi pulls in to the ground floor entrance lobby, you are given a royal welcome. The staff could not be more attentive in providing a genuine personal service. The rooms are of a good size with fantastic views over Tokyo. Through sheer laziness I ended up having more meals in the K'Shiki restaurant where the waiters provided excellent meal recommendations. Cannot wait to go back there.

Everything at the Mandarin Oriental was perfect. The rooms are large and beautiful, the food at the restaurants fantastic and the service absolutely impeccable. We asked them for some help organising the last leg of trip in Japan, weeks after we were to leave the hotel, and they helped with every little detail, always following up and making absolutely everything easy for us. We really appreciated this, especially since they had nothing to gain from it apart from some (ever more) satisfied customers.

This was the best money we have ever spent on a hotel. In the beginning MO price seemed quite steep, it was 450 euros per night and we usually spend less. At the same time it was our wedding anniversary so we decided to splash. Best choice we ever made. The service we received was unparalleled. Given that we travelled during Christmas and the New Year period and it was our first time in Japan, we asked the concierge to help us with booking the train tickets from Tokyo to Kyoto. In the end they booked us the tickets for our whole 10 days stay in Japan and in different cities, despite all the difficulties caused by the fact that we travelled during the holiday period when the trains we full and apparently booked by the locals well in advance. The attention to detail from the personnel was exceptional. On our anniversary we ate at the Sense restaurant - food was delicious and they brought us a cake as a (free) surprise (we were happy that they did not sing some Happy anniversary song though...). The views from the room and from the restaurant were breathtaking, during breakfast we could see how the Sun raises over Tokyo... Well, in the beginning the hotel seemed so chick that it was a bit intimidating, but the personnel always made us feel welcome. In the end of our stay in Japan we came back to Tokyo and had a reservation at Four Seasons, since they had a promotional rate, which was slightly cheaper that MO. However, after MO the Four Seasons felt just ok (though we once stayed in 4S Las Vegas and it was superb), nothing exquisite and charging for each little thing/step extra, which was not the case of MO. In sum, MO Tokyo made us feel very welcome and very special and was a great introduction to Japan and its people. Now we'll be judging all hotels according to its standard, though I am not sure other hotels will be able to match it.

I have stayed here multiple times for business and leisure. Great hotel, excellent service, spacious and well decorated rooms. Knowledgable staff. Great view for all rooms, and delicious buffet breakfast (at a cost). Great for business and leisure. The only drawback is that if you plan to spend alot of time at Shibuya and Shinjuku areas, then the commute may be time consuming. However, it's very close to Ginza and Marunochi area - does that help?
Love Toyko vibrant and active. Love the strange bathrooms and those high tech toilets. The people at the hotel were really friendly and always carry a grin. Love the restaurant food in the locaolity.

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is probably the best hotel I have ever stayed at. The rooms are spacious, luxurious and have excellent views of Tokyo city. The cuisine, the decor and the facilities are superb. But most of all the staff are an example of true hospitality. Their courtesy, friendliness, promptness, efficiency and sheer perfection completely blew me away. And they all knew my name! In short, I felt i was the only guest at the hotel.

As many have said before, the level of service is excellent. When my wife turned her ankle and was unable to walk, the duty manager arranged an appointment at the nearby clinic, loaned us a wheelchair, and arranged for someone to accompany us to translate. We were away one night visiting Nikko, and our luggage was looked after and delivered to our new room on our return. Staff recognised us and welcomed us back. The rooms are large and comfortable, bathrooms excellent, and views stunning. Yes, it's expensive but their luxury break deals help. The buffet at the Italian restaurant is great!

We were impressed with the Mandarin Oriental. The concierge staff was extremely helpful and very knowledgeable. They pointed us to a few great dinner spots and spoke great English. There is a subway stop right outside the building, so the location is convenient. The views from the rooms and the lobby/restaurants were amazing. The breakfast buffet was good also.

Where to start? My family and I went away for my father's birthday and decided to stay at the Mandarin Oriental. Before I even left for the hotel I was emailing the concierge and the restaurant managers. I organised my father's birthday dinner at the Tapas bar, and spoke with the concierge about other restaurants (booked Robataya and also Ukai-Tei) and also a day trip to Kyoto. Their prearrival service was fantastic, and it was nice to know a lot of the trip was taken care of before we left.We arrived at the hotel by hotel organised van at around 8pm after a long flight and the first thing that hits you is (1) you are on the 42nd floor, and (2) are the huge 2 storey windows that look over Tokyo! Kumiko (the concierge) was there to greet my entire family and provided the train tickets to Kyoto, and all the information on the private tour we booked as well as the restaurants in a plastic folder. She included maps to the restaurants as well as confirmations. We were then escorted to our rooms which were three all in a row (which is very unusual). The rooms were amazing with great views over the whole of Tokyo. The beds were very comfortable and they had slippers and gowns. They also gave us little food items every day (we had strawberries, sashimi, cakes, chocolates etc). The hotel is very clean and the staff are all very firendly. The bar is amazing as it is two stories and has a waterfall and seats floating over a pond. Everyone is so helpful and always knew our names. They did such thoughtful little things.. such as we had left a book on the bed open to the page we were reading and when we got back it was on the bedside table with a book mark in it. They let us have our rooms until 4pm on our last day even though the hotel was fully booked. We requested some information on Disneyland and 3 mins later they had slipped all the information we needed under our door!!!We went to three restaurants at the hotel (the breakfast one, Sense (the cantonese) and also Tapas. They all had amazing decor and the breakfast was amazing. They had so many different options, and lots of fresh fruit and vegetables. Sense was so tasty! They cut up peking duck in front you of and the prawns were very good. They had a good selection of wine too. The best was the Tapas for my father's birthday. It was over 20 courses and each was better than the last. They did amazing things with food. Kumiko also organised a surprise for my dad which was very special. The location is pretty good - only about a 10min walk to Tokyo station, or a 5-10 min ride to Ginza. The staff outside always help you get a taxi and provide you with cards to show the driver so they know where to take you. They also make sure the driver's know where you are going before they leave. When we were leaving to the airport the van the hotel had organised us was already waiting out the front with our luggage already in it.The restaurants the hotel booked provided us also with amazing service. We always had private rooms/good table and they all knew it was my father's birthday so they all went above and beyond and gave him presents (flowers, the took photos of us and made it into a booklet for my father etc). The tour in Kyoto that the hotel booked was also the best I had been on!The hotel went above and beyond what was expected. They completely blew away our expectations (and we are picky :) ). I can't wait to go back, and wish I was there right now :)

There's very little about this hotel that's not to love. The views are spectacular. The decor is clean and contemporary. The rooms are spacious. The dining options are nicely varied and never fail to impress. But what sets this hotel apart from all the others I have stayed at is the level of service we received. Simply put, I have never experienced better service than I received during my week-long stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. Some of it is admittedly cultural. The staff bowing to you as the elevator doors close is one example. Yet the service here is more than simply tradition at play. Rather than try to describe the experience, which would surely be inadequate, here are some examples:1) We traveled to Kyoto via the Shinkansen bullet train for an overnight stay. When we asked the front desk how to purchase tickets for our trip, they offered to send a member of the concierge staff with us to the train station. Sure enough, she joined us on our taxi ride to the station and helped us purchase our tickets to Kyoto. 2) We checked out of the hotel for the one night stay in Kyoto, leaving our large bags behind at the Mandarin Oriental. When we arrived back at the hotel, the staff instantly recognized us, even though we had not provided our return information. They escorted us to our new room, which already had our luggage. We never had to "check back in" to the hotel. It was as if we had never left.3) Every time we ate dinner at the hotel, they would take our room number. Upon returning to the room, no matter how little or long we took to eat, the housekeeping staff had completed the evening turn down service. Those are just a few of the examples of the extraordinary service you will receive should you stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. Other little examples abound that you will surely experience on a daily basis.We stayed in a Premier Grand King Room, numbers 3204 and 3208. A few nice features about the room worth mentioning: 1) The floor-to-ceiling windows offer spectacular views of Tokyo. It's especially riveting at night when the city lights up. On clear days, you can see Mt. Fuji in the distance. 2) A control panel next to the bed allows you to open and close the blinds and adjust the lighting throughout the room. 3) A small closet next to the door is used to discretely deliver laundry and the morning's newspaper. No need to answer the door to accept any of these items from staff. You know they've arrived when the "valet delivery" sign is illuminated. 4) The shower comes equipped with three heads, any of which you may use depending on your shower preference: a movable shower head; a fixed, massaging shower head; and a rain shower head. 5) No need to bring a converter for the American three-prong electric plug. The desk has an outlet with a plug that is compatible for laptop cords.A few final notes about the hotel generally: 1) Please eat at either the 6:00pm or 8:30pm seating at Tapas. Maximum seating is only eight people. You sit side by side along a counter facing Chef Ramsey. He guides you through about 15-20 small dishes created through the process known as molecular gastronomy. It is an intimate and amazing culinary experience you will never forget. 2) Please get a swedish massage from Yumi. The spa itself is incredible and the massage was probably the best I've ever had. 3) The hotel is located right on top of the Mitsukosimae subway line. While the location of the hotel itself is not ideal for tourism, the subway is easy to get to and manage to travel on.The only negative comments I have about the hotel are that the bed is not soft enough for my taste (personal preference) and the steps required to get out of the hotel can be irritating. The reception area is located on the 38th floor, while our room was on the 32nd floor. In order to exit the hotel, we had to take an elevator up to the 38th floor and then take a separate elevator back down to the first floor. However, that is really a minor complaint.Any trip to Tokyo would not be complete without a stay at this hotel. It is definitely worth the cost, especially if this is your first time in Japan.

If a first impression counts for anything, this hotel is simply stunning. Yes, it is one of the most expensive hotels out there. At the same time it is low-key, service is exquisite (and yes, we used the concierge, the restaurant, room service), the views are unbelievable AND it's in a great location. It's somewhat reminiscent of the Park Hyatt, which may still have the nicest rooms, but you are steps from Mitsukoshi Department Store and the subway, and a short walk to Tokyo Station. The business district in the area has a complementary shuttle bus that connects the station basically to the hotel. Our room was spacious, with floor-to-ceiling windows, and a fabulously comfortable bed. There are lots of lovely hotels in Tokyo to choose from depending on whether you want to shop, visit cultural sites, or just relax. This one is great for being pampered.
user_name:
jolielaide
New York City, New York

review_body: Mandarin Oriental has a very high standard in all their hotels. This hotel is beautiful and the staff is always willing to help. The conceirge is capable of arranging top of the line private tours.

I've stayed at the MO Tokyo a dozen times or more on business. This last week I brought my family for the first time. The MO staff have been consistently excellent making every effort to assist in any way possible including helping with my two baby daughters. I'm always amazed at the consistency of their service level and the eagerness of the staff to help. Furthermore the rooms are tasteful and restrained whilst retaining every comort while the common areas are splendid. All in all this is the best business hotel I have stayed at anywhere and it's fantastic for families too. 5-stars without a shadow of a dount.

I have written about a couple MO properties now, stayed at quite a few too, and I have yet to find a hotel that can match, let alone beat, what Mandarin is doing. Put simply, they are the best at what they do. The design, the decor, the staff, everything is done properly. It is miles and miles ahead of what anyone else is doing, and when you stay at one you will know what I'm all about. To focus a bit on this hotel, it is extraordinary. My only complaint is that its geared more for a business traveler as its not close to where all the action is in Tokyo like the Peninsula is. That being said, its a different way to experience Tokyo...more authentic perhaps...not touristy, not overly crowded. Its charming.
breathtaking views....lovely staff.....very personalized service...just loved my stay....rooms with very modern decor and very clean

We have stayed at the Mandarin several times. The service here is unparalleled. The rooms are quite large with a fantastic bathroom. The breakfast buffet has a great selection of western, Japanese and oriental selections. The lunch that we had in the K’shiki restaurant on the 37th floor (same level as the lobby) is always excellent. This stay we had the treat of a clear Mt. Fuji view.
