The location is ok, it is just above the Mitsukoshimae subway stop, three stops from Ginza. Other than the large Mitsukoshi Department Store next door (which btw has an awesome food court in the basement), you have to walk to the Tokyo Station area (15 minutes) or Ginza (20 minutes) for lots of shopping or food (there is a 7-11 about a block and a half away for beer/snacks). This hotel is very expensive but is a great splurge if you can.

I can only echo what has been said by everyone else. This place is a marvel and a gem and if I'm ever in Tokyo and can afford to stay here I definitely will. The service is almost embarrassing, it's so good and so attentive. The food in the restaurants, and especially the appetizers and drinks in the bar on the 38th floor overlooking a truly spectacular view are also spectacular. The room I had overlooked the west side of Tokyo and was splendid, including a crystal clear view of Mt. Fuji. The same view could be found in the fantastic bath in the spa, where you loll in the wonderful hot water gazing out upon the wonderland that is Tokyo. I'm afraid if I go on too much you'll think I've been paid by the hotel, but please believe me when I say I've NEVER stayed at any hotel that delivered so much. DON'T MISS THIS GREAT PLACE!
bit expensive,so good for ur special day.they have beautiful viw from rooms and restaurants.our roomz bath was awesome sooooo romantic we could check in at the room too.easy and quick :DDD

I have made reservations to stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo from mid Feb 2010 for 2 weeks with my family and a friend and his family. This will be my first stay at this hotel as I usually stay at the Park Hyatt in Shinjuko and more recently, the Ritz Carlton in Mid-Town. The decision to stay at the MOTYO was made after the repeated recommendations of a couple of friends.Online reservation was painless and efficient, what has followed after the automated email confirmation is the reason to my first Trip Advisor review. Shortly after the automated email, I was greeted by a more personalised email from the Reservations Team and later, Ms. Yoko Sumida and her colleagues from the Concierge Team. Since then, they have helped me make half a dozen dining reservations, made restaurant recommendations, floral arrangements for my wife's birthday, birthday cakes, transportation arrangement from Narita Airport to the Ski Resort that I will be staying at 7 days prior to my arrival at MOTYO, in-room amenities for kids and the list goes on. While all of these arrangements have been taken care of in the most possibly detailed way. Having stayed at so many 5 star hotels throughout the years, this particular pre-arrival experience has been truly exceptional. MOTYO has really really raised the bar. Can't wait to be there in 4 weeks time. Will write a review after my stay.

We spent a wonderful time in the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. Service was excellent and we felt like VIP’s. The concierge desk was extremly helpful. Restaurants are elegant and first-class and even the all day dining restaurant K’shiki is a beautiful place with different great creations. The decoration is contemporary and luxury. Even the exercise room let you feel different. Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is very centrally located. I hope to come back again.

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo met all our expectations from the moment of our arrival when we were greeted at the front door and whisked up to the lobby until the time of our departure.The room was spacious by any standards but certainly by Tokyo ones and beautifully decorated but with restraint.Service was great from arrival to departure. The assistance provided for organizing our onward journey was just exceptional. We had in-room breakfast and found this the only weakness. While very good in quality it arrived too early and the form provided is not unambiguous for all items. However apart from that all services provided were just perfect !

The level of service I am continuosly receiving as a guest of the Mandarin Oriental is unmatched among any business hotel in Asia Pacific. From the welcome drink in the room, to the right adaptors being already in the room on arrival, the laundry bags already having my name on it, from basically all staff knowing my name to being extremely helpful in all requests, the service exceeds any expectation or experience in other business hotels. Quality and freshness of products at breakfast is great, views from the rooms are phantastic, size and quality of equipment of rooms is very generous. I have spent many nights in many trips at the Mandarin, and I will always return.Only criticism: extra charge for internet use!

I think that this is the best property in Tokyo -- much better than both the Ritz and the Peninsula (2 other recent entries into the market).Best things about the property:- Impeccable modern Asian design- Great views of the city (even from the restrooms)- Top notch service that is a more flexible than most hotels in Japan. Very attentive and successful in both responding to and anticipating needs- Diversity of restaurants - Spacious well-designed rooms- Large wet area connected to the spa- Intimate / quiet feeling in public spaces Opportunities for improvement:- Location isn't perfect for tourism but isn't bad- You pay dearly for the privilege (especially at the spa)- Bar area can get smokey (but this is Japan)

A beautiful hotel...Of course it is still new. But I really like the décor of this hotel!The room was beautiful, too. I think we had the deluxe or premier deluxe (I don't remember). A basic room at this hotel, but it was nice enough! Impeccable room and bed and bathroom...so far this was the best I have ever stayed. We had an access to the Spa, Heat and Water, so we had made a reservation and tried.What a wonderful view from the Spa! I was actually alone there, so I just swam in the jacuzzi. It was a luxury to sit alone in the sauna and looked at the night view of Tokyo...We dined at the Italian? restaurant, but perhaps should have chosen the Chinese or the Tapas at the counter because the cuisine was not so impressive. They could have done better, I think.But overall, this is an excellent hotel. I enjoyed staying here very much.

Amazing staff, views of Tokyo. Conde Naste did article on 10 best consigners in the world---the gentleman who was ours, Adam--yes he was one . Bamboo flooring, several TV's, phone in each room. The gentleman at the reception area had us booked fpr our ride back to the airport by the time my husband turned around to ask him to take care of this. One of the very best hotels we have ever stayed in.

The Mandarin Oriental chain opened this new hotel in Dec 2005 on top of the Mitsui tower in the Nihombashi district (located North-East from the Imperial Palace). Naturally the views are superb (especially in the evening) with the lobby & main bar being at the top floor and the rooms being located below. The rooms are very well appointed with the same style as the refurbished Mandarin Oriental Hong Kong. We had a Deluxe room viewing eastwards with a relatively large size for Tokyo (about 50 sqmeters). The rooms facing westwards (towards the Imperial Palace) are more expensive but their views is probably more impressive.The bathroom is separated from the bedroom with a glass panel but you can close the stores if you wish to do so. The shower area does not have a curtain or a glass door. Instead, the whole shower area is an open space next to the bath which is typically Japanese. (Japanese people will shower first before slipping into a hot bath tub).All bathroom amenities are presented in a superb lacquered box and this is so far the only hotel I visited where they provide you with a small bottle of pressurized shaving cream alongside their razor kit!Being extremely recent, the main switches are all electronically commanded and quite intuitive to use. Note that there is a "service box" next to the door where the staff will put the daily newspaper or shoes (complimentary shoe-shine service at night) without having to open your door (pretty much like the Peninsula in Hong Kong).Service is very efficient and friendly but this is usually the norm in Japan. The Italian restaurant on the first floor has a nice buffet.Only downside is the location since Nihombashi is mainly a business district (the Tokyo Stock Exchange is nearby) so you need to take the subway (station is just below the hotel) or a taxi if you wish to go out (Ginza/Shinjuku/Shibuya/Roppongi). Note that the Mitsui tower is mainly an office tower with the Mandarin Oriental on top, so at street level you might not notice the main entrance of the hotel which is slightly off the main road. Also take a hotel address card to show to taxi drivers since some of them do not know this recent hotel. (Mine dropped me off in front of the Mitsui tower entrance instead of the proper hotel entrance, so that I had to drag my luggage in several escalators before finding my way to the hotel)Best option to/from Narita Airport is the "friendly airport limousine" which is a bus service between the airport and the main hotels in Tokyo. When going back to Narita, you can directly buy the tickets at the hotel concierge and the bus will stop in front of the hotel.Overall a beautiful city hotel from the Mandarin Oriental chain which adds to the stiff competition of 5* hotels in Tokyo!

The hotel is perfect in every detail - the service, the decor, the view over Tokyo, the restaurants and bars.The hotel is at the top of the building between the 31st and 38th floor. This means that every floor has a great view. The only downside is that you have to go up to 38th floor before going back down to the rooms - but this is not a big problem.The one star Michelin restaurant Signature is excellent. It is French inspired cuisine, but with Japanese service and quality.Of course - this level of luxury does not come cheap - but it is worth it!

We love Japan. It's the cleanest, safest, most polite country on Earth. It's the only place I know of where in a few hours you can move from a 300 year old world famous ryokan to a high rise temple of modernity. That's exactly what we did when we left Tawaraya in Kyoto and caught the Shikansen to the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo. We're big fans of MO properties. We've stayed at a least a half dozen. They don't have a "plebeian frequent guest program" but they when you check in the system alerts reception that you are a loyal MO fan and you are rewarded.MO Tokyo was spectacular. World class service and every modern convenience you could want at your finger tips. We enquired about some eye glasses at the concierge desk and in a few minutes we were given printouts of the model we were interested in with maps to nearby stores. The lobby lounge was elegant and romantic and the prix fixe lunch was one of the best values to Tokyo. Room service breakfast was perfect and the subway was conveniently located in the lower lobby. We always feel welcomed and at home in MO properties. MO Tokyo was no exception.I don't know what category our suite was but it must have been high up the food chain. Originally we had planned to stay only three nights but we liked our suite, the location and the service so much that we extended to six. By my count there are five world class uber-luxury hotels in Tokyo. MO Toky would be uber-luxury in any country.

I stayed in the mandarin Tokyo for 5 nights during my first trip in Japan . I am a business man and I have travelled a lot during my life and at high standard thanks to corporates I have worked for but honestly I found the experience in Mandarin unique .Courtesy and professionalism over the top , a special reward to the Concierge team that looked to us like royals , and a little bit shamefully I admit I have never left a tip . Enjoy

Just returned from a vacation in Japan. The Mandarin was an excellent hotel. Nice views from the lobby and main rooms. We had a Dynasty Suite with a formal living room and separate bedroom ... wide views of Tokyo in both rooms. Decor was dark contemporary, very nice finishes. The staff was most accommodating. I would recommend this hotel if you are going for business, but the location was not the best for holiday travel. I see that some travelers are deciding between the main five star hotels in Tokyo and on that note - I prefer the Peninsula in Tokyo because of its location and the food is also a bit better there. The Park Hyatt is another favorite. Still, aside from the very hard beds (found in all the hotels that I have experienced in Japan) in the Mandarin, there is nothing to say except positive comments.

My husband and I stayed here for the first two nights of our honeymoon. The service was fabulous from the moment we approached the entrance of the hotel- one chap whisked our luggage off via a cargo lift, and we were greated and taken to reception via the normal lift. Check in was fabulously quick, we were allocated a room earlier than the normal check in time, and our luggage was ready and waiting in the room for us when we got there. Brilliant. We had a card from the front desk staff wishing us a happy honeymoon, and the girl who brought us a refreshing drink in our room was very sweet and was helping us with suggestions about how to get around the city and where to go. The rooms are huge and my husband couldn't stop playing with all the gadgets! The tv is bigger than our entire flat back home! The bathroom is great - lovely deep bath and walk in shower, perfect for a soak to get rid of the jet lag (we saw sunrise almost every day in Japan, but rather than spoiling the holiday, it was actually very special as the view out of the window as the sun rises is breathtaking). Another nice touch was the aromatherapy oil which was left for us on our second day, and all of the little trinkets in each drawer you look in (hair brush, fan, every connector for every computer you could ever imagine etc) We left a similar review to this on their in room comment card and got a lovely letter from the hotel manager when we returned to the UK saying that he had shown our comments to his staff to "boost morale". THe only thing that could have made it better is if he offered us a free night at a Mandarin Oriental of our choice to show his gratitude! It is expensive, but its worth every penny. We will be back, both to Tokyo (which is a fabulous city) and to this hotel.

For sure the best in Tokyo, but don't expect anything even remotely funky. As the area it's in, the hotel is business like. The service levels are not to be experienced in Europe and it makes it hard to come back to the so-called palaces back home. Rooms are huge and extremely refined, so quiet you can sleep anytime like a baby (one of the rarest commodities in hotels where doors usually bang after 7 am)At the Mandarin you can feel housekeepers pride in being the best in the world. The food at breakfast is worthy of Michelin stars. If you are very picky with details and are looking for ultimate comfort this hotel is worth the expense.

Surpassed all my expectations on just about every level. First, the rooms are HUGE by Tokyo standards and beautifully laid out. (The bathroom design is so elegantly functional I took photos and careful note of it for any future home renovation project.) The service is exceptional, discreet, professional and fastidious without being fussy. The room is equipped with every amenity you could want and some you didn't know you would need. Also, at the time, you could smoke in the room, and even though the windows obviously on this high-rise hotel are all hermetically sealed, the air filtration and circulation system in the room was so excellent that I could breathe in comfort even as my spouse had her fix of pre-slumber cigarette in the room.The nighttime view of Tokyo from the top-floor lounge/bar is breathtaking (even the view from the men's room! If you ever go, you'll see what I mean). Only minus. The food at the western restaurant (French/Italian?) in the hotel wasn't really anything to rave about. Also, the hotel is apparently not well known to most Tokyo cab drivers. The entrance is on a side street off a main thoroughfare, which actually I prefer but makes it a bit difficult to locate by sight.

All reviews are very positive and with good reason.This hotel is magnificent. The lobby on the 38th floor is superb. The bars are beautiful and views are superb.It is not however a typical holiday hotel, it's a business hotel but we stayed there for leisure and had a great time.Service: Fenomenal. Probably the best I've ever had. Staff are so friendly and helpful. Nothing is impossible. Our luggage didn't arrive for two days and the hotel provided us with an emergency pack that was very helpful. Adam, the concierge is really friendly and very helpful.Rooms: Stunning rooms, very big, absolutely beautiful decoration and style. Bathroom is huge with a big bath and separate shower as well as toilet. You receive excellent toiletries. Room itself is beautiful, they think of absolutely everything to make you comfortable.I would definitely recommend this hotel.

My husband and I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental for the first few days of our honeymoon in Tokyo. The hotel is undoubtably wonderful - the staff are excellent - friendly, attentive and as our Japanese is limited, their English was excellent.The rooms were huge for Japanese standards - with great views, large bathrooms and huge beds. The breakfast, as other reviews have said, are large and the choice of food as well as the quality is really good. The location is slightly out of the main tourist areas but is close to the subway which helps to navigate the city easily.The only negative for us was the cost - the hotel was really fantastic but I'm not sure it was worth what we paid. Also, in hinsight, it is a hotel more for business travellers than a typical honeymoon venue.

Everything about this hotel was 1st class!! The rooms were very comfortable, the hotel staff is the best in the universe, the restaturants and bar are fantastic, the location was great with easy access to the subway system. The cost for the room was also an excellent value because they offered a discount along with $75/day credit towards restaurant, bar, and spa services. We had a wonderful stay and if I ever return to Tokyo I will stay at the Mandarin.

This quite-new property is definitely up to Mandarin standards. Whilst the formal spaces are as grand as you'd expect, it is really the efficient and caring service that sets the tone. As non-Japanese-speaking travelers to Japan know, this is one city where the concierge desk can make the difference and the team here was spot on, with prompt responses to pre-trip inquiries, good communication about what to expect (quality of seats in a venue, for example), and a no-question-too-small attitude.Rooms are large for Tokyo. The breakfast buffet is extraordinarily good with an array of Japanese, Chinese, and Western choices, and every piece of fruit arranged just so. The gym is excellent. Sadly, I did not get to the spa, which looks great.Given the current economic climate, rates were surprisingly non-stratospheric..

Our stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo exceeded our every expectation. The staff were all incredibly attentive, helpful and kind. Our room had a gorgeous view of the city and was beautifully appointed. The rain shower in the bathroom was a welcome surprise after a long flight. Another great thing about this hotel is its location next to the Mitsukoshi department store and the subway is accessible beneath the hotel. We plan on returning to Tokyo and will stay at the Mandarin Oriental again.

As with most who have writtem about the MOT, its a place thats hard to fault. We stayed in a Premium Grand Room which was huge, decorated with modern japanese elegance and having every amenity you could possibly conceive.But I thought I could provide a little more information about its location, which we also found hard to fault. Firstly there is little doubt that the Metro subway is the only way to go and having two lines accessible from within the hotel building (in the basement) was great. We reached every corner of Tokyo without having to change lines more than once and navigating the subway is quite easy if you are used to subways.Also the immediate environs of the hotel were unexpectantly modern, spacious, quiet and clean. The hotel is also right next door to a huge department store which has a food basement that has to be seen to be believed. But if you also take the opportunity to walk around the very safe side streets, you will find a wide vareity of traditional shops and great restaurants that are well worth a visit. For example we found a Tempura restaraunt 10 minutes from the hotel that was 100 years old (what an experience). Also the Imperial Palace East gardens are only about a 15 minute pleasant walk away, which is somewhere you just have to go (especially in Spring).There is no doubt that the MOT is very expensive, but so is Tokyo in general. However this was one of the very few visits I walked away from feeling totally satisfied and totally enthused about everything.

Pros: Modern, sophisticated plush rooms. All the curtains are electronically controlled. The bathtubs are fan shaped, actually looks more like a seashell. Of course, the shower are excellent with all kinds of controls. Bathroom amenities include brush, toothbrush, toothpaste and excellent shampoo, conditioners. Incredible Spa with hot soaking tubs facing the city skyline. Breakfast buffets are incredibly delicious. East meets West with all kinds of pastries, eggs (egg benedicts!), rice, cold cuts, homemade jams, fruit, yoghurt. The beds and linens are extremely soft and luxurious. Flat screen tvs in the bedroom and bathroom. Cons: Nothing really. If this even counts: internet at the business center was not free. Overall: Highly Recommended.

What can I say about this hotel that hasn't already been written on this site? It was amazing. We were only there a night on the last night of our Japanese honeymoon and we were treated like royalty. The floor to ceiling window in our room gave us an incredible view of the Tokyo skyline and we watched the sun setting over the sky scrapers from our room. We ate in one of the hotel restaurants and had many cocktails in the bar all while sat watching Tokyo by night 37 floors beneath us. It was the most fitting end to a perfect trip away.

The most wonderful hotel in Tokyo. Seriously. Everything is impeccable. The best concierge service in the world. Located above subway so perfect for getting around. Can't recommend it highly enough....

Certainly found using the airport limousine service from the Navita airport to the depot and then 2 minutes taxi very easy and convenient. The welcome and pleasant staff we found no fault with and they were supremely helpful with booking restaurants where only Japanese was spoken. Superb room, we over looked the city. Good location can walk to both ends of the main city. Only one hickup when one night we had a snack in the bar and my wifes meal arrived but mine didn't and took a considerable time to do so. I even offer to change my choice. All ended reasonable well with them letting me have it complimentary, although only mine. One night when we came back the staff excitedly showed us that Mt Fuji was visable through the darkening haze. Next morning we rose with the sun and were treated to see it in all its' glory. Recommend eating in Tapas bar with chef J Ramsey who was at Heston Blomenthals and received his first Michelin star the night we were there. If you like that style its superb.

we stayed at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo for 5 nights....i will make this review simple because i think everything was excellent at this hotel...Rooms: 10/10Staff & Service: 10/10Location: 8/10Food: 8/10Concierge: 10/10Hotel Facilities: 10/10I think the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is 1 of the best hotels in the world, everything is top quality.....

Just look at the other reviews in general and you can get a feeling of how EXCEPTIONAL this hotel is.I stayed here with my wife and 14 year old son.I am not joking but it is probably the best hotel I have stayed in along with the Oriental in Bangkok.Location,excellent and above the subway is a must due to the size of the city.The rooms,decor,facilities,lounge areas are superb.Plenty of places to relax with a drink aswell.Yes it is pricey but so is Japan.This place is class at the highest level and as for the service it makes you feel like royality.I have stayed at many top hotels and visited many and one of my hobbies is to research and read about and visit these hotels.This hotel is virtually faultless trust me.

We had high expectations for this hotel after reading the reviews on TripAdvisor. Maybe that is where we went wrong. We were surprised to find that the Hotel is hidden away in a large office building (it has no street presence). We were standing only 50 metres away from the Hotel but had to ask someone where it was. On entering the doors of a large office building, we had to look all around before finding a discreet door tucked away in the corner of a building containing shops. We took the lift up to the 38th floor where the lobby is located. Normally a hotel lobby is a relaxing place where you can sit down and organise yourself before checking in. The Mandarin lobby is soulless and makes you feel conspicuous and uncomfortable. We can’t really put our finger on it rather than say that being in the lobby felt a bit like waiting to see someone for a job interview.We feel this Hotel is better suited to the business and not leisure traveller. Maybe you can appreciate it more if you are not paying for it. The service is slick and professional but forced/awkward and doesn’t put you at ease. It’s as if they are trying too hard but not really wanting to act in this manner.We booked a Corner room at Yen 19,000 (GBP 560 or USD 1,000 per night). The view was amazing. The room was small but we were expecting that. The view from the bathtub in particular, was really good until the windows fogged up! There is not much space to lay out a suitcase. So compact, yet nice.A small point which annoyed us… we were charged for 8 cups of green tea which appeared to be free as displayed, but alas no. Only when we checked our online bill, did we see that this was GBP 8 pounds each. On further inspection, the mini-bar price list showed that coffee was free but tea was charged. This seemed very strange for such an expensive hotel.The concierge staff were very good and confirmed our flights for us and even booked us 2 tickets on the train to the airport. A nice touch.With regard to the common areas, sadly, Japan has a culture of smoking (although not as much as we were expecting). As all of the bars and restaurants are open to the lobby, the smell of cigarettes emanates throughout the common areas and is particularly noticeable in the morning… yuk! The breakfast room has amazing views and the service is excellent. We ordered eggs from the chef and he found our table to deliver them when done. However, there is a problem with the air-conditioning (which seems to be a common problem in Japan). In particular, if you go down for breakfast at 6:30am (as we did on one day), make sure you are wearing beach shorts and a t-shirt as the air-con only seems to start at that time. The sweat was running down our back…All in all, the hotel is good, but not great. We were expecting something over and above say, the Oberoi chain in India, but alas it’s not a touch on the Oberoi Udaipur. I would recommend that the Mandarin Managers undertake a fact finding mission there to see an amazing hotel. At the prices charged by the Mandarin Tokyo they need to up their game.On the other hand, if you are not personally paying for it, then you’ll probably find the Mandarin perfectly adequate (but we doubt outstanding which is what you expect at that price point).

I am here with my husband and two kids (7,8 yrs) and as I write this review it is NY Eve and I sipping an Asahi and looking out on the most spectacular city night scape I have ever seen! We are in a two bedroom suite which is huge by any countires standard stylish and beautiful. We travel extensively so It takes alot to 'wow' us but I can honestly say every moment of our 5 night stay here has been magnifiicent. I don't want to leave here! Usually when you stay anywhere there is a list of both Pros and Cons....I can't think of any Cons so let me just give you the Pros:Check in - Flawless and all of the 20 or so floor staff knew who we were and addressed us by name. Note during our entire stay when requesting something from concierge ect and I have said would you like my room number? Staff have agian used my name and have known my room number! I don't know how they do this but it's a really personal nice touch. We arrived on an early morning flight several hours before any hotels check in. We were given a room with no fuss and not the normal we are doing you a favour, we don't have to give you a room until 3pm attitude you sometimes find in the industry. We were escorted to the room and shown all the entertainment system, blind systems, light systems ect (Japan is a country of techno and this hotel lives up to the standard there). The room was spotlessly clean as anticipated and uses material, wood and stone in different textures to create a relaxing beautiful space. We went out every day but didn't really want to leave the room. The children were catered for beautifully with their own size gowns, slippers and welcome ameneties. Again nice touch. Welcome amenaties for adults as well.Products - So may products to use during your stay means you don't have to worry if you forget somthing they even provide hairbrushes and PJ's. Room is service twice daily and at turndown they also provide you with aromatic lavender oil to help relax you. Oh and the bed......unbelievable. The toilet also unbelievable (more technology), one of those toto toilets with warmed seat, lots of jets and then self flushes when you are finished. The bath in the master suite looks out over the Tokyo skyline also.Room service - 5 star restaurant grade meaning you could get away with not leaving the room to eat. They made to order things for the kids that weren't on the menu at reasonable price. Breakfast buffet had a wonderful selection that did not have that buffet wilted look about it. Fresh and sublime. We are booked to try ONE of the michelin star restaurant tomorrow - there is three inhouse! So undoubtly you can't go wrong with food here.Location - You are right above the Japan Metro with easy access to anywhere in Tokyo. We have had fun navigating our way around this quick clean and effiecient means of travel. Tokyo is a really safe city for tourists and I we haven't seen any seedy side or felt uncomfortable anywhere. Spa - spent a few hours escaping here. Two whirlpools, steam room, sauna again with the most amazing views - I watched the sun set over Mt Fuji there tonight. Very clean with washing before entering and in true Japan bathhouse style in the buff. I am booked for a treatment tomorrow you have to book well in advance as they are the best in town.In summary as I could go on and on this place is amazing. This is not a hotel but an experience and one of which we have been very lucky to have found. Don't miss it!Happy New Year!

A simply heavenly experience. The rooms are extremely spacious and beautifully decorated. The service is exceptionally personal. The restaurants serve delicious food. My only reservation would be the portions in the restaurant, which were very small (even though the price wasn't!). Ultimate luxury in Tokyo, and a great location too, right next to the tube station and minutes from the shopping district.

We had recently stayed at the Mandarin Oriental San Francisco in September and based on our wonderful stay at that property, promptly decided to stay at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo during an upcoming trip to Tokyo. In fact, the MO San Fran's GM acted as a liaison with the MO Tokyo on our behalf - what wonderful customer service! From the very moment we arrived at the hotel to our departure - we were completely wowed in every sense - it was so hard to leave. We were warmly greeted (they knew our names within 30 seconds and continued to greet us by name throughout our stay) and check in was gracious and efficient. We stayed in Room 3406 and were afforded a magnificant view of Tokyo's skyline and Mount Fuji. The room category was Premier Deluxe King and the room and its amenities were top notch. The room was huge with a large walk in closet and floor to ceiling windows; the interior decorating beautiful and comfortable. The lighting was excellent and bathroom, shower, and toiletries were all great. As other reviewers have mentioned, the TOTO toilet will amaze you. The breakfast buffet was excellent with just the right amount of options and variety - it was a pleasant way to start each day. The fresh squeezed orange juice and coffee were excellent too and the staff were wonderfully attentive and friendly. Room service (I ordered coffee for the mornings) was excellent and prompt. The workout center was top notch with new treadmills, ellipticals, and Cybex machines - all with a great view of Tokyo while you work off those calories.The Concierge team was phenomenal and assisted us with the purchase of bullet train tickets to Kyoto, car service, ryokan suggestions, etc. prior to our arrival. The team's responsiveness via email was incredible and throrough. Once we arrived, the team provided wonderful sightseeing and restaurant recommendations (be sure try their shabu shabu restaurant recommendation!) and excellent maps. The hotel is located on top of a Metro stop so it doesn't get any easier to tour the city. The Metro system itself is easy to navigate and much quicker (and cheaper) than using a taxi. The hotel is also located next door to one of Tokyo's main department stores - be sure to stop by the basement's food department.One minor negative was that we had dinner one night at the hotel's Signatures restaurant and to be honest, we were a bit disappointed in light of its one Michelin star rating. We opted for the tasting menu and although all of the courses were beautifully presented and the service excellent, some of the courses were a bit sub par. The chef (s) are Austrian and the menu highlighted Austrian fare rather than French inspired courses. Several of the courses were very heavy (i.e., lots of meat, starch, and gravy) and the portion sizes were a bit large considering there were 7+ courses to navigate. But, it still was a pleasant and enjoyable evening overall.Although the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo is not inexpensive, it is worth every single penny and spoils its guests in every respect. We were constantly greeted with warm smiles, attentiveness, and graciousness. I can't say enough on how wonderful this property and staff are. Go if you can - life is too short!

We stayed two nights at the Mandarin for our wedding in Tokyo, and it turned out to be a perfect choice. The place is everything you would expect and more: The rooms are large, impeccable, comfy and luxurious (we had a Mandarin corner room, highly recommended, huge windows on two walls offered a spectacular view of Tokyo from the 35th floor, amazing at night). The location is nearly ideal, 1 subway stop from Tokyo station, and the entrance to the subway is within the building. The entire place looks gorgeous, the lobby bar and restaurants are almost as amazing as the Park Hyatt across town in Shinjuku. Room service is prompt, corteous, and quality of food is excellent. Best of all: Every single staff member we came across were friendly, efficient and made us feel like royalty.The day before the wedding turned out to be a bank holiday, which could have caused us some real problems, but the staff were really helpful with the final arrangements for the wedding. During the stay they excelled in every way, we soon just called the front desk whenever we needed help with some silly detail. They came through for us every time. It's not Tokyo's cheapest hotel, but well worth it if you really want to pamper yourself.

The hotel provided top notch service from arrival to departure during my short stay there. I used American Express Platinum to book the Mandarin Deluxe Room. Upon my arrival, the hotel has already upgraded me to the Premier Grand Room (a two level upgrade), along with complimentary breakfast and lunch. I stayed at the hotel during my two segments in Tokyo, visiting Kyoto and Hakone during the interim. I inquired the hotel staffs (most of them spoke fluent English) about the Hakone Freepass before I left for my day trip to Nikko.The hotel staff not only offered to get the Freepass for me (at no extra service charge), but also included a whole lot of local information about Hakone when I picked up the Freepass the same night. The hotel also offered me to store my luggage during my 3-trip the Kyoto and Hakone and stated the luggage would be placed in my room upon my return. Room: The Premier Grand Room is large by any reasonable standards. The walk-in closet area was spacious enough to probably put six full sized luggage. As mentioned by other members, the room included every amenities imaginable from a bathroom to work area. The cotton swap even had ear picks at the other end. The room also offered the most advanced washlet from Toto, Neorest 600, with automatic cyclone flush. As can be seen in my attached photos, the view from the room was impeccable. The hotel offered both wireless and wire internet connection at 1800 yen per 24-hour period.Service: Besides the items mentioned above, the hotel staffs made me feel truly welcome from the first moment I stepped off my taxi to the time I left the hotel. The hotel staffs were always filled with smiles everywhere in the hotel. Food: The selection for breakfast at K'Shiki was not great (compared to Peninsula Beijing), but was certainly much better than Park Hyatt Tokyo. At 2800 yen (or 3800 yen with eggs), I considered the price very reasonable. The selection for the buffet lunch at Ventaglio on the second floor also was not great, but at 2800 yen, I felt I got the food and service that I expected to pay more than $90 USD in any hotel restaurants in New York City. It was actually less expensive than my bento meal at Tokyo station. Location: The location was about 7 minutes by taxi from Tokyo Station. The taxi fare was the starting 710 yen. I took taxi ride 4 times and all taxi drivers recognized the location of hotel with ease. The hotel is right by the Bank of Japan. Spa: The use of the fitness center was free of charge to the hotel guests, but the wet area cost addition 6000 yen. I did not use either facilities during my stay there. Overall: The hotel was in the same price range as Park Hyatt, Peninsula and other top notch hotels in Tokyo; however, the room and service were certainly better than these hotels. This would certainly be my No. 1 choice for my trip to Tokyo next time.

I stayed with my friends at Christmas and the service was fantastic! The hotel gave us Moët & Chandon and apple with welcome message as special gifts!I would love to stay there with my boybriend next time...!

We decided to stay at the Mandarin Oriental after reading the near flawless reviews here on trip advisor, and with that in mind as well as the expensive room rates, we had extremely high expectations.We weren't dissappointed at all! This hotel has a reputation for outstanding service, and not only did it meet our expectations, the standard of service exceeded our expectations. They managed to single handedly save our trip as I was foolish enough to leave my Camera bag on the train as we arrived into Tokyo from the airport. The friendly lady who checked us in not only spent the evening negotiating with Japan Rail, getting them to search for and recover the bag, but also, one of the conceirge staff lived out where the the bag was being held, and he volunteered to go and pick up the bag himself as it was being held way on the outskirts of Tokyo, near his home and bring it back when he started his next shift. It was amazing service, and executed perfectly, thanks to Mandarin Oriental Staff I was able to get my camera back and capture many memories of this amazing country. We couldn't thank them enough.We also wanted to take the Bullet Train to Nikko in two days time, but were a bit worried about how to go about doing this, so we asked the concierce, and they actually went down to the station themselves, booked the tickets and they appeared under our door in a beautifully presented envelope. Again, amazing service.The room was really nice, oriental feel with two large and extremely comfortable beds. The massive Flat screen TV was another great touch. The bathroom was great, with a deep spa which had its own flat screen tv. I couldn't really fault the room at all, it was just perfect. Some negative reviewer stated that there was no coffee and tea making facilities in the room, but that definately wasn't the case for us, and my partner can testify that it was really nice coffee! Our room as on the 35th floor, and featured extremely good views over tokyo, especially at night when the city lights up!The Buffet Breakfast probably wasn't the best buffet i've experienced. It was small without the massive variety that I love in many 5 star hotels, but everything was nicely presented and it was a pleasent experience as it wasn't completely overrun with people like some breakfast buffets, infact there were only about 4 other people there, we got the impression that most people had room service, as the room service menu seemed to have ALOT more variety, so we tried that the next day and it was magnificent. Beautiful Belgian waffles!We had Room service for dessert one night and a lunch as well, both were excellent quality, some of the best room service i've had. Unfortunately we couldn't test any of their other restaurants for dinner, preferring to eat out at the Ginza.As far as location goes, it's probably not IDEAL for leisure travellers, but Tokyo is such a massive city with attractions scattered accross a variety of precincts, so each area has its benefits, but if you want to be in the thick of the action, Shibuya or Shinjuku are probably the best places to stay. But in saying this, we found the Mandarin Oriental's location just fine! It's located on top of a subway station, which is great, with direct access to the popular Ginza district and its high end shopping, eating and the famous sony show room, and also direct access to the magnificent temples of Asakusa, so all in all it's a pretty good spot to be honest. It's relatively quiet as well, which for many people is a plus. All in all, a fabulous stay, with very memorable service.

We just returned from a 3 days stay at the Mandarin Oriental. While quite pricey, this hotel simply cannot be faulted. The service was impeccable. They were all very attentive from the moment we arrived at the hotel until we left. They even assisted me in finding certain japanese products I was asked to pick up while in japan. They found the products at a discount which they passed on to me and left them in my room after returning from a long day touring the city. They simply passed the cost onto my checkout bill. The room we got was in the 36th floor and had incredible views of Tokyo. Out of all the hotel rooms I have ever stayed at, I would say this room was the most well thought out. The bathroom shower had every type of shower head you can think of. The tub was deep and had a small flat screen tv and its own beautiful view of the city. The toilet had the fully automatic japanese-style bidet with every conceivable setting for your derrier. The bathroom was also well stocked with the usual amenities, bathrobes, and towels. The bedroom had a huge flat screen HD TV, the bed was large and comfortable with large view windows. The hotel also provided a small bottle of incense/fragrance that you can use to make the room smell like a spa. They also provided you with separately shrink-wrapped bedroom slippers and comfortable japanese yukatas (robes) for loungewear. The bed was incredibly comfortable. The buffet breakfasts were not as as elaborate as other hotels we have stayed in but the selection provided is still quite nice. Staff at the restaurant again were efficient and attentive and you cannot ask for a better setting to have such a nice breakfast with panoramic views of the city. This hotel is one of the best out there. If you can afford it, I would recommend you stay here.

Enjoyed a 3 night stay. Staff are very efficient, from the moment you arrive they know your name and strive to give service. Especially, enjoyed that bell staff run to press the buttons in the lift. Everyone was very helpful, one bell staffer escorted me to an international ATM (in the Post Office in the building) after I struggled to find one.The location is good in that Ginza is nearby and you have a metro stop in the building. I recommend the metro as Ginza traffic can be awful.The rooms are modern and large but lack much charm. Our room had a separate tub with an odd shape and an adjoining unenclosed shower making half the bathroom a wet room. While we showered you could feel a draft as well. That being said it was a waterfall shower and well appointed. The room featured a good size work desk and large plasma TV that proved hard to use. Another issue we had is that the AC did not really cool our room even when set to 18 C. Breakfast at the buffet was fair and service was very good. Had a great pizza for lunch one day at the same place. Really enjoyed the bar for a drink, the golfball sized MO logo ice cube in my scotch was very cool. Prices are very high but you are in Tokyo so that is normal. We used the metro extensively and toured the Ginza area that we really liked. If you can afford a hotel in the price range the MO Tokyo is a solid choice. We also spent 3 nights at the Park Hyatt which is great but requires expensive taxis to get around. Highly recommend Kyubei Restaurant in Ginza. The food is divine in the chefs choice style of Japanese. Dinner for 2 will match your room rate but do go if you can and like Japanese.

I have initially high expectation of the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo and I was looking forward very much to my stay. This hotel comes with glowing reviews from every published travel magazine. A near perfect 5-star review ratings in tripadvisor. The #1 hotel in Tokyo and the first to win the distinguished 6-star award that the hotel proudly displayed at the entrance. More important, the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo in particular was supposed to have near “legendary great service”, a traditional strong trait of the Mandarin Oriental brand. So things can’t possibly go wrong, right? Wrong. Very wrong. Unlike most other casual reviewers, I admit I’m rather fussy and discerning traveler and have seen and experienced the best that the hotel industry in Asia has to offer. While difficult to please, I do have certain basic expectations what a 5-star hotel should be and judge according to the value they deliver for the price. The Mandarin Oriental due to it’s reputation, charge the highest room rate in Tokyo and accordingly, so does my expectation. This review is a bit long so do bear with me.“Service” saga at the Mandarin Oriental TokyoUpon arrival by taxi, my luggage was promptly taken care of and I was escorted to the 38th floor lobby. Check-In was longer than usual as the front desk staff apologize and said that he had to “search for my room”. I wonder why this was necessary as they had my firm booking on hand and I have told them my arrival time. Surely, they should have allocated the room before my arrival as all premium 5-star hotels do. Another staff then escorted me to my room, a Mandarin Deluxue Room. Upon entering the room, I was taken aback. The room feels cramp and small. There is a small bathroom with only one sink. Much of the space was taken up by the King Size bed and a bulky sofa by the window. There is no walk-in closet. In fact, there isn’t even a designated space to put luggage. The only place to put the luggage is next to the bed. I am sure this room is not 50m2. If it is really 50m2, they should have easily designed a bigger bathroom and incorporated at least a luggage storage space instead. I immediately told the hotel staff that I was not happy with this room and asked if there were bigger rooms available. Bewildered, she replied that she need to check and Front Desk will contact me. Ten minutes later, no calls. I called Front Desk myself and was told immediately that “all rooms are fully booked and we only have the Mandarin deluxe available”. I was skeptical as it was not a peak season and the way he answered so quickly most like means that he did not really checked. I told him again I was not happy with the size of the room and asked to change. Again the reply was that “the larger premier rooms and suites and are all not available”. I repeat again my demand this time in much firmer tones and insisted that he checked again and said I was not pleased with this smallish room that they assigned to me and asked him to check with his manager. Finally he replied that he “need to check”. After 5 mins, he called back and said that bigger rooms were now available. And he accompanied me to check the rooms myself. I decided to change to a Premier Room ( with additional room rate ) instead and even this room feels very small, but at least it has a walk in closet. However, the fact is the rooms were actually available, why was I told there were not in the first place? It just goes to show the front desk staff actually did not bothered to check initially. This kind of attitude is unacceptable in a hotel of this class. Next I started to notice that the room was absent of any welcome amenity of any kind. Not even a fruit basket. I asked the Front Desk staff that was assisting me on the change of room if there were any welcome amenity. Again he seems surprised by my request and said that he “will check”. I told him usually hotels of this class provide some basic welcome amenities such as a chocolates or tibits or at the worst case, at least a fruit basket. Furthermore, I reminded him that this should be automatically provided, not wait for the guest to request; otherwise, it’s not a welcome amenity. After a while, he called back to tell me that they do not have the welcome amenity that I asked for. Their welcome amenity is oranges. He even asked “Do you like us to bring the orange to your room?”. I was stunned. Oranges!!! How very “impressive” for a flagship hotel of the Mandarin Oriental Group! I must have been spoiled by the generous welcome amenities given by other hotels including both MO group’s own hotels in Hong Kong and the Peninsula Tokyo right before my stay at the MO Tokyo, which the Peninsula generously provided complimentary chocolates, biscuits, tibits and even a bottle of Peninsula’s signature Red wine. Anyway, I told him no thanks. The oranges did came eventually during turn down service, 3 puny size mandarin oranges. How very generous for a supposedly “6-star hotel”!Urging to have a cup of coffee in my room, I searched the mini-bar area and suddenly realized that no instant coffee was provided. How can that be missing? Even 3-star hotels provide coffee in their rooms. Perhaps the housekeeping forget to replenish the coffee? I called again asking where’s the coffee. Again I was told they “need to check”. Subsequently, I was told the hotel provided tea in the minibar. Yes, fine, but I’m a coffee drinker and not a tea drinker. Am I the first hotel guests in MO Tokyo that is a coffee drinker? Then the staff replied there do not have coffee in the room but he can called in-room dinning for me and bring up a cup of coffee which of course, comes with an astronomically price ( in-room dinning is generally very expensive in Tokyo ). So no thanks! Really, at the price they were charging, what’s the tremendous difficulty to put a few packets of instant coffee? The Peninsula Tokyo by the way comes with a Nepresso coffee machine with gourmet coffee standard in all rooms. By now, I really started to regret my stay at this hotel. Looking thru the room, while rather tastefully decorated, it is no where in the same league of luxury as the Peninsula or even the Ritz Carlton Tokyo that I have stayed before and not even as spacious and well equipped as the Four Seasons Marunouchi. There are insufficient plugs on the writing desk. No coffee machine ( as expected since the hotel doesn’t provide coffee), smallish bathroom with only one sink. There is a 45” Sharp LCD TV and a DVD player but no A/V sound system. Part of the walls have stains on it, indicating poor housekeeping. Connecting the iPod means playing the music thru the TV’s tin-can speakers which sound quite awful by the way. The bed is also nothing to write home about, standard 5-star hotel beds and the quality of the linens are below that of the Peninsula or Ritz Carlton ( both of which uses Frette linens ). They did provide a long pillow which I requested earlier but it was hard as rock and I didn’t use it. Getting tired of the mundane room, I left for the gym to get some exercise. Again this hotel couldn’t cease to annoy me. I was the only one using the gym and found the temperature to be too cold. The overhead air condition was blowing very cold air directly at me while I was working out on the thread mill. I requested the gym attendant to adjust the temperature as it was too cold. She said she “need to check” ( by the way, this always happen with this hotel, everything they “need to check” ). After 10 mins, it becomes freezing cold. I questioned the attendant again why such a simple request like adjusting the gym temperature is so difficult? Then another staff with better English told me that temperature adjustment in the gym can “only be done at engineering” and they are “working on it” so it will take some time !!!! I decided to leave the gym upon hearing this rather than freeze myself to death. The next day when I checked out, I noticed they bill the rate different from what I booked, ie higher. I show them my booking confirmation which after including the charges for the room upgrade, the figure is incorrect. Again, three of the front desk staff become confused and stared at that invoice punching their calculators while at a loss for words. Agitated, I told them to just go ahead to charge the credit card rather than waste time figuring out the difference. Finally, after like 10 mins staring at the printout, one of them explained that the extra cost is because the tax applied on the charges for the upgrade as well. How come they don’t even know their own billing system?The only place that I got some genuine 5-star service from this hotel was at Signature, the Michelin star rated French fine dining restaurant located in the hotel. Not only was the food delicious, the service was also great and the chef even personally came out and thank me for my patronage, a gesture that I really appreciate. I also took the opportunity to request an empty box to put my bottle of wine and they got it for me right away without confusing stares ( I dreaded making this request to the hotel staff ). I requested also for an additional order of dessert to be brought to my room later than evening and it arrived exactly on time and with complimentary coffee!. Finally the Captain at the restaurant can speak perfect English so I don’t have to go thru any hassle with my requests! He is the only Japanese staff I encountered in the whole hotel that can speak fluent English. If only the other aspects of the hotel were as good as my experience in Signature, this hotel would have deserved its reputation. Common Areas and ViewThe hotel common areas were indeed very beautiful with magnificent views. The entire lobby contains two wall of glass that allow the evening view pouring in. All common areas are beautifully adorned with either Japanese artwork or rich panel wood. Returning to my room in the evening and looking at the mesmerizing view of the Tokyo’s evening skyline, momentarily, I was even tempted to forgive all the service hiccups that this hotel put me through. Ultimately, simply having great views is not enough to qualify as a great hotel in my books. The Ritz Carlton at Roppongi also have great views and miles better service than the Mandarin Oriental. The hotel is located in the Marunouchi business district so there’s not much of interest there for shopping or night life. ConclusionIn summary, with the exception of Signature Restaurant, this hotel’s service stinks. Everything they will answer they “need to check” and the level of English proficiency among the staff is the lowest among all the Tokyo hotels I have stayed in so far. Sure, they are all very polite and will smile and even bow to you ( and they does this a lot ) but when you need to get something done and any request out of the ordinary, the staff become easily dazed and confused. I cynically wonder if all these smiling and bowing were simply done to disguise their incompetence. So to conclude, this hotel is a major disappointment and does not live up to its reputation that it supposedly deserved. I paid top rates for this hotel at Yen70,000++ a night plus another Yen3,000++ to switch to a bigger room, rates which are already more expensive than the Peninsula. Yet, comparing every single aspect with the Peninsula from location to room quality to amenities to service, the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo simply falls flat on the face, greatly surpass by the Peninsula and the other hotels that I have stayed in Tokyo. It’s also the worst Mandarin Oriental hotel that I have tried so far. The only redeeming quality of this hotel is the great view it offers. Perhaps this hotel used to be great but they must be getting complacent which explained the falling standards. If they failed to please discerning frequent travelers like me, I see little chance that this hotel can compete with the new Peninsula which in my opinion is miles better and the true #1 hotel in Tokyo. Already, I can see there are many more guests in the Peninsula compared to the Mandarin Oriental as the lobby of the Peninsula is always very busy while the MO is quiet. It’s a real pity as I’ve been a big fan of the Mandarin Oriental group. The management of the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo better wake up and re-train their staff or they will see more business loss to the Peninsula. As for me, the decision has already been made. I would not come back to this hotel again, except perhaps to patronize the Signature restaurant. For the great views and the great service and food at Signature, I award this hotel a 2 star rating, and I’m already being generous. I know this review doesn’t agree with the rest of the reviews here but these are my actual experience and for anyone who has also stayed at the Peninsula Tokyo will know what I mean, there’s simply no comparison.

We stayed at the MO Tokyo in June, and while I did love my stay there, it ended up being extremely expensive, but then again, you are in Tokyo and everything is expensive, so you deal with it when you get home and enjoy it while you are there. The lobby and the bars around the lobby are simply stunning. Very cool decor, up 38 floors with amazing views of Tokyo. On the downside, the drinks in the bar were $21 USD per drink and they were pretty small, so after 4 drinks a nearly $200 tab felt excessive. We didn't try the tapas bar but it looked great and other reviews rave about it so i wouldn't miss that.The location is in a bit of a business/dept store area, but its actually really central to everything, relatively speaking, given how huge Tokyo is. You are very close to Ginza, Tokyo station (hub for trains all over Japan), and the Tsukiji fish market.Rooms are nice, but definitely on the expensive side. At $750 US per night (what it comes to after that 18% tax you dont see in the rate) the rooms could be a little bit more exciting. I usually dont mind paying up for a great hotel room, but we were out exploring most of the time and really only got to enjoy the room to sleep.This is the only hotel I have every stayed at in Tokyo. Given that everything at this hotel level is very pricey, I would recommend it.Its beautiful, the staff is helpful, and its calming to return to after spending a day out on the mania that is Tokyo. Oh, one more thing, we were in our room on the 37th floor when an earthquake hit. The building swayed and creaked, but that is what its supposed to do apparently. Its been built to withstand quakes, so you can feel good about that!

A really great hotel. Great service, great rooms. The only downside was the location, which was good for Tokyo Station and the Imperial Palace, but quite a way away from some of the more interesting areas of Tokyo.

The hotel has a fabulous design sense and the rooms are especially comfortable with unbelieveable views. However, what takes this hotel to the next level is the service and attention to detail. The staff responded to every request with a thoroughness my husband and I have never experienced. Whether it was directions, use of subway, restaurant reservations, or restaurant recommendations they exceeded our expectations. The kicker was when we left and arranged the limousine bus service. I told them we were spending our last night at an airport hotel. When we went to get on the bus they provided me with a detailed map of where to find the next hotel, how to get the free shuttle bus, and the specific times to get the shuttle. The detail was amazing, and I had not even requested any of the information, which was extremely helpful. They refused to take a tip and my husband had to secretly hand them a tip to be discrete. Great hotel and great service. They even waited for us to depart and say goodbye before we got on the limousine bus to the airport.

We stayed for the first night of our stay in Tokyo at the Mandarin Oriental, booking a Deluxe room as part of the seasonal packages offered by the Hotel's Web site.The room was fully conform to the web site pictures, spacious with impeccable fittings. Exceptional TV and Multimedia equipment (a set of cables makes it possible to use the flat panel LCD TV as output for your laptop). Service was perfect throughout. Breakfast was fine, perhaps not as impressive as the rest.The most memorable event was the dinner at the "Tapas" (the name of the restaurant) Molecular Cuisine restaurant. Because the restaurant only serves 6 guests for two services each evening we thought it would be impossible to get in, yet the hotel staff spared no effort to find us space - eventually by adding two seats. My advice however from now on is to book the restaurant in advance not to put staff through too much pressure! BTW the Tapas is really value for money (around JPY 30,000 for two with 24 tapas each). The room itself as expected is not exactly cheap, but in line with hotels of that category.

You can never be sure, when you read lots of glowing reviews about somewhere, that, when you go, your expectations will be met. Staying at the MOTYO, they are. We had a wonderful 3 nights there earlier this month. It is quite spooky that they greet you by name when you arrive to check-in at the lobby. My guess is that they take a quick peek at the luggage labels as they retrieve those from you at street level, but how several of them remember your names a couple of days later is indeed impressive.The hotel is wonderfully situated, being right above a Metro station, and even better, on the Ginza line which goes to all the places you want to see, or links to other lines, and is next door to the magnificent Mitsukoshi department store. I could easily have spent many more hours and yen in there. There were also several convenience stores nearby, selling all sorts of interesting stuff, especially great Japanese chocolates.Visiting in August as we did, we were never going to have clear views of Mt Fuji, and although our room on the 35th (!!) floor didn't look over the prized Westerly view, we had the bonus of being able to see the 'Golden Flame' (?Turd) of the Asahi brewery. Besides, after dark, all views are equal.Many people have gushed about the glass-walled bathroom, but although handsome, I must admit that this is highly impractical. When ever either of us went to the loo in the night, torch in hand to find the way, the other was instantly awoken - the situation was not helped by the electrical toilets of which the Japanese are so keen. This whirred and flushed all of the first night, leading us to unplug it last thing at night after that, replugging it in the morning. The shower and bath were gorgeous, though, the latter being deceptively large enough for a decent soak in after busy days pounding the Tokyo streets.Adam and the rest of the concierge team were really helpful, and the eateries they recommended were great - a wonderful sushi bar and a shabu-shabu place, both within walking distance of the hotel (our experiences better than Bob and Charlotte in Lost in Translation). There were lots of other good places which we discovered ourselves just by walking a bit.The breakfast buffet was good, although not quite as good as that of the ANA Hotel in Kyoto, with an interesting little starter drink of brown sugar and rice vinegar (sounds disgusting but I liked it), and the eggs, I bet, come from very happy hens, judging by what they're fed on!We were very envious of the people just arriving as we were leaving, and we will definitely return to the MOTYO when we go back to Tokyo.

We stayed in a fabulous two-bedroom suite at the amazing Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo for a full week in July. I can summarize our experience by simply stating that this is one of the best hotels in the world, and we rate the service there as the finest we have EVER encountered in our travels.We enjoyed a great flight with excellent service on Singapore Airlines (one of three best airlines in the world) from Los Angeles to Tokyo. When we arrived at Narita Airport, two people with the hotel’s “Meet & Greet” service were there at the gate when we got off the plane, and helped us negotiate the airport and quickly through customs/immigration, then on to the Mandarin’s Deluxe Van that would take us to the hotel. Our experience has shown us that although expensive, these two services are well worth paying for when arriving at a big, complex airport in a non-English speaking country. We departed Narita at about 6:30pm and the drive took approximately 1 hour & 15 minutes. The Senior Guest Relations Officer – Takashi Kurono – met us when we arrived and escorted us directly to our room, where he took care of the check-in procedure. Takashi was terrific and gave us much good advice in finalizing our plans for touring Tokyo. He also followed-up up each meeting with excellent data and maps to help us with our self-guided tours. We then visited the famed Ginza area that night.This was our first trip to Japan and we rank it among the most fascinating places we have visited. Tokyo is amazing, and could be best described as a much cleaner & newer New York City, filled with extremely nice, respectful people. We had no problem getting around the city by ourselves and only used a guide/translator and driver for a day and a half, when we were visiting artists in remote studios. The trains and subways were fairly easy to use and there was always some nice local person around who would help us figure out nuances of the ticket machine or location of the train. Would recommend spending a full day using the Yamanote Line train that makes an oval loop around the city. It runs above ground so you get to see much of Tokyo while riding. We began at 9:30am (to avoid earlier rush hour period) by walking 10 minutes from our hotel to Tokyo Station, bought “all day” tickets and boarded the train. We then got off for walking tours at the Shinbashi, Shibuya, Harajuku, and Shinjuku stations, on the way to looping back around to our starting point late that night. Had a great dinner (and view) at the New York Bar & Grill on 52nd floor of Park Hyatt Hotel in Shinzuku, where “Lost in Translation” was filmed (recommend watching before first trip to Tokyo). The Mitsukoshi Department store located next to the hotel was our favorite in the city. We visited the Ginza area several times for great shopping and restaurants and other interesting sites like the Sony Building and some museums. Also took the subway back from Ginza to the stop right next to our hotel. The Imperial Palace Garden is only a short 15 minute walk from the hotel and very beautiful to see.We also liked visiting the following areas: Ueno Park, Asakusa, Akihabara, Roppongi Hills, Hamarikyu Garden, Shiba Park, Tokyo Tower, and a boat cruise down the Simuda River.Had room service at the hotel every morning and a number of nights, and service and food were terrific. Tried the Sense restaurant one night and it was great. Our only disappointment with the hotel was their currency exchange charge of about 7.5%, which is the highest we can remember encountering at any hotel. Would recommend walking to the bank next door to the hotel where the charge was only 1% for Travelers Checks and 2% for USD conversion to Japanese Yen.Following our stay in Tokyo, we planned to take the Shinkansen bullet train from Tokyo Station to Osaka. The hotel took care of everything, booking and acquiring our first class (green car) tickets on the newest trains – Nozomi 700 series – which provide an excellent 2 ½ ride. They arranged a Deluxe Van to take us to the station and amazingly, one of the Bellmen escorted us there and through the chaotic station to our train, and also pulled several of our heavy bags from the Van all the way onto the train. We arrived at the station 30 minutes before our departure, so we could be first in line boarding our train car and be able to store our 3 heavy bags in the slot at the back of the car. The Mandarin also arranged with our Osaka hotel (Ritz Carlton) for them to meet us at the train platform when we arrived there and take us to the hotel. There we spend 1.5 days touring Osaka, then went with a guide on train to Kyoto for day trip, and repeated same process in Nara the next day. We stayed in Osaka (rather than Kyoto or Nara) because we were then able to fly direct from Osaka Kansai airport back to America (SFO) on United Airlines, which was very good (only one level below Singapore) and seemingly unrelated to the quality of its domestic service.

We stayed at the Mand. Tokyo twice, once before travelling to Kyoto and then again upon return to Tokyo...a total of six nights. We had a mixed experience. The lobby is stunning in a very chic and original way. There is a pretty happening bar scene. The location is good for business but we were leisure travellers and to get some of the newer upscale shopping areas and art museums I think the RC has a better location. Service was mixed. The bellman were outstanding , check in quick considering when we arrived we were disappointed with our room size and could not get an upgrade unless we paid $300 more which we did. I had read about their spa and was excited to check it out. We were really covering a lot of ground touring every day and normally I would have gone for a massage probably every other day. The spa told us that we could only use the jacuzzi between 6:30 am and 9:00 am or pay $160 to use it. We found this ridiculous since we were paying approximately $1000/night to stay in a Mandarin suite. We also tried to get massages and found it near impossible to get in. Also, strangely the "intro massage rate " was $160/hr and $340 for 80 minutes which made little to no sense. We found ourselves going to the RC and 4 S to get a massage a the end of the day and both were very welcoming. When I finally went to the spa manager to tell her about out difficulties with the spa she apologized, walked me back to my room and handed me her card suggesting that she call in advance if I stay in another MO hotel. I found this a bit strange b/c I didn't think they were able to provide a reasonable welcome to the spa in their own hotel.The rooms are gorgeous with great bathrooms and loads of bathroom amenites. Mitsukoshi is practically in the basement with the world's greatest dept store food market in their basement. The concierges gave us 2 very poor dinner steers, one on our last night of our trip to a brightly lit sushi bar in an office building that sat about 12. They told us it was one of the best sushi bars in Tokyo. They were out of tuna, yellowtail and eel when we ordered and unapologetically substituted with other fish as if we would not know the difference. When we told the MO concierge she was apoogetic saying that they were out of everything b/c it was 9:00 on a Friday night?! That said, the Tapas Molecular Bar right in the hotel lobby was on of the greatest dining experiences we have ever had and actually an excellent value at $125pp for 25 courses!! This is a no miss. All in all, we had a nice experience but would go to the RC next time inTokyo both for the location which is better for leisure travelers and also for the warmer staff. They were much friendlier to us as outside guests on two visits than we found anyone other than the doormen to be at the MO during 6 nights/ two stays.

From the first Moment everything is perfect.This is really first class. If you can pay the price: do it, you will never forget it. This Hotel is just a dream. The view you have from the rooms are one of the best in Tokyo.Japan in general is country of perfection but the M O is even better. All the time they try to do the best for you and belive me they do ! I can not wait to go back one day.

The hotel lobby is fabulous. I was not sure if I should go here or to another hotel, but I decided to check out MO. The hotel rooms are probably better at the Peninsula Tokyo but the bar, the ambience, the service at MO is absolutely fantastic. The best contemporary chic designed hotel.

There have been so many wonderful reviews for this hotel, I am a little hesitant to repeat them again, but just having returned from a week in Tokyo, I have to share this experience.A family of three, we spend a lot of time travelling all around the world. This was however our first trip to Japan. I choose the MO because of all the great reviews. Therefore, our expectations were extremely high. Premisis - About the building , the entrance, the lobby, spas , rooms , bars etc, all I can say is that I was flabbergasted. I have worked before on several hotel building projects, and I have a tendency to look at the quality of craftmanship in the design and fitting. I try to see where they have cut the corners, or made a small mistake. After spending a week at the MO in Tokyo, I found nothing! Although it seems not possible to me, they did not cut any corners! They have simply taken the best materials available, and applied them in an absolutely fantastic solution. I am not talking about one part of the hotel, I mean everywhere. From the entrance door to the bathrooms, it is perfect. (Small tip - have a look at the floor in the elevators or the stairs going from the lobby down to the bar. It is a black marble, but look for the blue highlights which shimmer in the day light. Amazing touch!)Service - This is by far the best trained hotel staff we have ever encountered. I cannot say enough about the front desk and concierge team. As in a previous review, we have been surprised by their friendlyness and competence in making our stay most enjoyable. From a fast check to a perfect check-out it was great. (Tip- the counters of the reception are beatifully lined in leather. small but nice touch. Also, if you are presented a pen to sign your bill or anything else. No flimsy plastic pens, but substantial writing pieces.)The concierge team has organised a guide, recommended and book restaurants, organised train tickets, recommened shopping tours etc. We could not have been more pleased. But to top it off, it was not the perfect rooms, the great spa, the wonderful views, great room service etc, that mattered, it was the true feeling that they care about you as a guest. This is something which begins in the traditional Japanese culture, but is perfected in the selection and training of the staff at the MO Tokyo. Example - we had booked a private guide for two half-days. This was a wonderful lady who spoke great english and took us to the places which were of our interests, and not only the ones in the guide books. After spending time with her she obviously learned about our interests in Japan and the history, culture , etc. After the second tour, on the day of our check-out, I received a small package from the concierge. I gift. I don't want to get into details here, but it was not a gift of high monetary value, but one of extreme kindness and consideration on part of the concierge team. After showing this small present to my wife, she practically started tearing-up in happiness. It was exactly what we have been wanting to bring back from Japan, and even better it was made for and about our family. In a situation like this, saying thank you seems too little, but is is all you can do. This was the so called "icing on the cake". After spending a week in Tokyo, we went on to Kyoto for few days. We stayed in a very nice hotel, the Hyatt Regency, and upgraded to a very nice room, but after staying at the MO you just become too pampered, and anything else is a bit of a let down. Upon returning to Tokyo before our flight, we spent one night at the MO and felt as if we were returning home. Of course, we were greeted with the welcome back, and how was your trip to Kyoto. Wonderful! If you have the time and means to spend at the MO in Tokyo, please do not hesitate. It goes well beyond five or six stars in our eyes. Of course it all comes with a price attached, but for similar money you can also get so-so service. So don't make that mistake and stay with the MO Tokyo, perhaps the best hotel in the world!

We began and ended our vacation in Japan by staying at the Mandarin Oriental/Tokyo. The hotel sets the standard for luxury. It sits on the 32-38th floors of an office building in a commercial section of Tokyo, with floor to ceiling windows providing sweeping views of eastern and western Tokyo. The guestrooms facing the west-- Mandarin Deluxe -- cost more, and offer a view of Mt. Fuji -- which only can be seen during certain times of the year. During our stay, Mt. Fuji was shrouded in fog. It might be better to spring for the higher priced room in the wintertime, when the mountain is visible. Tokyo's eastern exposure is also breathtaking, but be prepared for early morning sunshine pouring in when you open the draperies.  The rooms are relatively large, and every detail has been arranged with a traveler's comfort in mind: For example, there is a closet adjacent to the door of the guest room where the morning paper, polished shoes or other service has been discretely placed, that the guest can access from inside the room without opening the front door. The elegant bathroom has a wall mirror that slides so that you can have an unobstructed view of Tokyo from the bathroom. Each shower provides three shower heads -- a downpouring overhead unit; a wall mount, and a handheld unit.
