The lighting is ample and strategically placed.There is a well-equipped exercise room with floor to ceiling windows overlooking east Tokyo, featuring a wide range of Life Fitness equipment connected by wireless headsets to cable; and complementary freshly squeezed juice is served, A box in the guest rooms contains a collection of broadband ethernet and video cords. Broadband access is complementary. The service staff are ubiquitous and very helpful. When we returned to the hotel a week later for our last evening in Japan, the staff greeted us by name.Because the hotel is only two years old, some taxi drivers are not familiar with its location. Be sure to get a card with the hotel address and map on it before you go out, to avoid problems returning to the hotel.Dining in the more casual restaurant (where breakfast is served) on the 38th floor was excellent and had a range of reasonably priced choices. The breakfast cold buffet featured wonderful pastries and fruit, as well as traditional Japanese offerings. A hot buffet is also available.While expensive, the Mandarin Oriental was by far the best city-based hotel that we stayed in. We would definitely book it again if we return to Tokyo, unless the rates become out of sight. We enjoyed an internet off-season rate.

Having chosen to walk from the Japanrail station to the hotel, we weren't entirely sure we'd found the Mandarin Oriental, until we rounded a corner and saw the sign. Walking towards the doors of the hotel, a porter rushed towards us and took our cases, while another member of staff greeted us. As we walked, he asked my surname, and without looking at any notes, confirmed my first name. I know it's a small thing, but it immediately makes you feel like they're making an effort. We were escorted to the lift, and up to the reception/lobby floor. The porter had obviously called up to reception when we went to the lifts, because when we arrived in the lobby, they had my paperwork waiting on the reception desk ready for my signature. They also presented me with some concert tickets I'd ordered ahead. Superb.We booked a Mandarin Deluxe room, which was vast. The corridors to the rooms are arranged in such a way that you feel you're actually in quite private wings of a smaller hotel. It's another small detail that adds to the comfort of your stay. The room was immaculate, and every item in it felt very high quality. Even the slippers were the best hotel slippers I've ever used, and the bathroom accessories (including a surprisingly good hair brush) were excellent. Items were replaced on a daily basis, so almost as soon as we unwrapped a brush from its little Mandarin Oriental bag, we'd find another one in the bathroom. Also in the bathroom, you would find an almost unbeatable walk-in shower, a huge, fast-filling bath and a top-end Toto toilet, complete with an "extra deodorising" button.Another notable feature in the room was the massive flat-screen television, and its extremely impressive array of entertainment options. These included internet radio, meaning we could ditch the dubbed international news channels, and listen to our favourite BBC 6Music shows. The bed was supremely comfortable, and the air-conditioning was quiet and effective. We weren't fortunate enough to see the top of Fuji during our stay, due to cloud, but you would have an uninterrupted view on a clearer day. The only criticism I would have of the room is the lack of drawers; there were none in which to store clothing. Perhaps they're not used to people staying for extended periods, but we had to improvise using the Kimono box and the top shelf of the wardrobe (not suitable for someone under 6ft tall, I'd suggest). Free wireless broadband access was very useful, though, and the in-room safe comfortably accommodated my 15" laptop, cameras, documents, etc.The hotel isn't in the most convenient of locations, if you're in Tokyo for fun. It's about 25 minutes on the tube to the bright lights of Shibuya, 10-15 minutes to Ginza and Akihabara, and at least half an hour to Shinjuku. However, because it's on top of a tube station, most of these places are reached very easily. Shinjuku's a little awkward, as you have to change line a couple of times, or walk to a different station. But Shibuya and Ginza are directly accessible, and Akihabara isn't far from a direct station. We enjoyed being slightly out of the madder parts of Tokyo, knowing that it was easy to go in to the more exciting areas. It was a short walk over to the Imperial Palace and its peaceful grounds and nearby high-end shopping.The hotel bar was expensive but stylish, with a view over the city towards Fuji san. We ate in the restaurant on the lobby level once for dinner and every day for breakfast. Dinner was rather nice, but unspectacular. Breakfast was wonderful - everything you could want, and all sorts of eggs cooked to order. Also, room service was delicious and well presented.Staff at the hotel were unfailingly polite and helpful. We had a couple of problems with our automatic curtains/drapes, and the housekeeping manager was disproportionately but endearingly apologetic, and did his best to sort things out swiftly. It was hardly a problem...we just had to draw the curtains by hand for one night. The concierge was also very helpful.We stayed here for 6 nights, and loved every one. Tokyo is a fascinating city, with so much to do. And this has to be one of the world's finest hotels, within easy reach of some of the world's finest shopping and entertainment. If we go back to Tokyo, I don't think we'd consider staying anywhere else. We've stayed in quite a few good hotels around the world, but this one takes first prize. So far...

Stayed here for a couple nights recently. Excellent (large) rooms with great views over Tokyo. Service exemplary.Great spa and fitness room.Stayed in quite a few hotels in Tokyo, this is my fave for now.

During a recent business trip to Tokyo, I chose the Mandarin Oriental that I found the hotel to be an excellent choice and just another wonderful property from this hotel chain. The lobby was beautifully decorated with views of Tokyo and the room was modern with every amenity once could want. This hotel met all of my expectations and would certainly visit again when in Tokyo.

Stayed at the MO from 30 May till 1 June and then from 3 June till 6 June. We have stayed in many top hotels, and we just expected another 5-star hotel experience. As our cab approached the hotel driveway, the doormen were already enthusiastically waving to our cab, ushering it to stop where they were all eagerly waiting and with great efficiency, they unloaded the bags from the boot even before we paid the cab fare. We were greeted with warm welcomes and ushered to the 38th floor where the reception desk was. After a quick check in, we were shown to our room. Amex Centurion has a stay 2 nites, pay 1 nite promo at all MO hotels, valid for once a year and we took advantage of that. We were upgraded to the premier king room but decided to splurge on the executive suite for an extra 20,000 yen. It was very spacious, the bathroom had a free standing bath and a huge shower with seating for 2 people in it! The bed wasnt a full king, my only grouse for the price we were paying, we should have a full king bed. Broadband access is free, huge flat screen tvs, and very plush coverings. But the reason why i am writing this review is not because of the room, many good hotels have this too. Its the MO service that we are most impressed with. We have never experienced a level of service that "goes the extra mile" as we did here at MO. We were going to Izu, a 3 hour train ride out of Tokyo and altho I had done my research on the internet, we still had a few queries about getting there. The train schedule seemed to indicate that we needed to transfer trains but other sites said diff things. We checked with the front desk at MO and immed the man there, a very helpful Mr Takashi, offered to help me decipher and make out the route there. He took my train schedule and other info, made a copy and said he would get back to me. In less than 2 hours, they slid a note under our door and said that they would be happy to purchase the train tickets for us for the journey there and back to Tokyo. Of course we said yes please, and an hour later, the train tickets were sitting at the front desk waiting for me to pick them up. I only paid for them at check out. Someone actually went to the train station and bought the tickets for us, how cool is that!When we got back from Izu 3 days later, we were greeted with "Welcome back Mr ---!" by the doormen. How do they remember everyone's names?? I wouldnt flatter myself to think that they remember only our names of course, that they remember returning guests by name is amazing to me. Went to the spa and hub did a facial. They didnt just complete the facial and forget all abt him, they advised him on his skin type and how to manage his skin care. All in all, the service at the MO is stellar, and unmatched in all the hotels that we have stayed at, we have never felt so pampered and taken care of. We were not just guests, we were valued and treated with utmost respect and hospitality, they fully deserve their 6 star rating and what they lose out to in terms of location (how i wish they were in a shopping belt!), they more than make up for it in unparalleled service and warmth. Will def stay there again!

We stayed @ Mandarin Oriental for just 1 night before going home. I thought it would be impossible to top Ritz but they did it.Unbelievable hotel. We had an amazing view from our room. Would absolutely stay again.

The Mandarin Oriental Tokyo met all our expectations from the moment of our arrival when we were greeted at the front door and whisked up to the lobby until the time of our departure.The room was spacious by any standards but certainly by Tokyo ones and beautifully decorated but with restraint.The service was impecable. Staff never failed to be helpful and courteous.The spa was excellent.This was just a heavenly stay, in a hotel with its head it the clouds.

For our family of four, we booked two adjoining corner rooms and now we are spoiled for any other hotel. Both rooms had endless views and were perfectly furnished. It can be quite difficult to find a hotel in Tokyo to accommodate a family, but the MO did so beautifully. My kids pointed our that their twin bedded room was even larger than our corner-king and technically they were right, but ours was quite satisfactory. The staff knows the essence of service and achieves a very high standard in a country that has perfected the art. The only downside to this hotel is that it's located in a business district and there's not much to do in the immediate area. There is, however, a very convenient metro/JR station on the ground level.

Having stayed at some of the most expensive five stars hotels around the World, I can confidently say that Mandarin Oriental Tokyo really does deliver to a level that puts it in a league of its own. Everything from the hotel facilities, location, customer service and room size is absolutely superb. The only drawdown to a MO that really got it right is the spa treatment prices which are VERY high by any international standard.Will definitely be choosing to return next time in Tokyo.

Staying here is a real experience - we booked for the view and it was defiinitely worth it ! The rooms were flawless: Perfectly comfortable bed, very nice and high quality furniture and a fantastic view from everywhere (including the bath room). Shower and bath were both extremely comfortable.Service was great from arrival to departure. The assistance provided for organizing our onward journey was just exceptional. We had in-room breakfast and found this the only weakness. While very good in quality it arrived too early and the form provided is not unambiguous for all items. However apart from that all services provided were just perfect !

Exceptional.!!! and from someone who is very fussy , that's praise indeed.This has to be one of the best hotel i have ever stayed in, and i have stayed in some very nice hotels around the world. Everything about the hotel is perfect but the most outstanding has to be the wonderful staff, without exception all the staff were exceptionally helpful, polite and friendly, nothing was too much trouble for them.

Our stay at the Mandarin Oriental was flawless, as usual for Mandarin Hotels. The room was spacious with a fantastic view of Tokyo and Mount Fuji beyond. Service was excellent, room service was prompt and the food was great. Bathroom had all the amenities you'd need and more. Breakfast was delicious with either a buffet or waiter service for meals prepared to order. Again the views were amazing, service and food excellent.With all the hustle and bustle of Tokyo it was great to come back to the hotel and relax. If we returned to Tokyo again we would not hesitate to book again.

We stayed at the MO in July 07 and have very fond memories of this hotel/holiday. A truly magnificent memory, which my husband and I will cherish for, I am sure many years to come.This is a fantastic hotel. It is the best hotels I have ever stayed in. The service was first class and the staff could not have been more polite, helpful and courteous. The rooms are beautifully decorated (and we only had a standard room), spacious and comfortable with a great floor to ceiling view. The design of the room is very stylish and comfortable with high quality materials and appliances. The room has a big Plasma TV and plenty of other fancy technology (i.e ipod and laptop connections). The bathrooms were also top notch, with a lovely big bath and separate shower and little flat screen TV. This is an expensive hotel but in comparison to other 5* hotels in Tokyo not that much more (sometimes even less) and well worth it. We did not choose a breakfast rate as it is in a city and coffee shops are close by. We had breakfast in several coffee shops (like Starbucks or similar), which were all in 5-10 min walking distance and always on the way to the place we wanted to visit that day.The location is also good. The subway access is in the hotel and you can get across town with the very efficient subway system. The hotel restaurants are also excellent. Again pricey but food and service were out of this world. There are plenty of restaurants in nearby Ginza. Just jump in a taxi, the staff at the hotel entrance help in explaining the drivers were you want to go and make sure you know how to get back to the hotel – very sweet.Another great benefit was that the Internet access was free.Overall I am just repeating what many people have said before me. Fantastic Hotel you won’t regret staying at this hotel, it is a real experience.

I have stayed here now a few times and it is absolutely perfect. Arriving in the lobby on the 38th floor with a view of Tokyo all around you through the glass windows is surreal. The staff makes you feel welcome from the moment you arrive. The rooms, the service, the spa, and the gym are all top notch. You can't go wrong with a stay here.

I stayed at the Mandarin for 3 nights in January and it was wonderful. After being stuck in traffic on the yellow bus for 2 hours, it was a relief to see the room! I agree with another reviewer, MO beats the Park Hyatt hands down. The hotel is very conveniently located and is right ontop of the subway station. The bedroom, bathroom, view (could see Mt Fuji!), and service were excellent. LOVE the bulgari white tea bath products :)
user_location: Travel and food addict in HK
user_name:
blubs
Travel and food addict in HK

review_body: Just returned from Tokyo and I cannot write enough good things about this BEAUTIFUL hotel. The location is excellent - there is the Metro in the basement which makes it very easy to travel around Tokyo. The staff are incredibly helpful with queries you have and advice on planning your site seeing (or cherry blossom viewing). The rooms are STUNNING!!! SUCH attention to detail. Big room, wonderful bathroom. It was difficult to actually LEAVE the room it was so nice. The view was spectacular. We could see Mount Fiji and the Tokyo skyscrapers. This has to be one of the BEST city hotels I have stayed in. VERY impressed! Would def want to stay here again!

Our recent stay met all of our expectations.Had a west facing view where we could see Mt Fuji every morning.Fantastic since it was sunny and clear during our winter stay.Spent 3 nights and I cant say enough about the service of this hotel from the airport pick up,quick check-in to the service at the top floor bar.Rooms are spotless and the views spectacular.Though not in the middle of all the "action" we managed to walk everywhere or take the subway which is located nearby.Ginza district is only 3 stops away.The only negatives are the high prices charged at the bar-but that is typical of Tokyo hotels.Also the exhorborant prices the hotel charges to transport you from and to the airport.When we were there the cost was over $500 us each way!!!! Its much cheaper to take a taxi to Tokyo station and take the Narita Express train-about $40 per person.Would def stay here again.The only other hotel we would consider based on location and rooms would be the Peninsula in Ginza.You can check that one out too.

Your reviewers are 100% right. This is really world class. The wow factors are;1. Great rooms with stunning views2.An amazing 'front of house' - fast, friendly, efficient3. Little details - like the eggs at breakfast which have a reddish colour as a result of being fed on a diet of chilli and rosehip.4. A 'can do' attitude by staff. (For example, I wanted something that wasn't on the menu - they made it!).Very minor niggles...and yes, they are minor...were service in the 'all day dinning' restaurant was well meaning, but a touch all over the place. And the baths are large and nice but weirdly oval. Not ideal...but hey this place scores 98.5% (and no one get's 100%!).

This place is the bomb. Stayed at Park Hyatt before as well--it's no match for MOTYO. Really convenient--mitsukoshimae stop on the metro is literally under the hotel. Great location if you like to jog : routes that circle the imperial palace..concierge not as great as last time. what happened to adam chapin? he was the best concierge. The fitness center is great, overlooking great city views. an attendant greets you with towel and bottle of water and offers cold juice on your way out; although last time i also got a cool, damp washcloth. maybe i looked sweatier? anyway, after jogging one morning, the downstairs greeter practially ran to beat us to the elecator to give us some water and towels. really impressive! the breakfast is really nice too, especially since it can be a challenge to find breakfast outside the hotel. kind wish i could live there...

We stayed here on our way home from a tour of Australia and to be honest I was gutted to leave after a few days. It's quite simply one of the best hotels I have ever stayed in. The service was first class and the staff couldn't have been more courteous. We stayed on floor 38 and the view of Mt Fuji in the morning from our window was breathtaking. The hotel has lots of great restaurants and you must have cocktails in the lounge as the views over Toyko are uninterrupted.I loved the bed, it was huge and the most comfortable few nights sleep I've ever enjoyed. The rooms are furnished to a very high standard indeed.I also loved the spa facilities, they don't seem to advertise that they are free, but you'll get the best views ever and it's open quite late. I also enjoyed a signature treatment which was fab, though a little pricey.If you're like me and debating over the Hyatt or the Mandarin, I promise you won't be disappointed, it was perfect in every way.Oh and if you get the chance, hire a private guide circa £100 for two people (or if you're brave enough go it alone) and take yourself down to the fish market where you'll catch the fish auctions, it's incredible. We also went to a traditional Japanese tempura restuarant which the concierge organised.

We stayed 2 nights at the MO with 2 children. It was excellent in everyway. The room was large and the view was to die for---even at breakfast we could see the sun rise slowly over Tokyo. The location is not right in the midst of tourist town but it is conveniently close to everything due to a great subway/train system underneath the hotel. Ginza is only 2 stops away--about 5 minutes. However, it was the small touches or the attention to detail that made this hotel extremely memorable for us. The bathroom IS definitely the best room with tv, deep soaking bath, 3 types of shower heads and still the view! The service was wonderful---nothing was too much trouble and they even took us down to the station to showed us how to purchase tickets for the train. Not that daunting but it cut out a lot of possible confusion. I was also able to get the concierge to purchase JR train tickets to our ski resort before we arrived and charge it to our room. These tickets can not be purchased outside of Japan so the concierge saved me much precious time in that regard. All I can say is that the hotel staff were absolutely warm, efficient, and truly helpful in every possible way. Yes, it is expensive but worth it to experience the best---at least once! Oh yes, the breakfast buffet was excellent---very nice smoked salmon, eggs benedict with crab meat, and truly crisp luscious french pastries to enjoy. We loved it so much we really didn't want to go out and brave the wonderful city.

Being used to stay at top notch hotels around the world, when we arrived to Mandarin Oriental, we were blown away. We arrived very early (at 6 o’clock am) to Tokyo airport, so we were at the MO around 8:00 and they had our rooms ready. They knew in advanced, but they took care of that little detail. Check in was courteous, efficient and fast. They understood that after 15 hours of travelling we needed to rest. However if it had took a little more, it wouldn’t had bothered us, the lobby is beautiful. Being at floor 38 and having views to all Tokyo, is just fascinating. When we arrived to the rooms, the wow factor continued. Rooms are elegant, contemporary yet classy and rich of Japanese heritage. We reserved rooms looking toward the Imperial Garden and Mount Fuji, which are a little bit bigger than the rooms facing the other side. High technology is everywhere. The bathroom is impressive and the shower is the best. Breakfast was included with our rate, so we had it. It was fabulous. When we entered the restaurant (with views too), we saw a not-so-large selection. But soon we learnt that it was just half of it, the other part was “a la carte”. The selection in the menu was gourmet and the food surpassed the expectations. The only place I can think of having a breakfast as good is the Peninsula Hong Kong. When we left the hotel, it was before the restaurant was opened, so they gave us box-lunches, which were quite good.The facilities are not just the only great part of this hotel, it is the service. They are really happy that you have chosen their hotel. When returning to the hotel, we were greeted with “welcome back”, for example. These kinds of little touches make the whole experience satisfying. Staying at MO is staying at the best hotel of the world.

This was our first stay in Tokyo and choose MOT over PHT purely based on location. MOT is closer to most of the tourist locale which can be easily reached via subway with the Ginza line. The room was excellent - clean and funished with quality furnishings. The bathroom/shower was probably one of the best in the world. For $700/night, I expected a bit more from a service standpoint. I received as good of service and recognition from most standard Starwood hotels in Asia for half the rate. Maybe I expected a bit more for such a lofty rate. Many nights, I sat at the desk looking at PHT wondering if they had better service than MOT.

This was our first stay at a Mandarin Oriental and we were blown away by the attention to detail. We'd give it brownie points for:1. being able to check in at 10am without any fuss2. the Aromatherapy Associates toiletries & natural bath sponge3. the aromatherapy oils that scented the rooms4. the AMAZING floor to ceiling views5. the quality of the furnishings and bedding6. the technology - LG plasmas in the room/bathrooms7. the fab shower ...the oval bath took a wee bit of getting used to8. the service in the hotel bars and restaurants9. professionalism and warmth of staff in general10. The MO bar - forget Lost in Translation and the Hyatt...this is the real deal for your cocktail with the skyscraper viewtiny gumbles..1. The rate on check in didn't quite correspond to the internet rate quotes but we stupidly didn't have the rate to hand to disagree (not tax, we's allowed for this).2. Having to go via the impressive lobby to get to the spa/leisure facilities3. Not having a detailed spa facilities menu - either a hard copy on on the guest services screen on the plasma.A fabulous place to come back to after days spent in crazy, wonderful Tokyo. After 4 nights we didn't want to leave. Our new favourite hotel chain.

Had a nice, two-night stay at the hotel during my trip. The location is reasonably convenient, being above the Mitsukoshi-Mae station on the Ginza line. It's a bit away from most major attractions for tourists, but you can easily get around on the subway.The lobby is on a high floor, and gives a feeling of tranquility. There are bars and restaurants on the lobby floor as well as below, accessed via stairs. Nice views of Tokyo from there.The rooms are very nice and comfy - big for Tokyo. The decor is subtle and pleasant. The bathroom is wonderful - my girlfriend's favorite hotel bathroom. Dining at Tapas Molecular is a nice experience if you like that sort of thing, which I do.

This was my first MO but probably won't be my last! The rooms are huge by any standards, and for Tokyo they are almost obscene. I was in a Mandarin room, on 33rd floor facing the Imperial Palace gardens and the Tokyo Tower. The view was amazing, and had it not been overcast I would have woken up to Mount Fuji too!Plus points: staff at front desk, concierge, housekeeping are excellent. The beds are super-comfortable, large and the blinds are blackout which makes sleeping in all too easy! The bathroom is beautiful with a great shower. Front desk arranged the Limo Bus to Narita for me, and switched the tea in my room to English breakfast when they reaslied I dislike green tea. They even delivered fresh milk every day for it too. (You can take the girl out of England...) Not so plus points: restaurant maitre d'hotel was snooty (just the European guy, all the Japanese staff were faultless).
I loved the rooms, absolute top class!Service meticulous!Food very good..Location very nice with Mitsukoshi next door!Hope to stay there soon again!!

The Mandarin is phenomenal. Although expensive, there are few hotels in the world that rival it. From the elevator that takes you to the 38th floor to check in, to rooms with amazing views, to the service, to the tea and incense provided, to the audio/video system, to the bath robes, everything is fantastic.The staff remembers you as you come and go, everyone tries to help you, and the room and amenities are top notch. The TV shows a ton of english language programs (including the Discovery channel) and includes hook up cables for your iPod, laptop, or anything else with a connector.The beds are amazingly comfortable. The staff goes out of its way to make sure anything you need is done. The piano bar on the 37th floor is a perfect place to try a drink and look out over the city, even if you aren't a guest of the hotel.

There isn't enough praise that I can lavish on this hotel and its wonderful staff. We spent four glorious nights at the Mandarin Oriental over the Thanksgiving holiday. Being a kitchen and bath designer, I was anxious to see the much lauded bedroom and bath design. I wasn't disappointed. Many people assume that minimalist design is cold, sparse and uninviting. These rooms are high end luxury at its finest. Elegant materials, warm woods, special touches, and sound proofing make you want to stay forever. And the bathrooms? Wow.....you can't beat the combo of Asian design and German engineering (the shower and lavatory plumbing are HansGrohe from Germany). The Japanese Toto toilet took some getting used to, but that heated seat was a real treat! Probably the most comfortable bed/pillow combo I've ever enjoyed in a hotel and the linens were as high end as I had expected.The staff were polite, attentive and unobtrusive. The staff at the Concierge desk were extraordinarily knowledgeable and helpful for much more than dinner reservations! The public rooms are utterly amazing. The three stacked fireplaces were picture-worthy! And the view of downtown Tokyo exceeded all expectations.Treat yourself to something extraordinary and stay at this wonderful hotel!

I will be brief, as others have already provided ample praise for this spectacular place. On the pricey side, but well worth it. Great location, wonderfully helpful staff, incredibly quiet rooms, staff will cater to your every need. Probably the most comfortable bed/pillow ever. Highly recommended. The heated toilet seat, with electronic controls for "rear cleansing" and "front cleansing" was a new one on me.

Well, what can I possibly say about this hotel in the positive that has not already been stated!! Beautiful room, we stayed in a Mandarin Room with views out to Mount Fuji. Stunning!The bed was supremely comfortable with a light as air doona.Room service was prompt and special. Enjoyed the extra touches like flowers on the room service trolley.The evening turn down service was amazing to watch, one almost felt like royalty as the staff quickly and quietly buzzed around the room replacing towels, readying the bed and putting out evening water and incense.The best thing about this hotel was the conceige service.Wow, they arranged hire bikes for us in a jiffy and because we had asked on short notice they were concerned that we would have to collect them ourselves. Map with full directions was provided.The bike hire proved to be the best $5 spent on the trip as we toured from one end of Tokyo to the next over the following 2 days.Booking restaurants and ensuring correct directions were done with a smile and without fault.Only thing to keep in mind that this hotel is not cheap. With added service charge and 2 room service meals and breakfast we paid over $1000 Australian dollars per night!But hey, what an experience!

A flawless, beautiful hotel with drop dead views. I was wavering between booking the MO or the Park Hyatt and boy am I glad I chose the MO. We had dinner at the Hyatt and it doesn't even come close. The service was beyond phenomenal and the rooms were spectacular. I can't gush more about this hotel...it was as close to perfect as a luxury hotel should be.
user_name:
cjthekid
New York City, New York

review_body: I was fortunate enough to have had the opportunity to stay at this extraordinary hotel for 4 days recently through work. This is simply put: the BEST hotel in the world. It's beyond 6 stars and they can do no wrong.We booked an S class limo service from the airport and from the moment we arrived at the hotel, they had staff and porters waiting for us. The staff to guest ratio is incredible and you always feel that someone is nearby to assist. They took us immediately to our rooms where check in staff were on hand with arrival documents. Our bags came quickly thereafter and we were free to enjoy the incredible views of Tokyo that this hotel offers. The hotel sits atop an office building and has 30th+ floor views of the mountains, the city (Ginza is down the road) and you can see parts of the Imperial Palace's park lands.The premier grand deluxe rooms were breathtaking. Extremely spacious by any standard and exceptionally luxurious. The details are what matter here: a hand written note card tells you the day's weather information and tomorrow's; everything automated and electronic (including blinds and curtains); HDTV flatscreen; iPod plug in point; yoga mats and umbrellas; walk in wardrobe area; separate spa bath and open style shower... You couldn't ask for a better appointed room. And like the earlier reviews mentioned, the little "hand through" closet at the door is a very well conceived idea for the room. They delivered messages and newspapers without ever having to knock.We also enjoyed the inclusive breakfast every morning. You can order eggs a la carte/any style and there was the great buffet. More fusion style than simply Japanese, and they had a nice selection of beverages. We also had one business lunch in the all day dining restaurant and the food and service was very good. The only complaint we had here was that the coffee service was a tad bit slow every morning. We also invited friends over to enjoy the views at the tea lounge near the Mandarin Bar. We had tea, drinks, and some Chinese appetizers and the staff were not only attentive and friendly, but the service is non-instrusive in a nice and discreet way.We also used the gym everyday. The treadmills have views over the entire city and the large flat screens with wireless headsets made running very enjoyable. The gym is well equipped and the fresh juices and fruit are a nice touch. The staff person there was always helpful and on hand to make your work out productive. On our first time, he recommended the spa on the 37th floor which was free of charge if you use the gym. We followed his advice and went down to use the spa pools and sauna/steam room. This had to be the best and most relaxing thing activity in all of Tokyo. The views from the spa pools are hard to beat!The other thing we noticed that was exceptional was the house keeping staff were always on top of everything and you never saw them. A house keeping trolley was never in sight! They always knew when we weren't there somehow and they would always make up the room and do the turn down service. The aromatherapy bowl in the turn down service was a very nice touch prior to bed time.Another example of how great the level service is: hotel staff bow everytime you walk by and wait for you to pass. They wait for lift/elevator doors to close before moving on. And above all else, they have the "just say yes" attitude which makes everything a joy.I would highly recommend this hotel for both business and leisure (although Roppongi would be a better location for leisure travellers). The subway is just downstairs and very convenient and there is plenty to do at this location (the office building has a food court and shops). If you are debating which hotel to stay at in Tokyo, you will not only get the best in Tokyo here, but the best in the entire world.

I did research tokyo hotels quite a bit before deciding on the Mandarin Oriental. Besides that this hotel is rated on this website as the #1 hotel in tokyo, I read every single review and all rated this hotel a 5.0. Notch up another 5.0 for the hotel from me.Top notch room, service, spa, restaurants, room service, view. From the moment we arrived to when we left. Above all, you will find the concierge service here alone worth it all. Very highly recommended ! Period.

The title of this review is a bold one, but I do travel extensively for business and this is simply a flawless hotel. From the extraordinary rooms, to the food, to the peerless service, everything is *exactly* right. Budget permitting, I'll definitely be back.Of course there's the view. Little things, like the compartment in the closet where you leave things for pickup so the staff never need to bother you when picking up or leaving things for you, make this hotel a cut above most. The room is beautifully appointed, with high-quality laquer boxes for storing things like yakuta and slippers. The bathrooms are a delight - although if you want to use all the functions on the hi-tech toilet it may take you a while to figure it out. At the desk in the room there's a connection panel - with high quality cables - so you can run your iPod or portable DVD player, into the entertainment system, or even play something from your laptop. This makes it a very pleasant hotel if you're stuck doing business. Of course if you're like me you'll want to spend most of your time out of the hotel exploring Tokyo, and the location is great for that: Tokyo Station is 3 minutes walk, and there's a subway station just around the corner from the hotel entry. There's plenty of great eating in nearby Ginza, but going further afield is easy. The staff all speak flawless English and are great with directions.By the way, Maranouchi department store, just around the corner, sells some lovely porcelain.The hotel restaurants are also exceptionally good, if slightly westernised for my tastes (I prefer a traditional Japanese breakfast, but I'm odd like that).If money is no object, get the hotel limousine from Narita. If money is an object, get the shuttle bus that runs from Narita to the hotel by way of the downtown air terminal. Or get the train to Tokyo and a 500Y taxi ride from there (or walk - it's only a few minutes if you don't have much luggage).If you have the money to splurge, this is one splurge you won't regret.

We stayed 2 nights in the Park Hyatt Tokyo and 1 night in the Mandarin Oriental Hotel. We preferred the Mandarin Oriental for all ! The Corner room was AMAZING, the view was beautiful, the bathroom really crazy with a Lcd flat screen and a view on tokyo bay... The reception and the staff were the best I ever saw during all my trips ! They booked sumo tournament tickets for us and deliver them to our room with no charges. The french restaurant was incredible and the food really nice. All wines were availables, with French Saint-emilion of 1984... The french chief of the restaurant came to thank us at the end of the dinner and stayed to discuss. All in this hotel is perfect and gorgeous ! There are no questions for this hotel, if you have the choice and the money, take immediatly a room ! You will have a real experience and a nice dream !!

My husband and I spent our honeymoon in this hotel, and felt in love with the spetacular view, the great breakfast, the amazing spa, the best bathroom. Unbelievable, even better than the Oriental Hotel in bagkok! The service is impecable. The best hotel I´ve ever been.

After a grueling trip across the Pacific, what you really need is an island of peace and quiet. The Mandarin Oriental is that special sanctuary that you have been dreaming about. At first you might not appreciate the understated decor and the ever present, but discreet service, but after a day or two, you will feel that you want to stay there forever. We had a corner view room and it certainly was worth the princely sum that such a view commands. You can sit for hours and just watch the lights twinkle. And the service is impeccable whether it is booking a rail reservation or writing a note to a store to return a defective product. We also loved our dinner at the Italian Buffet restaurant. Other hotels will have a lot to live up to after our wonderful stay here.

My favorite hotel chain is the Mandarin Oriental. And this one is a perfect example why. It made our Tokyo visit just marvelous. Service is top-notch. Terrific room with stunning views. Quality, first-rate furnishings and beddings. Heated toilet seat! Spa was magnificent. Over-all first class.

This hotel deserves the fantastic reviews. Like others, we've been to other "tier one" Asian hotels. Nothing (in our experience) comes close to MOTYO. The Concierge team in particular is masterful. They made our 4 days stay magical. They looked after every little detail, helped us to find special places that suited our desires, and responded effortlessly to tough requests at the last minute. The rooms are comfy, the food is great (although the breakfast is a bit weak). The Molecular Bar is a food experience. All in all - highly recommended!

Is this the best hotel in the world? Quite possibly, as I've not stayed in all of them. It is certainly the best hotel I have ever stayed in!The rooms are stunningly gorgeous, and we awoke on 5 out of the 7 days to see Mount Fuji beyond the amazing views of Tokyo. Everything about the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo was perfect, from the cushy slippers to the amazing service.I would highly recommend this hotel to anybody and everybody. Our party included children from the age of 4 to grandparents (age 80) and everybody was happy and impressed. My only slight concern was that although the restaurants were lovely to look at (and the service was superb), the food was not on par with the surroundings. Presentation was beautiful, but taste-wise, not 5*.

Having stayed in Tokyo at both the Park Hyatt and Grand Hyatt as well as Four Season one several occasions I can say that the Mandarin is right up there with the best.Service:Japan is world leader in service, so expectations are sky high and the staff at Mandarin get top marks. No other place in the world will you get better service than at a five star hotel in Tokyo and this is clearly one of them. It cannot be described, it must be experienced but it will leave you spoiled. Go anywhere after this and it will be a dissapointment. Location:It is good for business as it is walking distance to Marunouchi. Hence also convenient for tokyo station and ginza. But otherwise not as exciting neighbourhood as the Grand Hyatt in Roppongi.Interior:Very nice and feels new. Good sized rooms, good bar and lounge. Negatives:Does not have the excitement and views of the American Bar & Grill on top of the Park Hyatt. Location is not very exciting for leisure, Grand Hyatt is better for that. But don't get me wrong, this is one of the best hotels in the world in my book.

This hotel was wonderful. When we arrived there were lots of people to help and we were ushered up to the 38th floor for check in. The views from the reception were breath taking and the area was very stylish, with interesting art and historic objects. Our room was huge and had floor to ceiling windows with spectacular views. The room was open plan but zoned into areas which was cleaver use of space. The bathroom was great with a shower to die for (3 different shower heads!). The toiletries were excellent and of high quality. We ate at the chinese restaurant which was lovely but of the haute cusine variety so the portions were very small and they looked at me with horror when I asked for rice! Once again the views were gorgeous from the restaurant and service impecable.The location is central with there being an metro station under the hotel which makes getting around very easy. Overall I would definately stay here again without hesitation.

We stayed at the MO for our last night in Tokyo. It was a special treat for my birthday and was truly unforgetable. We booked a great rate directly on the hotel's website, which included evening meal, in-room movies and minibar.The very attentive staff presented me with a great birthday card and balloons at dinner then more gifts when we checked out! The hotel is very sumptious and everything you would expect from a 5 star hotel. The decor was beautiful and the bathroom was gorgeous.

We spent 5 nights in Tokyo at the Mandarin, and could not have asked for a better hotel. My husband and I were in a corner king room, and my parents stayed in the Premier Grand King. Both rooms were spectacular, and quite spacious by any standard. Our corner king room had windows all around and into the bathroom, and when I took my nightly scented salt-filled bath, I was able to peruse the amazing city views from the 35th floor.My parents' room was even bigger than ours and also enjoyed amazing city views. It would be an understatement to say that they were pleased.There was an artfully presented snack left for us in the room each afternoon which was quite unexpected and delightful.The location was extremely convenient. The subway stop is located within the building itself, and Ginza is about 20 mins away by foot. The service was incredible. Smooth, polite, efficient, competent and discreet without being overly solicitous. From the moment we checked in until the day we left, I felt like a pampered guest, and truly regretted leaving.We stayed at our very first Mandarin property in Hong-Kong (Landmark Mandarin), and we have become loyal fans of this hotel chain. They know how to run a top-notch luxury hotel, and we will certainly be looking for other mandarin hotels when we travel again.
user_name:
PeckCheck
Perpetually planning our next adventure

review_body: My husband and I stayed here for two nights while vacationing in Tokyo and were extremely happy with our choice. The graciousness of the staff made us immediately feel warm and welcome. We had arrived from the train station and as soon as we walked through the door, our bags were whisked out of our hands while we were directed to the elevator up to the top floor where the lobby was. And what an absolutely stunning view of Tokyo the lobby has! We were escorted to our room and oriented on the amenities in the room. Everything - from the check-in to check-out process, helping us with transportation to the airport, etc.- was done efficiently and competently. Our hotel room was very spacious (by Tokyo standards) with breathtaking views of the city. It had a large picture window. Decor was understated and elegant. Had free internet access and wide variety of TV & music programming so it felt like home. The bathroom had a great shower with 3 different shower options. Also fantastic soaking tub with own wall-mounted TV. It was also the little touches in the room that were nice - a large assortment of Lupicia tea, scented oils for the room, a turndown service that included the next day's weather forecast, yukata robes, slippers, and bathrobes, large umbrella since it rained frequently while we were there...The only drawback is that the lounge & bar appears to be very popular... and extremely smoky. It was very crowded at night both nights we were there, and so any visions of us enjoying a relaxing drink gazing at the lights of Tokyo quickly dissipated as we were unable to find a seat anywhere. We did enjoy a nice glass of wine in the Tea room. As an aside, if you are into interior design, the decor in each of the dining areas are worth checking out. We felt that this stay was amazing... if we have the opportunity to travel with our kids to Tokyo again in the near future, we will likely stay here. A true home away from home.

Stayed at the MO at the end of our two week honeymoon in Japan. The location is very good - in the business district - but crucially really close to Ginza and Ueno districts which have plenty to do as well as being on the same tube line for Shibuya/Montesando. The room was great and the bathrooms particuarly nice - very deep baths and plenty of bathroom freebies that my wife covets so dearly.TV options were cool with lots of free HDTV documentaries and the movies were reasonably proiced at Y1500 - which is fair for a hotel of this nature.They charge Y6000 to use the sauna as well - which I thought was a a cheek - but they don't have a pool and the spa is probably one of the cities best ($280 USD facial anyone?).The bar was also great for propping yourself up at - although the all female bar staff and the particuarly annoying bar manager annoyed us. She refused to ley anyone sit in the waiting area for the French restaurant, even though we could plianly see waiters breaking the tables down (i.e. no one would have to wait to eat in a half empty restauarant, so this waiting area would never be used for it's intended purpose.) We also ate at the Molecular tapas bar - which was fun - but hard to recommend. A particular note was the concierge who recommended a brilliant cheap noodle house and the maps they give you to explore are a notch above the kind you normally get.Hard to fault apart from the grumpy and jobs-worthy bar staff....The staff ARE nice - but the Park Hyatt is in a different world when it comes to service.

I stayed at the M.O. with my son and my sister for a summer vacation as tourists and were so happy with our choice. They treated us like royalty...even letting us check in IN our room. The front desk clerk walked us up and took my credit card info. there saying we had had a long journey and that we should relax. The room was technologically tricked out (electronic shades, drapes, lights) with a great view of the city and bay area. The bathroom was amazing including a toilet with heated seat, auto flush etc.The large jacuzzi tub was nice and three types of bath salts were left each day. The room included a hot water server for tea on demand and three types of fantastic teas were provided. Bedding was luxurious and the matress was perfect. The room service was prompt but I found the food to be just slightly above average. My sister slept on a rollaway (as usual when she travels with us) and said it equaled the beds in the room which were fabulous. She said it rivaled the rollaway at the FourSeasons Beverly Hills. I think she should write a hotel travel guide for roll away beds. This hotel is located in a high rise that is above the subway system and that is great for getting around. We took one cab the whole time. Do not book your airport car through the hotel unless you are spending someone elses money. $350.00 USD. The shuttle bus takes about 15 extra minutes for $30.00 USD. There is a am/pm shop located on the underground floor of the building that has unique drinks and great quick japanese breakfast items like rice balls stuffed with salmon and eda mame. Perfect when on the go. Ask for soy sauce. I have also stayed at the Four Seasons Maronuchi in tokyo which was also lovely, but I prefer the Mandarin. Spa...best in the East (or west!) Enjoy your stay!!!!!

My husband and I stayed here in March and had a wonderful experience. The people at the places we went to were all amazing and this hotel was exceptional. The service was better than any where else in the world. I am not easy to please but they were able to do it. The room was amazing overlooking the harbor and city, at night it was amazing. The location was great with lot's of places to visit nearby as well as the subway beneath the hotel. I do recommend getting a card from the front desk with the address of the place your staying because the cab drivers for the most part do not speak any english and need addresses for most places. You will be glad you stayed here. We have been wanting to go to Japan for about 7 years and every time we would tell a travel agent they discouraged it greatly. They kept telling us it was extremely expensive and hard to communicate. You could compare the pricing to London, Paris, New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, or any other big city. I'll admit the signage was a bit intimidating so make sure you have maps and addresses. The people are very service oriented everywhere you go and in a world where service no longer matters it was extremely refreshing. For this alone it is high on the list of going somewhere to be pampered and appreciated for your business. I recommend setting up tours, the guides speak english very well. So don't let your travel agent discourage you from the best trip you could take.

All of the previous reviews about how fantastic this hotel is are true. It really is an amazing place that captures the essence of Japan but not doing it in a way that would make foreigners uncomfortable.What impressed me the most happened upon check-out. The duty manager introduced herself, and escorted me to taxi waiting downstairs. On the way she asked me sincerely if there was any way that my stay could have been improved and then apologized for a technical glitch that had happened two days earlier in the room. 1. I can't believe she found out about it - it was so minor. 2. i can't believe she remembered 2 days later.The rooms are a tech person's dream - all of the audio/visual is run by a receiver and a computer that are kept in a small compartment that's locked under the TV. As I was going through the TV channel guide, the windows blue screen of death popped up. I called the front desk, IT came within 3 minutes, and rebooted the computer. Everything fixed within 5 minutes. One really nice touch is the evening appetizers brought to your room by housekeeping. Also of note are the free internet and complimentary bottles of water. I hate luxury hotels that try to pad your bill by charging you for things that should be included.Next time I'm in Japan, I'll definitely be back.

We stayed one night after an exhausting day of air travel. We reserved a corner city view room. The carpeting, bathroom, and linens were spotlessly clean. The staff was reserved but friendly. It's an excellent balance. Room service was impeccable, and the food was excellent. The extras were well thought out, but not extravagant (slightly disappointed by this) such as: aromatherapy, shaving set, hair tie, comb, toothbrush, lotions, soaps.Aside from a small, frayed hole in a yukata, I would rate this "almost perfect."

After a thrilling and hectic week in Japan, and sampling the very best hospitality the world has to offer, I can finally concluded the trip as the highlight of all my holiday trips so far. I was fortunate enough to sample the legendary Park Hyatt Tokyo, the ever stylish Grand Hyatt Tokyo, and the best among all, the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo (MOTYO).LOCATION MOTYO is located at the heart of the pulsating Kanda commercial and financial district, an area adjacent to the Tokyo Station. MOTYO is the newest kid on the block, perched some 30 stories above the new 38 storey Nihonbashi Mitsui Tower, which is designed by one of the world foremost architects, Cesar Pelli, who is most notably responsible for creating Malaysia’s pride and joy, Petronas Twin Towers. Despite its close proximity to Tokyo Station, -about 5 minutes by cab-, Kanda has not been an area of choice for stay, as it has been in dormancy in the hotel scene for quite sometime, until MO finally arrived on December 2005. This probably explained the difficulty that I had to deal with the cab driver, who spoke no English at all, and knew nothing about the Mandarin, or if there existed any hotel in Kanda area. I instructed him “Mandarin Hoteru, Mitsukoshi-mae”, to explain its proximity to the local landmark Mitsukoshi department store, which is adjacent to MOTYO; and also subway stations that bears its name, -Mitsukoshi-mae-, both served by the Hanzomon & Ginza Lines. As the driver had little clue of the “hoteru”, I further hinted “Nihonbashi Mitsui Building”, of which he still yet to get the idea. It was only became handy to be an architect who has an extensive knowledge of buildings in major cities in the world, that I led him by pointing towards the MO building when we were very close to the area. It finally, however, brought me only to the kerb side of other office building, some 100 meters away from MO’s ground floor lobby. Imagine: a stranger leading the way to a taxi driver, it just didn’t make any sense. So remember these keywords: Nihonbashi (Japan’s first road), Mitsui Building, and Mitsukoshi. It’ll definitely get you near MO. Airport Limousine buses pass the hotel on the way to Narita Airport, but I was told that MO is the first hotel for the pick-up, and there will be few more other stops, so the journey will be quite long and delayed. The fastest way through public transport to the Airport will be taking a cab to Tokyo station; and catch the punctual Narita Express (NEX) that comes at an hourly interval. I did the impossible task of rushing late to take the 11am NEX train with only 30 minutes and was still in the room just about to check out. After much running, some traffic delay inside the taxi, coins dropping at ticket counter, and much running again at the station, I finally made it inside NEX and off my way to the Airport. SERVICEHands down the best in Tokyo: gracious, unobtrusive and first class. Everything is handled efficiently. Even my email correspondence inquiring of the many room types was handled accurately within 24 hour. Staff even apologized for my confusion of the room types!!.Likewise, when a ground staff saw me dragging my luggage after being dumped by the taxi driver on the kerb side, he quickly came to the rescue, helping me with the luggage and led me straight to the lift that took me to the sky lobby on Level 38. The receptionists were very friendly and spoke fluent English. Check-in was swift and while there don’t forget to ask for local maps and transport timetables. A female staff then proceeded to escort me personally to my Mandarin Corner Room and straight away helping me with the luggage. Being a gentleman, I insisted to carry it myself midway in the hallway, as the thought of a woman bringing my luggage is simply wrong. Inside the room, she explained the plethora of the room amenities and gadgetry, which I have become familiar now, having stayed recently at the Landmark MO in Hong Kong that has similar setting. She was very gracious and wanted to make sure my stay to be the most pleasant one. She turned out to be the Duty Manager!. Likewise, during my rush check-out time, I refused the offer of yet another female staff to take my luggage and stormed off to the lift. Within seconds, the Resident Manager ran and fetched me to offer help and joined me inside the lift until I finally got in my taxi. Staffs at the ground floor lobby bow whenever they saw me; I felt living like a king for one day.RoomsRooms arrangement are unique at MOTYO as all rooms are located beneath the sky lobby at level 37 -38; in comparison to the usual arrangement of, say, Grand Hyatt Shanghai, where the Sky Lobby is sandwiched midway between the office levels below and guest rooms above. Henceforth, whenever you want to leave the hotel from the room: you need to take a lift up to the Sky Lobby and then take a separate lift down to the Ground Floor Lobby. You will get use to it!.MOTYO has 5 room types, including the Deluxe, Premier Deluxe, Mandarin Deluxe, Mandarin Corner and Premier Grand. Each has a generous space of 50m2, the largest anywhere in Japan, and Premier Grand has an even larger area at 60m2. The best room would have to be the ones facing the Imperial Palace ground and Mount Fuji, which in this case only available at Mandarin Deluxe and Premier Grand only. Others simply face Sumida River; expansive view of low rise Tokyo to the East and Tokyo Bay to the South East. My 50m2 Mandarin Corner room has 270 degree breathtaking view of both Tokyo Bay and the river view from Level 36. What is unique with this room, and hence my persistent when booking it, is the wrap-around full height window on the corner bedroom and also the bathroom, resulting in a well-lit room during the day; and at night it is amazing to have a soak on the tub with the amazing Tokyo night scene. That said, the room is narrower than others, but longer with the addition of a central vestibule separating the bedroom/living area and the bathroom. It is beautifully decorated with soft hues in contemporary setting, fitted with a superlative High Definition 45 inch (yes, 45!) Panasonic Aquos directly fronting the bed with an impressive 50 channels, arranged as part of the stylish and user-friendly communication interface, which allows guests to check their bills, set a healing background music, select TV and radio channels, and also access to pay movies. There is even a DVD player with virtual surround sound system for convenience; and broadband internet was complimentary: what a luxury!. Both bedside console panels allows you to operate all electronic gadgetry in the room, including the dual-layer, electronically-operated curtains. Wardrobe is even stocked with yoga mats!Although I was slightly disappointed with the narrowness of the room, it is still supremely comfortable, and at night you can have all windows opened and the whole night scene of Tokyo is presented to you like a giant wallpaper background.The bathroom is luxuriously decorated with acres of quality marbles, beautiful frosted glass and expansive Tokyo view from the bath, which can be concealed by an electric timber shutter. Above the huge bathtub is another 20 inch LCD TV, which will then confuse you as to what to choose: the view or the movies?. Another unique feature exclusive only at MOTYO is a pass-through box adjacent to the entry foyer, which allows uninterrupted delivery and handling of laundry, shoeshine, newspaper and other requests, so say good bye to a knock on the door screaming “Room Service”.FACILITIESThere are many dining establishment inside the hotel, including a French, Cantonese, Italian and an all day dining restaurants. There are also the popular Mandarin Lounge in loft setting; Mandarin Bar and a tea corner off the Cantonese restaurant. On the ground floor, just outside the hotel foyer is the elegantly decorated Mandarin Cake Shop which stocks fine chocolates, scrumptious breads and cakes and many yummy treats, all elegantly packed for takeaway. Recreation facilities include spacious and well equipped gym and fitness center; and a luxury spa in an elegant and contemporary setting. A key feature to the spa will be the indoor swimming pool which has one side edgeless towards expansive Tokyo view. A visit to the spa will not be complete without a few minutes relaxing by the pool. Sadly, I did not pack any swimming trunk, and rest assured swimming in your undies will be quite a spectacle, especially in an establishment like this. So it’s a no no!.VERDICTMOTYO is spectacular, truly befitting of its tag as Japan’s most expensive, luxurious and exclusive hotel. Service was exemplary, which has been the hallmark of the Mandarin Oriental group. Accommodation is the most spacious anywhere in Japan and is supremely luxurious, yet comfortable. It is without doubt, the highlight of my hotel stay in Japan. Park Hyatt comes second, albeit with a much dramatic view from its room towards Shinjuku skyline.

This is probably one of the best hotels I've stayed at anywhere! It offers a great view, helpful staff and absolutely the best room and bathroom! The gym is also fantastic and also the best hotel gym I've seen anywhere! There is no doubt this is THE BEST hotel to stay at in Tokyo. There is probably only one thing I'd change: Japanese food on the room service menu. I stayed here when it was first opened so maybe they have changed it by now. The staff reall do go above and beyond to help you. I also wish there were more interesting restaurants around the hotel.

This is a really excellent hotel; newly built and beautifully designed with stunning views, the rooms are cleverly laid out and my favourite in Tokyo (not shabby from age like the Park Hyatt, not impractical like the Conrad, not fussy and old-fashioned like the Westin). The service is fantastic, maybe even a shade better than the other excellent Tokyo hotels. Food is good if not quite as good as the Conrad. Location is for me the best of the bunch. It's expensive but well worth it. My favourite Tokyo hotel right now. My only very minor complaint is the impractical lift-up-to-the-lobby and then separate lift-down-to-the-room, but then again many Tokyo hotels are guilty of similar.

I had only a little over 24 hours in Tokyo at the back end of a three week business trip. I stayed one night at the Mandarin but wished I could have stayed longer. Everything about the hotel is flawless - from the warm gracious greeting when you arrive, to the unbelievable views from the 38th floor check-in. Not to mention the gorgeously designed bedrooms and baths.Make sure you fully utilize the concierge. They go above and beyond to help you explore Tokyo. As I mentioned I had very limited time. I spent about 20 minutes with the concierge desk mapping out what I would see - and feel that I was very well advised.One highlight was going at 5 a.m. to watch the tuna auctions on the fish pier - I highly recommend this experience. Afterward you can have sushi for breakfast that will guaranteed be the freshest and best tasting sushi you have ever tasted!

I stayed one night at the Tokyo Mandarin Oriental in transit to Malaysia. I had almost a 24-hour layover, so I wanted to experience a little of Tokyo. Also, none of the airport hotels looked too appealing. The Mandarin Oriental turned out to be an excellent alternative to a dreary airport hotels. One key point - - the staff all speak English which makes everything so much easier when you're exhausted and trying to check-in after a 14-hour flight!The hotel is absolutely beautiful, immaculate, and has every thoughtful ammenity you could imagine. I got a rate of 54000 Yen which equates to about $445.00US (tax and service included) on the hotel's website. The rate also included complimentary internet connection which most hotels charge for. This is an excellent deal compared to similar hotels in the US. It's difficult to get a room at the MO in NYC for less that $700 per night. My room had a western view which looks out over the Tokyo skyline. On a clear day, you can see Mount Fuji. The room was very large with a gorgeous marble bath with separate shower, w/c, and huge soaking tub. I had a king size bed that was very comfortable - - expecially liked the pillows as they were large and very fluffy.Breakfast was excellent with all the usual western breakfast items. The pastries were especially good. The restaurant is on the 38th floor with floor to ceiling windows. My table was right against the glass so the view during breakfast was excellent.The fitness room was great with state-of-the art equipment and cordless headphones provided so you can listen to music or watch TV during your workout- - limited English stations. The fitness center is also on the 38th floor and all of the equipment is set up facing the windows so you have a beautiful view to enjoy while you sweat!Arrival and checkout were flawless as was every interaction I had with staff. The service was flawless and everyone was so kind. In my opinion, this hotel is phenomenal - - highly recommended.GROUND TRANSPORT TIP: It's very easy to take the Narita Express from the airport to Tokyo station and then to get a cab to the hotel. When you buy your ticket at the airport after clearing customs - get a ROUND TRIP as this will save you time on your trip back. The ticket will have the date and time of your train on it as well as your seat. Seating is by Car, row and seat. I was in Car 1 seat 7A. Get the hotel staff to translate your ticket for you. For your trip back to Narita, be sure you know which terminal your airline flies out of at Narita. American has just switched operations to terminal 2. You must know this ahead of time as there are two stops at the airport. There is excellent sinage which will direct you to the Narita Express platform. When you get to the platform at Tokyo station, there will be signs on the floor on the edge of the platform that indicate where your car will stop. The hotel is just a short ride from the station. The train takes about 55 minutes each way. Caution: allow plenty of time for your return trip to the airport. My train was about 45 minutes late on the way back. I had built in an extra hour so I was fine. You can also take a bus, which they call a limousine, but if you get stuck in traffic your journey could be very long indeed. It is a little tricky negotiating Tokyo station even though everything is signed in English, too. If you contact the hotel, they may be able to forward a map of the station or a link on the internet that has a map. I had a paper document that the hotel e-mailed me with the name and address of the hotel in Japanese - - important. Your cab driver will need this. If you need any help getting to the hotel, you can e-mail the hotel ahead of time. They are very helpful.

In a city as sliced and diced as Tokyo, it's indeed welcome to find a truly sublime respite in Nihombashi - manageable walk to Tokyo Station, Imperial Palace, Ginza, Otemachi. Knowing how to compete and win in non-Japan Asia, London, NY, Miami and slected elsewhere, MO did its best to create the killer category in Tokyo.The space, food quality, rooms are all at high quality design and achievement. Add Japanese pleasing manners and quality of high service among all the staff, and the formula is ideal. This place is special.

Having read previous reviews, my expectations of the MO Tokyo were high. It did not disappoint. On any measure this is an outstanding hotel: service is attentive and charming, without being cloying. All rooms are a good size, and extremely well-designed and appointed. Dining in all the restaurants (including the bar) was good value for the quality and presentation of the food – plus, breakfast is served in the west-facing restaurant from where, on clear days, the snow-clad cone of Mt Fuji is clearly visible. As one has come to expect of any MO hotel, all public areas are also very beautiful – reflecting both contemporary design and local Asian influences in details, material and fabrics. (A prominent Japanese fabric designer was involved in the design project). Finally, in what is essentially a low-rise city the MO towers above local buildings – providing every room with jaw-dropping views across this extraordinary metropolis. This is used to great effect when being taken to your room for the first time in the evening; as you’re lead in, the window blind slowly goes up revealing a million lights of Tokyo stretching as far as you can see. Throughout this hotel the details have been really thought about. For me, it’s these that turned a great stay into an unforgettable one. I would return to this hotel in a heartbeat.

My wife and I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental on our way to and from Micronesia for 2 and then 3 nights. Where to begin? You step out of the taxi and into another world of the most perfect service imaginable. When you ask a question you don't just get the answer, you get a totally comprehensive compendium of information on the subject. When you ask the concierge to book a table at a restaurant you get the reservation confirmed in writing, a map to the location with directions and a note in Japanese for a taxi driver to get you there and back again. When we left at the end of our second stay the time elapsed from calling the front desk saying we were ready to check out to sitting on the airport bus with our luggage neatly stowed and a complementary bottle of water and a newspaper in our hands, including paying the bill, was 7 minutes! And at no stage did that feel rushed!The decor and fittings are absolutely the best, the view from the 38th floor reception or from the enormous rooms is to die for and the pricing of everthing you normally feel ripped of over (minibar, phone, room service etc) is perfectly reasonable (or free in the case of wirless broadband).I have yet to experience anything better!

I accompanied my husband on his business trip to Tokyo. I stayed in Mandarin Oriental for 5 days and he stayed another 4 days for his business meetings. We are both very impressed by the immaculate service.Everything mentioned by all the reviewers was on the spot.He had stayed in Conrad, Grand Hyatt in Tokyo previously and said that MO is the best. I must raved about 1 incident here that impressed me enough to write a letter to the General manager .We had asked the conceige to make a reservation on the "Romance car" train from Odayku rail to Hakone. The lady on duty had spent us a confirmation letter to our room to confirm the reservation. On the day of departure, we checked out and had left our letter in the luggage which was being stored by the bell captain. We went back to conceirge to get the letter and a different guy was on duty. He couldn't locate the reservation letter. Anyway , we left the hotel and rushed to Odakyu Rail located in Shinjuku station.It was peak hour in the morning and it took us more than 30 min to Shinjuku station. After we got our tickets from Odakyu and was about to board the train. We saw Masuda san the guy who served us in MO.My first thought was he was off duty and but he told us that he had make a trip down to locate us when he found our reservation no. for the train. He was very apologetic and was worried that we got lost in Shinjuku station. He even gave us 2 bottles of warm Ocha for our train trip! We were blowed away by his incredible and excellent service that was way above our expectation.Besides, excellent facilities and location, the top notch service of the staff was the key factor of being the one of the best hotel in Tokyo.

Japanese speakers will immediately get the title of this critique - "sugoi" means either "awesome" or "amazing", and this is really the best description of this new arrival to Tokyo's increasingly exciting hotel scene. The hotel is located between levels 30 and 37 in the Mitsui building, in the heart of Nihonbashi, a stone's throw from the Otemachi financial district and the neon lights of Ginza. There is so much going on in this part of town that one doesn't have time for jetlag! While some may prefer the new developments in Roppongi, there is still the seedy side of that area to contend with, and believe me, there is nothing down market about the MO's neighbourhood! The Tokyo megalopolis sprawls out beneath your feet, and the views are absolutely breathtaking from any angle. My room was westward facing, and the views on Fuji-san at sunrise were astoundingly beautiful. All rooms at MO are huge, by any standard. They are tastefully designed, are complemented by a large flat screen TV, and are very - well - zen. The bathrooms come with all the extras, including self heating, self-deodorizing, and (yes) self-flushing toilets - this is Japan after all! There is a smallish fitness room - perhaps too small - on level 37, but it's the après workout in the spa which more than compensates. The Spa promises amazing views of the city - whether you're sitting in the jacuzzi, in a massage pool, or the sauna. The hotel staff are friendly, attentive, and efficient - they are perfect! Gone are they days of drab, characterless hotel rooms in Tokyo -- Hurrah!!!

An amazing, classy, sleek but warm hotel in a wonderful location. The service is first rate-with staff greeting you personally at every entrance, great restaurant service (and food excellent as well) and the concierges are top notch. They are ready with maps. instructions printed out in Japanese for taxi drivers, restaurants, massages, etc. The room (deluxe) was top-of-the line tech from the three shower heads, top-of the-line toilet (warm seat and self-flushing), deep bathing tub, wireless keyboard to check your mail on the 50 inch flat screen tv (oh yes-there is one by the tub as well). By your bed you can press buttons that open the shade &/or drapes to display the floor to ceiling glass windows overlooking the city. The hotel is on the 30-38 floor providing dramatic views. While we were there it was evident that there was a upscale, hip crowd at the bar. I chose this hotel as I was meeting my daughter who is in her 20s who worked for several travel magazines and who lives in Sydney. We loved the vibe-enough people around but never loud or crowded. Very personalized. My daughter wasn't feeling well one night and at 11 o'clock they made her oatmeal and also got in some things from the drugstore in an amazingly short time period.This place is a real class act and the service is truly impeccable!

Stayed for two nights at the Mandarin Oriental, Tokyo. The room had a magnificient view of Tokyo and the staff could not have been more helpful. A few examples of the outstanding service: 1) Inquired on how to use the Tokyo subway system on the first day of our stay. A staff member actually escorted us downstairs to the subway and gave us directions on how to buy ticket and gave us a little tutorial on how to use the subway.2) Staff assisted me on how to use a Japanese phone card to call home and waited by the phone to ensure I had success. The next day she saw me in the lobby and asked again.Room was spacious and had the touches that one expects from a high end hotel (i.e. big fluffy robe, slippers, turndown service, large soaking tub, luxurious bed linens, etc.). Would definitely stay here again and is well worth the money.

I have been a travel agent for over 25 years and have been to many of the 'world's best'. I have never written a review on a website until now, that is because the Mandarin was just that good. I didn't get a discount, but decided to treat myself on the last night of my Japan vacation and stayed at the Mandarin Oriental.Simply put, it is the best hotel I have had the pleasure of staying in. From the moment you get out of the cab and are met at the lovely 1st floor lobby you are met with sincere smiling faces ready to whisk you up to the 38th floor lobby. AMAZING!My breath was taken away with the view, everyone knew my name - (walkie talkies from the first floor lobby) - and whisked me to my room in minutes. The door opened the bellperson opened the blinds and curtains via remote control, and I was in heaven. If you go, you must go for a drink in the bar - service as always exceptional, beuatiful people in a beatuiful location. As we were exhausted we ordered a light room service dinner - very very good, and not as expensive as one would think. About the same as a 4 or 5 star restaurant here in Canada. The hotel - everything, rooms, staff, decor, attitude was superlative. I wouldn't hesitate to go back - thats if I can afford it ;)Please feel free to email me with any questions.[-]

This was our second visit to the MO Tokyo, but this is our first write up. Not that the first visit was not good - it was excellent. . But what was worth a mention this time round was the effort the staff in the MO made to locate our camera bag which we left on a domestic flight. The check in staff who helped us worked tirelessly throughout and when the bag was located, took a taxi to the airport to fetch it at around midnight. Service at its very best.

I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental for one week in September 2006. From the start to the end of our trip we were delighted with the service and all our needs were taken care of immediately. We were touched at how thoughtful and polite the staff were - as soon as we arrived we were taken to our bedroom and checked in there. Little snacks arrived daily, and we received weather forecasts and scented oils. The room was spacious and tastefully decorated, with a live orchid and a range of soft lighting. In the bathroom was a large, soup-bowl like bath with bath salts provided daily, and a wetroom area with a rainforest shower head, a normal showerhead, and a handheld showerhead. A tv was mounted on the wall in the bathroom, as well as the large plasma screen in the sleeping area. The decor was beautiful throughout the hotel and in our room, with wonderful views, and everything was utterly luxurious. I wish I never had to leave. It was a wonderfully romantic hotel and I'd go back in a heartbeat. It is the best hotel I've ever had the pleasure of staying in and I don't forsee any other hotel ever being able to top the experience we had here.

We booked the Premier Grand Rooms, we were thinking about booking the corner room, but corner rooms can't add extra bed. We have a huge window with a very nice view of the Tokyo city.
