Room was nicely decorated, the room is pretty big comparing to other tokyo hotels. I love the bathroom, it was really nice. Service was wonderful too, the conceirge desk helped out a lot with the area info, book restaurants & train tkts for us. We'll def. stay at MO next time when we're at Tokyo

Stayed at the Mandarin Oriental with my boyfriend who was on business. Service was brilliant, very friendly and definitely the best of any previous 5 star hotels we have visited (although yet to visit the Oriental in Bangkok which I hear is very good). For my boyfriend the location was also better than either of the 2 Hyatts, as his Bank is located in the Otematchi business district. Highly recommended.

We stayed here for 3 nights on our honeymoon and were very pleased with our choice. Our room on the 34th floor had a fantastic view, especially at night, as we had chosen a corner room. Although the room wasn't particularly large (it is in Tokyo after all) it was extremely comfortable and very clean. The bathroom was very cool with all the usual Japanese toilet gadgets as well as separate wet room and bath. The hotel staff were excellent throughout, especially the concierge service who organised a tour of the palace grounds for us and some sumo wrestling tickets as well. The food was very good and the bar nice and chilled out. Top marks.

My boyfriend and i stayed 5 nights in this hotel in May, and it was a trully unforgettable experience! the hotel had a very impressive view, our rm was on the 32nd floor, overlooking Asakusa. The sky was quite cloudy throughout our stay, the view would hv been 10 times better if there was clear, blue sky, but still it's breathtaking! I like the wooden floor in the room, which seems much cleaner then carpets: ) but be careful with the marble bathroom, it's quite slippery....the amenities from Aromatherapy Associates was very good, others were also filled up once it's used up! Fast internet connection was being able to be accessed once we plug in the lap-top--for free!we arrived in the airport at ard 2:15pm, despite we had to tk the train to the other side of the arrival terminal and the long queue at the custom, we were still able to catch the 3:15pm Airport Limo to the hotel, which was important because there is only 1 bus per hour, if we missed it, we could only tk the bus at 4:15pm. Although many has commented there is always traffic jam in Tokyo, but we were lucky to reach the hotel in just 1 hour, i guess it's because the hotel is located on the east side of the city, and MO Tokyo is the second stop after the bus gets off the highway, rather then going all the way to Shinjuku area which you hv to go all the way to the other side of the city. hotel staff was very friendly, when we asked for recommendation of where to buy cameras, they were very enthusiastic in looking for shops to recommend. On our last day when we checked out, we had asked the staff to help bringing our luggage to the lobby, then downstairs where we took the airport limo back again (this time, it's a much longer trip, since the bus was stopping in some other hotels in the area before going to the highway), the 2 staff who helped us with the luggage had accompanied us all the way to the bus, helping us to put the luggage on it, and they stand right next to the bus for 10 mins to see us off! besides, one of them got on again, just to deliver us a bag with 2 bottles of water insde! which was such a kind gesture!We didn't use any of the restaurants, so i'm not able to comment, but there are Starbucks, MacDonald's, and a local buger store(sorry, i forgot the name of it), and with Mitsukoshi dept food hall, it's very conveient when you wanna grab sth to eat. I'll be staying in this hotel again for sure!!!

We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental Tokyo for four nights in May, 2006. We had a beautiful suite, tastefully decorated with every amenity. The views of Tokyo were a show every day and night. The views alone would cause me to recommend this hotel, but there is more. The service was friendly yet unobtrusive. The staff is young and enthusiastic. The restaurant on the lobby floor was a very pleasant place to have breakfast each morning- again with Tokyo views. The accomodations have been described and photographed by other guests. Wondeful place to stay, very convenient with regards to the subway in the basement and the entrance to the Mitsukoshi Dept. store foodhalls also accessible via the basement ( no need to go out onto the street to get to Mitsukoshi). I will stay here again when I am in Tokyo.

After reading many of the reviews submitted by fellow readers, we decided on staying at both the Grand Hyatt and the Mandarin Oriental. There is only one word to describe this hotel - phenominal (actually, two words - the second would be 'expensive'!). We stayed in a corner room that had a view to the north and west. It was ok, but I think looking south one can see Tokyo Bay and Tokyo Tower. The rooms in the hotel are on the 30 something floors and the views are great from that height. Those afraid of heights should not stay here!One thing that is important to note is that the hotel is located in the "Nihonbashi Mitsui Main" building, NOT the "Shinjuku Mitsui Building". This is important, as they are located in completely different areas of Tokyo. Upon arriving in Tokyo we took the Narita Express train direct to Shinjuku station. This station is a zoo! After locating the Mitsui Building we realized that something didn't look right (it's just your average high rise office building). I called the hotel and the operator very patiently gave me subway instructions that were right on the money. A half hour later we were at the correct Mitsui building. For those considering using the subway, a point to note is that there is an entrance directly from the subway station (Mitsukoshimae station) into the building. It is located to the right of exit A7. Exit A7 is a bit of a walk (all underground) from the "Hanzomon Line" but is located directly over the "Ginza Line".As for the hotel, we can't find anything to find fault with - which is good, because at a nightly rate that would exceed most people's monthly car payment, a stay here is truly a luxury. Is it worth it? In our opinion, if you can afford it - yes! The room has features we've never encountered anywhere - A pass through compartment for newspapers, your laundry, etc. A live orchid in the room. A toilet that you have to see to believe. Curtains and blinds that operate electronically (you can pretend that you're in your own CEO's office!). A large screen LCD or plasma HDTV (not sure which it was), and a second TV located next to the soak tub (this TV is has an independant tuner, so one can view unique channels). An instant hot water machine is also in the room. The hotel provides thick terry cloth robes, Japanese style sleeping robes and cushy slippers.The bell man who helped us when we checked in greeted me by name when we left the hotel later in the evening. That was really impressive. We can't comment on any of the restaurants or room service, as we didn't use them. It's so much fun being at this hotel that some may find it hard to leave. The hotel is located not far from the Ginza area and about a mile east of the Imperial Palace. The concierge service was very helpful with suggestions and dining options in the neighborhood (don't feel guilty using them, as there is a 10% service charge added to the bill. This seems to be customary in Japan). The one thing that is a bit of a bummer is that the Mandarin Oriental chain does not have an affinity program. You can receive miles for your stay, but the airlines that participate are all Asian carriers. Considering the cost of the room, this may give an edge to a Starwood, Marriott or Hyatt property in a future stay for us.

This hotel was simply fabulous. I had never seen something like that. Service is amazing, rooms are huge for Tokyo. Amenities are the best. There's a metro station in the same building as the hotel. The location is great. You can't find any better hotel in the world. It's brand new and it's located in the best ciy in the world.

I reserved this room for my partner's birthday and I must admit that it was a great choice! The Mandarin Oriental has got to be Tokyo's current "It" hotel. The views and the luxurious offered to their guests are phenomenal.ROOMI reserved the Mandarin Corner room (on the 33rd floor) which is the only room in the non-suite category to offer city views from windows in the bathroom. The room itself was very spacious and luxuriously appointed. The 45 inch LCD TV/personal entertainment centre was huge and the A/V kit which allowed my iPod to be plugged in was a great luxury. Needless to say, the personal entertainment centre itself offered a vast selection of music and videos. The room had two huge windows (more like glass walls) which offered breathtaking views of Tokyo - With the blinds and curtains controlled by controls near the bed. The bed was very comfortable and the bed sheets were the finest Egyptian cotton.BATHROOMOne word: Ultra-luxurious! The marble bath, the separate rain shower cubicle, the Aromatherapy Associates amenities, a bathtub LCD TV, separate washroom, all with beautiful views of Tokyo. One small glitch was the glass door to the shower: Make sure you don't hit it whilst in the shower because it easily opens and lets the water out.HOTEL FACILITIES/RESTAURANTSThe hotel offered a fitness centre/Spa (but no pool), but we didn't use these facilities. We did however dine at the Tapas Molecular Bar. The usual 2 hour dinner course was part entertainment, part food "science" but thoroughly enjoyable. Don't be put off by the small portions, as there are about 25 courses to this meal. Also, don't forget to make advanced reservations as only 6 people can watch/dine at this bar. Afterwards we enjoyed a nice Cuban cigar and champagne at the Oriental Lounge while enjoying the views of the Tokyo night sky.SERVICEThe service was VERY good, but again with some minor glitches. I made all my reservations via the Internet, and the people with whom I had correspondence with did mess things up a bit. I first made a reservation for the Tapas Molecular Bar at 6:00 PM, but changed it to 8:00 PM and received a confirmation e-mail. But on the day of our stay, I was told that my reservation was for 6:00 PM. I suspect this was due to the level of English proficiency of the person with whom I corresponded. It was obvious that they weren't proficient in English since there were numerous spelling/grammar mistakes in their e-mails. These slips while unacceptable by some (i.e. How hard is it to run the spell-check option in one's e-mail program?), they can lead to obvious reservation errors as it happened in my case.SURROUNDINGSThe hotel itself is a business district which is historic, but offers little in terms of entertainment. Your best bet is to explore the area.The hotel is about 15 minutes to Tokyo station and 30 minutes to Ginza on foot. Alternatively, you can use the subway which is easily accessed from the ground floor of the Mitsui Building (which the hotel occupies).CONCLUSIONWONDERFUL! The Mandarin Oriental Hotel is a bit pricey and the service can be spotty, but you do feel like (minor) royalty while staying here.

I stayed here in early March 2006 (and will be staying again in mid June 2006). Actually my first experience with this hotel was about a week before I stayed there. I was in the area and stopped by to have a quick look. One of the staff saw me looking around the lobby and asked if they could. After I explained I already had a reservation and this would be making my first stay with them they offered to show me a room like I had reserved. They also confirmed my expected arrival time for the reservation I was holding and after explaining I would be arriving a little early (12 noon) they said they would do their best to have my room ready. When I did check in the next week at around 12 my room was already ready (despite standard checkin time being 3pm). The staff were also able to recommend a very nice local sushi bar nearby and the location above the Mistsukoshi-mae subway station is very covenient. The room, a Mandarin Grand King, was relatively large with floor to ceiling windows (view out to the right of the Imperial Palace and the Bay Bridge over to the left). A large bath area with separate shower. The TV is a big flat panel display and you have lots of connections for internet or even for using the TV speakers for playing music from your pc. I have stayed at the Park Hyatt in Tokyo before and that was my favorite, however I really like the MO now and its convenient location. Also for my upcoming stay even though the internet site showed no rooms bieng available, I contacted the hotel directly by email and they were able to confirm a room for me immediately. A wonderful hotel to stay at if it is in your budget range (average 54,000 JPY/night for me).

Stayed at the MO Tokyo in mid April, highly recommend, a very nice hotel, rooms and views were lovely. Hotel is right beneath Mitsukoshimae station along the Ginza line. Nice location, next to Mitsukoshi department store, and walking distance to Takashimaya at Nihonbashi. If you are arriving by train from Narita, it is also possible to walk from Tokyo station - about 15 minutes if you know your way.

We stayed at the MO in early April, at the peak of the Cherry Blossom season. It's a marvelous place. The views are just amazing, the rooms are spacious and the service is great. The location is ok; the hotel is about a 15 minute stroll from Ginza, and right above a metro station. The only problem we encountered was that cab drivers didn't know how to find the place (but of course that's a pretty common problem in Tokyo).

My husband and I stayed three days at this hotel while we vacationed in Tokyo. The minute you pull up you are treated like a queen and king! You are immediately escorted to the check in floor by their wonderful staff. Everyone here greets you with a bow and smile and will even run ahead of you to open your door! The rooms are great...big, very zen, and peaceful. I really enjoyed a nice bath in their big oversized tubs! They even have a tv in the bathroom and lavendar sea salts for your bath. Room service was also a joy..they wheel in a table completely set up even with a nice floral arrangement. We were celebrating an anniversary and they even sent up a bottle of champagne and chocolates!We got free breakfast which i didn't know was included..it was very healthy and delicious! Don't be surprised when you walk into one of their restaurants they know you by name...I was shocked by this!The spa is a real treat! To enjoy one of their fabulous suites you must book a two hour treatment which kind of sucked but trust the views were worth the money!Overall, our stay at the hotel was fabulous...we love staying at MO hotels...they are always so impressive!

We stayed for 2 nights in Jan, 2006. The view from our room was spectacular. The room was modern, clean and very comfortable. The service varies a bit. As a new hotel, there are still somethings to be sorted out. We booked our room with American Express FHR program but despite asking for it, we did not get a room upgrade; the hotel was not full. We will go back even just for the view and its location.

We stayed at the Mandarin Oriental in Tokyo in January 2006 for 3 nights after it just had been open for 1 month. The place is fantastic: rooms are large and very comfortable. The views are great since all rooms are on high floors. You get the typical 'Mandarin Oriental' Service - nothing is difficult and all your questions and problems are dealt with promptly and very professionally. If you want to have lunch in one of their restaurants you would need to book because the set lunches are very popular and excellent value. All restaurants are very good quality - but stay away from the Italian restaurant Ventaglia which is located on the second floor of the Mitsui tower. It advertises itself offering north italian cuisine. It was a disappointing choice of mainly fish dishes. The size of the dishes was a joke. It was one spoon of pasta for a main course. Not really north italian style at all. Bad value and mediocre cuisine!. However, the Spa is a a real treat. You can relax on water loungers and look over Tokyo's skyline. Treatments are first class and will be adjusted to your personal requirements. The only thing which was not too great was that check in is at 3pm. We arrived around 12:00 noon after travelling through Japan and had to wait until 3:00 to chekc in. It was not such a big deal - but we even could not get a table for lunch which was disappointing. I can recommend the hotel and the location is excellent. THere is a metro station in the basement of the building. I would always go back.
